11.content:
A deathly silence ran through the halls of the ancient, unhallowed lair, whose winding and maddeningly complex tunnels sat beneath the sleepy and unassuming village of Little Silverhorne. Many a story of it's deeply buried and mysterious caverns had been told to the children of the village at bedtime; stories of great adventurers plundering it for treasure, and of great monsters and elaborate traps, designed to sabotage would-be thieves planning to steal from the legendary Sitharli. The Lipomancer.

One such tale had found it's way to the ears of Jane Drake. She sat in the Hare and Vole Inn, which lay at the heart of Greatmanor, one of the largest human settlements in the north, and by far the northernmost. She sat looking out of the window at the sunset over the snowy valley, sipping a glass of wine, "Another if you please Barkeep." she said turning to face the burly looking man behind the bar.
She spoke in a firm, but melodious voice. A man walked over to the bar, sitting next to Jane "Drake?" he asked.
"Yes. Watcher?" she replied.
"Indeed." he said.
"Will you have one?" Jane enquired, lifting her wineglass.
"No, thank you..." he said hoarsely "... about the deal."
His face was obscured by a pointed brown hood, somewhat like that which a monk would wear, but Jane was certain he wasn't a monk. "Of course, I have the money with me now..."
She untied a small brown leather satchel from her waist and laid it down on the bar before him. "Good..." he said simply and took the money, putting it in the inside pocket of his cloak, adding "Yes... very good."
"And your end?" she said, not too eager about the fact that she still had nothing and he had her money "Can you tell me where this village is?"
"Of course, to find the Lipomancer's lair..." he breathed in deeply "...seek out the village of Little Silverhorne."
And with that he slid off his chair again and began to slink his way out of the Inn. "Wait..." Jane shouted after him "...that's it?"
"That is all you need to know to find it, although you may come to regret doing so..."
"What do you mean?" Jane yelled after him as he left.
"...you'll see." he said as the doors closed shut behind him.

Jane sat up in her room above the bar, the sound of dancing and merriment could be heard from below. Jane looked over the map that she had spread across her table, the light dancing across it as the candle flickered a little in the wind. She picked up her compass and stared at it for a moment, flicking it a little so that it found north. It was only a six or seven hour journey from Greatmanor to Little Silverhorne. "I should set off first thing in the morning..." she thought to herself "...so that there is still daylight enough when I get there to try to find the Lipomancer's lair."
She was pleased with herself and decided to turn in for the night; putting her hands up above her head she pulled a small headband from her hair, releasing it in a cascade of jet black. She pulled a nightgown over her slim, pale skinned frame and lay her head on her pillow, closing her pale blue eyes.
11.title: Seek Out the Village of Little Silverhorne

111.content:
Bleak. Quiet. Lonely. Desolate. Jane had gone through all the adjectives she could come up with to describe Little Silverhorne. It was a tiny village, and while not as distant from proper civilization as many other villages, felt like it was on the edge of the world. Overcast clouds covered the sky and blended with the snow capped peaks surrounding the town. Houses were few and separated by wide lanes. Only mild conversation from the town's only pub and the rhythmic dinging of a distant blacksmith showed Jane that the place wasn't completely dead.

What few people she saw on the streets moved with a slow deliberation. They answered questions readily enough, but gave no more than that. Jane found that the only real commerce coming to and from the town was a caravan that came every two months or so. Travelers were rare. Those that came by were only passing through. Jane felt only the usual suspicion of travelers in the villagers' tone. The Sitharli sect was a secretive one. If any of them--or the entire town for that matter--were worshipers of him, they didn't show. They probably thought the Lipomancer was such an obscure legend, the treasure deemed so mythical, that few would even have heard of it, let alone come looking for it, Jane thought.

Jane entered the town at dusk, having dawdled too long on the road. The path to Little Silverhorne was rocky and ill-maintained. She found the pub, which doubled as an inn, and entered, feeling she had exhausted any useful sources of information still out on the street. Besides, she was tired and hungry.

Inside she took a seat in a corner. She was wearing a travelers cloak and hood, a universal sign of somebody on the road and just passing through. But she couldn't count on being completely inconspicuous. Professional thieves like her were using the old mysterious traveler guise for so long now that anyone was just as likely to assume she was up to no good as not. The patrons spoke in hushed conversations, although none seemed to notice her. Jane noticed a pattern, now that she saw so many together. While the men had the normal range of body types. the few women around were either plump or outright obese. They had the same cold demeanor as the men. Jane noted this with both pleasure and hesitation. Sure, maybe there were Sitharli worshipers and a treasure horde here, but she knew about too many secretive cults who did not like letting outsiders leave. This would have to be a quick job.

Two waitresses scuttled between the tables, bringing beer and food to the townsfolk with little prompting. They were both large, but one was so fat that Jane wondered how she navigated the crowded floor so deftly. Jane reacted with a reflexive disgusted expression as she approached, her features fortunately hidden by her hood.

"Beer, traveler? Food?" she said in a surprisingly pleasant tone.

Jane nodded to both.

"Steaks' the special today. It's always the special."

"That's fine."

Waiting for her food, Jane saw two others wearing the trademark travelers' cloak as her. One was a man, a few years older than her, and he obviously had noticed her, although was taking pains to conceal it. He too took a corner seat by a window. The other traveler looked out of place despite her dirty cloak. Underneath she was wearing an ornate read dress that was too tight for her soft body. She was the thinnest woman there other than Jane, but she still had a noticeable potbelly, and her pale, delicate face was rounding out. She had an almost regal demeanor to her. Jane could tell her story just looking at her. A young girl disenchanted with court life, runs away, and now is in a desolate tavern far from home, alone, scared, probably running out of money. She was looking down at her empty plate with a tired, almost desperate expression. When the waitress brought her another plate, this one full of steamed potatoes and herbs, she cringed. She weakly tried to wave it away. Jane listened in, barely making out the conversation. The girl had a very regal accent, and spoke in a discreet, scared voice.

"Please, no, no," she said.

"On the house, miss," the waitress said. "You look like you could use a meal."

"Please, I don't . . . I don't want this . . ." it was too dark to be sure, but Jane thought she was either on the verge of crying or was already there. She leaned back in her chair away from the food, her hands pressing on her round belly, compacted into the fine dress.

"What's that?" the waitress said, confused. "Eat up, dear. Keep your health up."

"I . . . I've only been here two days and . . . and . . ." the girl began sobbing, and nobody took notice. The waitress stood next to her and patted her on the shoulder.

"There there. There there."

"Do you know who I am?" the girl almost shouted. A few looked over, then went back to their conversations.

"Doesn't matter to me who you are, miss. Just glad to give you a proper meal."

The waitress walked off, leaving the food. The girl was crying softly as her chubby face leaned toward the steaming dish in front of her.

"Why? Why are you making me . . . like this . . . eating . . . always . . ." her broken sentence trailed off as she began obediently eating her food.

The other waitress brought Jane's beer and steak. It looked delicious. She was looking forward to it, but that whole overheard conversation had shaken her more than she was used to. She tried to shrug it off, but it left an extremely bad feeling about this whole endeavor in her.

Jane drops a purse full of gold on the counter and gets up, rushing to get out of the inn to find just what the hell was going on. Jane wasn't really the caring type, but she was curious so she decided to go and see what had upset the girl so much.

Jane got up out of her chair, picked up her steak and beer, and went over to the girl's table. As she got closer she heard the girl crying softly, muffled by the food she was shoving into her mouth.

"For someone so upset about a meal, you don't seem too reluctant to eat it once you start," Jane said to the girl sitting opposite her as she placed down her food. Now that she was close, she could see the girl's face was very pretty and as she moved while she ate two pointed ears poked through her long blonde hair. "An elf!" Jane thought "Don't get many of those, let alone chubby ones." The elf was clearly chubby, her face was rounded and, though Jane couldn't see her stomach, her dress looked stressed.

"Please," the elf started through a mouthful of food "The food here... it's only been two days... I was thin like you... But they don't stop," she managed through mouthfuls.

"Yeah right," Jane thought "She isn't fat, but people can't put on that much weight over two days," If the elf was telling the truth and she was as thin as Jane then she must have put on twenty pounds!

"Well leave then," Jane humored.

"I can't," she said, frustrated.

As Jane was contemplating what the girl in front of her was saying, her stomach rumbled and she was suddenly aware of the steak in front of her, "One bite can't hurt..." she muttered, lifting her fork and knife.

"No!" Came the muffled cry of the elf.

Does Jane...

11132.content:
Jane ignored the elf and cut the steak, putting the slice on the fork and dropping it in her mouth. The elf girl looked horrified, she looked defeated as she ate another mouthful. Jane was amazed by the food, it was so good!

She ate fast and hungrily, demolishing the steak. After finishing, she sat back with her hands on her slightly distended stomach. The elf finished shortly after and looked at Jane's ready eyes. "I tried to warn you" the chubby elf said as one if the waitresses came over.

"Enjoyed the starter I see," the waitress said happily motioning to the empty plates.

"Starter!" Jane said in shock nearly choking on her beer.

"Of course, here's the main meal," the waitress pointed to a huge serving trolley being pushed by the other waitress, two plates were on it piled high with all kinds of food. Jane found her mouth watering at the tower of food. One was placed in front of her and the other in front of the elf.

"I can't, I really do need to sleep though," Jane said nervously to the large woman.

"Nonsense it's free after all!" She said with a grin.

Despite her better judgement Jane found herself eating the huge meal, becoming more and more afraid that what the elf said was true. She ate the whole meal, her stomach now pushed hard against the leather armor she wore beneath her hood. Once more the waitress came, this time with a huge cake for dessert, and once more Jane failed to resist. The whole thing was eaten and the elf continued to sob quietly, matching Jane's own eating speed.

After eating so much she couldn't think straight, and the two waitress showed Jane and the elf to their own separate rooms. Jane fell on her huge bed and was asleep almost instantly.

By morning Jane found herself looking in the mirror, her face was softer as was the rest of her, over one meal she gained 10 pounds.

She tried to leave but was met with breakfast, then lunch, and then dinner.

On the fifth night Jane was brought to her room and fell on the bed. "Can't sleep... Need to escape." She had to leave now, after five days in the tavern she had packed on 50 pounds. Her face was soft, her arms lost their tone, her stomach now was soft and jiggled slightly if she moved too fast. Her butt was bigger too, complimented by her thicker thighs and even her boobs had grown slightly.

She knew that night was the one time she could leave, but the food made her so sleepy. She got out of the bed, her leather armor groaned in protest, it had already ripped in the stomach area and threatened to show more with each pound. She fought sleep and left the room. The bar was empty and the door in sight. She was going to leave when she remembered the elf, "I can't leave her," Jane thought. She went into the elf's room to find her asleep. The elf was about 10 pounds heavier than Jane, most of the weight going to her belly and breasts giving her a top heavy appearance.

"We have to go!" Jane whispered in a hurry, waking the elf. She was confused and tired, obediently following without a word. As the night air hit them they both woke up more. They ran as fast as their new weight allowed them and escaped the town into the forest.

"Thank you so much!" the elf choked out nearly crying from happiness.

"It's fine we're free now, why were you there?" Jane asked

"I was heading to the Lipomancer's lair, I heard tales of treasure and found where it is."

"Wait you know where..?!" The chubby rogue said grabbing the elf's thick arms

"Y-yes" the elf stammered "In here," she said pointing at the forest

111321.content:
To Jane it seemed like they were lost in the forrest. The two had only been in the forrest for about an hour, but she swore she saw that same weird face-shaped rock three times. She began to wonder if the elf actually had any idea of where the lair was. However even if she didn't, elves were suppose to be at home in nature, she should be able to at least get them out of the woods... right? Jane's nerves were not helped when the elf gave off a confused expression when they hit the rock the third time.

"So are you sure you know where the lair is?" Jane inquired.

"Ahhh! I mean.... yeahhhh it shouldd just be a little furtherrr," the elf stuttered. The elf then started to twiddle her thumbs together.

"Are you sure because I'm pretty sure we have passed the same area three times already !?"Jane exclaimed. The elf seemed to visibly shrink at this statement, only giving out a faint 'yeahhhhh'. Jane internally sighed, great I'm already scaring away my only good lead to the treasure so far ; no wonder why my last partner bailed out on me. I can't afford to scare her away, otherwise ill be back to square zero. She barely even looks at me, i better try to ease her before she tries to split from me.

"Listen, I'm sorry for yelling. I'm just a little stressed out with all this craziness going on. Hell, i don't even know your name yet or anything," Jane stated, hoping to ease her new traveling companion.

"Ohhh it's okay you didn't do anything wrong. I'm just still a little freaked out from the tavern. I thought i was never gonna get out of there," the elf said while shuttering.

"Lets start over then." Jane stopped walking, put on her award winning smile and extended her hand out." My name is Jane. I'm an adventurer from a town far far away. "

"My name is Ma - AHHHHH!" the elf exclaimed with a panicked expression.

"Your name is mah?" a confused Jane asked. This girl might be a tad off her rockers, Jane began to worry. The elf then suddenly dragged the bewildered rogue close to her.

"No it's Mara. But forget that, were being followed by the staff from the bar! We have to hide now!" the elf whispered.

"How can you te... ," Jane began to ask but was interrupted by another louder voice.

"They went this way, they couldn't have gotten far," exclaimed a woman in the distance.

The elf quickly began to panic trying to figure out what to do. Jane also was feeling a bit uneasy as she looked down at her extra flab she acquired thanks to that dam town. Not wanting them to finish whatever they planned to do with the two, she quickly tried to look for an escape of some kind. Thankfully her training as a rogue had improved her sense of sight, allowing her to spy a narrow crevice that lead to a small cave.

"Quickly, we have to get out of here!" the Jane stated. She then quickly grabbed elf's hand and started to dash forward. "There is a cave up ahead that is hidden enough for us to hold out in."
111321.title: No time to waste, let's go.

The cave has some secrets!
1113211.content:
It was a much more narrow squeeze then Jane was used to, 'curse you evil steak for damming my weight ', but they made it into the cave with plenty of time to spare. The two quietly waited for the sound of footsteps to pass into the distance. Still a little concerned about the skulking party from the tavern and the fact that the sun was quickly setting, the two decided to camp it out in the cave before heading out. Unfortunately for Jane, she was having trouble finding her matches in the dark.

"Curse you matches for being so small and hidden," the rogue cursed at her bag.

The elf chuckled at this state of dismay. "I might be able to help you out with that , so you don't start stabbing your bag," the elf replied. She then produced an intense blue green flame from her hand, which proceeded to float to the center of the room.

"You could do that the whole time, thanks for the help," Jane grumbled. "So judging by the blue flame i take it your a mage?"

"Oh right we never really introduced ourselves... well at least i didn't," the elf proclaimed. The elf began to remove her cloak, allowing Jane to finally get a good look of the girl underneath. "My name is Mara. As you can guess from the pointy ears I'm an elven mage, I'm from a village pretty far from here."

Jane however barely heard the last part of Mara's statement as her jaw dropped when the elf took off her cloak. In front of her lied one of the most beautiful girls she had ever come across on her travels. The elf was sporting silky smooth golden blond hair. She wore a red ornate dress and some exotic looking shoes that almost looked to be wooden. In the bar Mara seemed to be very thin with a potbelly from their stuffing nightmare, but now she was rocking a stunning hourglass figure most girls she knew would die for.

'That's not fair she had a potbelly like me just a little bit ago, how did she turn it into that,' Jane pondered. However she realized that elf girl was just staring at her, with her face a little red. Realizing she must have been gawking at the poor girl she embarrassingly recomposed herself.

"Oh um that's cool." Jane mentally face palmed herself. 'Come on get a grip master rogue, so much for being suave.' Deciding it would be better if they changed the topic she asked "What are you doing out here anyway?"

"Same as you I imagine, looking for the grand treasure of the lipomancer's lair," Mara replied. "Though I may have gone in over my head." She nervously scratched the back of her head. "If my panicking before didn't hint it off, I'm kinda new to this whole adventuring business."

"Well how many adventurers have you been on before this?," Jane asked.

"This would be the first one....," Mara practically whispered in shame.

"WHAT! " exclaimed Jane. "This is not first adventure material, the lipomancer is a very dangerous person!"

"I know but.... i just ...I .... i don't wanna talk about it okay," the elf murmured. A pained look hit Mara's face and she almost looked like she about to start crying.

"Hey hey it's okay, lets just worry about that later. For now lets get some sleep alright?" Jane insisted.

A replied *sniff* okay, was all Jane needed to hear to start unpacking her knapsack. The last thing she wanted to do is make her new fragile companion cry. Finally all set Jane prepared to pass out when she noticed that Mara was about the lie down on the cold cave rock.

"What are you doing," Jane inquired.

"I sorta left behind some of my supplies at the inn," Mara sighed. "I was so lost in the moment of escaping I didn't remember to grab a lot of things."

"Well you can come share with me then, and i won't take no for an answer!" Jane declared.

The elf girl quietly came over and started to snuggle with the red-headed rogue. Mara quickly entered the land of slumber, while Jane took one last glance at the girl who was smiling a tad. 'Maybe this adventure won't be so bad after all ' Jane thought with a big grin.

11132111.content:
The next morning, with no sign of the crazy villagers outside, the two adventurers set off on their hunt to the lipomancer's lair. However, as the day prolonged they found themselves ironically hungry. They decided to take a break to find some grub with Mara searching for berries while Jane tried her luck at fishing. Unfortunately for Jane, her luck seemed to be on vacation as she was not getting a single bite from the fish.

"God dam fish, in this god dam river are so stingy and rare," she grumbled to herself. She had been here for what felt like an hour, with only sight of a single fish that passed by earlier. She was starting to believe that there weren't even any other fish besides that one in this god dam river.

Just like it was on queue however, a fish suddenly appeared, proceeding to slowly inch up on her bait. With glowing hopeful eyes Jane watched as this fish was getting closer and closer to her worm. All her hope quickly turned to rage as a much larger fish then proceeded to devour the smaller one. With its prize it then proceeded to quickly start to swim down the river.

"WHY YOU NO GOOD, THAT WAS MY FISH," Jane exclaimed.

Jane was just about to jump into the river knives a blazing to chase this no good fish thief (ironic isn't it) before she heard a ruffle behind her. Ever alert she quickly found a good position in some bushes to ambush this nearby visitor. 'Maybe it's a delicious pig we can cook up,' Jane hoped to herself. She was about to jump at whatever it was before she saw the pointy ears she had started to grow accustomed to. Lowering her guard Jane proceeded to walk up to her companion, who by the look of her empty hands was having just as much luck as she was.

"So no luck with the berries i assume," Jane solemnly asked.

"No, but i found something else you need to check out. Unless you are not done yelling at the fish," Mara jested.

Mara lead the way into a small clearing in the forrest. In the center of this clearing laid a large wooden box containing tons of food. The food varied from pies, cakes, bread and all sorts of goodies.

"Why didn't you say you found food before," Jane cheerily stated. Jane then proceeded to start to walk towards the box. "Come on let us grab some of this great food and......"

"Wait!" Mara exclaimed while holding Jane back. "Don't you find it strange how this box made it out all the here and it hasn't been touched. What if it's cursed food like the food in the town or a trap from the town!?"

"But it could have easily been a crate from a merchant's wagon that happened to fall off the cart. Which has been waiting for two lucky girls to find and enjoy its contents," Jane retorted.

The two girl's stomachs proceeded to show their opinion with a quick growl from both of them followed my a minor stomach pain. Whatever they were gonna do, they needed to decide now whether to enjoy this seemingly innocent gift or play it safe and continue their hunt for food.

Heard a strange noise.

As much as Jane wished it wasn't so, Mara was probably right. The weirdness of this box just happening to appear with not a soul disturbing it is too suspicious to ignore. The box could easily have been a trap from the village folk, lipomancer or some yet seem enemy. If Jane had not have been in such a hungry state she too would probably have recognized this as the trap it almost certainly was.

Speaking of which, without the food from the boxes Jane was feeling very miserable from all the hunger pains. While she normally could go days without a proper meal, the stuffing at the inn seemed to mess with her stomach, making it desire more substance then she was used too. "Don't worry i will get some for us," Mara yelled back down to Jane.

'Also god dam, after this I need to ask some elves for climbing tips, she puts me to shame,' she told herself. It had been only about a minute and Mara looked almost one-third up the massive tree.

Just then Jane .....

1113211111.content:
All of a sudden, a strong aroma hit Jane like a brick. Caught by surprise, the smell quickly overwhelmed the rogue, not that she was complaining. The smell was divine, giving off a very sweet scent. The fancy perfumes of mansions, the rogue had broken into, did not even compare to this scent. The aroma seemed to float in from somewhere deeper in the forrest.

Jane didn't even notice her whole body started to move towards direction of the odor. The smell was so intoxicating, she was lost in its beauty. Even when she did notice her movement she brushed off as if nothing was amiss. ' Mara will be fine and i have some time before she gets back, i must figure out where that heavenly smell is coming from,' Jane told herself.

Within a few eager steps she quickly found the source of the sweet scent. A cluster of purple trees lay before her. While the trees did not compare in size to the tree Mara was climbing, they were impressive in their own right, giving off a strange glow. When Jane got closer, further inspection showed that the glow was from the golden liquid that seemed to ooze off each tree. The liquid in question seemed to be some sort of tree sap and also seemed to be the origin of the smell.

As Jane continued to walk toward these strange trees, the scent grew more powerful and potent. Her mouth started to drool at the sight of the delicious smelling sap. ' I'm just really hungry is all' thought Jane, trying to justify her strange actions to herself. ' I wonder if the sap tastes as good as it smells.' She slowly gathered some sap in her cupped hands, brought it to her face and sipped the liquid down. As soon as the sap hit Jane's tongue, her senses went wild. This sap was one of the best things she had ever eaten with its smooth texture and heavenly sweet taste. She rapidly downed the rest of what she had in her hands and went head first into a puddle of the sap.

Had she not been so overwhelmed with all these blasts to her senses she might have been concerned with her odd behavior or what this sap was doing to her. Her mind however was so distracted from these sensations that she didn't even care she was slurping the sap up from the ground. All she knew was that the liquid was delicious and she wanted more.

Alternate Method
11132111111.content:
While Jane was busy being enticed by the forest, Mara had almost made it to the top of the giant tree. She was thankful for her great climbing abilities she developed over the years. While it is commonly know that elves typically live in forests, most incorrectly assume that elves are all amazing at anything to do with the woods. Granted everyone in her village does know how to climb trees, Mara was one of the best, with no one coming close to her prowess or speed. While Mara was proud of this accomplishment, it was always watered down by a sour reminder. A reminder of the loneliness that caused her to become this good.

Mara growing up had an enjoyable childhood, with loving parents and many friends. When her parents discovered that she had arcane abilities they were overjoyed with pride, telling their little angel that she had a great gift. When she finally was of age, she was sent to one of the magic academies to master her abilities. However when she arrived she started to feel like she was cursed rather then gifted. She quickly tried to make some new friends but she almost always ignored by the other students. She didn't understand what she was doing wrong, why these people were being so cruel to her.

Eventually one day the loneliness got to her and after classes she felt like she needed to get away from it all. Remembering the good times when she used to go on mock adventures with her friends at home, she decided to explore the woods surrounding the school's grounds. As she traveled through the woods, the feeling of mystery around every turn made her forget her troubles and she quickly began to relax for the first time in a while. She laughed when she tripped on a log, she felt proud when she climbed large tree, and gazed in awe when she found a beautiful clearing of flowers. From that day on she took many trips into the woods after her classes. Each time she pushed herself harder and harder wanting to find more new areas to explore. While the loneliness always returned later, the happiness these trips brought was good enough for her.

Mara finally reached the top of the giant tree, making her way over to the fruit. While the location of the fruit she could see from the ground, she could not really see much about the texture of the food until now. While she saw the fruit was yellow, she didn't see these strange markings on the fruit. The markings were all purple and almost looked like another tree with a big red x though them to Mara. While she did find the markings weird, the fruit seemed good enough. She proceeded to take a small bite out of the fruit, quickly regretting it. While the fruit was not poisonous or have some weird charm in it, the fruit certainly did not taste that good. She was tempted to leave the fruit there but, the elf knew that her and Jane were way too hungry to care. So she proceeded to gather some fruit into her bag.

Speaking of Jane, Mara did not really know what to make of her so far. She hadn't really met too many humans before this, only some traders that came by her home village every now and again. Jane certainly seemed nice so far. Mara certainly was thankful for her rescuing from the village inn, even if she didn't listen to her warnings. Jane was definitely one of the prettiest humans she had met so far. Mara certainly hoped they could become friends, she didn't really want to go on this adventure on her own. 'Only time will tell i guess' Mara thought to herself.

With her bag now filled, she went to the edge to tell her companion that she was finished. As she got to the edge and looked down she became disheartened from the lack of Jane. The elf began to feel saddened at the thought of her companion ditching her. She slowly started to climb down, but as she grew closer to the ground she heard the sound of what seemed to be eating in the nearby distance. Hoping her companion had just wandered off because she found food, Mara quickened her pace to where the sound was emitting from. After two minutes she finally saw Jane in the distance, near a cluster of trees.

"Oh Jane why did you wander off? Did you find some food or something?" Mara inquired as she approached the rogue. When Mara got closer she realized something was wrong. Jane was not eating food as she suspected, but devouring this strange golden liquid off the floor. She was not even using her hands to gather the liquid, instead deciding to slurp up the liquid on all fours like some sort of animal. More worrying was the fact that she must have been here a while as her gut seemed to be a little more extended then Mara remembered.

"Jane what are you doing, are you okay?" Mara asked. With no response from Jane again Mara's concern grew. She quickly grabbed Jane, trying to drag her away from the liquid. As soon as she did however, Jane seemed to try to fight back to get to the puddle.
11132111111.title: Mara's problematic past. Time to save Jane!

choices: Wakey Wakey Eggs and Bakey (next day everything is fine)
The large amount of trees gets to them in the night
111321111111.content:
"Jane, come on snap out of it," Mara pleaded to the rogue. She was playing tug of war with the golden liquid's pull on Jane, and she was losing that battle. Mara was not that physically strong and she didn't want to use magic to avoid accidentally hurting Jane.

"That heavenly smell, that mouthwatering taste, I must have more," Jane mumbled to herself. Jane still was under the allure of the liquids aroma. She was so lost in its trap, she didn't even notice Mara was there. Her only concern was getting more of that delicious smelling and tasting goo.

While struggling to hold Jane in place, Mara wondered what smell the rogue was talking about. Mara assumed the rogue tried this goo, and was charmed with some sort of addictive flavor. However it would seem the liquid also had an addictive smell to it, which Mara could not smell in the slightest. While the taste would obviously elude her without trying some, she should still get a whiff whatever this aroma is. Obviously the elf was thankful she couldn't smell the scent, lest she end up like her hunger crazed companion, but she hoped she could find some key to curing Jane with her immunity.

Jane's struggling to get to her delicious treasure, unintentionally gave a swift elbow jab to Mara's jaw. Mara yelped in pain as her head was knocked upward but she maintained her hold of the entranced rogue. This knock upwards shifted Mara's view from the addictive goo on the floor, to the strange trees the liquid came from. She only had a quick glance at the trees before finding Jane, but now getting a better look she noticed how odd the trees were. The trees were completely purple, almost like someone had splashed paint all over them. The elf had seen purple leaves, before but never purple wood.

While Mara pondered at this strange tree a small spark clicked in the her mind. The fruit she just picked, didn't it have that strange violet marking on it. Mara quickly reached into her bag to grab one of the fruits, which unfortunately let the struggling Jane inch a little closer to her prize before Mara's arm returned to its hard grip. Inspecting the fruit again she noticed that the design was very close to the shape of the strange trees before her. The fruit must have been what kept her from being trapped by the strange sap. Maybe it could cure Jane?

The elf tried to shove the fruit into the Jane's mouth, but could find no way of moving her hand close enough without letting the rogue run free. The elf didn't know how long the fruit's effects would take, not wanting Jane to get addicted again before it worked its magic. Still not wanting to use magic on Jane, from fear of hurting her, she decided to trip the girl instead and rush her. With a quick shift of her grip from Jane's upper body to Jane's legs the entranced rogue quickly fell down, landing on her filled bellied which proceeds to jiggle from the impact. Before Jane could recover, the elf sat on the girl while proceeding to cram a fruit down Jane's throat. With something to eat again in her mouth's vicinity, she happily chewed down on the fruit.

"Ugh," groaned Jane. "What did you make me eat, it tasted like dirt had a baby with mold?" inquired the Rogue, as she tried to brush her tongue.

"Jane are you okay?" asked the worried elf, thankful to finally get a response.

"Besides needing soap to wash the taste outta my mouth, I'm fine. Where are we anyway?" Jane replied.

"I'm not really sure, but Jane you don't remember? You were in some kind of trance and ate tons of that strange goo," a confused Mara asked.

"No not really. All I remember was this great smell and..... wait did you says tons," exclaimed a now panicked Jane. Looking down Jane could see the damage that was done to her figure. An extra ten pounds seemed to be added to her already chubby body and straight on her gut, much to the girl's dismay. The girl's emotions quickly turned to anger from this realization.

"God dam tree in this dam god dam forest with its god dam fattening magic," cursed the rogue as she stomped around.

"I'm sorry if only I was quicker," the elf sadly stuttered. Mara proceeded to slowly look downwards, carrying a gloomy expression on her face. Jane eventually caught a glimpse of this in her rage. She had forgotten about the delicate side of the elf, she encountered the first night. Not wanting her bad temper to scare off her companion she quickly cooled down.

"Hey it's not your fault. My own stupidity got me stuck in this mess," Jane reassured the elf. "Besides look at the bright side, when the plants are trying to fatten you up the lipomancer's lair can't be that far."

"Yeah, I guess your right," Mare replied shyly."But still maybe if I was around I could have ...," Mara started to say, before she was met with finger on her lips.

"Shush you, don't go blaming yourself for everything. I'm the experienced adventurer here," Jane proudly stated with a smirk." Your allowed to make mistakes, while I shouldn't be making such silly ones. So the only blaming around here should be directed at me, understand?"

"Yes mam," Mara replied with a small smile. "And thanks."

With enough non cursed food to last them a while, the two set off towards where Mara believed the lair to be. On there way they passed dozens of clusters of the purples trees, all erupting with the same strange addicting liquid. Jane shuttered at thought of what one tree did to her, let alone if she had lost control here around all these trees.

"Your sure those weird fruits you have will keep working right," Jane sheepishly asked.

"I believe so, I'm not really sure," replied Mara." But someone or something obviously wanted to show us that they protected against those tree's effects. I doubt they would go through all the trouble of marking them all if they didn't work."

The sky quickly grew dark and the two were forced to set up in a nearby cave. Unfortunately for them, they were still right in the middle of the strange purple trees but they could travel no further. While Jane was concerned about falling into another trance, Mara was confident that the fruits would last the night. Just as a safety precaution though, the two stuffed their noses up with cloth and ate a little more of the fruit before drifting off into slumber.
111321111111.title: A Warning from Someone

choices: The house belonged to a lady
The house seemed empty, but maybe more sinister then thought.
1113211111111.content:
As the sun rose up, so did the two adventurers. With the lack of extra blubber on the girls, it was clear that the fruit did the trick for protecting them from the tree's magic. They were about to head out from the cave, when the sounds of a thunderstorm echoed in the distance. With the dark clouds coming closer, they decided that it would be smarter to wait out the storm in the safety of the cave. The two girls quickly found themselves in a situation of awkward silence. While they both had spoken to each other before, it was generally about the adventure or some trap. They both realized they really didn't know much about the other, not having time to have asked questions with all the craziness of the past few days. Finally getting sick of the silence, Jane decided to be the one to start the conversation.

"So Mara, since we have some time to kill why don't you tell me about yourself," Jane curiously asked.

"Oh, well there isn't really much excitement to tell," Mara bashfully replied. "What exactly would you like to know?"

"Um, why don't you tell me about your home town. You said it was called Elysian correct?" the Rogue inquired.

"Yes, and the name does not lie. The town really did feel like paradise, at least to me," Mara stated. "As you properly guessed, the town was in the middle of a large beautiful forest. Some of the buildings were actually built into and on the trees. We also had a river that ran straight through the village, eventually becoming a small lake we used as a pool. As for the village itself the food was delicious, everyone was kind and there was always something to do for excitement."

"I assume you had some family and friends in the village?" Jane asked.

"Oh yes, I'm part of a family of 5. There are my two parents Seith and Azura, my younger brother Erlan, and my younger sister Ava. As for friends most of the village was friendly towards each other, but my best friends were Elora, Jill and Rhys. There was also my close friend Grunger, a dwarf from far North, but he had to move back home eventually. We all used to have so much fun, going on pretend adventures in the woods, mock battling each other or trying to make crazy devices." Mara quickly seemed to get lost in thought, remembering the good old days when life was simpler.

"So why did you leave anyway, seemed like you had it pretty made," Jane jokey asked. She quickly wished she hadn't however, as an aura of gloom seemed to cast over Mara.

"Well eventually my parents discovered I was a mage when i was around 16. When I was finally of age, I was sent to the academy to train my skills," Mara stated , with a look of pain quickly developing. "And I ... I don't really want to go into the rest. I'm sorry."

Mara seemed very uncomfortable Jane noted, as the elf seemed to visible shrink and turned her gaze from Jane to the empty cave floor. She felt bad for quickly ruining the mood, but in her defense she didn't know. Jane proceeded to walk over to where Mara was sitting, given the girl a reassuring pat on the back.

"Hey it's okay, you don't have to go into anything you don't want to talk about," Jane insisted. "Were friends after all and friends respect each others privacy."

Mara turned her head back to Jane with a bewildered expression on her face. "Were friends? I mean you want to be friends with me?" Mara stammered.

"What? Why wouldn't we be friends?" asked a confused Jane. "You seem to be pretty friendly and considerate. Not to mention you probably saved my life earlier, or at least my waist. Of course were friends."

As Mara began to process Jane's statement, a broad smile started to quickly form on the girl. It was a smile that Jane hoped she would see a lot more of on their travels. While Jane already thought the elf girl was attractive, she seemed even more beautiful then before. However more importantly, this seemed to be the first time on their adventure that Mara seemed truly just happy. Not worried about some danger or in pain from some unknown past, just happy. Mara suddenly gave Jane a quick hug, causing the unsuspecting rogue to develop a small blush.

"Thanks, I've been traveling alone on the roads for a while. It's comforting to have a friend again," Mara revealed.

"Oh um yeah, of coarse," Jane coughed.

"Hey it seems the storm is gone," Mara exclaimed. "We should head out."

They ate a small chunk of their protective fruit, and quickly set out. As they walked Jane continued to ask Mara questions about her village life. Mara began to tell all sorts stories of her youth, like her adventures with her friends, or her mischief with her siblings. After a while, Mara eventually ran out of stories she could remember.

"So now you know a little bit about my youth, what about yours?" Mara questioned. "How did you wind up becoming a rogue?"

"Well I.....," Jane began to start, before getting distracted. "Hey Mara, what is that?"

In the distance lay a mysterious looking house. While it seemed strange that someone was living all the way out here, the architecture of the house was the more peculiar part. The design of the house was normal enough, but the material it was build out of looked abnormal. Neither girl could say for certain what the house seemed to be made of.

The two decided that despite the strange appearance of the house, the house seemed normal enough. They hoped that whoever lived their was home. A local would be great help with navigating the forest or getting a better idea of where the lipomancer's lair was. The two companions made there way over to the door and knocked. Suddenly the door opened....
1113211111111.title: Village Life and Strange Houses

choices: Astra helps the two set off in the right direction towards the lair
Astra is actually working for the lipomancer(by choice or not)
11132111111111.content:
The door slowly opened, revealing a tall young human woman. The 5’7 woman was wearing a linen shirt with a purple skirt, which had a floral design too it. Besides a little pudge in the stomach area, she seemed to be in amazing shape. Being in shape would definitely help carry her big breasts, she barely contained in her shirt. Her face, in contrast to the rest of her body, made her seem very delicate with all the fine features it held. That same face now held a surprised expression on it at this moment.

“Well, this is unexpected. I rarely get visitors, specially such adorable ones,” the woman stated with an almost sultry tone.

“Hello, uh miss. I’m Jane and this is my friend Mara. We were wondering if you could give us some directions,” Jane replied.

“Of course, how could I deny such friendly and cute guests. The name is Astra by the way,” the woman answered. “Now where are you two little ladies goi…. ,” the woman began to say before suddenly halting.

“Are you okay,” Mara questioned.

“You two, inside now,” Astra barked. Her previous tone now completely replaced by a serious one. The two girls wondered what changed in the few moments of their conversation to cause this shift.

“Why? What’s going on,” Jane demanded.

“That’s what is going on,” Astra whispered as she pointed behind them. As the girls turned around, their expressions dropped. In the distance roamed what could only be describe as a massive blue monster filed with some kind of liquid. While it seemed to currently just sitting there, who knows what it would do if it saw them. The two girls decided they rather not take that chance, proceeding to follow Astra into her home.

“Are you sure were safe in here from that thing? It’s almost as big as your house,” Jane inquired.

“Yes, were fine. My house is made from materials that seem to ward away the monsters,” Astra insisted.

“Was that massive creature a slime?” Mara asked. The elf on her many travels has seen some crazy creatures. On one such trip she had encountered some slimes. The ones she ran into were small and adorable, generally made from human wizards practicing animation spells on water. Creating life takes a lot of energy, so most animation spells at their biggest wind up human size. The amount of power that would be required to make one that size would be enormous, requiring a seriously skilled magic user to produce.

“Honestly I have no idea and no desire to get that close to find out. Well, on the bright side I now have plenty of time to give you guys directions,” Astra joked.

Rather then stand in the door entrance all day, Astra lead them to a living room area. The room, besides the small pieces of furniture to sit down on was mostly empty, suggesting Astra had not lived here for long. The room also had door that presumably lead to the sleeping quarters. While Mara and Jane sat down, Astra quickly went to the kitchen to get some refreshments for her guests. She eventually returned with some bread and water.

“So where are you guys headed anyway? I’m honestly surprised two young ladies came to woods like these,” Astra questioned as the girls began to munch on their bread.

Jane slowed her chewing down, trying to come up with an answer to the woman question. While she seemed nice, her run in with the townsfolk made her wary of the people here. They could all be working for the lipomancer. Before she could come up with a response however Mara blurted, “Oh well, were looking for the lair of the lipomancer.”

Jane could only face palm at the nativity of her partner. Astra on the other hand was startled by this statement.

“What, why would you wanna go there? Do you know how dangerous it is,” Astra harshly exclaimed. “You should just go back to wherever you came from, it's not worth going there.”

“Hey, I will have you know were experienced adventurers. We can handle anything the lipomancer can throw at us,” Jane argued.

“That’s just what Lana said before she went missing,” Astra countered with a deflated expression.

“Who is Lana?” Mara asked.

“Lana, she is my sister,” Astra sadly replied. “She was an adventurer as well, and thought she could claim the treasure of the lipomancer to help out the family. That was a month ago and we haven't heard from her since. That is what is in store for you too, if you follow this foolish quest. I came out here to try to find her, but haven't had any luck getting past all the traps and monsters.”

“If you want we can help find your sister,” Mara offered.

“I said no, I don't want more people to share her fate,” Astra yelled.

“Listen you can’t stop us from going out there to find the lair. We are gonna go there with your help or not. So instead of this non sense help us get there and we will more then happily look out for your sister on our travels,” Jane declared.

Astra sighed, knowing that she could not persuade these two to give up their quest so easily. It seems to be a trait in all adventurers to be stubborn as mules, just like her sister she supposed.

“All right fine, you win,” Astra conceded. “ While I don't know the exact location, I know which direction to head from here. If you promise to bring my sister home, I’ll help you out.”

“Deal,” the two girls replied.

On that note Astra offered to let girls stay the night to rest and prepare for their journey. Knowing this might be the last nice place they stay at for a while, the two girls accepted. The three proceeded to eat some dinner that Astra cooked, while she told them about how she winded up here.

Astra was part of a family from SummerStone. The whole family worked, her father as butler, mother as a cook, her sister trained to become a knight, and she herself as a builder. Everything was fine until her father became ill. Most of their income had to be transferred to his treatment, leaving not a lot left for the basic necessities. Lana, hearing a rumor of the fabled lipomancer treasure stash, decided to set out to find it to help out her family.

While her father did start to get better, no one heard back from Lana in over a week. Worried, Astra set out to try follow her sister’s steps from what she had been shown. When she reached these woods, she immediately fell victim to the same trap that Jane fell to. Thankfully for her one of the fruits that cured the affliction fell into the liquid she was devouring, snapping out of her state. Eventually after nearly running straight into big blue, she decided she needed a safe haven. She proceeded to build a house from the strange purple trees in a few days. Luckily for her the wood seemed to have a weird effect of scaring off the monsters. She continued her search but ran into more obstacles everyday. She was actually starting to run out of time, needing to go home to help pay the bills while her father recovered.

After dinner Astra showed the two to their quarters, her room in fact. She insisted that as the host she could not make her guests sleep so uncomfortably, and that she could sleep on the couch one night. The two thanked her hospitality and said their goodnights to the Astra as they prepared for bed.

“I’m glad we are helping her,” Mara stated, as she prepared her bed. “I couldn't imagine what I do if one of my siblings went missing.”

“Yeah, but hey Mara listen,” Jane replied. “You gotta be more careful about what information you tell people. While Astra turned out fine, what if she was like the villagers or a minion of the lipomancer.”

“I had not even thought about that,” Mara admitted. “I’m sorry, I'm not really good at this.”

“It’s okay, just be careful from now on all right?” Jane repeated.

“Yeah, I’ll try to be more careful. Good night Jane” Mara replied.

With that the two adventurers went to bed.
11132111111111.title: The Missing Sister

choices: Run into monsters (possibly some tiny slimes)
Find something strange(object/building/structure)
111321111111111.content:
The sun slowly started to rise, casting a dim light in the woods. The sunrise bounced off the morning dew, creating bright glow in the woods. Birds were chirping, a nearby stream was trickling, and insects were humming. If one did not know the dangers that lurked in these woods, the forest would seem very peaceful and an inviting place. The peace definitely did help make sleeping easier, as the two girls continued to slumber in Astra’s bed. That was until a loud noise stirred their slumber.

“Owww, god dam it,” Astra cursed in another room in the house.

The loud shout was enough to slowly wake Jane and Mara from their deep sleep. The two groggily opened their eyes, until they were met with a surprise. When they went to bed, the two tried to give each other as much space as they could on Astra’s bed. Awakening, they found themselves inches away from the other’s face. A small blush formed on the two girls, each of them quickly trying to come up with a response to this awkward situation. Jane, staring at Mara’s stunning face, was starting consider just going straight in for a kiss, but Mara beat her to action.

“Oh, I’m sorry,” Mara exclaimed, jumping out of the bed. “Guess I’m a bit of a bed hog,” Mara joked, as she nervously scratched the back of her neck.

With the shock of the situation passing, Jane’s natural roguish charms were given time to work their magic. “If it means I get to wake up to such a beautiful sight, you can hog my bed anytime,” Jane teased as she slowly got up. Mara’s blush, turning a deep crimson, was all Jane needed to see to know she still had game. Deciding that to be enough for now, the rogue fixed up her bed hair and proceeded to her pile of cloths.

“Come on Mara, lets go check if Astra is up,” Jane said, as she started to dress. Mara, who was still flustered from Jane’s comments, slowly proceeded to ready herself for the day as well. With the girls finally dressed, they proceeded out of the room to search for Astra. Eventually they found her, with a pained look on her face as she held her left hand in a bucket of water.

“Astra, are you okay?” Mara inquired, as she rushed over to the builder.

“Yeah, I'm fine,” Astra asserted. She raised her hand from the bucket, showing the hand to be a little red and swollen. “I’m just a bad cook is all. Tried to make something since you guys are my guests, wound up cooking myself instead.”

“Here I can stop the swelling,” Mara offered. Taking Astra’s hand, the mage began to cast a spell. The effects were immediate as the hand proceeded to shrink in size, though maintained its red color. “The rest should heal shorty. Now no more cooking, we can handle it,” Mara declared, already making a beeline straight for the cooking area.

“Thank you, I appreciate the help,” Astra replied. “Lana was always the one that cooked with mom, I'm afraid I'm not as skilled in that regard.”

As Mara prepared breakfast, Jane started going over directions with Astra. Lana had carefully done her research before heading out. Eventually, Lana had made a map of where she believed the entrance to the lair was located. While unfortunately Lana still had that map, Astra was present for a lot of her sister’s work and was able to piece together a lot of what she remembered. Before the two girls arrived she had mapped out a lot of the forest, getting a good idea of what area to head to.

Some point during their conversation, Mara had returned with a delicious meal for the three. Some fluffy pancakes, some warm soup, and even chopped up some of that weird fruit they still had. Eagerly, the three chowed down on their meal, commending Mara for her good cooking. At some point Jane noticed that Astra had stopped eating. A distant stare plagued her face as if she was in deep thought, contemplating something.

“Jane, can I ask you a question,” Astra abruptly asked. With a pancake stuffed in her mouth, Jane proceeded to nod for her to continue. “I just don't get why my sister does this all the time. She keeps going off on these wild adventures without regard for anything else. It is constant danger she doesn't need to put herself though, I mean she has a job lined up in the city. You are an adventurer too, why do you do it?”

“Well, it kinda started by necessity,” Jane began to explain. “When I was a young, my father died in battle. While we had money for a while, raising three kids as a single parent was hard. The situation became a lot worse, when one day we were robbed by bandits. The worst part of that was they stole my father’s sword and watch, the only two items I had left of him. Enraged and determined, I vowed to get back our possessions from these no good thieves. Unfortunately for me the clever bastards had already sold off our stuff to merchants. Eventually, I tracked down the one of items to a small house in the woods. At the time I did not know the house belonged to an old ranger, who quickly took down me as I was inexperienced. When I explained my plight the old man took pity on me, deciding to train me so I could finish my quest. ”

Jane paused for a second, to drink some of her water. The others had stopped eating, enamored by her tale. She was confused why Mara was so surprised from tale before remembering she hadn’t gotten a chance to tell this story yet. Feeling refreshed from the water, she continued on with her yarn.

“Now with proper training, hunting down the rest of the stolen goods was a lot easier. I was able to get back most of our stuff including my dad’s longsword, though I was never able to find what happened to my father’s watch. When I returned home, while proud of what I accomplished, I noticed that something felt missing. I missed the excitement of travel, the thrill of danger at every turn, and the feeling of accomplishment from a hard mark. So I continued my work, taking contracts to steal items or just exploring ruins on my own for treasure. It’s not really about the cash, I don't keep most of my scores. I send most of my loot back to my mother to help take care of my younger siblings. It’s more about the excitement, the thrill from it all.”

“You sound like a danger junkie,” Astra jested. “But I kinda get where you are coming from. Though still doesn't sound that appealing for me.”

“Eh, it's not for everyone,” Jane replied with a shrug.

“Isn’t it hypocritical of you to steal from others when you were robbed?” Mara inquired.

“I only steal from thieves or people with so much stuff they don't notice something is missing. Totally different scenario,” Jane insisted. Mara about to respond with a rebuttal but when she noticed Jane was back to eating, she decided to let it go.
After finishing breakfast, the two girls got ready to head back out. Astra helped the two pack, even kindly giving them some of her extra supplies. With there bags all packed, it was finally time to head out.

“Thank you, so much for your hospitality,” Mara said. In tradition with elf customs, she proceeded to bow, showing respect towards her host.

“Yeah, and thank you for the supplies,” Jane added, giving the host a more casual thanks with a friendly handshake.

“If you two find my sister, that is all the thanks I need,” their host replied. “You two are welcome to come back if you need to, I should be here for a couple more days. Also when you two find my sister, tell her she better be ready for an earful when she gets back.”

On that note the two headed back into the woods, continuing on their adventure.
111321111111111.title: Awkward Encounters, Danger Junkie Jane

choices: Sure we can use the extra help
Actually You should go keep Astra company, she is lonely and could use a friend
1113211111111111.content:
Loud laughter broke the silence of the otherwise peaceful forest, as the two girls continued their trek. The companions had set off following Astra’s instructions carefully, and so far had not run into trouble. To pass the time, Jane began telling tales of her previous heists.

“What do you mean they had no pants on?” Mara giggled, as small tears began to form on her eyes. The elf was so distracted that she almost walked into a low branch, only managing to duck at the last minute.

“Careful there giggles, trees can be deadly,” Jane joked with a big grin. “ I figured if they couldn't find there pants that would slow them down. The guards must not have noticed as they busted straight out of the building after me. Was totally worth it though, as after I lost them I heard a loud scream from a woman behind me, followed by someone yelling ’You perverts, put some clothes on.”

“That’s awesome, I’m sure they sure weren't ready for that huh,” Mara chuckled, starting to wipe away the tears. “That reminds me of a spell I once read about that makes clothes invisible. Always wanted to try it on mean girls at school, but never had the balls to do it.”

“Wait what, there is a spell for that?” Jane exclaimed, turning her head towards Mara.

“I know right, it's so oddly specific. Though to be fair, we are chasing someone who specializes in fattening magic,” Mara argued, with a shrug.

“What a useful spell to know when sleeping next to a lovely lady such as myself,” Jane teased, as she wore a devil smirk.

Mara’s face turned a deep crimson, a wave of embarrassment rushing over her. “What, wait no, I would never,” Mara stuttered.

“If you wanted to see me without clothes, all you had to do was ask,” Jane replied with a sultry voice.

After hoping over a small puddle, the rogue turned back towards Mara to check out her work. Mara was so easy and fun to fluster, even if Jane did sometimes mean what she said. The elf was currently speechless, with her head lowered to hide her massive blush. Unfortunately for Mara, with her head down she could not see a low hanging branch, walking straight into it instead. With a smack, the mage was knocked down straight into the puddle.

Jane rushed over to her friend, feeling a little guilty for distracting the girl. “Mara, are you okay,” Jane asked, as she extended a hand out to help the girl.

“Yeah I’m fine, just a little wet you jerk,” Mara retorted. With help from Jane, the girl got up and proceeded to check out the damage done. The two were met with a surprise as Mara was completely dry.

Their confusion was answered as they noticed a small stream of liquid returning towards the puddle. Jane previously assumed the liquid was normal water, but now that she wasn't distracted she noticed the liquid was not transparent but a neon blue color. The stream quickly gathered into the puddle, which suddenly started to pulse. Assuming the worst, the girls quickly got into a battle stance, ready to face this new foe.

Suddenly the pool of liquid shot straight up, starting to take on a humanoid form. As the transformation continued the gender of the creature was quickly cleared up as huge breasts and a sizable ass formed on the slender body of the individual. Finally the head formed on top of the blue body, which sported an almost childlike face with long flowing neon blue hair. After letting out a loud yawn, the woman seemed to squint her eyes while scanning the area. Once she spotted the duo a huge smile formed, as she slowly made her way over to the group.

“Oh boy travelers,” the liquid woman exclaimed. “My names Lily, what are your names?”

“My name is Jane and this is Mara,” Jane stated. The two girls remained in battle stances as they were still a little cautious of this strange girl. “If you don't mind me asking, what are you?”

“I’m a slime girl silly,” Lily replied. She proceeded to jiggle her whole body as if to validate her statement. “Now what are two cute girls such as yourselves doing in these woods?”

“We are looking for a missing woman,” Mara replied, starting to lower her staff. “Oh, we are also looking for an entrance to the lipomancer’s lair.”

“You are the only people I have seen I'm afraid,” Lily replied with a pout. “But if you are willing to follow me I can get you guys to that lair thingy.”

Mara and Jane exchanged skeptical glances at each other. While Lily seemed nice enough so far, she still was a monster girl. Monster’s can be nice sometimes but can easily be very conniving. Seeing no risk in giving the slime girl a shot, they agreed to follow her lowering their drawn weapons.

An ecstatic expression overtook the girl as she hopped up and down, shaking her whole body in the process. “Oh boy my master will be so proud of me, gathering up to girls for him,” Lily exclaimed.

“What,” Jane barked, rapidly drawing her daggers back out at the girl.

A shocked expression appeared on Lily’s face, her mouth was wide open. “I can’t believe I just said that out loud,” Lily solemnly stated. “I’m so stupid,” she exclaimed as she began to sob. The slime girl collapsed on the ground, tears flooding from her eyes. The sight was strange as her tears were made of the same liquid as her body, causing her to begin to shrink in size. The flying liquid seemed to slowly trickle back to the sobbing girl, to continue the cycle. “Now the master is gonna kill be for sure. I’m so stupid, stupid, stupid.”

“Your master’s not gonna get the chance after I’m done with you,” Jane threatened. This only made the slime girl weep even harder. This earned a quick bop on Jane’s head from Mara, who gave a ‘you're not helping glare’ to the rogue.
Mara began making her way over to the remains of the Lily’s body. “Hey, it’s okay. We are not gonna hurt you,” Mara softly said.

Mara’s words seemed to ease the slime girl as the tears slowed down, giving the girl’s body a chance to mostly reform. “You, mean it?” Lily murmured.

“Of course, just give us some information and we will leave you alone,” Mara affirmed.

Suddenly the slime girl gave the elf a surprisingly strong bear hug, smothering the elf’s head into her chest. “Oh thank you, thank you, thank you. You won’t regret it,” Lily happily exclaimed.

Jane began to chuckle as Mara attempted to free herself from being smothered by Lily’s breast, eventually escaping the girl’s strong grasp. “Why don't you tell us about this master of yours, the one you were gonna take us to,” Jane inquired.

“Oh him,” Lily stated bitterly. “The self pronounced slime king. I thought he be nice to me as I he created me, but I couldn't have been more wrong. All he would ever do was yell at me and boss me around. He told me if I didn't find people to bring to him, he would absorb me.” The slime girl began to shutter at the thought.

“Who is the slime king?” Jane questioned. “Is he a servant of the lipomancer or something? What does he want with all these people?”

The slime girl seemed overwhelmed from the barrage of questions, shaking her head in pain. “I’m sorry I don't know, I was only made a week ago,” Lily shyly replied. “I wasn't even conscience for half of that time, those first three days are a bit fuzzy.”

“Wow you're really young then,” Mara exclaimed, examining the blue girl. “Your species must age really quickly, for you to be this developed.”

“Aww, you say the nicest things miss,” Lily bashfully replied.

“So what can you tell us then Lily?” Jane asked.

“Not much I’m afraid. I’ve mostly been here, waiting to find some travelers to save myself,” Lily sadly replied. “I can warn you that there are some scary creatures that roam these woods at night though, so you should be careful where you sleep. Also you should avoid running into the slime king, he isn't a friendly guy. I’m sorry I don't know more, that is enough for you to not hurt me right?”

“Of course not, we promised didn't we,” replied Mara, with a cheery smile. “Just don’t tell your master you saw us okay?”

Jane proceeded to return back to their original path, beckoning Mara to follow. “Come on Mara, I think that is all were gonna get from the girl. We should keep going if we wanna make some distance before nightfall,” Jane called back. “See ya around slime girl.”

“Yeah your right,” Mara admitted, though she did not want to leave this girl so soon. “Thanks for your assistance Lily.” As the elf attempted to catch up the rogue a blue arm grabbed her hand, holding her in place. As Mara turned she spotted Lily holding onto her with giant puppy dog eyes resting on her face. “What is up Lily?”

“I was wondering if I could go with you guys,” Lily timidly asked. “The slime king is really mean to me and I don't wanna work for him, but if I'm alone he might try to kill me. You guys seem like your tough so you could protect me from him.” The slime girl proceeded to go down on her knees, starting to get into a begging position. “I can be really helpful as well I'm flexible, I don't need much food and I’m pretty strong. So can I come with you guys?”

11132111111111111.content:
“Can you excuse us for a moment,” Jane asked, dragging Mara away from the slime girl. When they were out of earshot range of the girl, Jane began to show her annoyance. “She tries to capture us, and then expects us to trust her enough to travel with us? She clearly is not the sharpest tool in the shed.”

“Hey don't say that, that’s not fair,” Mara argued. The mage took a quick glance at the monster girl, making sure she didn't hear their discussion. Lily seemed to be in her own world, gleefully observing a nearby butterfly. “She may seem developed, but she is still fairly young for her species.”

“Oh come Mara, don’t tell me you bought all that,” Jane jeered. “She just was making excuses once she realized she messed up. Probably wants to come with us, just to slit our throats in our sleep.”

“I think you're being a bit dramatic. She is harmless, naive but harmless,” Mara rebutted. Her normally calm and pleasant demeanor slowly shifted to visible frustration, though she was trying her best to hide it.

“You are still forgetting that this isn't a normal girl, it’s a monster,” Jane retorted. Jane’s statement seemed to hit a nerve, as the previously irritated elf was now steaming. The change in her friend’s attitude continued to be lost on the rogue, who was too distracted with the conversation. “Monsters are know for backstabbing wanderers. Come on Mara you know this.”

“I don’t care about her background, she deserves a chance just like everyone else,” Mara yelled. Jane had apparently completely set the fire completely ablaze, as Mara looked furious. If looks could kill, daggers would be flying from her eyes, not that she would need them with her fists tightly clenched up.

With the dramatic change in tone, Jane finally took a moment to observe her companion, and what she saw was concerning. She was very familiar with angry people, most of them were the individuals chasing after her to get back the rogue’s prizes of the night. However seeing the normally kind hearted elf get this worked up so quickly unsettled the rogue, as generally this had to be caused by something. It would seem that not everything was sunshine and rainbows like Mara’s stories suggested, as the girl looked to carry some baggage from her past. Jane hoped in the future the mage would share that baggage with her, but for now decided to concede their argument, not wanting to upset the girl further.

“Yeah, I guess your right,” Jane sighed. The red head nervously scratched the back of her neck, trying to come up with the right words to say next. “What do you suggest we do?”

Mara seemed to relax at the sound of Jane’s surrender. This new calm feeling was quickly replaced with a one of awkwardness, as she now realized how worked up she had gotten. “She could come with us or at least stay with Astra,” Mara sheepishly replied. “We can ask her which she prefers.”
“All right sounds like a plan, lets go tell our anxious guest,” Jane stated. She began to walk back towards Lily, when a she felt a small tug on her hand. Jane turned to find Mara holding her hand, with an embarrassed look on her face.

“I’m sorry for yelling before,” Mara blurted, her head starting to lower. “I just —” She tried to continue her thought but the words seemed to be lost on her. A sudden force on her shoulder knocked her out of her daze, as she raised her head back up to meet eyes with a concerned rogue.

“Mara listen, I know something is bothering you,” Jane softly stated. “You are not that good at hiding it and you shouldn't hide it from me, I can help.” A look of guilt seemed to manifest on Mara’s face. “But, I know it can be difficult to share these emotions, so I don't expect you to just blurt out everything. I just want you to know, when your ready I’ll be here for you. Okay?”

A smile started to etch its way onto the mage’s face, as she slowly hugged her friend. “Yeah I will,” Mara answered. “Thank you, for being so understanding.”

With the decision made, the two companions made their way back over the awaiting slime girl. Lily must have been bored waiting, as she now was morphing her body into various shapes. When she heard approaching footsteps, she quickly reformed into her normal form and started walking up the girls with hopeful eyes.

“All right Lily, here is the deal,” Jane declared. “You can come with us where we would expect you to pull your own weight and contribute to the team. It will be a dangerous, hard, and long adventure. Alternatively, you can go to our friend Astra’s house here in the woods. She will take care of you, and when she leaves you can go with her to find a new home. The choice is up to you.”

The slime girl pondered her options, before finally coming to a decision. “I would rather go with you two then some stranger,” Lily admitted. “So I guess count me in on your adventure.”

“Then welcome aboard,” Mara exclaimed. The elf proceeded to give a hug to their new companion, which quickly turned into her slowly sinking into the slime creature. The process only quickened when a confused Lily hugged the girl back, accidentally pushing Mara further inside her body. The slime girl was so excited about being part of the group, she didn't even notice when Mara started struggling to pull herself out.

Jane could only chuckle at Mara’s sad attempts to free herself, before deciding to help the elf before she was completely submerged. Jane tried to pull the girl out but was having no such luck, causing her to tug harder. Unfortunately when the rogue gave an especially strong tug Lily had realized the mage was stuck inside her and released her, causing the elf to go flying straight into a nearby tree. After a loud thunk, the poor elf landed on the ground, a lot more disoriented from her unintended flight.

“You guys are so silly,” Lily chuckled. The slime girl began to head over to where Mara landed before a nearby bunny distracted her. “Oh, it's so cute. Lemme give it a hug.” The girl proceeded to chase the rabbit, completely forgetting about the elf.

The rogue proceeded to head over to her dazed friend, still laughing at the whole ordeal. “You are right, she is totally harmless,” Jane joked, receiving a groan as a response from Mara. Jane then helped Mara stand, checking for any injuries. Besides a small headache, the mage was perfectly fine. After giving the elf a couple minutes to recover her senses, the three set off.

They continued following the instructions given to them by Astra, though at a slower pace due to Lily’s fascination with seemingly everything. Jane was beginning to get frustrated from their slow pace and was about to say something to the slime girl, but was interrupted by a soft bop from Mara. “Play nice,” Mara warned. Thankfully Lily seemed to notice Jane’s growing anger, picking up her pace.

After a some walking the group stumbled across a small lake. Deciding not to waste the good fortune, Jane and Mara proceeded to fill up on water. Lily on the other hand paused at the sight of the lake. Something about this area was familiar to her, but she couldn't quite place it. After several scans of the area, the gears started turning in her head.

“Guys we need to leave,” Lily exclaimed in a panicked voice. The other girls quickly stopped what they were doing, turning back to their companion.

“Why, what’s wrong?” Mara asked.

“The slime king’s domain is just past this lake,” Lily explained, pointing to the far side of the lake. “I remember coming here to fill up on fluids.”

“Well, that's just typical,” Jane complained. “That is exactly the direction of where our friend’s sister supposedly went.”

“She might have gotten captured by him,” Mara stated. “We should probably head that direction and check.”

“What no, you two said you would keep me safe from the slime king,” Lily cried out in fear. “He is very strong and dangerous, especially in his domain. We shouldn't go anywhere near it. Besides I haven't even seen anyone head that way. Your friend must have gone around the area.”
