112.content:
Jane opened her eyes to the beams of the morning sun shining through the window and onto her bed. After a rather uneventful night's sleep, she felt refreshed and ready to set out. She quickly dressed herself in her leather pants and tunic, the gear was not very protective in a fight, but what it lacked in defense, it made up for in maneuverability, just what a thief like Jane needed.

Yet as she was getting dressed, Jane suddenly felt a bit unsure about the journey that lay ahead. That sleazy informant had told her next to nothing, and so she really had no real idea of what this town was like. Thus she could either continue on with her journey, quite unprepared for what lay ahead, or she could ask the locals of this frigid barony for information on Little Silverhorne and possibly the secrets that it contained...
112.title: Second Thoughts

choices: Enter the shop, see what the owner knows...
Hit up another tavern and threaten someone with pointy instruments!
Stand in the street for way too long and get your purse of coins snatched.
1121.content:
Jane threw on a thick fur robe and headed out of her room and down the stairs into the tavern proper. As she passed through, she scanned the room for sign of her informant from last night, but didn't see him. She wasn't that disappointed though, she figured he'd be gone by now, but if she could have found him, she might have been able to grill him for more knowledge. She made her way out the door, not wanting to draw any attention from a bar room filled with men.

As she stepped out the door and onto the city's cobblestone streets, she felt a rush of excitement tingle down her spine when the chill of the cold, winter air hit her face. It wasn't snowing at the moment, but it had recently, and it was a rare moment for this town to not be covered in the stuff. Yet despite the harsh climate, Greatmanor was one of the largest cities Jane had ever seen, and the bigger the population, the better a chance that somebody would know something about the tale of the Lipomancer...

She looked up and down the street, trying to decide where she should start. She could always try to get somebody to talk, but if a person knew information about a hoard of immense wealth, chances were that they wouldn't be giving up such information so easily. In any other town, the vicious rogue could likely use intimidation to get what she wanted, but that wouldn't work too well here. She began to walk down the road as she thought about what she would do. Most of the population of Greatmanor was either made up of gruff, strong, burly men and women with long blond hair, or equally large and intimidating lupines, the indigenous white furred animal people who would likely tear your throat out if you even looked at them funny. Yes, trying to get information would be difficult... But as difficult as going into a town blind? For all she knew, it could be a trap.

She stopped in her tracks as a little shop to her left caught her eye. The sign read "Marcus's Exotic Imports", nothing too out of the ordinary, but it would be a good place to start. If anybody was likely to trade with the town of Silverhorne, it'd likely be this guy.
1121.title: Where to Begin?

choices: "....A man not too long ago brought in this small statue..."
"....He was here actually, just yesterday! Should still be in town!"
11211.content:
Jane opened the wooden door to the shop a small brass bell tinkling as she stepped in to find a veritable labyrinth of junk, or "antiques" and "curios" as some would call it. She pulled back her furred hood and attempted to navigate her way through the store, hoping to find the owner somewhere around here. The place wasn't that big, really, it was just all the crap lying about which made it difficult to maneuver through. Over there were piles of plates: tin, wooden and chipped and fractured china, over here stacks of old and musty books, most made illegible by grime and age. After passing the shelf full of scrolls and the barrel stuffed with broken farming implements for the third time, the brunette finally admitted to herself that she was lost.

She stood still for a moment, trying to get a sense of her location, listening to the silence...

And then she heard something: Footsteps against the stone floor! She slowly followed her keen ears as they led her past towers of trash and piles of worthless minutiae until she finally found an aged wolf sitting at a wooden counter. His fur looked gray and somewhat mangy, his muzzle scared by old wounds, the most prominent of which led up to his left eye which was covered by a black, worn eye patch. The rest of his wardrobe was mundane in comparison: He wore a dusty looking black vest over a somewhat frilly, yet dirt-stained white shirt, and black pants with gold embroidery, as well as several stitch marks and mismatched patches covering tears and holes. It seemed to Jane that the store's owner was about as old and battered as half of his wares on display were.

The wolf seemed almost surprised to see a customer in his shop, eyes... or eye rather, widening as he held his head in a grimy paw and smiled, "Why hello there... young lady... hehe, what might you be buying today, hmmmm?"

"I never said I was looking to buy anything..." She said sternly, "I assume you're the owner then? Marcus?"

His smile widened as he nodded quite vigorously, "Yes, that is me! And if you are not here to buy, then..." He paused slightly, glancing at certain parts of Jane's body, "Then, hehe, what might a woman such as yourself being doing in my fine business...?"

The rogue groaned, then threw a small purse of cold onto the counter, sending it skidding towards the lecherous old creature, "You can have those if you shut your gods damned mouth you stinking old mutt. Now, I need to know if you have anything in this junk pit relevant to my interests..."

"Alright, alright! No need to get angry! Can't blame me you know!" He said as his pulled open the sack of coin and thumbed around with the pieces within, "Oooh... well, uhhh, what might your interests be lass?"

"I need to know if you have any information on... or better yet, any artifacts relating to the Sitharli..."

Marcus picked up one of the gold coins and bit into it, looking closely at its surface as he said, "The who....? Oh! That... urrhhm... what was it, Lipomancer fellow?! Well, you see... hehe...."
11211.title: Some Valuable Information

choices: Head off after this man directly.
Ask around in town some more.
112111.content:
"...A man, not too long ago, brought in this small statue."

Marcus reached down behind the counter, withdrawing the item in question. "Exquisite work... If you disregard the subject matter."

Jane found that hard to do. The miniature sculpture was of the Sitharli, or so Jane assumed. Carved from white marble, it matched the mysterious descriptions given to him in myth and legend, though his face remained cloaked in shadow. The little Lipomancer held a plump female human in his grasp from behind, one hand placed on her burgeoning belly and one hand on a hefty looking stone breast. What appeared to be a long, tentacle-like tongue protruded from the figure's hood, snaking into the woman's mouth. Jane wasn't sure, but the expression on his victim seemed to be more of ecstasy than agony.

A shiver went down Jane's spine. "Revolting."

Marcus nodded. "Mm. Looks like some kind of votive idol to me. Y'know some folks, secretly, worship this guy. Form cults dedicated to him, clandestine rituals, all that stuff. Personally, that seems like a bit of inflation... But maybe, there's a point where a man can gets so powerful that he might as well be called a god."

The rogue just rolled her eyes. "Some idiots will worship anything. I once had to infiltrate a cult that worshiped a potato. Not even a potato that looked like anything, just a potato. I'm not impressed." Marcus shrugged. "Believe what you want. I, personally, only believe in one thing..." The aged lupine rubbed a piece of gold meaningfully in his hand. "Man that sold this to me was some kind of wandering sellsword. Said he'd gotten it from the Lipomancer's lair, that he didn't want to look at it anymore. Apparently brought up bad memories for him. He left town this morning, heading south. You can probably catch him, if you hurry. As for the statue... This'll be more than enough to pay for the nasty little thing, and that juicy bit of information." Marcus chuckled as he brought the bag down behind his counter. "Anything else, lassie?"
112111.title: But Is It Art?

choices: Stay in the room, then set out immediately when morning comes.
Go back to Marcus, that mangy mutt has some explaining to do.
1121112.content:
Jane held the statue in her hand… not liking the way it felt in the slightest. She was beginning to regret her purchase, not only due to the bizarre and disgusting subject of the sculpture itself, but also because it felt that, despite the hooded statue’s lack of eyes, that the tiny Lipomancer was watching her intently.

“What’s with this guy and fat women anyways…?” She asked nobody in particular before stuffing the disturbing idol into her pack with a grimace: She didn’t really want it, but after paying that much gold for so little information she wanted SOME form of compensation.

“Mmm…? What was that you said…?” Marcus asked, tilting his head to one side quizzically while once more leaning against his paw.

“Nothing at all Wolf, I won’t be needing anything else, thank you…” She said, bowing slightly before swiftly leaving the shop.

She began to make her way back through town, hoping to find at least another lead before she set out. It had begun to snow now as she made her way through a twisting, yet deserted alleyway, and she still could not shake her sense of discomfort. Finally she stopped, pulling the marble statue from her pack before tossing it into a snow drift.

“There… that feels a bit better…”

She continued on her way, but did not get far before she felt a strong, firm grip on her shoulder, stopping her dead in her tracks. Was she that distracted that her keen senses hadn’t warned her of somebody else in the alley…?

“Excuse me miss…” A deep, but calm voice said from behind her before the hand on her shoulder withdrew itself.

Jane turned around, looking up slightly to see a rather large, black furred bull man standing before her. He wore a dark green robe, but this did little to hide how spectacularly obese the beast man looked. Yet he had a kind expression on his face as he looked at her, “I believe that you dropped this…” He said before presenting her with the statue.

The rogue was quite shocked, she was almost certain that nobody had seen her disposing of it, yet here it was again, “I… I don’t know what you mean… that… that horrid thing doesn’t belong to me!”

The bull merely smiled before gently, but firmly placing the statue in Jane’s hands and cupping them forcefully around it, “You should be more careful with these things…” He chuckled before moving past her to walk out the mouth of the alley.
Jane’s eyes were wide with shock as she looked at the statue she once more held in her trembling hands, and then to the street that the bull man had disappeared to. She considered once again trying to throw the thing away, but she knew that somehow it would find its way back to her. She just shoved it into her bag once more and turned right at the street ahead, the opposite direction that the bull had left through.

She walked down the street, trying to think of other ways to be rid of the creepy object. Perhaps she should drop it down a well? Or sell it to some other vendor… As she was thinking to herself, she once more felt as though she were being observed, though not by the statue this time. She stopped and looked across the street as she noticed a rather mangy looking young wolf man staring at her, but as she tried to catch any more details about him a horse-drawn carriage interrupted her line of sight. When it had passed, the lupine was nowhere to be seen.

The pervasive sensation of being spied upon, however, remained.

She quickened her pace down the busy street, slowing only when she had neared a blacksmith’s open air shop. She looked around, being certain that nobody she could see was looking before she snatched one of the small, but sturdy hammers from a table before moving on.

She turned into the next alleyway, following its passage until she found almost exactly what she needed: A nice, secluded place to smash the heinous idol into oblivion. Sure, it was a crude solution, but it seemed to Jane to be the simplest and most effective. She soon came to a quiet hidden little courtyard garden with a lone tree stump in the middle. There were windows looking out from the posh looking residences onto the courtyard, but Jane made sure that nobody was looking before she laid the statue down upon the stump.

Grinning, the rogue pulled out the hammer, raising it high above her head before bringing it straight down through the statue. The thing seemed to break all too easily, but Jane ignored this oddity, glad to be rid of the accursed object as she kept striking it, pulverizing the idol into dust.

She panted a bit from exertion as she let the small hammer slip free of her grip to the cobblestone path of the garden, giggling a tiny bit out of ecstasy, “I knew I’d be rid of that stupid thing soon enough!”

She paused for a moment, goosebumps sprouting across her fair skin.

She must have been too excited to have felt it before, but her keen instincts were telling her that she was being watched once more. No, not just watched, examined. As a rather attractive woman, Jane had felt the gaze of plenty men over her slender, exquisite body… but this felt even more intense than that. She looked about herself, checking each branching alley, each shady window until she caught sight of a gaunt, reptilian face staring out at her from a second story flat, just moments before it retreated into the darkness.

Jane made her way out of the courtyard as soon as she could.



The feeling of being observed wherever she went on the city streets continued to follow her, but the rogue kept looking for hints and leads about Little Silverhorne or the Lipomancer. She was more than a little put off by what was happening so far in her search, especially by the statue that still seemed to haunt her mind even after its destruction, but her greed for treasure and wealth kept her going.

She had checked in various pubs, taverns, and even some libraries for information on the town, but all she could gather about the Lipomancer was that he hoarded more riches than could be imagined, and all she found out about Little Silverhorne was that it was simply a rather small, normal farming community.

Finally, as the sun began to set on the cold, large city of Greatmanor, Jane decided that it was best if she got some rest at the inn and set out on her journey the next day. She passed quickly through the bar, making her way past the mob of patrons who were too busy singing to notice her before she had reached the stairs. She entered her cozy little room, flung off her cloak, and collapsed upon her soft, comfy bed.

She had to try her hardest not to scream when she saw the marble statue waiting for her on top of the dresser.
Yet she quickly noticed that it wasn’t the same one as before. The figure that the Sitharli held in his clutches was different, most noticeably fully clothed and thin. Yet he held her arms firmly in his grasp, his tongue still snaking out from beneath his shadowy hood, but instead of slithering down his victim’s throat it ran down her exposed cleavage, slipping between her ample breasts. The victim’s eyes were squeezed shut, a grimace of disgust and terror upon her face.

And to her horror, Jane recognized the face, the clothes. They belonged to her, sculpted perfectly in tiny marble form was a tiny marble Jane held helplessly in the clutches of a tiny marble Lipomancer.

She glanced at the door. She should lock it, stay inside until the sun rose and it was safer.

But then she thought about who might have done this. It was quite obvious that it was either a cult, a lone worshipper, or… she shuddered to think, the Lipomancer himself.

Whatever was the case, somebody must have told them that she was searching for the Sitharli, somebody had talked.
And Jane was almost certain who it was.
1121112.title: A Town Full of Eyes

choices: They bring her to their underground hideout.
She is taken to the town square...
11211122.content:
Jane grasped the statue in her grip, turning it the pained face of her little stone doppelganger was hidden from view before marching over to her inn room’s window and opening it. She stuck her head out the window to look about, noticing that the snow was coming down much more heavily as night fell before pulling herself back inside. Nobody was below her window, so she simply tossed the terrible sculpture of her and the Sitharli out the window, sighing as she heard the satisfying crack of the statue’s destruction.

She then threw her cloak back over her shoulders, making sure that the fur garment was wrapped tightly about her skimpy leather armor before she made her way out the inn and towards Marcus’s shop. When she arrived, she noticed that no lights were lit inside and that the door was ajar, slamming back and forth from the frigid northern winds. She pulled the door fully open, stepping inside the cramped little shop.

The place was quiet, and even with her trained hearing, the human rogue couldn’t hear Marcus at all this time. Nevertheless she was determined to find him in all the junk. In her hurry though she almost stumbled over what she first thought was the wolf’s corpse, but upon closer examination was actually that of the much younger wolf she had seen watching her earlier. She looked over his body, sprawled in a pool of blood, clutching a dagger and sporting sword wounds of his own. She stepped around the corpse and soon arrived at the counter.

She didn’t find Marcus however… instead she found something much worse.

It was another statue like the others, hewn from marble and depicting the Lipomancer clutching at a woman. Once more, the female depicted was Jane, but this time the rogue looked nothing like her current state… She was now completely naked… but that wasn’t what made the rogue sick to her stomach… it was the fact that she was now easily the largest part of the sculpture. She was fat, obese, whale-like, even more rotund than the woman in the statue Marcus had first sown her. The Jane depicted in the marble looked as the she could barely stand, her entire body burdened by rolls and rolls of chiseled blubber. A tiny, stone tear rolled down her marble twin’s plump cheek as the Sitharli held her from behind, one gnarled hand greedily clutching her sagging, bloated breast as the other sank into one of her disgustingly large buttocks. His tongue was, like the first statue, entrenched deep within his victim’s mouth, though unlike the other woman it was also wrapped about Jane’s flabby neck and chins in a gesture of dominance.

Jane gagged in pure revulsion, covering her gaping mouth with a gloved hand as she backed away from the obscene depiction of her. She shrieked in shock as she bumped right into something behind her, but her first guess at it being one of the various stacks of junk was soon proven wrong as a pair of arms ensnared her from behind.

“Let go of me! What are you doing?!” The rogue shouted as she kicked and struggled against her attacker. Usually she wouldn’t react so excitedly to a situation like this, but seeing an even more grotesque idol of her had put her nerves on their very edge, “Get off!”

“Beautiful… isn’t it…?” The man holding her calmly whispered into her ear, his voice serpentine, “My master willed me to make it… and the one you so cruelly shattered on your way here… Oh, but it is only a preview my dear… yesss… a preview of things to come…”

“What the hell are you talking about you sick freak! You let go of me, right now!” Her mind was still reeling with terror and shock as she kicked and grunted.

“The Sitharli my dear… he has seen you through my work… he has great plans for you…” She felt the man’s warm, long, wet tongue slide over her bare shoulder and under her chin, mirroring the statue on the shop counter, “Biiiig plans…”

Jane was about to protest even more, but a wolf in dark robes walked in front of her now, pressing a cloth into her mouth before tying it about her head to silence her. Jane could only grunt then as a burlap sack was brought over her head, her arms were bound tight in rope, and she felt herself thrown into the grasp of a stronger man before being lifted onto his shoulder and carried out of the shop.
11211122.title: Fulfilling a Prophecy… and Filling Out to Do So

choices: A massive crowd of people standing before a stage.
A cramped, dirty cell.
112111221.content:
Jane tried to scream for help, but all she could manage was a frustrated, muffled groan. Still, the man carrying her reacted, tightening his grip on her back and thigh respectively. She heard the bell at the shop door ring before feeling the cold chill of night passing over her, much of her cloak now draped over her head to leave her shapely legs exposed to the falling snow. She wondered why there was nobody to help her, hoping that the streets were merely abandoned, denying the possibility that perhaps whoever saw her was too afraid to assist. Still, she continued to struggle, kept trying to scream, even if it was truly futile.

“This is probably another stupid cult…” She thought to herself while wriggling in her abductor’s grasp. Jane had the dubious pleasure of encountering many cults and deranged secret societies over the years. Usually to Khorrus, or some other rage or death god, but occasionally there were even loonier ones who fervently worshipped something more idiotic, like the one that bowed to a bottle of elk phlegm.

“Over here…” She heard a hoarse voice whisper before once more she felt herself being carried through a doorway, leaving the frigid outside world behind, possibly for the last time.

They weren’t just in another building now however, the damp air giving rise to her suspicions, the horrible smell confirming them. They were now moving through the sewers, and from the many turns the group of kidnappers were making, it was a fairly large one at that. Jane tried to remember the lefts from the rights, but in the end there were far too many for her to keep track of, especially in such a panicked state. The constant threats from the serpentine sculptor didn’t help all that much, and Jane found herself dismayed to realize that they’d be less ominous were they simply planning to murder her.

“Your body is perfect…” He whispered as he kept pace behind the brute holding her, right by her ear, “Perfect clay to sculpt into perfect as we add more and more…”

They turned left.

“It is a simple stone block right now, but I can see, oh yes. There is voluptuous behemoth, waiting to be brought out…”
They turned right.

She felt his hand, scales clearly felt upon its palm as they rubbed roughly along her cheek, “You will be so beautiful, so massive… perfect for his desires!”

Her heart raced.

Wait! They turned… left? No! Right?! Did they turn at all…?

Her breathing quickened, growing out of control far too easily.

“Enjoy your small frame now my dear, for we draw close, and this is the last chance you will ever have to remember it.”
She squeezed her eyes shut, shivering as she heard the large figure carrying her let out a deep chuckle. She still tried to maintain her composure, knowing that even if she couldn’t remember the path they took that there was always another way out of these places, right?

Soon though, they passed through another doorway, Jane hearing it creak loudly on rusty hinges as it was opened, and then another, and another. There were more people here, she could hear them muttering amongst themselves before she was taken through yet another door and thrown from the man’s shoulder, roughly landing on a cold, stone floor.
Then the burlap sack is suddenly pulled from her head, and as her vision adjusts to the dim lighting of whatever dungeon they’ve brought her to she begins to make out…
112111221.title: A Frightening Journey

choices: Try to calm down… Maybe there’s another way?
There’s no time to gather her wits… This is the only shot she has.
1121112211.content:
There must have been dozens of people at least, all crammed in the rather large, stone vault she now found herself in. It was still very dark, only a few torches high up on the walls to dimly light the place, but from what she could see, many of the gathered men and women looked like ordinary citizens, perhaps even ones she had seen, quite a few of them appearing overweight or larger. Some, however, chose to wear dark robes over themselves, the cowls hanging over their faces to obscure them from view.

If there was any doubt before, now it was long gone: She was the prisoner of a cult.

Jane chewed at the cloth wrapped about her mouth nervously as they walked her out onto the stage. The crowd seemed calm and quiet, so she looked towards her right, examining the stage itself. It seemed rather large, though a stone podium at the front of it was the only thing standing upon it besides her and her abductors. It became obvious though that this was more than just some sort of theater or common hall when she looked towards the ceiling. Emerging from the wall was a statue of the Sitharli, and though it was only of his upper body, it was incredibly large, looming over the stage, its robed arms almost spanning the room as its giant hands seemed to be reaching towards the ground.

What concerned her most right now though were two long chains hanging limp from the statue’s arms, the manacles at the end swaying lightly back and forth. Jane was held in the middle of them by the brutish man who had carried her here, a shirtless blonde in ragged pants with a look of blind obedience on his dumb face. As she was held still, another cultist cut the ropes binding her arms, two more bringing the manacles to her before clamping them down securely over wrists. After it was sure she wasn’t going anywhere, the cultists cleared the stage quickly, leaving the still-gagged thief standing there before the gathered crowd.

She didn’t have to wait long though, for as soon at those who had brought her here took their places amongst their brothers, a man larger than most of the others entered the room. The robe he wore was a regal purple, embroidered with gold trim, and he walked with a gait that projected confidence and power, as well as a slight elegance despite his large bulk. The man strode slowly onto the stage as the gathered crowd murmured loudly. Even before he stood before the podium, it was obvious that he was the leader of this bizarre organization.

“Gathered believers, loyal subjects and devotees of the Lipomancer,” He announced in a deep, but familiar bellow, the crowd silencing as he continued, “We have all felt his presence, in some shape or form: whether it be in our bountiful harvests or the weight we carry in his name. We all feel respect and reverence for him, for we know what indulgences we may receive if we obey him, as well as what punishments await should we fail.”

The mob of deranged fanatics muttered in simultaneous agreement, Jane only bit her lip. It was one thing to be kidnapped and put on display in front of these nutjobs like a wild beast, but having to listen to their boring, twisted sermons was already tedious.

“There are some though, who do not understand his blessings: Those who do not respect him, nor see the beauty in his arts,” He said, raising his voice and pointing a robed hand in Jane’s direction, “Like this one… She found herself curious about our master, but instead of seeking to join our family and receiving his gifts, she delved for secrets that were not hers to know. Not as an outsider. People like this, people who refuse to see his majesty, must be shown it… as unfortunate as it is… through force.”

There was now louder, more fervent muttering as the leader pulled back his hood. Jane frowned to recognize him as the black-furred bull from earlier, the one who had made her so uneasy, even though he had only been kind to her. He turned to Jane, smiling gently even as his eyes glared at her with a purposeful focus as he pulled dagger from the folds of his robes.

“They must know his presence and become a part of his plan for all of us, willingly or not, for all must succumb to his blessing, or his curse.”

The crowd cheered now as he held the ceremonial dagger in the air before them, and as he turned and approached Jane slowly, her eyes widened in terror. She wanted to kick him, it should have been possible as her legs were still free, yet as she looked into his calm but determined eyes, she found that she was unwilling to resist, even as he raised the dagger before her. She couldn’t even close her eyes to ready herself as he brought the blade’s edge to the bare flesh of her arm, applying just enough pressure to break the skin and bring a small amount of blood to the surface. She bit at the gag in her mouth, yet was surprised to see the bull pull the blade away.

“They will feel his presence in many ways, through various methods, yet all will feel his burden in the end!” He shouted, the room echoing with his voice and the chants of the others as he held the bloodied dagger towards the ceiling, towards the statue of their vile Lipomancer looming over them.

“Si-Thar-Li!” He boomed, his followers parroting the chant continuously.

“SI-THAR-LI… SI-THAR-LI… SI-THAR-LI… SI-THAR-LI…”

As they chanted, a sickening, green sludge seemed to drip from the dark cowl of the statue to the floor in front of Jane and the bull. It became thicker as Jane looked up at the dark hole where the statue’s face should have been before what appeared to be a gigantic, green, slimy tendril oozed out of the opening. The cult leader removed the gag in Jane’s mouth, but she found that she was too shocked to say anything clever.

“What is that thing...?” She gasped, her voice wavering.

“It is his avatar,” He answered, grinning, “And it is your doom.”

Jane tried to think of a way out of this, there ALWAYS was a way out of situations like this, she had found through experience. Yet it was hard to think as she was slowly overcome by panic. The only thing she could think to do was to struggle against the chains: They and the surrounding structure looked old enough that they might not stand up to even a rogue’s strength.
1121112211.title: Why Couldn't they Worship Something Less... Nasty?

choices: Drink the mystery elixir and see what happens?
The cult obviously wants her alive. Maybe she could sleep it off?
11211122112.content:
Her head reeled as the green, gelatinous monstrosity coalesced before her. Although it had no face let alone any eyes, Jane knew it was aware of her, inspecting the tethered rogue with a tangible wickedness. Thumping like the fervent beat of a war drum, her heart seemed fit to burst from her chest! Panic washed over her like a bucket of ice water; there wasn't any time! Who knew what awful things the disgusting creature had planned! Fear flooded Jane's mind and she again tugged on her manacles. The right buckled some, and it was all the rogue needed.

"Not today, cowboy!" Another heavy pull and the chain burst free from above, crumbling the stone hand which had held it. Taken aback, the bull-man once more held aloft the dagger, ponderously striding toward her, shaking the stage with each heavy footfall. "Come on, come on!" the rogue growled through gritted teeth, clasping her right hand around her left wrist to re-double her efforts in breaking free. Seeing their sacrifice's rebellion, many of the less encumbered cultists now clambered onto the far side of the stage. Jeers of disapproval swept over the audience as the robed fanatics rushed toward her.

"Seize the woman! She must not escape!" The bull-man bellowed as he continued waddling toward her, weighed down by his surging gut. But his cries were too late, the left chain also gave way, causing an unready Jane to fall flat on her backside. She hissed and nursed her battered bum with one of her cuffed hands. Wasting no time, the robed minions had already halved the distance. No time to waste! Leaping to her feet, she turned about face and bolted for the opposite side of the stage, not wanting any of the creepy cultists to lay a hand on her. If anything though, Jane considered herself lucky that most of these crazies were too damned fat to catch her slender form.

A wooden door stood along the wall behind the stage, and Jane made for it, flinging each stride wide. "Don't be locked! Don't be locked!" Skidding to a halt, she fumbled with the heavy iron handle, and to her salvation it was indeed unlocked! Flinging it wide, the rogue rushed through and slammed it shut behind her. Unfortunately she couldn't find a lock on the inside either, so resting would have to wait. Padding footsteps grew closer and clearly the crowd was out for blood. Typical cultists; they never do like it when you botch their rituals. Eyes darted over the newly entered passage and she could see through the low torchlight that the path diverged in three directions. "Why are there always so many tunnels..." Sprinting down the hall, she again slides to a stop just before the split.

"Gah! Why doesn't anyone use signs any more?!" Throwing her hands up in frustration, she heard the door rattle back behind her. Crap! Those loonies had finally caught up! She had to make a decision and fast! No telling what they would do to her now that she tried to flee. And so she decided on the most ancient of decision-making techniques, passed down from the first men. "Eenie, meanie, miney, mo..." Reciting the short poem of her forefathers, Jane settled on the left-hand passage. After quickly wrapping the chains about her arms to avoid any dragging that might alert her pursuers, she sprinted once more into the darkness.

After darting through the winding corridor, she soon felt winded. Surely she was tired, but she hadn't been running that long. Stumbling to catch her breath, she could have sworn the walls were... breathing? In the low light she could still make out the stone walls clearly enough, but they indeed looked to be pulsing. Such a strange notion had little time to grow, for she clapped a chained hand to the wall at her right, bracing herself. Dizziness overwhelmed her and Jane flopped her back against the cold stone, sliding down to rest on the floor.

"W-What in the nine hells?" Swooning, she reached her hand up to her face. At that moment, it caught her eye. Although only a graze, that dagger had indeed drawn blood. "Poison..." It must have been; the dagger was poisoned! If she didn't find an antidote soon, she couldn't say how much longer she'd be able to stay conscious. Thankfully she heard no sign of her unwanted cult following.

Struggling to her feet, she slid along the wall, feeling the stone brush along her bare arms. While the coolness was a relief in her feverish state, it was coarse and abrasive, forcing her to wince through the staggering march. Jane only hoped that the corridor would lead somewhere, and fast...

After another few minutes of slow marching, the rogue silently thanked her luck. Before her stood another wooden door, and from the gap along the floor, it appeared to be dark on the other side. Good. No surprise friends to worry about. Jostling the handle, she smiled weakly as the door creaked open. Jane reached back and removed a torch from its sconce before shambling into her new place of rest. As the light washed across the floor and barely reached the walls, she could see it was some sort of store room.

Sacks full of various dried foods were piled on her left, and in front of her was a stack of crates, each containing different bottled elixirs and potions. Some were marked with a skull and cross-bones, and others seemed to be for your everyday allergies. Odd... One crate, set alongside the poison, was entirely unlabeled. Jane found herself no longer able to stand, and crumpled into a seated heap, back once more against the wall as her manacled hand wearily flopped into the crate. Trembling fingers wrapped about one of the mystery elixir's bottlenecks, and she brought it into the light. The fluid within was a bright pink opaque potion. Something about it seemed to imbue a sense of trust in it, though that could very well have been her poison-addled mind.

Time was running short on her consciousness. She had to make a decision...
11211122112.title: Flight of the Bumbling Free

choices: Jane ignores the food and continues into the dungeon.
"I'm sure one little bite won't do me any harm..."
112111221121.content:
Darkness crept at the corners of her vision, and Jane knew she had run out of time. Sure she had no idea what this mysterious pink potion would do; it could be more poison or it could be an antidote. At any rate, it couldn't be any more dire than her current predicament. Right, she had no choice. Flicking her thumb, Jane popped the cork and brought the glass vial to her lips. The smell of freshly picked berries wafted up to her nose before the tonic touched her tongue. It was unlike anything she had ever tasted! One ought to call it a nectar, for it was far sweeter than any potion she'd ever drank before.

However the effects were far from delayed, cooling the feverish heat that wracked her body down to a more comfortable warmth. Jane's vision had not yet recovered, nor her sense of balance as the room continued its slow turn, but the throbbing in her head was gone. Not gone, but different... She could feel a slow pulsing warmth now, starting at her lips. The tingling sensation was likely a side-effect of the sweet antidote, but Jane couldn't fight the feeling that it seemed to be moving; slowly coursing down her throat. Her hand now leisurely dropped the vial back into its place in the crate before tugging at her leather tunic's collar. This newly arisen warmth worked down toward her stomach, and as the pulsing strengthened, the rogue clasped a hand to her middle with a wince. The pain! Oh, the pain! It was crippling! Perhaps this pink potion was indeed poison, for it hurt now more than her prior plight. Both shackled hands clawed at her tummy as the toned abs contorted beneath her tunic. Or so they should have been.

"W-What's happening?!" Jane's shot wide when her fingers were not met by a sinewy six-pack, but by a slight... softness? Blinking hard, the roguish woman dropped her gaze to her middle, only to see that what had once been a trim waistline now carried a slight insulation to it. The word that had never been used to describe her still remained inappropriate: she was far from being fat, but it looked as though she had possibly gained five pounds! On her slim form, even that much was visible to the naked eye. All of her toned muscles seemed distant now as she looked over her exposed arms and thighs, petrified at the thin layer of fat that now rested between her muscles and fair flesh.

"This is impossible! How in the blazes did this happen?! I haven't eaten anythi--" A scowl tore across her countenance as she shot the silent crate of pink potions a venomous glare. The mystery tonic! That was the only explanation. Whatever this crazy cult had concocted, it seemed to have wrought this horrifying transformation upon her once perfect figure. Her quiet grumble echoed off the walls as Jane staggered to her feet. No matter. She was finally free from the disorienting poison and she could easily shed the extra padding in a week's training. The torchlight had waned some, and after scooping up the light source, Jane scanned the room once more for any supplies to come in handy. Her eyes glanced over the left side of the room and she briefly accounted for the surprising abundance of food.

A low growl rose from the pulsing, warm pit of her stomach. The rogue's eyes darted over the food stores again, lingering a bit longer than she would have admitted. "No no... no." Brows knit with melancholy as one hand rested against her flat, but soft tummy. "We're not hungry. Not yet. Stop your whining." Although the possible meals looked marvelously appetizing, the thought of what other enchantments laid within the rest of the store room frightened her. What if the food was cursed? She could possibly balloon to the size of a whale at one bite! Or worse, Jane considered the possibility that she might lose all control if she were to even taste some of the savory... decadent-- no! "Time to go. Right now!" Her fingers hooked into a claw and she punished her softened middle into silence before the creaking of metal alerted her to her wrists. "Oh yeah... I should probably fix this." Without further delay from poison or plumping pink poultices, Jane reached into her short hair and withdrew a simple bobby pin. Finagling it into one manacle, it quickly fell apart under her expert lock picking. In a flash, the second joined the first in a clash to the floor.

"Onward and upward." The rogue sighed to herself and gripped tight on the door handle, allowing herself one final glimpse back at the delicious assortment of foodstuffs...
112111221121.title: Think Pink

choices: Jane could try and fight the goo...
Or she can make a break for it!
1121112211211.content:
Temptation had been avoided, and Jane shut the wooden door behind her, torch still in hand. However, the hall from which she had fled before entering the store room was gone. "What the..." In its place stood a tall, winding stairwell. Clearly this place was out of the ordinary, and Jane blamed the likeliest of sources: magic. After all, she was meddling in the affairs of a cult, who knows what sort of black magic they practice to protect their secrets. But as a woman with no magical talents of her own, she had no choice but to play by their rules. For now. The sooner she discovered an exit, the better. This place gave her the creeps, the willies, and the heebie-jeebies all at once. Testing the path before her with one light tap of her boot, it was clearly no illusion. Jane offered a frustrated sigh before ascending the winding stairs. What bothered her most was her inability to see far ahead. Anyone could be waiting for her just up and around the corner, but thankfully the stairs did not continue on forever. At the crest of the ascension she finally saw the first open room since her escape from the fanatics. Jane yearned for more pacing room, she did utterly despise such cramped quarters, but she would make do, sitting cross-legged atop her cot. Her eyes shut, and she delved deep into thought. Tactics and grand design flooded her thoughts, until another waft of the slop filled her nose. At once, her collected mind scattered, and she shook her head clear. Jane glared at the malicious meal. Something was terribly wrong about whatever they sought to feed her, but she refused to give them the satisfaction. She would triumph.

Yet even the proudest will hesitates at times, and Jane's resolve shook with the rising growl of her stomach. "My mind is useless on an empty stomach..." she muttered softly, rubbing two fingers to each of her temples. "Perhaps if I tried to seduce one of them--" she pondered before another harrowing gurgle shattered her concentration. Silence followed, save for the dripping of water somewhere out of sight. The dim torchlight cast an orange glow across the minuscule cage, illuminating the increasingly appetizing trough of slop. Perhaps if she ate only enough to quell her pangs. Surely that would help her devise an escape plan. Sitting up, Jane rose to her feet and warily padded toward the cell door.

"Ugh, I can't believe I'm doing this..." she grimaced, crouching beside the trough. She brought it beneath her nose and wafted the meaty scent. It was still warm, and surprisingly enticing. It didn't smell as bad as it looked. In fact, up close... it actually resembled her grandfather's homemade chili. Strikingly so. Pausing, Jane inhaled again. "I knew it! It even smells like his recipe!" Salivating with nostalgia, she turned about and sat down against the barred door, placing the trough atop her lap. One distinct complaint would be a lack of utensils, but Jane quickly recalled her circumstances. Caution quickly fleeting, Jane shrugged and scooped a handful of the slop into her mouth.

Almost immediately, a rush of warm, savory nostalgia swept over her. No longer was the rogue locked away in a dark, cramped cell. Jane closed her eyes and felt the warmth of the setting summer sun on her face. The sound of waves crashing on a nearby shore, and the laughter of her loved ones. Opening her eyes, she was nine years old again. The midsummer festival bustled with activity, preparing for the coming evening's entertainment of firedancing, singing, and storytelling. Rushing along the trodden path, Jane hurried around the side of the beachfront cottage. Her mother, sister, grandparents, and several other families from the village all sat gathered around a long table. Strewn atop it splayed an assortment of meats, cheeses, breads, pies, and all sorts of decadent desserts. More food than she ever remembered seeing at these gatherings.

"Janie! Hurry up, now," her mother called and waved her over. She patted a seat between herself and Janie's grandmother. "We were just giving our thanks for such a wonderful community." Bounding with excitement, Janie hopped into her seat, smoothing out her long skirt. "Now, Janie, we know how much you love your grampapa's cooking. Why don't you have the first bite of his chili?" her mother motioned to the black cauldron of meaty delight. "It's right there in front of you." Janie nodded, and her mother ladled out a big bowl of the chili. Without hesitation, the eager little girl shoveled a big spoonful in her mouth. Just as she remembered... Opening her eyes again, Janie saw the bowl empty, and blinked in confusion. Her granmama patted her head and began piling several slices of various pies onto her plate, while Janie's mother began spooning out more of the chili.

"That's a lot of food, mama." Janie stated, looking up at her mother in concern. Yet her mother only gave her a dismissive wave. "I know how hungry you get, Janie. You'd better eat every bite, now. You don't want to make granmama sad, do you?" her mother cooed, cupping Janie's cheek. The young girl nodded with determination as the sun finally dipped behind the horizon. As the girl began her gastronomical journey, a ring of torches sparked to life around the table, illuminating all of the decadent morsels. Janie ate, and ate, and ate. Though time began to blur and melt away as the food piled into her gullet. Despite her childish size, she never seemed to get full. Her clothing still fit, and she hadn't grown an inch, as though nothing she ate reached her stomach.

A sneeze erupted from somewhere beyond the torches, followed by cursing and the sound of hushed whispers. Janie peered out into the darkness and shook her head. Nothing. After already consuming the full crock of chili, three loaves of bread, an entire wheel of cheese, and two whole pies, she stopped eating. Janie scrunched her eyes shut once more, and flung them open. Memories of summer fell away. Once more the rogue sat in her cramped, dirty cell. In her lap lay an empty trough, licked clean. Though... clean was hardly an appropriate word for the situation. Jane succeeded in emptying the trough, though some of it lay smeared across her front, as though it dribbled from her mouth, down her chest, belly, and into her lap. Wait, belly? Jane blinked, unable to recognize the tinge of softness enveloping her core. Everywhere her body strained against the confines of her leather armor. Not enough to hinder her movement terribly, but extreme ranges of motion could lead to popped seams.

"What... what happened to me? Where did I go? How did I..." Jane gawked. Shaky hands pinched an inch, then moved about to her thighs and pinched a veneer of pudge up along her hips. "What did you do to my body?!" Her breasts too felt fuller, as did the breadth of her behind. Jane climbed to her feet, grunting slightly at the increased effort. Overall, it felt as though she must have gained about twenty pounds. But how...

A hissing laugh erupted from beyond her cell. Snapping her eyes up, Jane realized that torches now encircled her small cage, much like they had the table in her vision. From beyond the ring of light, emerged a cloaked figure. Arms folded into the opposite sleeves hid any physical marker, but the hissing laugh confirmed that this was likely the sculptor from the shop. His hooded head sized her up and down with an approving nod.

"What do you want with me, freak," she spat at the ground, turning to face him directly.

"Oh you are performing so wonderfully, my dear. In such short time your frame has begun to ripen beautifully," he hissed, gesturing toward her soft middle, which, now that she stood, appeared to have borne the brunt of the cursed flab. "Do you submit?"

Jane leaned forward, and the reptilian man mirrored her, his scaly face now visible up close. "Never," she whispered, and seized him by the collar, pulling him into the prison bars. His hood fell back, revealing his face to the light. Jane successfully pinned him to the cell door before three other hooded figures rushed them, prying her arms away. She growled and fought, but quickly released the man and retreated to the back of her cell, curling up on the cot.

"Ha! You have spirit! I am certain the master will enjoy breaking your will," the cultist hissed, adjusting his robes and once again donning his hood. Without another word, the lot of them snuffed out the torches and exited the room. However, before he shut the larger room's door behind him, the lead cultist glared at her from the hallway beyond. "I look forward to seeing the results of your next feeding, insolent sow." With a creak and a slam, the room fell to silence, all except that perpetual, slow drip.

Jane scowled at the door, still curled atop the cot. She loosened her stiff posture and opened her curled fingers, revealing one of the lizardman's ornamental earrings. She spread a sly grin before bending it into a proper lockpick. "Time to go to work."
11211122121.title: Food for Thought

choices: Jane visits a local healer/priest/mage in search of a cure.
Jane sets out to hunt down Nasha and this 'Sitharli'.
112111222.content:
Jane was thrown roughly to the ground and the burlap sack was ripped from her head. Disoriented, for a moment she could see nothing but an uneven string of stars glowing orange in the darkness. She blinked. No, not stars -- torches. She was in the town square, kneeling uncomfortable on the cobbles, and surrounded by at least a dozen people dressed in all-concealing gray robes. In front of her, standing on the raised platform where -- where executions would take place, she realized with a cold feeling in the pit of her stomach -- stood an imposing hooded figure draped in black vestments.

"Bring her forward," hissed the figure. Two of the gray-robes stepped forward and seized Jane by the upper arms, heaving her onto the platform. She landed heavily on her front.

That was just unnecessary, she thought in irritation. Then she was being hauled to her feet by the figure in black. Jane saw that it was a woman -- a rather chubby woman. Sheer, midnight-black silk clung to every plump curve. The dress must have cost a fortune.

Jane felt her gag being loosened, and drew in air to scream. She exhaled it again silently when she felt the sharp tips of a pair of daggers against her throat. "Damn. Can't you give a girl a little space?"

"Same old Jane," sang a sickly-sweet voice. Jane recognized that incongruous little-girl timbre, and knew what she'd see even as the figure drew back her hood.

"Nasha," she growled. The woman giggled. Jane remembered her; they'd worked together for several weeks a couple of years ago. Thief and necromancer, plundering the tombs of the dead for antiquities for a certain rich old weirdo. It had just been another job for Jane, but Nasha -- the pale, skinny blonde was obsessed with death. She was always fondling the skulls and climbing into the sarcophagi. Jane shuddered at the memory. She'd been happy to see the end of her employment.

Doubly happy, she realized with a groan, because it had ended with her walking off with Nasha's pay as well as her own. Not the sort of thing you wanted to remember about someone who had you tied up and surrounded.

"Oh, you remember me?" Nasha singsonged. "I certainly remember you; and trust me, what's about to happen couldn't happen to a more deserving person."

Jane would have happily grovelled for her life if she thought it would have done any good -- in her line of work, they didn't much care for silly notions like putting honor over survival -- but she didn't think it would do any good, so she didn't. Instead she spat defiantly. Thanks to the wind, most of it ended up back on her. Great.

Nasha laughed.

"Before I die," Jane said, licking her lips, "before I die, answer me one thing. I don't care who's paying you or why they're doing it. I just want to know how you managed to get so gods-damned fat."

Nasha laughed again, and patted her round stomach. "It wasn't hard, wasn't hard at all. I've been waiting for you to show up so I could deliver it. Waiting a long time. It was small at first, but all the time, it was growing. Stretching -- stretching me out. I thought you wouldn't come. Though I would be waiting until I burst. But -- but you're here now--"

She grinned, a horrible rictus that distorted the black briars tattooed on her cheeks.

"--you're here now, and now you can have it."

"What are you talking about?" Jane asked. And then something happened that she never would have expected in a million years.

Nasha kissed her.

She just stepped forward, took Jane's very surprised head in her hands, and planted a big, wet, open-mouthed kiss on the thief's lips.

"Mmmph?!" said Jane. And then she felt it.

Something was flowing into her mouth. Filling it. Forcing its way down her throat. It tasted a little like warm, spicy bread dough. It wasn't bad, but the fact that it was happening at all terrified her. What was going on?

In less than a minute her stomach was full, but still the flow continued. She tried to pull away, fighting against Nasha and her minions. They held her fast. She was in pain now, her stomach screaming. Her throat convulsed, trying to eject the stuff from her body, but the inexorable force-feeding continued. Jane was sure she was going to die.

But... she didn't. Even though the stuff kept coming. Her clothes began to feel tight, not just around her grossly distended middle, but everywhere. Stiff leather creaked. Laces came undone, or burst. The ropes bit into her wrists painfully. Already forced to breathed shallowly through her nose, she snuffled desperately, feeling as if she would suffocate.

Finally, when the pressure had grown almost more than she could bear, the horrible flow of sticky-sweet matter stopped. Jane was dropped to the wooden planks of the platform like a sack of potatoes, gasping for breath and gagging. She heaved, but nothing came out.

Once, on a dare, she'd entered an eating contest against a rather large lion barbarian -- and won. She'd been miserable for days afterwards, though. That was the only experience she could possibly compare to this. Except this was about a hundred times worse. She felt -- full. Really, really full. And not just in her stomach; all over, as though she'd been filled like a wineskin.

Above her, Nasha laughed again, and Jane looked up blearily to see those cold, blue eyes staring down at her from out of a -- slender face?

"You don't know what a relief this is!" the necromancer said, smoothing the fabric over her now-flat stomach. "I've had that thing in me for nearly a month, and I was getting better every day. I almost regretted taking the job. You really have no idea what it's like to be fat." She grinned. "Though I suppose you do now, don't you?"

Horrified, Jane looked down at herself. It was true. She wasn't just full. She was fat -- so fat she was bursting out of her leathers everywhere. She must have put on sixty pounds in a matter of minutes.

She was ruined as a thief. She wanted to cry.

Nasha kicked Jane in one chubby flank. "Aren't you the lucky one, though? It's catch and release, today. We're throwing you back until you get a little bigger." She leaned close. "And you will get bigger."

"Damn you, you--" Jane was interrupted by the gag wrapping back into her mouth. She tried to fight, but with her hands tied, the knots biting cruelly into her pudgy wrists, and weighed down, she couldn't manage much. It must have been enough to make them nervous, though, because she felt something slam into the side of her head. She felt stars, and then blackness.

She woke up back at the inn, with a splitting headache. She only had to look down at herself to come to the gut-wrenching realization that it hadn't just been a nightmare.
112111222.title: Mouth-To-Mouth

choices: Jane demolishes the pancakes. It would be a shame to waste food...
Jane musters her self-control and stops eating. She needs that cure!
1121112221.content:
Jane couldn't bring herself to get out of bed. She lay there simply staring in disbelief at the changes she'd undergone the previous night. How could this have happened? Was this some sort of spell? She raised her arm and whimpered at its weight. More so, she turned her wrist about, unable to see any muscle definition. Whatever had filled her up seemed to have settled, for she no longer felt inflated, just heavy. Then she recalled the spicy, doughy bread-like substance that poured down her throat. Maybe that wasn't magic at all. Maybe it was just some strange poison! Jane smiled and shot to an upright sitting position, only to frown at the sound of the bed's creaking frame. Adding insult to injury, the curve of her tummy poofed out and hid the view of her undergarments. "Great," Jane began, "I can move now, but on the off chance Nasha wasn't lying, I'd better find a fix to this and fast!" Swinging her legs out over the side of the bed, Jane grimaced at the sensation of a slight jiggle to her thighs.

"Lazing around is the last thing I want to do in this state." The fluffy rogue rose to her feet and at last inspected herself in her room's standing mirror. She couldn't help but hold a steady frown. Although the weight was distributed evenly across her body, she had always been more of a slight pear shape than a true hourglass, even if it was almost unnoticeable in her former body. Whatever affliction that wretched necromancer placed on her had only amplified this part of her, and she could see her hips had widened significantly, with a healthy layer of fat piled around her thighs and rear end. This was not to say that the rest of her went unscathed, as she could no longer see her precious six-pack of abs, and her bosom strained against her linen chest bindings. Jane cupped her hands over her somewhat enlarged bosom and sighed. "At least I still have my center of balance." She patted her backside and immediately flushed red as a small ripple spread around the point of impact. "That witch is so dead."

Ignoring the infuriating changes that had affected her physique, Jane hastily rummaged through her belongings, desperate to find anything that would fit her less-than-fit form. The rogue tossed aside a small pile of leathers before finally holding up a short, red tunic and matching skirt. "My priestess costume?" She had forgotten she still had that, but it looked loose enough to at least contain her small potbelly and wide hips. Without delay, Jane pulled the tunic over her head and slipped her arms through the long, wide sleeves. She couldn't help but notice her barely doughy upper arms pressed against the sleeves, but it was nothing too uncomfortable, and they wouldn't rip. The skirt, however, was another story. Jane managed to slip her feet through the top, but once the waist of the red skirt reached her thighs, the task became a bit more daunting. Inch by inch she slunk down into the skirt, only to meet resistance at her generous backside. Tugging the cloth up beneath the minor shelf of her ass sent a wave of jiggling through both cheeks, and Jane clenched her teeth in frustration. With one final yank, the skirt popped up over her buttocks, leaving Jane to sigh in relief. It was not the most comfortable, but it still fit her enough to allow for mobility. "For now..." Jane muttered, considering the warning Nasha had flaunted in her face. The rogue needed a cure as soon as possible.

After repacking her flurry of clothing and equipment, Jane fastened her dagger to one forearm for easy access, noting that the bracer was a little more snug on her wrist than usual. Packing complete, Jane stood and caught sight of herself in the mirror once more. "Oh, come on." She had forgotten the openness of the red priestesses and the clothing that reflected their lifestyles. Jane's tunic fell short around her midriff, something she would never object to in her usual physique, but now it did nothing but put her pudgy tummy on full display. In order to better worship their fertility goddess, the priestesses also wear their skirts in the fashion of "low-riders" to better display their hips. With Jane's added poundage, this would allow onlookers to not only see the lower curve of her belly, but the clothing's tightness created a small muffin top around her hips and waistline. "Perfect..." Rolling her eyes, Jane immediately swaddled herself in her heavy, winter cloak before slinging the pack over her shoulder. "At least it's cold enough to cover up."

Jane locked the door behind her and marched down the stairs into the inn's main hall. The catlike innkeeper waved her down with one furry paw behind the bar, flung his dishrag onto his shoulder, and smiled as she approached. Jane did all she could to hide her softer face, and hastily tossed a handful of coins onto the bar along with her room key. "Thank you for the room, sir."

"No thanks needed, but are you really leaving us so soon? We barely had the chance to..." Much like Marcus, the cat man gave her a once over before continuing. "We hardly got to know you, miss." He casually rested an elbow on the counter top and twirled the key around his finger. "Sure we can't interest you in some breakfast before you head out?" As Jane shook her head, her stomach protested without missing a beat. The loud, churning growl could be heard across the quiet, empty inn. In response, the cat man flicked his ears and spread a fanged grin. Jane could only blush and turned away, looking to the door. "Our special this morning is buttermilk pancakes with fresh fruit." He paused, teasing one whisker between two clawed fingers. Jane stopped, craning her head back.

"Pancakes?" She unconsciously licked her lips. The thought just occurred to her that she didn't eat a proper meal the night before, other than that disgusting ooze from Nasha, and even though the thought of that thing pouring inside her nauseated Jane to no end, she couldn't help but feel a little hungry. "Sure. Just one though. I'm very busy this morning." Without delay, the cat man nodded and turned toward the kitchen. He shouted something incomprehensible and offered Jane a wink.

"Take a seat, miss. I'll have them right up for you." He nodded again and returned to his work of polishing glasses from the night before. Jane wondered why barkeeps always seemed to have an endless supply of things to clean. Maybe it came with the personality of owning an inn. Who knew. All Jane knew was that she felt hungrier and hungrier as the seconds ticked by, and as the pain settled into her stomach, she found herself a seat to knead the dough of her soft tummy into submission. Jane looked around the room, and noticed it was completely empty save for herself and the innkeeper. Strange that no one would be up this early. Where were all of the other guests? But before she could think too hard on the matter, the innkeeper returned with a platter piled high with at least a dozen pancakes smothered in rich, golden syrup and heavy with butter. Each small pile was dripping with minced strawberries and blueberries. Jane's jaw went slack at the sight and she whipped her head to stare down the cat. He simply smiled back. "Enjoy!"

"I said one! This is not one!" Jane furrowed her brow and pointed tersely at the ridiculous portion of pancakes.

"Yes, miss. This is one: one order of pancakes." He raised a brow in confusion and folded his arms across his chest.

"You sneaky bastard, I'm not paying for all of this!" Jane placed both hands on the platter and grunted as she slid it away, only managing to move it a few inches.

"But you already have... breakfast was included in your room rental."

"Oh... really? Well, I am hungry, so I suppose I should at least eat some of them." She grunted again, sliding the massive mound of carbs back toward her. "Thanks." She shot the last word back to the cat before completely ignoring him. He bowed silently and strode into the kitchen behind the bar, leaving Janeto her meal in peace. "Wow... that is a lot of pancakes." As if to agree, her stomach immediately growled its impatience. "All right, all right." The rogue scooped up her cutlery and began to slice up the first pancake. Dipping it into the rich, sticky syrup, she brought the blueberry laden bite to her lips and went wide-eyed as it hit her tongue. These were the most amazing pancakes she'd ever tasted! They were incredible! Chewing and swallowing, she wasted no time in carving up the remainder of the first pancake. Jane smacked her lips and nodded to herself. "That should hold me over--" But in defiance, her stomach growled violently. "What? Oh, come on. One is plenty!" Although they were awfully tasty, and she hadn't tried the strawberry pancakes yet...
1121112221.title: A Cry For Help

Jane gives in, and tries the "greatest" breakfast the inn has to offer
11211122211.content:
"One is definitely enough", Jane snapped at her moaning stomach. It grumbled back defiantly. "Well ok. Just one more! It would be a shame to waste so much". Jane made a start on her second pancake, this one tasting even better than the first. Before she knew it, she had finished the pancake. Her stomach gurgled once more. "Ok. Maybe one more", she soothed. But three wasn't enough. She helped herself to another, and another, until she had finished the entire plate of pancakes. "Whew! Those were good!" Jane cooed, patting her stuffed gut. Her waistline now a couple more inches wider than after it's enhancement the previous night.

"I should really start to ask around town and get some answers", Jane thought to herself. Just as the thought crossed her mind the landlord returned again to where she was sitting. "Ah good! I knew you wouldn't be able to help yourself" the cat-man stated with a grin, almost menacingly. "Oh yes they were lovely. Thank you", Jane responded cheerfully. "I really should get going now though", she added, clutching her belly. The landlord moved closer to her, and in a tempting voice said "but surely you would want to try our most highly rated breakfast? It's even better than those pancakes!". "Even better than the pancakes!?", she replied quizzically, licking her lips sub-consciously.

Jane had some thinking to do.....
11211122211.title: Waste Not, Want Not

choices: Stick it out. Wait for the witch and question her!
Get out of there! The witch is clearly evil!
11211122212.content:
Jane shook her head and prodded her belly into silence. "One is enough." After a small fit of grumbles, her stomach ceased its retorts, allowing Jane to push her chair out and rise to her feet. As if on cue, the innkeeper returned from the kitchen accompanied by two of his kitchen staff, a pair of female cat people. Jane offered them a polite smile, but the only stared back. "Thank you, but I'm not that hungry." No response. "I told you I only needed one!" She laughed her smoky laugh, but the joke was lost on them. Their stares turned sour, and the trio approached, setting the rogue on edge. "What's wrong?" They continued to close the distance, hands at their sides. "I already paid for the meal, what's the big deal?" No words, but the pair of females each drew a length of rope from behind their backs, and the innkeeper held out a very familiar burlap sack. That's when the realization hit her. The ceremony! How could she have forgotten? There were enough torches present for the whole... town. All three cats flashed their fanged grins as they leapt at Jane. She hopped back, but tripped on the hem of her long, winter cloak. Crashing to the floor, the plump rogue had no time to fend them off. Both staff members grappled for her wrists and held them fast. Jane thrashed her thick thighs, landing a direct hit into the cat's cajones. He yelped and crumpled into a heap at her feet. Both females almost had her wrists secured when the rogue relaxed her arms, only to catch them off-guard by quickly flinging them together, bashing both kitties' heads together. With all three incapacitated, the rogue scrambled to her feet and fetched her cloak. A light sweat broke out beneath her scarlet garments, and Jane knew she would not have been so winded if she were sixty pounds lighter.

"Time to go." Throwing the cloak about her shoulders, Jane set out into the bright, winter morning. The sun reflecting off the fallen snow nearly blinded her after the dimly lit inn, and the scent of the town flooded her nose. Blacksmith smoke, roasting meats, even the snow itself. Anything beat the stuffy tavern air. Jane remembered her discovery, and scanned the street, again noticing that familiar feeling of being watched. She threw on her hood, clamped the cloak tighter around her body, and marched through the snow toward a nearby alley. Without a plan, Jane had no idea how to remove the curse, or poison, or potion, or whatever was causing her body to swell up. Where could she find a cure? Who would know how to fix it? Jane mulled over the possibilities, and snapped her fingers in the cold air. "A witch." Witches were renowned for their knowledge of curses, poisons, and potions alike. If anyone could help her, it would be a witch. But where could she find one? They weren't exactly accepted by society, so finding one would be difficult. Nobody in this town could be trusted, but Jane knew one man who had an affinity for the unusual: Marcus.

Slipping between the alleys and shadows of the town, Jane successfully avoided suspicion and now stood before the door to Marcus' shop. Pushing it open, she peered inside. No sign of the murdered wolf from the night before could be seen, and Jane stepped out of the cold, morning air. "Hello?" She called in a low voice, and without delay the familiar businessman strode out from behind a pile of junk, some odd gizmo clutched in one hand and a magnifying class in the other. His eyes went wide and he dropped both items, turning to rush for the back door. Jane cursed and charged after him, but the shopkeeper knocked over a pile of books behind him, causing Jane to once again trip over her cloak. Modesty was clearly not worth the price of agility. Shedding her winter wear, the rogue dashed after him, her winter weight bouncing in plain sight. "Get back here, Marcus!"

The wolfish store owner turned about and whirled a small object at Jane, landing a direct hit against her forehead. Collapsing in a daze, Jane shook her head in time to see the shopkeeper slam the back door behind him. Damn it. He was her only connection. Jane rubbed the small lump above her nose and grabbed hold of whatever had knocked her down. "Of course." It was yet another statue of Jane and the Sitharli, but this version reflected her current size, and she was posed clinging to his feet in groveling worship. "Disgusting..." The rogue tossed it aside and brushed off her skirt. Then it dawned on her. "Wait, a minute. This guy collects all sorts of stuff. Maybe he has something here I can use." After all, Marcus was clearly involved in her capture somehow, so he must know something about what happened to her. Tapping a finger to her chin, Jane meandered through the piles of seemingly useless junk until she stopped at his office in the rear of the store. "He's got to have some record of his business here." Finding the door locked, Jane grinned as she scooped up the nearby statue of herself and smashed it through the glass window, causing the word 'Office' to scatter at her feet. The rogue reached through and unlocked it from the inside before swinging the door open wide.

Inside the room sat a filing cabinet and a desk, both plain and unassuming, but atop the desk rested a large book bound in purple leather. A single eye was carved into the cover, and Jane flipped it open to the page containing the bookmark. There in ink was her name, followed by the words: 'bearer of the gift.' What gift? The statue? The thing inside her? She continued reading and flipped to the previous page. There she saw Nasha's name and the description of a remote hut out in the wilderness wherein an old crone had been contacted by the Sitharli's minions. It couldn't have been more than an hour from town on foot, and Jane decided it was her best bet.

*****

After sneaking past the guards and leaving town, Jane hiked through the quiet, windless forest in the direction mentioned in the book. She decided it would be wise to bring it with her, and now carried it in her backpack. The plump rogue was most thankful for remembering to grab her cloak, as even the high noon sun was not enough to warm the wintry weather. Her breath hung in the air, but before long she saw the telltale sign of fireplace smoke rising over the treetops. Crunching through the snow, Jane caught sight of a large, ramshackle hut, the source of the smoke. Cautiously, she approached the window and peered inside. For all she knew it could be another trap set by that wretched Nasha. To her amazement, there was no one inside. Above the fire sat a large cauldron, and Jane knew this had to be the right place. She checked the door, found it unlocked, and slipped inside. The hut consisted of a single, round room with the fireplace at its center. The walls were lined with bookshelves and workbenches piled high with beakers of technicolor tonics. Her salvation could lay within any of them, but it would be foolish to drink anything without first consulting the witch.

It was then that the smell of something absolutely tantalizing caught her nose. Jane followed it back to the cauldron and peered inside. It appeared to be some sort of meat stew with boiled vegetables and a rich, savory broth. Her mouth watered simply seeing and smelling it, and Jane noticed an empty, clean bowl and spoon resting on an adjacent table. It had been several hours since she had that one pancake... surely the witch could part with one bowl. Without second thought, Jane ladled the soup into the bowl, filling it to the brim. She plopped down into a nearby chair and blew across the soup's steamy surface. It smelled even better than before! Greedily bringing it to her lips, she slurped it down, feeling the warmth trickle down her throat and settle in her belly. It was more than delicious; it was heavenly! Who knew witches could cook something so tasty! One spoonful after another brought the spicy soup to her eager mouth. Before she knew it, the stew was gone and she had already licked the bowl clean. A small burp rumbled from her sated stomach, and Jane couldn't help but notice a spicy, bread-like... aftertaste. "Oh, no... not good!" She hadn't noticed, but the stew tasted exactly like the thing Nasha spewed into her throat!

Looking down, Jane could only whimper as the changes took hold. The tingling started at her chest, spreading out to each arm. Although not clad in her skin-tight leathers, Jane felt the swelling beneath her tunic nonetheless. First her arms thickened slightly, now stretching the sleeves around her doughy triceps. Her wrists grew even softer, straining her forearm sheath to uncomfortable limits. Even her fingers now looked puffier as dimples began forming between her knuckles. A warmth rose in her chest with each breath, and Jane winced as the linen bindings now squeezed against her swelling bosom. Between the first ceremony and the soup she had easily grown from a B cup to a solid double C.

"Why?! Why can't I catch a break?!" Jane clutched her chest, but grimaced as the warmth roiled into her tummy, spreading out over the soft flesh. The same sensation of swelling took hold, as her slight curved belly now pushed forth. Her tunic began to ride up, exposing more of the pale, round flesh. Where the extent of her tummy had previously sat as a pronounced muffin top, it now pushed out at least two more inches, stopping just before it could succumb to gravity and reach her lap. But the changes were not done just yet, and the last warmth reached her buttocks, filling out her already round ass, deepening the crease between her rump and thighs. Those also grew, and now touched near her crotch. Walking would be bothersome if they scraped together... Finally subsiding, Jane had clearly gained another fifteen pounds from just the one bowl of soup. Whatever this witch had planned, this stuff was far stronger than the goop Nasha used. Jane needed a plan and fast. Could she trust the witch?
11211122212.title: The Cat, the Witch, and the Wardrobe Malfunction
