1251211.content:
Maria's head was pounding furiously when she awoke from her coma. When she opened her eyes, she saw that the world was nothing more but a blurry haze of strange colors and indescribable shapes.

She blinked a few times, bringing the world into view, and discovered that she was laying in a bed, staring up at a dark sealing covered in cobwebs of all sizes.

Where was she? Why didn't the brute known as Kovan kill her when he had the chance? All she could remember was his menacing smile, his hand reaching out towards her.

Maria heard the door of the room swing open, and through it came strutting a robust wolfess, carrying a crate full of what looked like medical supplies. From the way she was dressed, Maria could easily tell that she was a warrior: she wore padded leather, a plate of armor strapped to it here and there, and a razor-sharp dagger hung at her side.

"Ah, your awake," she said when she saw the fox staring at her. She had a stern but, strangely, motherly voice.

"W-who are you?" Maria managed to ask weakly, her voice harsh from disuse.

"Don't speak," the wolf said, pulling out a vile from the crate. It was filled with thick white liquid. "Drink this," she instructed.

Maria hesitated but drank it, tasting herbs with a hint of alcohol. The pain in the fox's head evaporated into a dull throb.

Who are you?" Maria tried again, her head much more clearer now, putting more force into the question.

"I," she began, "am Jeanette; one of the soldiers and healers of Lord Murray."

"Lord Murray?" Maria asked, not familiar with the name. She had heard of many small lords that govern their small folk around the forest, but this one was completely new.

"Well, that's how he likes to style himself these days. He's actually our clan's chef," Jeanette explained.

Maria's eyes examined the room, noting how abandoned it looked.

"What is this place?" she asked, throwing the covers away and standing up from the bed.

"O, this?" she custard with her paw, "This was supposed to be a castle, but we couldn't restore it back to its former glory. We were at least able to turn it in to a stronghold."

"But why would your clan need a strong-"

Maria was cut off in mid-sentence when a gang - for the were too disorganized to be called a group - of wolves came barging in, spears in their paws.

"We're here for the fox," what looked like the leader of the gang said, "Lord Murray wants to have a word with her."

Maria was marched down a hallway, her paws bounded by thick rope, guards flanking her in all directions.

They walked into a large room that most likely served as a throne room, and on a simple chair sat a fierce-looking wolf, watching Maria with mild interest. He, like the rest, wore thick leathers, but had much more armor covering him, and an eyepatch covered his left eye.

Behind him stood Kovan, grinning, his body and upper leg wrapped with bandages.

"Who are you?" Lord Murray demanded.

There was no sense of rebelling, so Maria had no choice but to give her identity away.

"My name's Maria."

Lord Murray studied her for a moment. "And why do you reject submission from your Lord's men?"

He was talking about the fight she had with Kovan, Maria knew. Even from behind Lord Murray she could see the brute smiling even wider.

"These lands have no lord that govern it; there free forests," Maria said.

"Until now," Lord Murray said.

Kovan cleared his throat. "My Lord," he said, "We must still discuss a proper punishment for her behavior."

Lord Murray shot him an impatient look. "What? For giving you a boo boo?" he said, his voice thick with mockery, "You've survived worse than this, you bafoon. She did not know, and a punishment isn't necessarily then."

Jeanette gave a snort in amusement, and a few chuckles went up in the court. Kovan took a few steps back, stunned. His pride had suffered a gut-punch.

"As for you," Lord Murray said, turning his attention back to Maria, casting her a menacing smile that looked very similar to Kovan's, "We can't have you running around warning everyone about what's going on. We still need to take this forest unaware. So, we will hold you here till further notice."

Maria felt her heart sank, but she did not protest, allowing herself to be taken away by the guards.

12512112.content:
As Maria allowed herself to be willingly taken away into captivity, she was led up many spiral staircases, ascending higher and higher into this crooked stronghold, reaching a room that the fox least expected ending up in: a castle's tower.

Now it was time for Maria's pride to take a gut-punch. Never in all her life did she expect to be locked up in a tower like some helpless, fragile, innocent, pretty maiden, waiting for her night in signing armor to rescue her. A smelly, slimy dungeon was sounding better right now.

The room was surprisingly well furnished, even though it was still basic: there was a steel bed with a actual feather mattress on it, a desk for writing with its own chair, a wardrobe, though, it was completely empty, and even its own privy.

But it still had a neglected look to it: dust covered the surfaces, a few spiderwebs stood in the corners with their eight-legged creators standing idly in the center, waiting patently for their next meal.

Maria was pushed almost gently inside by one of her escorts, and, as expected, the heavy wooden door swung shut and was locked from the outside.

The fox attempted to inhale deeply to exhale as a sigh, but she nearly choked on the stuffy air. There was one small window just above the bed that could be opened, which, surprisingly, had no iron bars to speak of.

This was bizarre for Maria; why would they leave window so unprotected? Did they want her or any other prisoner to escape? All her questions were answered when she opened it for they first time and peered outside.

It was a sheer drop of hundreds of feet, leading to a small courtyard bellow. The stones, for some reason, were far too smooth for a climb, and even if she had the help of some sort of climbing gear, she would never risk such a deadly feat.

Maria hated to admit it but she had a fear of heights. Even now her heart was speeding up in her chest and her palms were beginning to sweat.

With a groan, the fox sat down on her bed, waiting, like the spiders, for something to happen. And she waited and waited.

Hours turned to days. Food was brought to Maria a few times per day by male and female wolves alike. She tried her best to grab their attention, begging them to tell her of any news or to send a message to their chief, but her efforts were all for naught.

They only greeted her with expressionless faces, not even uttering a grunt or gesturing with a nod. She had half the mind at a certain point to grab one of her "servants" and force them to do what she asked, but Maria knew such an action would be disastrous.

They weren't those bony, small, weak, dimwitted servants you saw at any ordinary castles; they strong, tall, clever wolves that had seen some hard times on the fields of battle.

The chances were greater that they would overpower her in a split-second if she even dared to make a threatening move towards them. Even if she did accomplish such a deed, there was still the chance that they might cry out, alerting the guards outside, who had weapons and could end her in a moment, for they did not need her. She was just another mouth to feed in the stronghold.

No! It was better to be safe than sorry.

Maria kept count of the days by scratching lines on the grey stones by using her claws, and on the sixth day of her imprisonment she received a visitor.

But who was it?
12512112.title: Locked away in a tower.

125121121.content:
On the sixth day of her captivity, Maria heard the familiar sound of keys jingling and the lock of the heavy wooden door unlocking. For a few moments a strange madness took a hold of her, a madness of a prisoner kept isolated far too long in his cell, craving for the outside world, for freedom, but the fox conquered it before she did anything stupid; it would take a lot more than that to make her crack.

It was not some random wolf bringing Maria her morning bread (though, she wished it was, for she felt rather famished), but it was one of the guards that stood post outside.

"Oi, fox, you got a visitor," he told Maria.

Now who could that possibly be? She only knew two beings in this castle at some level, and the good spirits forbid that it should be Kovan. Maria swore that she would claw his eyes out if he dared come all this way to bully or mock her. She didn't care if she had no weapon to speak of, or if there was guards to subdue her, or if the attempt of assault would only lead to her death in the end.

But, when the wolf stepped aside, allowing the visitor to enter, Maria saw that she was lucky today: it wasn't the brute but Jeanette. The fox was delighted by the sight of the sturdy wolf, feeling that her life got so much better, but she was surprised at the same time.

"Jeanette?" Maria began, "What are you doing here?"

"O, I just came here for a talk, that's all," she answered, smiling, but she wasn't looking the fox; instead, her gaze was focused on the guard, who was closing the door behind him and locking it for safety reasons.

Maria frowned: someone keeping her company in her lonely hours would be nice, but it was a little out of character for a wolfess like her to visit for idle chatting. Something told her that she was here for more than that.

Her suspicion proved correct ones they were alone, for Jeanette's expression shifted, becoming serious with a hint of anger.

"Listen," the wolf began, taking a seat next to Maria on the bed, "You're probably wondering why I'm here, and you probably figured out a long time ago that I'm not here for idle talk. Hell, I'm not even supposed to be up here! Murray's got a lot more bossy lately, and he's threatening to hang every second wolf he sees for treason, so I'm risking my own tail for this. I had to bribe the guards a handsome amount of cash to see you."

"Sounds like you guys are on tough times," Maria concluded.

"Indeed," Jeanette confirmed, "And things are reaching boiling point ever since the chief sided with a powerful sorcerer to help him with his campaign."

"Sorcerer?" Maria asked, growing both concerned and interested.

People who had skills in real magic was both feared and a little shunned from society. So, it was odd that a bunch of barbarian wolves, which was a rather superstitious lot, would ask help from something they would avoid like a epidemic.

"Yes," Jeanette said, "He calls himself the Lipomancer."

"Odd name," Maria said, raising an eyebrow.

"His name is the least of our problems," Jeanette said, "Ever since he arrived three days ago there have been conflict going on inside the clan. Now, I know that our kind can be...well, barbaric at times, but I promise you we're not without honor. This whole using magic thing to take over the forest isn't what we do! If we go to war, we want to do it fair and square! No tricks, no sorcery. It's not fair using magic in a battle. Even for an enemy that's harsh!"

Maria nodded in agreement, for magic was a unfair tool to use in war. The fox had seen its destructive power in the fields of combat: it could kill platoons in seconds, poison armies, rendering them useless, and make Generals mysteriously die, turning the tides of the event completely.

"Why are you telling me this?" Maria asked.

She had a feeling that there was some sort of conspiracy going on here.

And once again her suspicion proved correct when Jeanette said the following: "Okay, let me get to the chase," she said, before dropping her voice to a whisper, "I'm planning a mutiny, and I want you to help me."

The bomb Jeanette dropped was pretty big, leaving Maria absolutely speechless. Like being locked up in a tower, she never expected in all her life to get in tangled in some political game.

But the question was: would she except!

1251211211.content:
There was a silent bargain being offered here, Maria knew: help me, and you will get your freedom. Even though the fox despised getting herself caught up in some political game (hell, she was a sword-for-hire), she knew she had to do this to get out of this tower.

"I'll do it," Maria said, breaking free from being dumbfounded.

Jeanette smiled. "Good," she said, "We'll come to free you tonight."

She turned and walked towards the door, but before she left, Maria could not help but ask: "Hey, Jeanette, why did you ask me for help?"

"I'll explain that in due time," answered Jeanette, "But right now I need to leave before someone catches me here."

And with that said, she rapped on the door a few times, saying: "Oi, Torus, I'm ready to come out now!"

There was a few moments of silence before the lock was being tampered with, and then the door opened. With one final wink to Maria, Jeanette closed the door behind her.

For some reason the fox found that waiting these few hours for night to fall was more agonizing than all her days here combined. When dusk finally arrived, Maria was laying on her bed, staring at the roof, waiting patiently for something to happen.

And then something did happen: Maria heard one of the guards shouting, "Halt! Who goes there?", the ringing of steel sliding out of a scabbard, cries of alarm, the clash of weaponry, screams of pain, bodies hitting the floor, and then everything went quiet for a few moments.

There was that jingling of keys again, the door opened, and Jeanette entered, dressed in armor with two swords hanging on her belt.

"Finally!" Maria cried.

The wolf grinned. "Impatient, aren't you?" she said.

"Well, isolation and boredom can make you a little Impatient," Maria said.

Jeanette began to fidget on one of her swords and pulled it free. "Your gonna need this," she said, handing Maria the weapon.

"Thanks," Maria said, taking the short sword.

The lifeless bodies of the guards were laying on the staircase outside. Ones face was smashed in, and another had serious cuts and deep stab wounds. Being the warrior that she was, the sight wasn't new to Maria.

"You did all of this?" Maria asked, nudging one of the dead bodies.

"I did it to that one," said Jeanette, pointing to the body with cuts, "Frisky little bugger that one was."

"O, and who helped you?" Maria asked.

"Him," she answered simply, pointing.

Maria looked towards the source she was pointing to and saw that it was...
1251211211.title: The assault begins.

choices: Suddenly, they were ambushed and captured.
Maria goes off to steal the wizard's staff.
12512112111.content:
Maria gave a small but intentional laugh when she discovered the irony of the situation; the very being that was helping Jeanette and who the fox had to work with, the very person that got her into this mess in the first place, was Kovan.

He was no longer dressed in leather but in steel, which had seen hard ware in battle, for it had deep scratched and marking where dents were bent right. But it was well-polished, for there was no rust and it gleamed in the moonlight that streamed through the window.

His was holding his enormous hammer in both hands, the slab of iron smeared with blood, which without a doubt belonged to the poor guard that had his face smashed in.

He looked bored at first, killing and rescuing not being a new thing to him, but when his eyes met Maria's his muzzle curled up in disgust, grunting, turning his gaze quickly away from her.

"Is everyone ready?" Jeanette asked, though it was rhetorical, not waiting for anyone to answer it before she said, "Let's go then."

They moved down the spiral staircase, Kovan at the back, Maria in the middle, and Jeanette at the front, leading this small party.

As they made there way down, the fox asked: "So, what do you need me for?"

She felt like this was the most appropriate time to ask, for the rebellion was starting and Maria had not the faintest clue what part she played in this.

"We're planning to take two birds down with one stone," said Jeanette when they arrived at a long hallway at the bottom of the staircase.

She turned right and continued: "The Lipomancer himself arrived two days ago, to have a little chat with our chief, most likely came to discuss when to attack and take over the area. His arrival kinda put the whole rebellion in jeopardy. We need to weaken the wizard, and you are the one going to do that."

"Me!?" Maria cried, shocked, grabbing Jeanette's shoulder and pulling their advances to a halt, much the Kovan's displeasure.

The wolf growled, muttering something inaudible, most likely something offensive, but Maria didn't care about him. The idea of confronting a wizard, a being of immense power, terrified her, even more than heights.

"How the hell the hell am I going to do that!" Maria cried. "I can't go up against a wizard; that's madness!"

"First of all," Jeanette said, frowning, frustration evident in her voice, "Keep your voice down; someone will hear you. Secondly: I'm not sending face-to-face against the Lipomancer; that is madness, but I want you to sneak into his room and steal his staff while I assemble the rebellion. You do know what happens if a wizard loses his staff, don't you?"

Maria nodded. According to the basic lore, a wizard's staff is his greatest weapon. The most powerful spells was conjured from there. Take it away and he would be left with his much weaker spells, leveling the playing field. Maria now understood what she meant.

"Okay," the fox said, growing determined, "Tell me where he is staying at and I'll sneak in and get the staff."

Jeanette quickly explained to her, and after that they proceeded, coming across a T-section.

"Take right, and you'll get to were you should go," informed Jeanette, "We'll go left and assemble the army."

Maria nodded and they part ways.
12512112111.title: Kovan!

choices: The games begin.
The games begin.
125121121111.content:
When they departed, Maria attempting to go right and Kovan and Jeanette attempting to go left, something unexpected happened; shadows emerged from the gloom if the two directions, their outlines looking like that of wolves.

Maria and Jeanette could only gave a cry, Kovan so slow that he was oblivious to what was happening, before the shadows pulled out a round orb, glowing a pale white color, throwing it at the small party.

There was a dramatic flash of blinding light, and Maria felt how she was quickly losing consciousness, the world around her falling into darkness.

When she woke up, thinking how ridiculous is was being knocked out twice in a single week, Maria discovered that she was laying on the floor of the castle's big throne room.

Sitting up, she saw that they were surrounded by wolves in armor, clutching spears, faces grim. Maria heard strange moaning sounds next to her, and when she looked she saw Kovan and Jeanette was stirring next to her, waking up from their unconsciousness.

When all of them were finally awaking, rubbing their heads, a familiar voice suddenly spoke: "Well, they say if you cut off the head of a snake the body would fall."

Looking up, Maria identified the speaker as none other than Lord Murray, who was staring at them with a angry scowl.

He pointed at the group, his finger moving from person to person he was addressing. "Kovan, my most powerful warrior, though you always were a little dim and a slippery bastard, and Jeanette, my most skilled healer who has more sense than she truly should have.

He moved his finger, pointing at Maria now. "And you! I don't have much to say to you, fox, except that I should have killed you when I had the chance."

"Traitors, all of you!" he yelled, "I should hang you now!"

"B-but h-how did you know!" Jeanette blurted out, her confidence and bravery she had earlier dropping, being replaced by fear.

"He didn't," came a voice, "But I did."

From behind the raised platform emerged a human, dressed in a long, red robe, a staff in his right hand. Even in his clothing that was designed to show little as possible of his figure, Maria knew from his bony hands and forearms that he was a thin man.

He had short, red hair and a pointy beard and mustache, giving his face sharp features. He was somewhere in his late twenties, but his chocolate brown eyes told that he had a great amount of wisdom.

"This must be the Lipomancer," Maria concluded, thinking to herself.

"I was suspicious about you the day I arrived here," he said, talking to Jeanette. "Lord Murray here said that I was just being paranoid, but I had a hunch that you were planning something, something that would ruin this whole entire take over of the region. So, I decided to spy on you, following your every movement."

"And that was how I discovered your plot," said Lord Murray.

"Yes," said the wizard, "We were just waiting for the right moment to strike, which was tonight. Though, I must admit that Murray's judgment here is a little harsh."

"What?" exclaimed the chief, looking at him with surprise and a hint of outrage.

"Yes," said the wizard, "You heard me. You said so yourself that they are good warriors and helpers, and it would be such a waste to kill them. Instead, why don't you just punish them, discipline them."

"Yes, sounds like a great idea," said Lord Murray, a sinister grin growing on his face, "I will break their bones, skin them and make a pair of good gloves, I will-"

But he was cut off when the Lipomancer spoke. "Slow down there, my lord!" he said, holding up his hand, "If you want to punish someone you don't need to make it so brutal. You need to be...creative."

"Alright," said the chief, calming down, sitting back on his wooden throne, "What do you have in mind?''

"Simple," he said, "I propose a game."

This time Kovan finally broke his silence. "I'm not playing any games, you walking stick," he growled, "Why don't we challenge each other to single combat, and allow the good spirits to allow who's innocent?"

Maria could tell that the Lipomancer was not pleased by the wolf's insult and suggestion, for he snapped his finger. Kovan's snarling muzzle suddenly closed shut, and he frantically touched, perhaps trying to pry it open.

"Dumbass," thought Maria, shaking her head.

The wizard continued, unhindered this time: "Each of you would use your special characteristic to win it."

He pointed at the three, naming them. "Strength." He pointed to Kovan, who was still trying to open his muzzle, his effort fruitless. "Wit." He pointed at Jeanette. "And stealth." He finished, pointing at Maria.

"Even the fox?" asked Lord Murray, raising an eyebrow.

"When you said "them" I thought that you meant all three of them, so, yeah, even the fox," said the Lipomancer.

The wolf shrugged. "So be it then."

"Alright!" exclaimed the wizard, stepping back, "Are all ready?"

It was rhetorical, Maria knew, and nothing she could say or do would stop him.

"Let the games begin," he announced, snapping his fingers, and there was a blinding flash of light.
125121121111.title: The wizard;s proposal.

choices: The following morning.
Something happens during the night.
1251212.content:
Maria's head was pounding when she woke up. When she opened her eyes she saw that her vision was blurry. She blinked a few times, bringing the world into few...and she saw that it was upside down.

She tried to move but felt a pressure preventing her from doing so. Maria quickly examined herself and saw that she was tied up by thick rope to a tree, her head pointing towards the ground and feet towards the branches.

Her head felt as heavy as led due to all the blood rushing to it, causing her head to spin and throb even more painfully.

But Maria knew that she could do nothing to her situation, for she had already felt herself, trying to find her hidden dagger, but it was missing.

To take her mind off of her predicament, Maria focused her attention to figure out where she was exactly.

It took a few moments, due to her uncomfortable position, but she figured it out: she was close to a large river, which flowed out of a huge lake, mountains and lush forest surrounding it.

She did not know this place, for she had never traveled further than the mountains which marked the borders of the free forests, meaning that she was quite a long way from were she ones was.

The sun was setting behind the mountains, casting a long shadow over the valley, setting it in the time if dusk even though it was only late in the afternoon.

Maria spotted a warhammer and pieces of clothing laying close to a rock, and she knew it was Kovan's, but where could that brute be?

Her question was answered when the wolf himself suddenly emerged from the waters of the river. Maria averted her eyes. He was stark naked, water running off his thick arms, pecs, well-toned abs and plumb sheath and dangling scrotum.

When he reached the shore, Kovan went on all fours and began to shake his body like a dog, sending water droplets flying everywhere.

"Well, well, it would seem that my little prize is awake," he said when he noticed Maria, a wide, mocking grin on his face.

Maria ignored him, still looking the other way.

"What's the matter?" he said, faking concern, "Are you angry that I knocked you out? Head hurting like hell? Sucks to be you! You shouldn't have fought me."

When Maria still didn't say anything, Kovan grunted, pulling his pack, which laid next to his clothing, closer to him, digging inside until he pulled out a roll of white bandages.

"Though, I have to admit that you put up a good fight," he said, wrapping the white cloth around the areas where Maria slashed him, silently indicating what he meant. "It's a rarity when my adversaries survive more than ten seconds against me. You topped twenty seconds! I counted them myself. You make a worthy opponent."

Maria had to admit that she swelled a little with pride, but she still remained stoned-faced, finally breaking her silence, still refusing to look at him: "What do you want from me?"

"Not much," the wolf said, wrapping the bandage around his hand, the very hand that caught her sword. "Just wanna take you to my master."

"Why?" the fox said, "Why didn't you just kill me there? You could have spared yourself a lot of trouble."

"True," said the wolf, "But if I did that I would not get my prize."

"What prize?" Maria asked suspiciously.

"The prize my master would give me, of course," said Kovan, finishing his last wound and reaching for his clothing. "He's never had a fox in his service before, and I think he'll enjoy it a lot playing with you."

"What do you mean?"

"You'll find out soon enough," he said, pulling up his pants, "But for now it's best that I make camp. It's still quite a distance before we reach our destination, and night falls quick in this valley. So, you better get yourself comfortable against that tree."

Maria gave I sigh. It was going to be a long night.
1251212.title: Confined to a tree.

choices: Are suspicious of Lucius Darkwood
Decide to get something to eat
125122.content:
Suddenly and out of nowhere an arrow strikes Kovan down, but only enough to render him unconcious.

"Who the hell are you?" Maria said.

"No need to worry fair maiden for I Lucius Darkwood have come to your rescue." A white wolf of a similar build to Kovac replied as he stepped out of the shadows.

Lucius wore a lightweight black cloak, a silver tunic, a golden quiver, and a sword.

"I didn't need rescuing. I can handle myself."

Lucius gives a hardy laugh. "There's no doubt there, but with your boyfriend cowering like a little girl I thought you would appreciate the help."

Maria growls at Lucius. "He is not my boyfriend! We just recently met! Wasn't it your kind that's threatening to take over this forest?"

"You must be referring to the Wilde Clan. Not all wolves share the same views."

"So you just happened to stroll by and decide to intervene?" Maria said with an eyebrow raised.

"That's partially true. My employer has sent me on a quest."

"What kind of quest?" James timidly asked.

"If I told you my employer would send their his army after us. Looks like I have to go. See you around fair maiden."

In a flash Lucius leaves as mysteriously as he had arrived and he took Kovan with him. Now with that settled Maria and James...
125122.title: The Mysterious Traveller, Lucius Darkwood

choices: A two-handed sword, lying in the middle of a patch of barren soil.
A few washtubs full of strange-colored liquids; an alchemist is probably nearby.
What appears to be part of a machine...
1252.content:
"Some weird... Thing?" Maria said. She wasn't quite sure what she was smelling; she'd smelled nothing like it before. It was an oily sort of smell, but not pungently so... Except for the fact that it also sort of smelled of charred meat and burnt grass, all rolled into one with just the slightest hint of raspberries. The aroma was quite confusing to the orange vixen.

She approached the scent, somewhere to the left of her in the woods, and took another whiff. It was a bit different, now: It had gained a hint of... Urine? "Ick..." she said under her breath. She was fairly certain she wouldn't be finding anything she'd want to see, let alone pick up... But, without anything better to do, she continued on in the direction of the scent, taking the scent with every few steps. She found that it... Changed, quite frequently. As she drew closer, the smell would become stronger, but would not always have all of its aspects. At times, it dropped its "burnt" odor; at others, it dropped its odor of raspberries. It was always "oily," though.

After a dozen or so more yards, the orange vixen still had no idea what the hell she was looking for. All she knew was that she was getting closer to it. After crawling through a convenient opening in a thicket of raspberry bushes ("Well, that explains part of the scent."), she laid eyes on what she had been looking for...
1252.title: Scent of Discovery!

choices: Maria finally notices the erpen, and reacts accordingly.
The erpens continue in their "hunt" with no resistance, tying Maria up easily.
12523.content:
"... What?" Maria said, perplexed. She was looking at a set of gears, roller chains and pistons... They weren't moving, and had no discernible reason for being behind a raspberry thicket. It wasn't old, either; in fact, it looked like it had been installed fairly recently, the components still shiny and free of rust. Even if it wasn't, it was still being maintained, judging by a generous coating of slick oil. "Why are you here?" she asked. It didn't answer, of course, being an inanimate object, and Maria, of course, didn't expect an answer.

She circled the mysterious mechanism, hoping to see if she could find its purpose. A more thorough examination did not yield any insight into its function, but did reveal that at least some of it was underground. "Where did it come from..?" She sat down next to the gizmo, staring at it intently. While Maria wasn't a mechanist or engineer, she did have an innate curiosity and appreciation for their craft. All of the spinning gears and flying chains and bouncing springs fascinated her, capturing her imagination in ways that sorcery could not.

Trying to understand magic as a non-magician was an exercise in futility: One could easily see that it was at work, but without years of study or a natural affinity, one could not see how or why it did. Machines were nothing like that: One could see that it worked, and with enough patience, would see how if the inner workings were laid bare. Pulling a lever could set a multitude of objects in motion, as if by magic... And yet, it was clear that it wasn't magic at all. And better yet, even Maria could pull that lever, if she wanted to; she'd find no such ease in summoning a ball of flame.

Maria reached out and flicked one of the gears, watching as it rotated. The pistons lazily extended, and the chain set another gear rolling, if only for a quarter of a centimeter. The orange vixen smiled. She placed her hand on the second gear and slid across it, getting a bit oily in the process. It was worth it, though, watching the machine work just a bit faster than it had. She continued to play with the machine, pulling on the pistons and spinning the gears until she heard a click.

"Oh! What did I do?" She scooted back a bit, thinking she'd broken it. Instead, however, it sprang to life... Almost instantly, in fact. The gears began to whir and hum and the pistons shot up and fell down rapidly; the machine was a blur of motion. "What did I do?" She looked on, watching the gizmo in action, still having no idea what the hell it did. She lowered herself to her knees and elbows, leaning in and getting closer to it, ass in the air.

A rustling sounded in the thicket, but Maria didn't hear it; she was paying too much attention to the machine. A moment later, a sizable party of strange, tiny humanoids emerged, each about as tall as Maria's hind-paws were long, but just a bit taller. They resembled opossums in body structure and coat, with fur-colors ranging from varying shades of gray, to black, with a few patches of brown thrown in. Their faces resembled that of a weasel's, apart from their eyes, a piercing red in color with yellow pupils, and two relatively long fangs on either side of their upper jaw. They didn't have much in the way of clothes, simply wearing brown loincloths with crude breastplates made from tiny bronze discs held together by bits of twine. They wielded weapons that were somewhat more impressive, though: Their little possum-claws were wrapped around the handles of something resembling tiny harpoon guns, all loaded with toothpick-sized spears. A smokey-gray one snarled as its eyes darted about.

"Ehjum skreek dul ku rahba!" it hissed.

"Dammit, Myrkis! What did I tell you about that 'Black Speech' crap? The Erpen speak English! We don't even understand the gibberish you're spouting, and I get the feeling that you don't, either!" a black one snapped in a somewhat squeaky voice.

"Sorry, Rellum..." Myrkis replied.

"It's alright... Now, what the hell did you think you were saying?" Rellum asked.

"Well, I said, 'Where is the creature that is tampering with our devices?'"

"Two things: First, that's more words than you even said..."

"Each of the spoken bits can mean more than one word, you know." Rellum shot Myrkis a dull glare.

"... Second, it's right there." Rellum motioned straight ahead, pointing at Maria's swaying backside and full, round hips.

"What the hell is it?"

"I dunno. 'Ours' sounds pretty good, though."

"It does, Rellum."

"I'm glad you agree, Myrkis." Rellum nodded. "Alright, then. We march ahead, fire on the beast, and then take our prey home. Charge!"

The party of fourteen erpen advanced on the orange vixen's ample ass, aiming their weapons upward at the center. Pulling the triggers, they let loose a volley of tiny harpoons... Most of which harmlessly bouncing off of Maria's leather armor. A stray harpoon did manage to strike the base of her tail, but did not penetrate whatsoever. "I hate bugs..." the vixen said idly as she waved her hand around her bushy tail, still unaware of the creatures behind her.

"Dammit, Kalx, your weapons are terrible!" Rellum growled.

"Sorry, Rellum," a fog-gray one replied. "You knew they were supposed to be experimental!"

"Bah! I'll just use my teeth... You all! Bind its legs... Kalx! Join me." Kalx nodded and followed Rellum up Maria's leggings, scrambling to reach the top as the other twelve threw twine around the vixen's shins, both efforts still unnoticed. Rellum's endeavor culminated in his arrival atop the vixen's right buttock, managing to stand even with the vixen's swaying. Kalx fell off on the way up, but a second attempt proved successful, joining Rellum at his perch.

"Now, what?" Kalx asked.

"Well, we figure out how to get past its armor... And then we attack!" Rellum said.

Kalx pointed at the waist of Maria's leggings. "How's about we pull that back?"

"Good thinkin', Kalx." The two erpens grabbed the vixen's loose-fitting waistband...
12523.title: The Hidden Gizmo

choices: "Sorry, but we just can't.  We'll come right back up for 'em, though."
"Eh, sure.  Why not?"
125232.content:
... And began to pull back, slowly, so as to not arouse the suspicion of their "prey," still enraptured by the whirring gears in front of her. Millimeter by millimeter, the vixen's leggings yielded the orange fur underneath. As the white fur of Maria's inner-thighs and inner-buttocks was revealed, though, they'd run out of room to pull. However, Rellum and Kalx had exposed more than enough of Maria's flesh; all that was left was to pick a target. They poked around, a bit, trying to find the softest spot, before deciding on the thickest part of each ass-cheek, right in their centers.

Rellum took the right 'cheek, dropping to his knees. He pointed over at the left 'cheek. Kalx took his cue, positioning himself just as Rellum had on the right. Rellum held up a claw, raising four of his fingers for a silent countdown. One lowered, and left three. Another curled right back into a fist, leaving two. Yet another fell, leaving one...

Meanwhile, the "ground team" were just finishing their job. They'd wrapped Maria's shins together with twine, nice and tight. They were surprised that their quarry had remained as still and "cooperative" as it had. They stepped back and admired their handiwork for a moment, after which they readied another loop of twine for Maria's arms. Back up top, Rellum's countdown concluded.

As the last finger lowered, Kalx and Rellum dove into their respective ass-cheeks, piercing the flesh with their sharp teeth. "Ow! Ow!" Maria cried. The shock of the attack sent her reeling; she rose up as she grabbed for her stinging buttocks, inadvertently dropping her pants the rest of the way to her ankles and revealing even more of her glorious ass, and fell to her side, where the ground team set to work binding her now-outstretched arms. Rellum and Kalx retreated from Maria's supple ass, jumping to the ground and watching the others do the rest of the work. They couldn't help but notice that the vixen's 'cheeks were swelling, a bit, though.

"Hmmm? What's goin' on with its ass?" Rellum asked.

Kalx slid his right claw up and down his right fang thoughtfully. "If I had to guess, I'd say that it's because we didn't wash our teeth off well enough after eating some of the 'Shrooms... And you know what they do to other creatures."

"Makes sense, I guess." Rellum watched the vixen squirm in her bindings as the ground team finished up. He approached the thrashing Maria's face.

"What the hell are you?" Maria asked.

"Ah, it speaks!" Rellum replied.

"You better let me go, or I'll throw you half-way across the forest..."

"Now, that's no way to talk to your new owners... You belong to us, now."

"Maria belongs to nobody!" Maria gnashed her teeth at the gloating Rellum, hoping that that, along with her words, would make her seem bad-ass. But alas, it did not. It's hard to look anything but ridiculous when you're tied up with your pants around your ankles. Rellum chuckled.

"Ah, but she does! Yes, the... Er... Creature..."

"Vixen. Female fox..."

"Thank you. Yes, the vixen does!" Rellum turned to the rest of the erpens. "Now, we pick her up and take her home..."

"No you don't!" Maria thrashed in her bindings, but only managed to exhaust herself. Twine was stronger than she thought, apparently.

"Done? Good." The erpens positioned themselves on either side of the vixen, thrusting their arms underneath her and lifting her up. They were stronger than she thought, too. The erpens marched out of the thicket, snagging some of Maria's clothing on hanging thorns. After a trip through the thicket and two right turns, the procession approached the wide mouth of a cave. The light grew dim as they proceeded inside, the only illumination coming from tiny torches on the walls.

"I didn't even know what the gears did!" Maria cried. "I'm sorry!"

"It doesn't matter now, uh... Uh... Vixen. You're ours!" Rellum replied. They passed a few erpens as they continued onward, most of which hammering on the walls with pickaxes. They stopped to gawk at Rellum's latest "haul," but got back to work immediately afterwards. As they approached the end of the pathway, they were met with a deep shaft with a pulley in the center, as well as a hunched-over black erpen standing next to three relatively-large baskets of purple mushrooms.

"Ah, hello, Rellum..." the erpen said in a hoarse, raspy voice. "I see you've made quite the find."

"Indeed, Jykle. We're gonna take it..."

"Her," Maria cut in.

"... Her down to the city; we'll figure out what to do with her, there."

"Excellent, excellent! ... Say, as long as you're going down, could you take the Liposhrooms with you? I brought everyone up here lunch, and they just say, 'No, Jykle, we don't want those.' And I tell 'em, 'Dammit, you'll eat if you're hungry.' And they say, 'But those are for livestock!' And I say, 'Well, hell, you're right!' Anyway, I've got three baskets of Cave-Pig feed... And I really don't wanna lug 'em back down. It'd be a waste to leave 'em up here, though..."

"I don't know, Jykle..." Rellum said. "I don't know if we can fit the vixen on the platform and three baskets."

"How 'bout you feed 'em to her?"

"But then she'd get really heavy. You know what those things do."

"Yeah, but... Fine. How about one basket? Save me some work, please."
125232.title: The Easiest Prey

choices: Welcome to the city of the erpen!
"This is where you stay until we figure something out..."
1252321.content:
"Sorry, but we just can't. We'll come right back up for 'em, though," Rellum said.

Jykle sighed. "You sure? You sure you can't take 'em with you now?"

"Yes, Jykle, I'm sure..." Rellum was becoming a bit annoyed with him. "It's hard enough to carry it right now..."

"Her." Maria snapped.

"... Carry her right now. If she was any heavier, we'd break our backs. You'll have to wait a bit, Jykle."

"Fine, fine..." Jykle shook his head. "The young people, today..."

Rellum just shook his head. "... Anyway. Put the vixen on the platform! We're goin' down!"

"Aye!" the others cried in unison, marching onto the wooden platform ahead of them. One pulled on a cord at the side, and the platform began to slowly descend down the shaft, the sound of sliding chains echoing all the while. For a minute or so, all that Maria could see was stone surrounding her in the darkness, with chains lifting and dropping all around.

The only thing that broke the monotony of her environment were the elevator's "stops." The first one showed Maria a big, round chamber, with the platform lying in the center. It branched out into several tunnels, where erpen laborers toiled. Some were mining, while others carried the the coal and iron ore that they'd found back to the hub. Still others lingered in the hub, their claws grasping chains that ran from floor to ceiling; the worked the elevator, and waited for Rellum's say-so to continue onward. The bound orange vixen noted that the area was well-lit; a stark contrast to the dim lighting in the above layer. Glowing white crystals lined the walls, each roughly two inches from the others beside it. Rellum nodded, signalling the elevator erpen. The erpen miners waved at Rellum and his party on the platform as they all descended even lower.

The next stop featured more of the same: A mining area, with miners, chains, and crystals. All that the erpen seemed to find, however, were lumps of tin. They continued to descend, each of the next three stops revealing more mines: Copper, silver, and zinc. The air grew warmer with each passing layer, and more humid.

The sixth stop revealed a rather unusual sight: What appeared to be a ranch. In the enormous chamber, erpen tended to strange, creatures, all of varying pastel colors. They resembled tiny swine, with their flat, disc-shaped snouts, plump bodies and cloven hooves. However, they certainly didn't behave like swine. They seemed to be rooting around the stony floor, but tended to stay rather still. Once in a while, they'd begin to lick the ground, swelling right before Maria's eyes. When they finish, an erpen would push them to another spot, where they'd stand, staring blankly ahead. At the back of the cavern, Maria spotted an even more unusual sight: In the cavern wall, the erpen had lodged an enormous specimen of the "Cave-Swine," one that was well over 20 times larger than all the rest of them. All Maria could see of it was its well-fatted buttocks; the other end was on the other side. As the orange vixen looked onward, a Cave-Swine emerged from between the two 'cheeks and plopped onto the cave floor, where it rolled over onto its hooves and joined the herd.

"Wha-?" Maria started.

"That's the Queen, over there... Not that it concerns you, vixen," Rellum said. "Why did we stop? Keep going!"

The "chain" erpens obeyed, and the platform plunged back into the darkness, coming down to the seventh stop. There were plenty of Cave-Swine standing about, albeit huddled together, but this wasn't a ranch. No, this was a slaughterhouse (or slaughter-cave, whatever). One by one, the swine were herded behind a wall, where each one would be sliced apart by an erpen with a knife into neat little chunks and piles of fat after getting their head lopped off. They didn't bleed, surprisingly, nor did they squeal. On the other side of the chamber were more of the swine, each getting loaded onto an odd machine one at a time, "sitting." A tube would descend from the device, which an erpen would jam into the swine's mouth. The same erpen would flick a switch, and the swine would inflate to a ridiculous size, becoming nearly spherical. It would be rolled over to another machine afterwards, which would puncture the swine's gut and begin to suck out the fat inside. The swine would squeal continuously as this happened, only stopping when it was completely empty and the machine withdrew. A dead, "deflated" swine would be left over, a pile of wrinkled hide, which would be taken away and placed in a pile to the side. Maria gulped; she hoped that any of this wasn't what the erpen had in mind for her...

Continuing the descent, all became dark...

"We're here!" Rellum shouted.
1252321.title: The Erpen Shaft

choices: There it is...  The body.
A trio of rather-menacing looking undead, standing about.
A...  Flower?
1253.content:
The vixen quickly pulled her muzzle down and cringed as her paws leap to her snout.

"Oh... Oh..." she muttered, as a foul stench assaulted her. "Oh, my... What on earth... Oh, is that..?"

Her stomach turned as she realized what she was smelling: The unmistakable stink of a decomposing body.

"Oh, no..." The vixen kept a paw on her sensitive nose as she took a few cautious steps forward. Did she even want to keep going? That's what an adventurer would do, after all. They'd forge onward, even if it meant seeing and smelling some deeply unpleasant... But, as Maria would often admit to herself, she wasn't a very good adventurer.

But turning back wouldn't do the fox much good. She'd already spent a day on this road, and she'd spend another simply going back the way she came with no towns or homesteads she could avail herself of for hospitality. If she was going to find somewhere to rest or eat, it'd be up ahead, and she'd just have to pretend that she was a good adventurer, and forge on.

The orange vixen resumed walking, grim thoughts filling her mind. Who, or what, met their end nearby? What grisly end did they meet?..

And what did they leave behind?

A few gears began to turn in Maria's head, and a shameful thought arose. Whatever they left behind, they mustn't need it anymore...

Was she really thinking that? That she'd simply loot a corpse?

The vixen sighed. Yes, yes she would. She had no money, and... Well, this is simply what adventurers do. Whether or not there was a... "Previous owner" nearby, they take things that they find in the wilderness for themselves.

The fox gingerly uncurled her paw from her muzzle, and took a cautious whiff, grimacing as the stench filled her nostrils once more. She could smell it coming from beyond a stand of trees, but couldn't see anything... But she was fairly close. She quickly returned her paw to her snout as she took a few careful steps off of the path and into the trees.

A dozen or so yards later found her nearing the other side. She could peer through some bushes between the trees and spy a clearing beyond, and at the edge of the clearing...
1253.title: A Morbid Stench

choices: A human.
An opossum.
12531.content:
The fox's blood ran cold as she saw it.

It wasn't nearly as grisly as she could have imagined, but all the same, she'd never wish to see it otherwise.

At the edge of the clearing beneath a shady tree was a sprawled corpse of as-yet undetermined species, its back to her. It wore a beige robe, and lying beneath an outstretched arm was a weapon lying in a spattering of blood.

Maria shuddered. As an adventurer, a warrior, no less, this sight shouldn't trouble her. She was trained to fight and kill, and when something dies, this is what is left behind. Somehow, though, this was different. This was no monster, but a regular person. It had done her no harm, and for all she knew, it had been murdered here. The fox took a moment to compose herself before she stepped out of the bushes and toward her "target."

She looked around as she crept forward, hoping she was otherwise alone, and not being watched by whatever left the corpse. She saw no such lurking murderers, and kept going.

As she got closer, she was better able to tell what the corpse was...
12531.title: The Morbid Source

choices: She's confronted by a passer-by, disgusted with the vixen.
The opossum herself has something to say about all of this.
125312.content:
Though the foul smell only strengthened as she closed the distance between them, Maria pressed on, and was able to get a better look at the body.

Before her lay a plump female opossum on its side, judging by the modest bust-line she could see over its shoulder, with a less-modest belly contouring the robe's fabric beside it. The vixen circled around to get a better look at the opossum's head. A long, white face, dark coloring circling two tightly-closed eyes, a pink nose at the end of a long snout, and sharp teeth visible inside of a closed jaw. A pair of pink, round ears crested her skull above her eyes, and she saw a small patch of the gray fur she'd assumed covered the rest of the 'possum's body between them. The 'possum's robe was closed, and she couldn't really tell.

The weapon Maria had spied earlier was now, quite clearly, a knife, lying beneath a black-furred arm ending in a pink-fingered claw.

Unfortunately for the fox, though, that was all she could really see; the opossum didn't seem to have anything on her besides her robe and the knife. But, as Maria knew, that didn't mean there wasn't anything she could take.

The fox began to gingerly pat down the 'possum, hoping to find a small bag or some other concealed storage, but found none. To her own disdain, she remembered: Opossum women had pouches...

Maria grimaced at the thought of actually probing a reeking corpse in search of that pouch and what it might hold, but... She was already here, she was already thinking about it... And she did see a small stream nearby she could wash her paws in afterward...

The vixen sighed as she knelt down and parted the 'possum's robe to get at her belly. It was gray, just as she suspected, and more than a little padded. It wasn't... Bloated, as she'd expect, which she found more than a little strange. In fact, as she reluctantly felt-up the body, she didn't notice any visible rot. Thinking about things made Maria sick, though, so she returned to the task at hand, lifting the belly to find the pouch underneath, above the 'possum's loin. As she slipped her fingers in, she was startled by a voice from nearby.
125312.title: The Didelphimorphic Dead

choices: I believe introductions are in order.
Or a confrontation, if you really think that's appropriate.
1253122.content:
"Excuse me..." a voice hissed in Maria's ear. "Just what do you think you're doing?!"

The vixen froze solid. She frantically looked around for the source of the voice before it spoke again. "What makes you think you can put your fingers in there?!"

Maria's head slowly turned to the opossum's, which had already turned towards hers. The opossum's eyes had opened, glaring golden eyes upon her, and her mouth had parted in a snarl to reveal the sharp teeth within.

"N-no..." the vixen stammered in shock. Tears welled in her eyes and she quickly withdrew her probing paw as she broke down at the thought of being confronted by a zombie. The apparent-zombie's claw darted forth from above the knife and shoved the vixen away, wasting no time in getting the upper hand as she quickly leapt atop the stunned fox, who had by now broken down in hysterics.

"That is a private area. You do not get to touch me there... Unless you buy me dinner." The "zombie" giggled at her own remark before she took a moment to look over the fox, who had taken her unrestrained paws and covered her eyes instead of attempting to push herself away as she half-screamed, half-sobbed.

"Goodness, are... Are you alright? Calm down..." The 'possum shook her a little, but that only made her cry harder. The opossum sighed as she got up off of the fox and looked at her pitifully. "Is this what you do every time you get called out for molesting people?"

"What... W-what are you?.." Maria stammered between sobs.

"Are you stupid..? I'm an opossum, haven't you ever seen..?" She stopped as she realized what was going on and burst into laughter. "You... You've never seen an opossum-"

"Don't laugh at me!" the vixen shouted, finding a bit of composure... Only to lose it again once the "zombie" sprung forward, getting in her face. She broke down back into sobbing as the opossum spoke again.

"You've never seen an opossum play dead?" The opossum kept laughing, as this was apparently very funny to her. Of course, it wasn't for Maria, still wracked in mortal terror... Which gradually made the whole situation less entertaining for the opossum. "... Okay, I guess you've never seen an opossum play dead."

The opossum took a moment to lift the vixen up and rest her against a tree as she kept sobbing, sighing before she resumed speaking. "Calm down. Calm down. I'm alive. Take a deep breath..." The vixen did as she was told, surprisingly, and the opossum threw an arm around her back, feeling the hard metal blade sheathed there. "Is... Is that a sword? You're a warrior? You're a warrior, and you break down sobbing when..? You know what, never mind. Just calm down." The opossum began patting the vixen's shoulder, and the two of them stayed like that for a while as the vixen came down from her hysterics.

"I- I..." Maria began, before being hushed by the opossum.

"Shhhhh. No talking. Just keep trying to calm down..."

Eventually, the both of them were completely silent as Maria regained her composure.
1253122.title: The Talking "Dead"

choices: "Sure..."
Maria stays behind.  Why on earth would you follow her?
12531221.content:
As the excruciatingly awkward encounter wound down and the ensuing silence took hold, the opossum spoke.

"So..." she began, removing her arm from the fox's shoulder. "Mind telling me who you are?.. And why you thought it was a good idea to stick your fingers in what you seem to have thought was a corpse?"

"I... I thought you'd have something valuable... Down there," the vixen began. "My name is Maria... I'm a warrior, I suppose."

"I see..." The opossum rose from her position next to Maria and waddled over to the bloody knife that she'd left a few feet away. The vixen watched her nervously as she plucked it off the ground and began turning it over in her hand. "You're a warrior, and not a thief..?"

"Y-yeah... I was desperate, that's all. And who are you?"

"Call me Lilac... I'm... Nominally, a cleric."

"Okay..." The vixen inhaled, and gagged, as her attention was brought back to the stench that lured her here. "If you're not dead, why do you smell like that?"

"Smell like..?" Lilac paused and made an appraising sniff. "Oh. Oh, boy... That's... That's embarrassing." The opossum darted behind a tree and began fumbling about beneath her robes.

"It must be. What is it? What are you doing?"

Lilac presented a large, stained pair of cotton panties to the disgusted vixen. "Uh... These. Opossums have an... Unfortunate tendency to release some, uh, fluid from our... Asses... When we play dead. I'm certainly not wearing these anymore," the 'possum said, punctuating her explanation by flinging the garment into the woods behind her. Both her and Maria watched in discomfort as it caught on a tree branch a few feet away. "... Well. I'm going to go find a creek to wash off in." Lilac stepped out from behind the tree and wandered off past the still-sitting Maria. "I guess you can come with me, if you'd like."
12531221.title: Introductions

choices: The two return to the clearing where they'd met.
They come to a campsite...  Presumably Lilac's.
125312211.content:
The pair stop at the stream Maria had spied earlier. It wasn't a particularly fast stream, as could attest the reeds gently swaying on its bank... Nor was it a particularly deep stream, its pebbled bottom visible in the dimming sunlight. Thus, it was perfectly well-suited for a pudgy opossum to wash the "ass fluid" from her legs and tail.

Lilac wasted no time tossing her robe onto the shoreline and wading in, unceremoniously plopping down in the middle. The vixen set herself down on the shore, gingerly dipping her hindpaws into the gentle stream... Taking special care to remain upstream from Lilac. The water was colder than she'd expected, no doubt about it, but after some time on the road, a bit of a soak couldn't hurt for her aching paws.

Minutes pass as Maria awkwardly peddles her feet in the water and Lilac prods at her lower half to give the stream as good a chance as it could to carry away the remnants of the foul-smelling fluid. Occasionally, they glanced at each-other, but no conversation was shared... Until Maria happened to notice the opossum spreading her thighs, exposing her nethers. The fox grimaced.

"Oh, never seen a vagina before?" the opossum teased.

"I- I have! I've seen lots- No, I mean... Don't you feel... Uncomfortable, displaying yourself like that in front of a stranger?"

"Oh? Why?" Lilac glanced down at her pussy beneath the water. "Is it deformed or something?"

"No, it's... It's just immodest."

The opossum mockingly brought a paw to her cheek, feigning bashfulness. "Oh, no..." That same paw came down on the water with a slap a moment later, followed by a derisive chuckle. "I don't really care that much for modesty, my dear."

"Oh, um. Okay." Maria looked away in discomfort.

Lilac sighed. "It's alright... I'm almost done washing 'her' out... There we go. All tucked away. Better?"

"Y-yeah..."

"Sorry to make you uncomfortable," the opossum said, with genuine sheepishness.

"It's alright, I guess."

Moments passed in silence as Lilac finished her wash and Maria stared down at her feet.

The opossum, having attended to business, sidled up to the stream bank to get a bit closer to Maria. Lounging on the sandy shore, she struck up a proper conversation.

"So..." Lilac began. "What brings you out here? Adventuring?"

"I suppose." Not much point in telling her her life story, right?

"Mmmm."

"And you?"

"About the same, I guess. I'd probably call it 'wandering,' though." The opossum began playing with a nearby reed, bending it between her fingers.

"... Same here."

"Yeah?"

"There really isn't a lot to do around here, lately." The vixen twiddled her thumbs. "I was heading to the next town over... Wherever that is."

"Sounds about right."

"So, what happened to you?"

"What do you mean?"

"I mean-"

Maria was interrupted by a loud growl. Normally, this would have alarmed the vixen-- Alarmed anybody, really-- and she'd leap to her feet, ready to attack... Had that growl not come from her own stomach.

The opossum chuckled. "Wow, it sounds like somebody hasn't eaten in weeks!"

"Well, a couple days, anyway..." Maria blushed and looked away.

"Shhh, shhh, it's okay. No sense being embarrassed about it." Lilac rose to her feet and padded over to her robe. "Only one thing for it, of course. Let's get you fed."

"Well..."

"Come on, now. Follow me." The opossum slipped her beige robe over her head and plodded away, gesturing at Maria.

The fox sighed and did as she was told. No sense passing up a meal...
125312211.title: A Bit of a Soak

choices: They continue deeper into the caves...
They're jumped by some odd creatures!
They trigger a trap!
They become seperated!
They hear a crying girl...
13.content:
The wolfess was sweating by the time she had opened the stone doors leading to the cave, a difficult task, even for a girl of her strength, and she was relieved to get out of the relentless, hot sun. She was a large, muscular, anthropomorphic wolf with light gray fur and blond hair, clad only in brown leather top and pants, thick leather gloves, and tough leather boots. She set down her massive, iron axe, engraved with runes and half as big as a man. Her partner she had brought along for this mission slipped in behind her as she sat down on a slap, her fur soaked and her tongue lolling out as she panted.

The man who accompanied her was a skinny guy dressed in black, leather armor and wielding two daggers. He was a rogue or a thief, one of those sneaky types if she could recall his profession (She, on the other hand, preferred direct confrontation). She stood up as he began to speak, towering over him.

"Sorry to say this Miss, but I didn't quite get yer name back at the Explorer's Guild, what was it again?"

The wolf girl cocked her head and replied, "Oh yes, my name is Johanna."

"Ah.... Yohonna! So you must be from the Northlands... Name's Richard by the way," He said, scratching his chin

She rolled her eyes.

"Yes, what was your first clue, now lets get this done with."

She picked up her gigantic axe, and walked deeper into the tunnels, the rogue following....
13.title: Johanna, a strong barbarian wolfess

choices: Left
Straight
Right
131.content:
Meanwhile, further into the caverns, deep in dark chambers which have never seen the light of day, something horrendously old and horrendously wicked stirred. Horribly emaciated fingers reached out of the darkness towards a softly glowing orb of glass, pulling it closer so it may study it more intimately. As the sickly luminescence drew closer to the creature's face, it was reflected in its unblinking eyes like two little skulls. He grinned hungrily as he peered into the depths of the crystal sphere, seeing the visitors as they arrived through the door. It had been quite a long time since he had felt pleasure, and this was a pleasant surprise indeed...

---

The two adventurers continued deeper into the tunnels, lighting torches as it became darker. They had come searching for treasure, a long lost trove that had fallen into legend, but was rumored to be in these very caves. Both were members of the local Exploration Guild, so both had been around the block a few times, yet there was still something different about the place, and the man and wolf could feel it.

It didn't comfort either at all when the tunnels suddenly split off into three directions.

"Hmm...." Johannna pondered, leaning against the wall, "We'll have to split up if we want to cover this whole place..."

Richard looked up at her as if she were mad, "Split up! What if there are traps, or one of us gets captured or..."

"The man we asked about this place told us it was abandoned," she said, placing her paw on his head and tussling his hair teasingly, "Besides, I thought you were sneaky?"

She ignored his grumbling as she decided in which direction to go...
131.title: Minor Setback?

choices: She kept moving forward.
1313.content:
Johanna chose the tunnel to the right.
"See ya at the end of the line," she purred, disappearing into the inky black. She soon realized this tunnel was different from the others.
Cold, sharp protrusions irritated her thick, padded paws and the smell was foreign to even her sensitive nose. Fearless, she continued forward in spite of these peculiarities. In the distance, from which direction she could not tell, she heard a screech. She pricked her ears and scanned for the way, but the noise seemed to come from nowhere and everywhere all at once. Her heightened and usually very useful senses were failing her in this place and that caused her hackles to rise and her nostrils to flare and search the air, deeper intakes of the atmosphere yielding nothing that could enlighten her.
1313.title: Right

choices: He solved the puzzle in five minutes
He solved the puzzle in half an hour
He couldn't solve the puzzle
133.content:
The dark cave had an ominous feel to it as Johanna and Richard walked deeper into the belly of the beast. There seemed to be an anonymous light source as the walls of the cave were never completely dark, but dark enough for Johanna to not see the vine that was used as a tripwire. Both of them gasped as walls quickly dropped behind and in front of them.

"You know, as a wolf you should have seen that" commented Richard, receiving a growl from the wolf girl.

There was a slight "glorp glorp" sound as a brown viscous liquid was being pumped into the room. Richard quickly panicked while Johanna glanced around the chamber and noticed several circular stones on the wall arranged so it looked like a target.

"Hey Richard, stop hyperventilating and look at this" Johanna barked before dragging Richard towards the strange symbol.

"Well, it actually looks like some kind of a puzzle" Richard deducted as he spun the rings, "I'm really good at puzzles, but it might take a while and we might be dead when this... oddly sweet smelling mud comes up to drown us... wait, do you think that?"

"Maybe" Johanna said as she stuck her finger at the brown goop, which has already traveled up to their knees, before giving it a taste. "Wait, this is FUDGE!"

"Good, good, then you can eat it and maybe I can still see the puzzle longer before it gets covered up by the fudge"

Johanna sighed saying, "well, if it's necessary" before she began lapping up at the fudge adding, "you owe me big time for this Richard."

Though the fudge was rising very quickly which meant that the wolf had to start eating fast.

Will Richard solve the puzzle?
133.title: They trigger a trap!

choices: The pair encounter a strange monster.
Johanna finds a peculiar item.
They meet another explorer who has already fallen victim to the Lipomancer.
1331.content:
As Johanna started wolfing down the fudge, Richard began his attempt to decipher the puzzle.

"Maybe if I...no, that doesn't work...perhaps I could..." Richard mused, running his hands over the stone symbol.

"We...don't...have...all day!" Johanna interrupted, pausing between mouthfuls to get the words out. She couldn't eat quickly enough to stop the flow, but if she kept at it, she could slow it down sufficiently and buy Richard a few minutes. She was surprised to find that the fudge was not only fresh, but downright delicious. She had to focus to keep from losing herself in the flavor.

"Just give me a second to work this out!" Richard snapped back, and returned his attention to the puzzle. The fudge was now about waist high. "Hey, I think I recognize these ruins." Richard said hopefully, kneeling slightly to get a better look at the details of the symbol. "That means, if I do this..."

Johanna heard a click, and the trap's mechanism went quiet. However, her mind failed to fully register this, and she continued lapping up the fudge. "Uh...Johanna..." She suddenly felt a light tap on her shoulder. "What?" she snarled, whipping her head away from the chocolate goop.

Richard jumped back about a foot, or tried to, but the fudge was still impeding his movement. "...You can stop now." he said sheepishly. The walls had already begun to rise, and the remainder of the fudge was dispersing through the hall. "Oh...looks like you are good for something." she said in an almost apologetic tone, and stood up straight. "I can't take all the credit. Without you here, my shirt would have gotten dirty." Richard replied with a chuckle, having regained his composure.

"Yeah, yeah. Let's just keep moving." Johanna said, lifting her foot out of the inch of remaining fudge. "I don't know who would make a trap like that...usually they use water or poison or something, and the puzzles are much harder."

"It's almost like they didn't want to kill us, only slow us down." Richard said, his attention now devoted to searching for more traps. "Well, let's just hope we don't run into any monsters for a while. I'm too bloated to do any serious moving right now." Johanna muttered, looking down at her now tighter top, which she now noticed was covered in spilled fudge. "My stomach feels like it's going to burst.'
1331.title: He solved the puzzle in five minutes

choices: A large slime!
A golem creature composed entirely out of food?
13311.content:
Johanna had to admit, it wasn't easy navigating the twisting passageways of this place, especially with a belly taught and full of fudge. She placed a paw on the stretched leather of her armor, a little bit worried as she felt her distended stomach gurgle through. Yet even more worrying was how eagerly she licked at the fudge still left on her paws and covering her clothes. Richard looked back seeing her lapping at a spot on the back of her paw.

"You alright? Need a break or something?"

Johanna looked up, masking her surprise with a growl, "I'm perfectly capable of carrying on, I'm just not used to being in such... a condition, if you really wanted to know..." She said, glancing back down at her painfully swollen middle.

Just then, they were both alerted to a strange noise from further down the tunnel, but unfortunately its source was shrouded from view by the darkness. Johanna placed her paw on Richard's shoulder, pressing a clawed digit to her lips before the two of the cautiously crept forward, coming face-to-face with...
13311.title: What was that?

choices: Gassed! Our heros are knocked out and captured.
They dodge a trap or two and enter a large room.
133111.content:
....Nothing? As Johanna poked her head around the corner in front of them, she was astounded by what seemed like a still empty tunnel.The long passageway was well lit with periodic torches. As far as she could see, nothing was there. Stepping out around the curb, she turned back to face her companion.


"I wonder what caused that?"


However, it was at that point that she felt what she assumed was a drop of water fall on top of her muzzle. Touching it with her paw, it turned out to be a slightly sticky, thick liquid. Looking up, she found her partner staring, jaw agape, with a lone finger pointing to a spot right above her head.


"It's right above me, isn't it?"


She barely had time to notice Richard nod before it struck. She braced herself for the impact.

============================================================================ ================================


Richard could only watch as Johanna was enveloped in what could only be described as a giant, yellow, blob. It fell from the ceiling, giving off a low roar, and swallowed the wolfess whole.

He flinched. Richard was not the brave type. Sure he was smart, and had the knack for stealth and pickpocketing, but direct confrontation was not his strong point. But after a moment of nothing he opened his eyes.

Whatever it was, it was just sitting there. Blocking the hallway, it had Johanna in the middle, and it looked like she was unconscious. Richard knew there was no way he was getting past this thing alone. He had to get Johanna out of there and fast. Luckily it looked as if the impact had created an air bubble around her head, allowing for her to breath, if only for a short amount of time, while he tried to rescue her.

Stepping up, he took out his dagger. The creature, if you could call it that, did not move or strike. It just sat there, like it was waiting for something. With a loud cry, he struck at it. At first the weapon went nicely through the beast, but it soon stuck fast. Try as he might, Richard was unable to pull it free. Suddenly, the thing gurgled, and began to suck his dagger into its midst. Yelping, the rouge quickly withdrew his hand.

"That was too close. A little slower and I'd be stuck in there too! Normal weapons don't work, but there's got to be a way to free her. THINK!"

It was then that he noticed a small object at the far end of the slime. It was a rune, engraved with and odd symbol he had never seen before. It was glowing a faint orange, which was difficult to pick out from the body of the slime itself.

"Ah Ha! That MUST be wha'ts holding the creature together! I can't get to it, but maybe Johanna can! But how can I wake her though?"

It was then that the idea hit him. It was risky, but it was the only plan that he had. Maybe a smoke bomb could jar the creature just enough to wake the wolfess without injuring his partner. Taking a bomb from his satchel, he lit it and threw it into the side of the leviathan. All that was left was to wait.

Richard noticed, as the fuse burnt, that the creature was moving more of itself to the space between the bomb and Johanna.

"What's it doing? Does it realize the danger it poses to her? It's trying to keep her alive???"
============================================================================ ================================

With a muffled pop, the bomb went off, sending a wave through the semi-liquid creature. As it passed the wolfess, her eyes slowly began to open.


Her head was pounding. "Ugh, I feel as if a 50 pound brick fell on my head. What happened." She tried to move her arms and legs. Nothing happened. It was almost as something was enveloping her....

Then it hit her. The Creature!!! Her eyes snapped open as she struggled to move. Then, she heard a muffled voice coming from somewhere around her. Looking out, she could see Richard waving his arms with an obvious look of relief on his face. Then, he started pointing to something on her right. Straining to turn her head, she managed to see what she assumed was some sort of rune caught in the middle of the beast.

"Obviously it's important, but how can I get to it? My arms are stuck, my legs can't move, all I can do is turn my head. I have to use my head to get to the rune."

Thinking back to the fudge trap, she remembered lapping up the fudge as it poured into the room.

"That's it! If I can't go to it, I'll try to bring it to me!"

Cautiously she stuck her muzzle into the goop. Sticking her tongue out, she tasted it. And it was delicious!

"It almost tastes like Honey!"

Slowly but surely, the wolf girl began to suck at the goo, with every mouthful bringing the glowing orb closer to her. Unfortunately for her, since she had to eat quite a lot of it to get to it. Doggedly, she slurped, coming up every so often for air. Eventually, after about 10 minutes, she was able to get the orb in her mouth.

"Maybe if I destroy this thing, I can destroy this blob, but hopefully not with me in it!"

Biting down hard, Johanna managed to crack, and then break the glowing rock. The Slime around her gave out a loud roar, and let go of its hold on her body. Quickly, the slime disintegrated, melting into the ground around her. Happy for the fresh air, Johanna laid down panting against the tunnel wall, covered in the sticky remains of her captor.

"Johanna! Are you okay?!?"

Richard quickly ran across the tunnel, kneeling next to her.

"I'm fine Rich, I'm fine."

"Thank the god's! That must have been awful!"

"It was quite an experience, and I'd hope not to go through it again."

"Yeah, I bet! It's weird though. I'm not sure that...thing...tried to harm you. When I tried to wake you up with my smoke bomb, it seemed like it tried to protect you..."

"Is that so?" said Johanna, lifting an eyebrow. "If that were true would it have caught me to begin with?"

"I guess not..."

"Hey, I'm just happy that I got through this unharmed."

"Well," said Richard smiling, "I think we had one casualty."

"And what's that?"

Grinning from ear to ear, Richard reached down and, much to the suprise of Johanna, managed to pat her now exposed belly. She had consumed so much slime that it had burst clean through her leather armor. Johanna groaned. Using both arms, she reached down and hefted up her now quite rotund stomach.

"Oh my lord! I'm like a tiger balloon!"

As she picked up her belly, her hands pressed into the soft surface. It was if she had a big ball of tiger dough attached to her middle. With a grunt, she tried to stand up. It needed little more effort than it should have. She stumbled, trying to maintain her balance. Richard leaned down and poked her new gut with a finger, leaving a depression that slowly filled out.

"Stop that!"

Johanna smacked his hand away.

"Come on, we've got to keep going."

"Keep going? How can you keep going in you condition?"


"I'll manage. Come on, let's get going. The tunnel widens out up ahead."

Richard could only shake his head, marveling at the wolfess's determination. Slowly, he turned, jogging to catch up.
133111.title: Sticky Situation

choices: Navigate the maze and risk any possible traps.
Eat the direct route through the walls.
1331112.content:
Towards the end of the tunnel they dodged a flooding trap consisting of transparent walls of magic which filled with something white and watery. When it finished filling, the walls came down and the fluid flooded the tunnel floor before draining away through what was found to be an illusionary patch of floor leading to a sloping tunnel. As the liquid drained away, Richard tasted some and reported it to be milk. Upon waving his hand through the patch of the floor the milk drained into, the illusion vanished and a mouth-watering scent wafted up the tunnel. Well, at least for Richard it was. Joanna was too full to find the scent of any food anything other than nauseating.

Deciding not to take any chances with the tunnel in the floor, they continued to the large doors at the end of the main tunnel.

Stepping through them, they found themselves in a room fifty metres square and at least ten high, apparently empty.

The moment the doors slammed shut behind them the whole room was bathed in a blinding yellow light. About thirty seconds later, their vision cleared up and although they couldn't see anything different, the could certainly feel something different. Joanna no longer felt stuffed full. In fact, she was feeling a little bit hungry. Richard, however, was doubled over clutching his stomach as if in pain.

"Are you alright?" enquired Joanna.

"Oh, I'm fine apart from the fact I'm absolutely starving!" moaned Richard somewhat pitifully.

While neither of them could have known this, their stomach capacities had been increased eight-fold without otherwise affecting them.

As if the room had been listening, a red pattern of a maze appeared on the floor and over several seconds a five-metre wall grew up on the pattern.

Joanna tried to climb the wall, but the surface was simply too soft to get a grip and she slid back down to the floor, collecting handfuls of red goop along the way. She tasted some and promptly spat it out again. Whatever it was, it was both very sweet and very sour and had an unidentifiable fruity flavour to it.
