13333.title: A Noble Sacrifice.

choices: Ignore the begger woman and procede to the dungeon.
Investigate the old begger woman.
14.content:
Mara had always been a rather lean elf, her body weighed only 90lbs which was very skinny for her 6ft frame though this body shape was quite common for elves who'd rather stick their noses in books of magic than elves who would go out hunting or questing. Even though Mara herself did go questing she'd mainly use magic from her hands or staff that she carried around everywhere, her mages outfit consisted of a long flowing navy blue robe that had many bits of intricate gold thread weaved here and there, it was very baggy on her thin, skinny body but she was used to it as it was quite light and comfortable. Her hair was a long flowing red with a small bobbled ponytail in the centre, her face was sleek and slender and her eyes were a glistening silver which gave her a very mysterious and magical look about her which was very true.

Her best friend and adventuring companion was a big burly dwarf engineer by the name of Grungor, he was a stout dwarf weighing about 160lbs which made him very wide and round on his 4ft 11" frame, he was a jolly dwarf that liked nothing more than drinking ale and building his guns. Grungor was very adept at traps as well plus he always carried a big two handed axe so he was very useful to someone like mara who was not so good with either traps or combat but what she was good at was magic and runes. Grungor had many scars over his face and had even lost his left eye which he covered up with a eyepatch, his hair was long and white as was his beard which reached his knees, on his back he carried a musket called "Old Flintshot" which was the first gun he'd ever made and still as good as it was around 50 years ago. Grungor was about 100 which was rather middle aged in dwarf terms as they lived upto 200 or more, Mara on the other hand was a very young 20 which was almost childlike to the elder elf age of over 300, but she had the body of a late teen early twenties look about her which matched her age.

One day, the pairing heard of a great dungeon which supposedly held vast riches and many great and powerful arcane artifacts, so the pair decided to seek it out. Halfway through their journey they came accross an old beggar woman who had a strange presence about her.
14.title: Mara, a cunning elf mage

choices: She delivers to them a warning.
She gives them food as repayment for Mara's generosity.
The two are ambushed while being distracted by the old woman.
142.content:
"Please, oh noble travelers!" The ancient, destitute woman pleaded, "Have some kindness? Spare a few copper for a poor old wretch..."

Grungor only scoffed as the pathetic beggar knelt before the pair, coughing and wheezing, her long, gray, dirty hair hiding the majority of her face. Mara, on the other hand, was touched by the beggar's plight, and decided to pull out her coin pouch to appease the crone.

This only caused the dwarf to grumble even more, and while he wanted to stop his companion, he simply turned a blind eye as she dropped a handful of coins into the old woman's grasping hands.

"Oh thank you my fair, sweet, dear kind lady!" She squealed, licking and kissing the metal currency a little too fondly.

"Of course elder, I am always quite happy to aid those in dire circumstances!" Mara replied, smiling widely as she beckoned Grungor to follow her further down the path.

As they left the beggar, Grungor cleared his throat loudly. Mara stopped, having noticed her friend's consternation earlier she knew that he had something to say about the matter.

"Gods-dammit lass! You know we don't have that much coin ourselves! Hell, I bet ya' my cousin's farm she was better off than we are!"

Mara sighed, feeling like a child scolded, as she usually did whenever Grungor lectured her, "I know Grungor, I know... but I just can't help feeling sorry for these people. Did you see all the empty houses and ranches we passed since the last town? Clearly this part of the world suffers, and if I had any chance, I would take it to ease that pain."

"Now don't give me any of your tree-lovin' elf crap! I know it's just because you were guilted into it, but I've seen enough of these types to know that that crone was acting. Something tells me she was foolin' us, she probably wasn't even homeless!"

"Then maybe she should be rewarded for her skillful deception?" Mara said, grinning as she noticed the aggravation on the dwarf's face. The two argued quite a bit, but to Grungor's frustration Mara never quite took the arguments seriously.

But then Mara's smile faded rather quickly and placed a hand in front of Grungor's chest to signal him to stop moving, putting her other hand's index finger to her lips.

And then the dwarf hear what had stopped the elf dead in her tracks, a faint shouting coming from the direction they just left from. They both turned to see the beggar from before running as fast as a withered old woman could.

"Wait! Wait, wait, wait, wait!" She howled, her voice hoarse and sore from her repeated screaming.

The two stood there, not having moved regardless of what the beggar had said.
142.title: Investigate the old begger woman.

choices: They head north immediately, following the crone's advice.
They decide to stop at a nearby village, hoping to get more information.
They make camp for the night, debating their next move.
1421.content:
"Wait..." The crone begged, out of breath, on her hands and knees, "You are heading towards the forest?"

"Hmm? The Waxing Woods ya mean? Aye, that's where we were headed through..."

"But it's dangerous! Filled with horrible creatures, even the trees are said to be wicked in there! You mustn't go..."

"But our destination is said to lie within! An ancient vault of wealth and power said to have been sealed long ago."

"Dammit yeh runt! Don't be telling everyone about the treasure!" Groaned Grungor, "They'll be wanting it for themselves!"

"Oh! No, no young elf, if you're looking for the vault then you won't find it in there... no, what you're trying to find is to the northeast, not in a forest but under a town."

Grungor stomped his foot in protest, pointing an accusing finger at the crone "Hold on you! How do we know yer tellin' the truth?"

The old woman reached into one of the folds of her robes and pulled out a coin. Yet it wasn't one of the ones given to her by Mara, nor was it any other common kind of currency the two had seen in these lands before. The coin looked as though it were made of gold, though it seemed quite a bit shiny for just an ordinary gold piece, and then there was the logo stamped on its face: A single watching eye.

"I have been there myself, back when I wasn't so old and weak..."

Mara stuck her tongue out at Grungor and chuckled, "You see? Maybe you should be more trusting friend... now how do we find this village?"

"Just follow the road that leads north..." She whispered, "Follow the signposts to Pighaven... that's where the vault you seek lies."
1421.title: She delivers to them a warning.

choices: Mara and Grungor arrive at Pighaven at dusk. The village is eager to host them.
Mara and Grungor are ambushed by a nefarious servant of the Lipomancer!
14211.content:
Grungor's beard bristled with envy. Stoic and stubborn, the Dwarf refused to believe this suspicious crone's words. That was until she showed them the coin. Simply breathtaking in craftsmanship, and the quality of the gold was unlike any he'd ever seen. While the witch gave instructions to Mara, the greedy Grungor ogled the eye-stamped coin, engrossed by his kind's innate lust for wealth. It was just so damn beautiful!

"Grungor, did you get all that?" Mara prodded the Dwarf's cheek with a slender finger. He shook his head clear of the fog, darting his gaze between the two women. The crone seemed much more relaxed in their company, and Mara waited with a hand on her hip. "Well?"

"Ah, erm... no. Where did you find that magnificent artifact? Is there any more treasure like that? Tell us!" Like a child in a candy shoppe, Grungor struggled against the urge to seize the coin for himself. He was absolutely enchanted by its unnatural shimmer. Mara slapped a palm to her forehead and turned back to the beggar.

"I apologize for my companion's foolishness. I don't know what's come over him..." The short elf smiled, flashing her pearly whites to the old crone. "Oh well! Must be a Dwarf thing." Now looking back to Grungor, the mage pointed Northeast toward a much more amiable path. "See? This is a far better lead than that creepy, empty forest."

Stubbornness trumped by greed, the Dwarf nodded with sheer excitement. "Aye, that it is. If there be more treasure like that lovely piece o' art, count me in!" Hefting his old rifle onto his shoulder, Grungor began his march down the road, completely oblivious to the twinkle in the old crone's eye. His elven companion was even less aware of the beggar's true intentions.

"You have my thanks, stranger. May your path be one of joy and happiness." With that, the novice mage bowed lightly and jogged after the tenacious treasurehunting Dwarf. Behind them, the old woman snickered and tucked the coin back into her sleeve. She simply watched the pair stroll off around the winding path.

"The master will be most pleased..." And with that, she slunk back into the shadows beneath the treeline.
14211.title: North by Northeast

choices: Some type of sludge creature ambling towards Mara's sleeping form!
Something else entirely.
14213.content:
Following the crones advice, the duo made there way north to the town of Pighaven. But, before they began their long journey, Mara and Grungor stopped alongside the road in a clearing of trees to make camp for the night, not wanting to risk the dangers of traveling in darkness. Mara quickly had a toasty fire set up with her magic, and Grungor had managed to capture and kill a couple hares to eat.

As Grungor prepared the hares for roasting, Mara turned to him and said, "Do you believe what the crone told us? That the treasure we are looking for lies underneath a town in a giant vault?". Grungor just glanced at Mara, then spoke in his gruff voice, "I don't trust her, but, what else have we got to lose, eh? Hell, I'd rather make my way to a town then walk through a musky old forest anyways..."

Mara just left the conversation at that and stared at the roasting hares, taking note of the muscular structure and tissue of the two animals as they cooked.

After a few moments, the hares were ready to be eaten, and Grungor passed one over to Mara. Grungoer dug inside his travel pack and pulled out a wooden case of various spices. He pinched a little between his fingers and spread it onto the hare. As he was about to take a bite, he noticed Mara staring at him.

"Well, are you going to share, or not?" stated the stern looking elf. A disappointed look crossed Grungor's face, as he was almost out of his specialty dwarven spices he had brought with from his homeland.

"...Ehh, only for you Mara." said Grungor as he passed the wooden case over to her. Mara's cold demeanor disappeared with a warm, cheering smile as she laughed at the dwarf.

"Thank you." said Mara as she dipped her head down in traditional elvish fashion as a sign of thanks. Grungor just lightly grunted as he enjoyed his hare. Mara followed his example and did the same.

**************************


Sometime in the middle of the night, Grungor sat up from his wool cot as he heard a rustling sound coming from behind them. He quickly armed his trusty gun, Old Flintshot, and warily aimed out into the dark landscape. He gazed over the area, trying to find any sign of motion, but could not see a thing.

"Hmm...It be just the wind..." whispered Grungor to himself as he lowered his rifle.

Just then, he heard another sound from behind, and quickly turned to discover the source of the commotion.

"Gotcha!....What in the name of..." gasped Grungor as he took in the site of...
14213.title: A Warm Fire, and an Unknown Threat

choices: The sun rises, along with Mara's weight.
Something else happens.
142131.content:
Some type of sludge creature! Without hesitation, Grungor lifted up his gun and aimed for what seemed to be the creatures head. When he knew he was right on target, he squeezed the gun's trigger and watched as the slug flew through the air to make contact with the odd creature. As the bullet neared closer and closer to the creature, it morphed it's figure and the bullet passed through a hole that materialized on the thing. Grungor just stood there, speechless as the creature continued to the still sleeping Mara.

"How in the hell is she still sleeping? My shot should have woken her!" thought Grungor frantically in his head. Just then, as he aimed for another shot at the thing, he was knocked down onto his feet by another unknown enemy. He quickly tried to get up, but to no avail as he was forced back down as a cloaked figure pointed their deadly looking sword at the dazed dwarf.

"I knew you two would fall into my trap. You know, you should never trust strangers..." said the figure as they removed their hood.

Grungor gasped as he took in the face of the old beggar lady standing before him. "Wha-? You? Why are ye doing this?!" shouted Grungor. The beggar lady simply smiled and cackled, an evil sound that could be represented by cuddly animals being killed, or a famine falling over a crop. "Because my master wills it!"

As Grungor sat trying to make sense of all this, the sludge creature was now covering Mara's face, her mouth unwillingly taking the creature into her body as she still unbelievably slept!

"Why ain't she waking up?! Get off of me, now!" shouted Grungor in anger, his face getting red from seeing the creature going into Mara. The beggar lady replied in a flat tone, stating, "You know those hares that you caught? I enchanted one of them and let them loose into the forest, knowing that you, the expert dwarf hunter, would catch them and likely eat them. Mara is in a deep sleep, and will not awaken until the sun rises." She followed her statement with a horrible sounding chuckle.

With the sword still pointed at his throat, Grungor watched in horror as Mara's stomach ballooned out from the ingestion of the sludge creature, most of the strange thing now inside of her. After a few moments, all of the thing had transferred itself into Mara's now bulging stomach, slightly red from the stress of holding the thing in. Mara didn't even move an inch as her stomach now gurgled and moaned from pressure.

With a swift move of her hand, the beggar woman placed her sword into a scabbard at the side of her hip. She then walked away, leaving Grungor to sit and stare at Mara's now bloated stomach. He realized that he was no longer being pinned down, and sat himself up with vigor. He looked around for the beggar woman, only to find she had disappeared.

"Damn it all, shes gone..." Grungor shuffled over to Mara, taking note of how peaceful she looked in her magic induced sleep. He cringed slightly as he looked over her burgeoning stomach in horror. "Ohhhh boy....she won't be happy when she wakes up..."
142131.title: 'Begging' For Betrayal

choices: “We should head out of the forest and make a small detour to this town here…”
“We should head deeper into the forest and try to find this small trading post."
1421311.content:
Mara slept soundly that night, in fact far better than she usually slept while traveling. Usually she felt uncomfortable lying on the flat, hard ground, and would often awaken in the middle of the night just from how uncomfortable it was. It felt amazingly good to her, being able to just lie there in her makeshift bed and nod off as soon as her red-haired head hit the pillow.

She would have enjoyed her deep slumber much more however, if it weren’t for the bizarre dreams that plagued her that night. She found herself in an enormous larder, so big that it felt like a massive cavern and packed with enough food to feed an entire village for weeks. The elf couldn’t help but notice that each and every piece of food lining the shelves and stacked about the floor looked absolutely delicious, and felt that it would be a shame if she didn’t try just a bit of each thing.

Soon however, as her robe grew tight around her and her breathing grew heavy from girth she was starting to realize that she had gone from tasting to flat out cramming food into her face. She kept eating regardless, staining her clothing with all sorts of juices, sauces, and icing until her robes tore away completely, revealing her plump and naked body beneath.

The dreaming elf’s avatar gasped in shock at this point, but when she caught sight of her traveling companion Grungor cheering her on happily. At that point, all shame melted away and she renewed her gorging with even more vigor, only slightly aware that somebody else was watching as well. As she kept eating, kept growing even fatter, and kept gaining even more rolls of blubber the presence made itself even clearer as a giant, disembodied eye that watched her every move. Yet oddly Mara didn’t even slow as it gazed upon her with its shockingly crimson iris, nor when she was finally brought crashing down to her flabby bottom, as even though she was now immobile the food always seemed to be within reach.

Grungor was gone now, but the eyeball seemed to grow along with the once tiny elf’s weight as her flabby flesh spread across the floor, and then pressed against the walls and shelves. Finally, after what seemed like an eternity of eating, even in her dream state, Mara had devoured every last scrap within the entire room. She also nearly filled the entire room, except for the space that was now taken up by the enormous eye. It glared at her naked, disgustingly bloated body, and the feeling of shame and exposure returned to her a thousand times over. She screamed as the eye stared at her, but was even more horrified to find that she didn’t recognize her own voice which had been distorted by tons and tons of fat. The eye seemed to glint while loud, mocking laughter filled the room.



Mara sat up suddenly in her bed, sweating more than usually, a chill running through her as she was frightened awake. It was morning now, the sun having just risen, and as she looked over her surroundings, she grew calm.

“It was only a dream…” She reassured herself, closing her eyes and sighing.

She put her hand to her chest… and then realized that something was off. Her chest felt… bigger than it used to be. She moved her hand down to her belly, and her blood ran cold with fright when it met the now curved surface of her paunch. She began to poke and grab at other parts of her body: the slight fat jiggling on her arms, her softer face and its double chin, her thickened thighs and plump ass.

Mara began to whimper at first, and then soon started to sob, “This can’t be… It was only a dream, how is this possible?”

Grungor, now noticing that the elf was awake ran over to her and pulled her close in a comforting embrace. When Mara felt the way her soft, doughy flesh pressed against his well trained muscles she pushed him away, shouting, “Don’t do that!”

“I’m sorry lass…” Grungor said, looking at the ground solemnly, “I tried to stop it, but…”

“Stop what? What happened to me!?” She yelled, shivering in a robe that was now a bit less baggy on her pudgy form.

“There was… well, I must warn yeh, but it’s gonna sound a bit odd, but there was this ooze… y’know, not unlike some of tha’ ones you’d find about caves and forests like this and such… But the thing was actin’ funny… it went straight for ya’ while you were asleep! I tried to stop it, but the old beggar lady we ran into, she held me still with a blade to my throat as it… And you must understand, she poisoned the hares so that you couldn’t wake… but the slime… the slime, it went into your mouth…” He shifted on his feet, noticeably uncomfortable as he recalled the disturbing sight, “I’d never seen quite anything like it…”

Mara sat still for a moment, her sobbing becoming less violent as she held her head in her hands. She was thinking, trying to determine what could be done, “I guess you were right Grungor… that crone couldn’t be trusted… But at least I think I know what she did to me…”

Grungor scratched his head, his furry eyebrows raising a bit on his forehead in interest, “Y’do, eh…? Something you learned from your studies then…?”

She nodded, grimacing as even that felt different with her slight neck pudge and new chin, “Yes… it’s something that ooze creatures like that can be made to do by some of the more powerful mages… it’s called by some ‘Forced Ingestion’, they can control the slime and…” She put her hand on her rounded belly once more, sniffling.

Grungor shook his head, sighing, “Now this is why I dun like magic ta’ much… so is there anything that yeh can do Mara…? Anything I can help with…?”

Mara thought a bit, then nodded slowly, “Yes. I can try to… force the creature out of me with my spells…”

She closed her eyes now and put both of her hands on top of her sagging belly. She started to mutter to herself in an ancient tongue as a light blue glow surrounded her hands. Her eyebrows furrowed in deeper concentration now as she stopped chanting and started grunting, visibly using a great deal of effort in order to try to expel the creature. Finally, after a few minutes and no result, the blue aura dissipated and she pulled her hands away from her stomach, panting while a bit of sweat ran down her forehead.

“It’s no use…” She sighed, “The thing… inside me is too powerful to extract with my magic. I’m still learning even some of the basics of sorcery. But we should find somebody who can get it out and soon…”

“Why do yeh say that lass…?” Grungor asked, a look of concern appearing on his face as he noticed one of worry on Mara’s.

“Because this spell that the beggar woman used on the slime… it could still be in effect…” The look of worry intensified, mixed with visible disgust now, “She could still control it, even while it’s inside. The fact that it’s spread to the rest of my body already makes me fear that this is indeed the case. And if she has control of the slime… maybe she has control of me as well.”

Grungor didn’t like the sound of that at all. He had seen magic do many wicked things in his long years of life, and one of his least favorite was when it turned friends against each other.

“Well then, we should head off immediately. I’ll pull out tha’ map, let you decide which course of action to be best…”
1421311.title: Waking Up is Hard to Do

choices: Continue following Mara, as she gorges herself on food with Grungor out scouting
Follow Grungor as he looks for the missing centaurs while Mara eats.
14213112.content:
After a brief discussion, both Mara and Grungor decided it best to head to the nearest location, which was a small trading post that was deeper into the forest. Grungor packed most of the supplies up, as he felt sorry for Mara and let her be. With the stuff packed up, Grungor led the way with Mara behind, swaying slightly as she tried to get used to her new girth.

"So, how far exactly is this trading post?" asked Mara with slight hint of anxiety. Grungor looked back at the elf, and said in a flat tone, "About a mile or two, almost in the center of the forest. I hear the post is run by a group of centaurs, though. Have ya ever seen one up close?"

Mara blinked, shaking her head. "No, I can't say I have. How about you?"

"Just a couple of times, decent enough folk they are. Though, this was a different group I believe, so I have no idea if the ones at the post are gonna be friendly."

"Lets hope they are..." muttered Mara, looking around the forest, keeping an eye out for danger.


* * *


After an uneventful trek through the dense forest, Grungor stopped and listened for something in the woods. "Hear that? Sounds like voices, I bet we're gettin' close to the post."

"Thank the gods, I'm starving!" gasped a rather worn out Mara, bent over with her hands on her knees. Grungor looked back at the elf with stern eyes. "Why didn't ya say something? We could have stopped to eat, for crying out loud!"

Mara looked up at the dwarf with weary eyes. "I...didn't want to impede on our progress...And besides, I thought it best that I hold my hunger while I'm in this...condition." Mara patted her burgeoning belly, a sliver of pale skin showing through a gap on her robe. As if in response to her a touch, her stomach let loose a loud gurgling sound, which in turn caused Mara's face to turn red.

Grungor couldn't help but grin, as he took in the sight of the embarrassed elf. "Well, I think we can fore-go caution just for a bit to get some food in your tummy, lass. I'm sure it won't do ya any harm."

Mara sighed deeply as she stared at the ground. "I..I suppose so. I mean, what harm could some bread do, really?"

"That's the spirit, Mara." And so the duo walked the last stretch to the trading post, their feet aching and tummy's rumbling.

They took in the sight of a number of tents surrounding the area, each with their flap open and a merchants table in front of them, most adorned with rare jewels or scrolls.

Yet, the trading post was deserted. "Thats peculiar, I coulda sworn I heard voices..." grumbled Grungor, his head swaying back and forth looking for any sign of life.

Meanwhile, Mara was gazing at the collections of jewelry and other objects at one merchant station. "Oh these really are beautiful, Grungor. I wonder where they got these?" She wandered over to the next stand, only to be met with an assortment of foods. Bread, cheese, pudding, some fish, fresh cut meat, and even cake! Mara's mouth began to water at the sight of such delectable food, and she licked her lips with hungrily.

"Well, Mara, I haven't the faintest idea where those centaurs went, so I'm not sure what our plan is now. I think I'll go look around the woods, see I can call em out."

Mara didn't answer though, as her mouth was occupied with a roasted lamb leg.
14213112.title: The Missing Merchants

choices: Grungor, the centaurs, or both return and find her.
The ooze within her begins reacting to one of its master's commands.
142131121.content:
Mara lay back in the silken pillows inside the tent. She hoped who owned it didn't mind that she was borrowing a place to rest -- or that she'd blazed a trail of gluttony through half of their stalls, for that matter. She did intend to pay for it... and with all that food sitting out in the open, animals were sure to come for it soon anyway... so there really wasn't anything wrong with it, when you thought about it.

She yawned sleepily, her silver eyes growing dull with exhaustion. Marching miles and miles weighed down by ooze weight and then gorging oneself to bursting on sweets and cheese were practically a recipe for inducing sleep. She drifted away for a moment...

... and drifted back to the sound of her stomach gurgling. Muzzily, she turned her head and looked out the window. Unless it had been more than a day, which she doubted, she'd only been out for about fifteen minutes.

How can I be hungry again?, she thought unhappily. I just finished stuffing myself until I could barely walk straight. I can't eat again! I'm too fat as it is!

But, she reflected, was she really? It was a spell, after all. An intruder. She wasn't fat -- she was just bloated with blubbery ooze. Once they broke the curse, she'd be back to her old skinny self again. She sat up -- oof, so heavy -- and looked down at herself, trying to hold the picture of the real Mara, the one trapped under the flab, in her mind. Yes, that was her. Thin as a whip. What could it hurt to eat a little more?

She was munching her way through an entire loaf of sugarbread when it hit her. The ooze! It must be breaking down the food almost as quickly as she could eat it. She shuddered to think about where it was storing the energy. Had she gotten fatter, just standing here eating? She threw away the last of the sugarbread. By the gods, if she didn't watch herself this could get out of hand, quickly!

Just then...
142131121.title: Post-Prandial

choices: Due to her use of magic, Mara expands during her sleep.
A traveler passes by to discover Mara and Grungor.
1421311211.content:
Mara watched as Grungor returned empty-handed, a look of disappointment on his face. Mara met him in the center of the camp and asked Grungor of the whereabouts of the centaurs.

"I couldn't tell ya! I looked for em everywhere, called out to them, but not a single centaur showed itself. I just don't understand what happened here..." said Grungor with a sigh.

"Well, perhaps we should take advantage of this predicament and "borrow" some supplies while they are gone. I'm sure they wouldn't mind."

Grungor grinned and scratched his beard while he thought of it. "I don't know lass, maybe we should-- " Just then, a sort of rumbling sound coming from behind them startled Grungor. Both Mara and the dwarf turned to see what the cause of the noise was.

A group of about six or seven centaurs were charging at them from a clearing in the woods, waving spears and swords above their heads. Mara and Grungor instinctively got ready to defend themselves, the dwarf drawing his gun and Mara preparing a fire spell. As the centaurs got closer, they could hear them shouting something above their charge.

"Dirty thieves! You will pay for this!" yelled a rather burly centaur with gray hair. It seemed he was the leader as all the other centaurs followed him. Grungor and Mara stood their ground as the centaurs surrounded them, spears lowering down and forcing them back to back.

"Now hold on here! We didn't steal anything! Dwarves honor!" yelled Grungor. The gray haired centaur merely snorted and pointed a finger at Mara.

"You lie! We know that cursed elf has stolen our food. Even now it rests inside her body, feeding that dark creature within her." Mara gasped in surprise at this statement. Grungor just sighed and placed a palm on his face.

"So...you know of our predicament then?" asked Mara. She placed a hand on her stomach, hoping maybe with her being surrounded, the goo creature would remove itself from her body out of fear. But this was a false hope.

"Yes," grumbled the centaur leader, "Our shaman sensed it within you as you approached our post. We hid among the forest, waiting to make sure you were not a true threat."

Grungor now had a question of his own. "So, how come I couldn't find you guys? I bloody looked everywhere for ya!" The centaur leader revealed the shaman as the one who hid the group from sight.

"But, we still have a problem, elf. You stole most of our food supplies. Either you pay us with gold so we can restock our foods, or we shall take you both as prisoners as long as we see fit."

Grungor angrily barked back at the centaur leader. "Listen up ya horse bottomed bastard! We got to get movin' and find somebody to remove this thing from my friend here! We don't have time to pay you guys back. I'm sorry, but that's just the way it's gonna be, and you ain't gonna stop us!" Grungor pulled up his rifle and aimed it right at the leader's head. Time seemed to freeze as neither person moved. Mara took this moment to channel a shockwave spell.

She was worried however, as she had only successfully cast this spell twice before. With her mouth speaking unheard syllables, Mara shook with effort as the spell neared completion. Just a couple more sentences left and.........done!

"Now, Grungor!" yelled Mara as she let the spell loose around her. Grungor ducked just as the wave of energy hit the surrounding centaurs with the force of a rock wall, each flying head over hooves into the surrounding forest area. The spell even toppled over most of the trading tents the centaurs had set up, with books and scrolls and weapons and other supplies flying through the air.

Grungor pulled on Mara's arm as she collected herself. "Come on Mara! Lets run while they're all scattered about!" Mara stood up and started moving quickly with Grungor, neither looking back to see if any of the centaurs had re-cooperated.

**********************



Mara and Grungor managed to stumble upon an old trail after a couple minutes of running. They stopped to catch their breath, both red and sweaty from the run. Grungor leaned on a tree, one hand on the bark and the other on his knee. Mara had sat down on the ground, both her hands behind her to support her weight. Her blue robe had come undone partly, letting her pale stomach peek through to the outside world. At the moment Mara cared not if she was openly revealing her blubbery form. She just wanted to rest her aching feet.

After a moment, Mara let her arms fall to her side and just laid down on her back, the already loose robe now falling away to fully reveal her soft form. She gazed up at the sky, which was remarkably clear of clouds, and a deep blue. A sense of peace washed over her, and her eyes began closing. Mixed with her body's aches and the serenity of the sky, sleep took a hold of Mara in an instant...
1421311211.title: Grungor, the centaurs, or both return and find ...

choices: Tod, tired of his mundane life as a delivery boy, decides to stay with the duo.
Tod turns and walks away, leaving the elf and dwarf. (Back to Grungor and Mara.)
14213112112.content:
Unknown to our tuckered out adventurers, farther down the path a young man was making his rounds as a pie delivery boy, and he was just beginning his journey through the forest. He hefted a large leather bag on his back, the sweet aroma of a various assortment of different flavored pies wafting through the air. "Sure is a nice day today", thought the young man, who's name is Tod. He figured today was just gonna be like any other day. Deliver some pies, get payed, and go back home to his father.

Tod began humming a song to pass the time, his eyes looking through the trees and bushes. He knew that the woods weren't always safe, so he usually brought a dagger with on his travels, just in case. The soft wind and the birds chirping dulled his alertness after awhile, the peacefulness of the forest taking a hold of Tod. His eyes were on the ground for a split second when he heard snoring up ahead. He raised an eyebrow inquisitively, surprised that someone -or something- was out on his trail. He put a hand on his dagger, his gaze darting forward.

Tod spotted what looked like a very plump woman laying down on the ground. He also saw a stout dwarf sitting and leaning against a tree. The snoring was coming from him.

"Odd. Just a couple of tired travelers." said Tod, bringing his guard down. He crept forward, not wanting to wake either of them. He stood over the woman, red hair flowing around her head. Tod let out a gasp as he looked at the woman's ears. "She's an elf! Oh wow, I've never seen one up close!" A big grin showed itself on Tod's face. He had genuine amazement on his eyes. He looked over the rest of the elf's body, his eyes growing even wider.

Tod had always heard of elves as being tall and thin creatures, their stature giving off the aura of nobility and intelligence. This elf, though, was completely different. Her body was doughy and soft. Her stomach a small, but definitely impressive pot belly.

For some odd reason, Tod couldn't take his eyes off the sight of the bloated elf. He felt his face growing flushed, beads of sweat forming on his forehead.

"Why am I feeling like this? This is all too weird..." thought Tod. He took a slight step back, snapping a twig under his foot. Tod jumped and let out a curse, looking to the slumbering elf to see if he had woken her. Tod's face grimaced, as the elf was now stirring, a light groan escaping from her mouth. Tod looked for some place he could hide himself at, but the nearest bush was much too far away for him to be unnoticed.

The elf looked up at Tod now, her eyes wide and alert. She took a quick glance down at herself and let out a yelp of embarrassment, pulling her robe over herself tightly. "You better not have seen anything, mister!" she stood, careful to keep her robe from opening up again. The whole time she kept her gaze on Tod, like she was trying to determine if he was a threat.

Tod slowly stepped forward, his hands up. "Don't worry, miss. I was just passing through-" Tod covered his face as the elf shouted back at him. "Don't take another step! Why should I trust you? Prove yourself, human." The elf's hand was glowing with energy, a fire spell ready for casting if needed.

"No! No, I'm not here to hurt you! I'm just a normal delivery boy, honest! Look, I just bring pies to people who ordered them." Tod pulled off his leather bag and opened it up for the elf to see. The reaction he got was slightly comical.

The elf dropped her arms, her mouth agape, drool appearing on her chin. She licked her lips in hunger, her eyes locked on to the bag of deliciousness. "Are...are those apple pies?"

Tod gave a cheer in his head. He was getting somewhere. "Apple, blueberry, cherry, raspberry, you name it. You know, I think I might even have some chocolate creme pies in here somewhere..." The elf moaned in ecstasy, creeping ever closer to Tod. The young man couldn't help but openly grin now. He had this elf in the palm of his hands. If it was either getting blasted by magical fire and dying, or letting this elf have his bag of pies and getting out of there unscathed...eh, it was pretty obvious.

Tod placed the bag gently on the ground, backing away from it slowly as he watched the elf dive into the bag, pulling out several pies with both hands. One at a time, she took a bite out of each and every pie, savoring the flavor. Tod couldn't believe what he was seeing. In an instant, the elf had demolished two pies by herself, not even stopping to catch her breath. She reached right back in, bringing a blueberry pie to her face. One, two, three, four, five....five huge bites, and the pie was gone. The elf laid a hand on her chest, and let out a low burp.

Tod watched in disbelief as the ravenous elf got right back to it, sticking her head into the leather bag and eating whatever found its way to the front of her mouth. Tod found that he had somehow sat down on the ground in the time he was watching this strange, but weirdly alluring elf tear through his whole supply of pies.

The rustling in the bag had died down now, the elf's head emerging from the bag. Her face was a pure mess. Blue, red, and whatever else was all over her mouth, her chin, and even her hair. She sighed deeply, her hands caressing her absolutely bulbous belly. The elf's robe had no chance with this behemoth sphere of flesh, and had parted once more. The maiden raised her arms over her head, a long and loud yawn escaping her lips. With one last groggy belch, she fell over onto the ground, her hands cupped under her head for a pillow.

Tod was, needless to say, speechless. He watched the elf as she slept, the gurgling from her stomach the only other noise besides her snoring. Tod let out a pent up gasp of air as he stood back up. He looked up at the sky to find that it was almost dusk. Time certainly passes by when you are watching an elf girl eat all of your pies.
14213112112.title: A traveler passes by to discover Mara and Grungor.

The trio are ambushed along the road by cloaked figures!
142131121121.content:
Although the pies had possibly saved his life, Tod knew he could not return to his father empty-handed. The boy's eyes scanned over the still snoring Dwarf and gluttonous elf, and an idea sparked in his mind. If these two were adventurers, maybe they were treasure hunting! Fear long gone after the witnessed binge session, Tod immediately dropped to the plump elf's side. He cleared his throat and placed a hand gently to her shoulder, hoping not to frighten the fluffy sorceress.

"Excuse me, miss?" He sat still, awaiting a response. The only sound to rise from the pie-pilferer was a gurgled belch. She wrinkled her nose and smacked her lips before nuzzling up tighter into a curled, chubby ball. Tod, the eager delivery boy, then nudged her some with the heel of his palm. "Excuse me." His push elicited no response, but the motion flowed through her fattened form, jostling her pale cleavage and sending slight tremors through the expanse of her pillowy tummy. Again Tod was struck with a strange, heated sensation as his eyes lingered over the peeking poof of her softened middle from between her robes. What was wrong with him? Ignoring the fantasies that played out in his mind, he shook her harder, raising his eyes against the momentum that would undoubtedly roil across her softened body. "Wake up!"

Finally roused from her food coma, Mara rubbed her eyes and looked skyward, only to have her view blocked by the vaguely familiar face of a young man. "Wha-- Who are you?!" She immediately slapped his hand away from her shoulder and scurried back. At least, she tried to scurry but found the escape far more difficult than she anticipated. Sitting up, hands on the road behind her in support, she looked down at her midsection with utter horror.

What had once been only a softened curve to her stomach, had now been overwhelmed by an absolute paunch. From her seated position, the mound of her belly now pressed against the once loose-fitting robes, emphasizing its roundness against the taut fabric. Her bloated gut now had the qualities of a blubbery cliff face, perching out from her skirt's waist sash at least a solid inch. Any shred of muscle definition had long since expired, as the flesh that ran down her tummy was equally soft but still held some firmness from the plethora of pies she had only recently gorged herself on. Trembling hands pressed against the sides of the swollen belly, but quickly recoiled. This was no nightmare! Succumbing to the shock, Mara let out a scream, shutting her eyes tight with terror and shame in one.

Grungor ceased his snoring sleep and bolted to his feet. Seeing the stunned boy kneeling before the screaming Mara only offered the Dwarf one conclusion: danger! Grungnor swiped up his rifle from against the tree trunk and pounced on the knee-bent interloper. Although shorter than the human, he easily bested the boy in brawn and weight. Without so much as a struggle, he had the young man pinned beneath one heavy boot, rifle barrel jammed beneath his jawline. "Mara..." Grungnor spoke, not tearing his eyes from the boy. But still she screamed, expressing the incredible capacity of her elven lungs. "Mara." No end was in sight for her shrill shrieking. "MARA!" Finally, as the Dwarf boomed his voice far above her own cries, the elf cut her screaming short. She panted heavily, one hand pressed to her full chest. "Did he hurt you, lass?" Grungnor jabbed the barrel harder into the boy's neck as he turned away, eyeing his elven companion up and down. "Ho boy..." Even he could see the change in her form.

The hem of her robe's shirt now fell a sliver too high, allowing the world to get a small peek at the very slight hang of the bottom of her belly, even as she now struggled to cover herself up entirely. In fact, just about everywhere was a bit more padded; her ass had grown noticeably, spreading out beneath her weight a tiny bit more than it used to as she sat. The robes in general were somewhat more snug all over, though it was clear she had grown the most around the middle, even if it was only slightly. She had probably only gained fifteen pounds, but a good portion now hung on her paunch, giving her robes a permanent tightness.

"No, Grungor. He's just some delivery boy." She sighed and grunted, struggling to her feet. The effort was greater than ever before, and this only forced a defeated pout to her lips.

"Right! Yes! Please don't shoot me, Mr. Dwarf sir!" Tod flailed his arms weakly beneath the weight of the Dwarf's boot. Grungor offered a stern scoff before lifting his boot and rifle from the boy. Tod hesitantly rose to his feet and dusted himself off. "Your friend is right, sir. I was just passing through with my delivery."

Grungor gave Tod the hairiest of eyeballs. "What sort o' delivery?" The Dwarf's interrogating gaze seemed to shrink the boy some, and Tod found himself unable to maintain eye contact.

"...Pies." The word fell softly, and Grungor sighed in relief. Clearly he was no agent of ill-will. But then the weight of the word hit Grungor hard, though not as hard as Mara's waistline. He whirled about, looking at the sticky-faced elf.

"Oh, lass... You didn't..." His eyes were wide, but before she could utter a response, another gurgled burp rose from the pit of her expanded stomach. Grungor sighed again, his rifle stooping to his side in defeat. Reluctantly, he turned to Tod. "Right... I suppose we owe you for the costs now, aye?"

But Tod had other plans. Too long had he followed his father's orders. Too long had he lived a life unfulfilled. "I have a better idea! You two are adventurers, right?"

Grungor arced his arm upwards, slinging the rifle to rest on his shoulder. "Aye." His brow perked high on his weathered forehead. Joining the questioning proved difficult for Mara, as she had to adjust to her now tighter robes. One hand steadied her churning belly as the other rested on a newly fortified hip. If this kept up, she knew she'd need a bigger wardrobe, and at that thought it was all she could do not to burst into tears again.

Tod flashed a grin to the Dwarf and folded his arms with an emboldened vigor. "Take me with you."

"...What?" Grungor and Mara replied in unison. Finally beside her stout companion, Mara rested her hand moved from plush hip to the Dwarf's stocky shoulder. Grungor had no trouble supporting the woman, but her added weight did not go unnoticed.

"Take me with you! I know the woods pretty well, and I can be really sneaky!" Tod splayed his arms and lowered himself into an appropriate sneaking stance to demonstrate his point. Mara rolled her eyes and Grungor rand a meaty palm over his head in frustration. "Forgive me if I have me doubts, lad." The Dwarf and elf snickered together.

Tod once more rose from the stance and crossed his arms with a huff. "I snuck up on both of you, didn't I?" The chuckling fell to silence and the pair both turned and nodded to Tod without a word. "Good! Then it's settled. I'll be your new guide through these woods." He puffed up his chest and raised a foot, planting the boot on a nearby stump, leaning out in a heroic posture. His hand lashed out and settled above his brow, gazing out toward the forest's horizon. "Many dangers await, and the roads are full of peril! But we shall persevere! We shall be victorious!" His boasting was met with only the chirping of crickets, and as Tod looked to his new travel companions, Grungor and Mara weren't even paying him any mind. They were packing up their belongings.

"Lad, unless you have some advice for our travels, please stop talkin'." Grungor took a swig from his canteen before offering it to Mara. She silently declined and slung her backpack over her shoulders.

"But... it's nightfall. Shouldn't we set up camp?" Tod stepped down from the stump and took his side by the pair.

"We already slept, silly." Mara laughed lightly, but immediately cut short and furrowed a frown as her hand steadied her tummy. The giggling had only encouraged jiggling. Grungor said nothing and took the lead, rifle grasped lightly in one hand as he marched. Mara gestured for Tod to follow, and set about behind the Dwarf, slowly growing accustomed to her new-found girth.

"Right! Wait for me!" Tod scrambled behind, excited to begin his new life as an adventurer!

1421311212.content:
Mara shuddered to think what might happen if she didn't keep her eating in check. If she wasn't careful, her nightmare just might become a reality! The sound of a snapping twig twitched the elf’s ears, and she glanced around, scanning the heavy foliage. “Grungnor?” Rising to her feet, with a bit more effort than she would care to admit, the elf tiptoed toward the direction of the sound just as more rustling could be heard. It wasn’t far now, and Mara stayed on guard, one hand already armed with enchanted fire.

Upon reaching the rustling, Mara squeaked as a substantially fat squirrel leapt from the bush and waddled toward a nearby tree. The elf let out a light sigh and aimed to return to the trading post until something glimmered from the corner of her eye. After facing the unusual shine, Mara realized it was in fact a brilliant portal flickering with purple light. With the knowledge that someone was targeting her, the elf knew better than to trust random magical doorways. Shaking her head at the obvious trap, she turned to walk away. Or at least… she would have turned around if her legs allowed it. Frozen from the bountiful waist down, Mara began to panic as her legs took on a life of their own, marching toward the gaping portal. “Oh no… Grungnor! Anybody! Help!” She flailed her flabby arms to no avail as her foot crossed the glowing threshold. Once she was fully engulfed in the light, the doorway snapped shut behind her, leaving no trace of her exit.

After an hour or so, the Dwarf finally stepped from the wilderness and entered the camp. “Lass, I couldn’t find them anywhere.” Grungnor paused, looking around for some sign of his elven counterpart. Not a peep. “Lass?” He stood dumbfounded and scratched his head. “Where’d ye go?”

Little did he know, Mara had been teleported across a great distance. When her vision returned, she found herself in the most unlikely of places...

Whelp not much to do but ask whoever lives in that house." Grungor approaches the house. An odd feeling of suspicion overcomes him. He swore that the house wasn't there the last time. "Well my companion and I have some darn problems. We had a run in with a witch who placed a curse lil companion. Now she's bigger than before.

The woman's unchanging eyes begin to tear up, but it was jelly that ran down her. Grungor was oblivious to the woman's strange tears as he noticed five centaurs eating trays of sweets.

1511.content:
The chainmail-bikini warrior woman strode into the temple, waving a greatsword as large as she was around in one hand with the same wanton recklessness already displayed by brazenly trespassing into a strange temple, alone, on the vague speculation that there was treasure inside. Sora was not the sharpest knife in the drawer, but she definitely had the sharpest sword on the rack. Often she survived her ill-advised adventures with what onlookers and survivors described as a lethal cocktail of titanic strength, savage martial prowess, and phenomenal dumb luck. But all of these qualities would find themselves sorely pressed by the fiendish dungeon of the Lipomancer.

The empty-headed swordswoman clambered through the dungeon door, which slammed shut behind her. Before her was a large room, looking to be a place of worship, judging by the mob of people in robes bowing with fevered reverence to a large statue of the Lipomancer in all his terrifying glory. In the scales he held there were two statues of immensely bloated women, one of them slightly larger than the other and thusly tipping the scale in her favor. The cultist with the fanciest robe made several motions over a potion on an altar before the statue, asking their god-on-earth to enrich it with his baleful blessing, before he was interrupted by Sora's exclamation.

"HEY! HEY, YOU GUYS! You got any treasure in here?", she asked with that same naive curiosity that often preceded the bloody brawls she usually found herself in for some reason.

With a single motion, the whole of the congregation brought their hooded eyes to bear on the audacious interloper. "The only thing you will find in here, infidel, is your death! Seize her, brothers and sisters! She will be a fitting sacrifice to our lord!"

Sora hopped up and down on her toes giddily, brushing back her shoulder-length cherry red hair. "Oh, oh boy! A fight! Even though you're all men of the cloth, don't think I'll take it easy on you! I loot regardless of gender, race, or creed~"

Sora had never been one for botany, but even so, as an adventure she had to maintain some knowledge of fauna.

These vines however, she had never seen. Tendrils, plumper than any swine, prize or otherwise, practically choked the entryway. Softly glowing bulbs of a yellow hue sprout from the end of the tendrils, almost as though they were flowers about to bloom.

Ever the curious one, Sora took a step towards the vines. The gentle, warm glow of the bulbs, enticing, almost hypnotic as she gazes towards them. It wasn't long before she was right up on them.

Doing what any competent adventure would do, she decided, the best course of action would be to prod the poor thing with her finger.

152.content:
Hikari stuck her tongue out in concentration, as she focused on her prize. Not five feet away was one of the biggest boars that she had ever seen, and she aimed to be eating it before the sun went down. Fortunately, it hadn't seen her yet; Hikari prided herself on her illusion spells, and right now she looked and smelled like a tree to the animal. Slowly, she focused her magical energy through her body, until at last it was focused in her fingers. With a whoosh, a bolt of magic force leapt forward from her pointer and index fingers, and struck the boar in the side of the head. The boar died instantly, slumping over as blood poured from the wound behind its eye.

It took Hikari no time at all to then use her magic to prepare a firepit. A telekinesis spell retrieved some logs and stones, and all she needed was a low-powered fireball to set the campfire going. Having exhausted most of her magical reserves over the course of the day, Hikari opted to use a simple strength-enhancing spell to stick the boar on a spit, and was content to rotate it over the fire she'd made.

As she let the meat cook, Hikari shrugged off the green hooded cloak she'd been wearing most of the day. From under the hood, black hair went down to her shoulders, as he brown eyes took in the meal. Her sizable chest was covered by a yellow cotton shirt which stopped midway down her torso, leaving her chubby belly uncovered (a result of having spent several sedentary years doing nothing but learning magic). Over her hips was a blue, knee-length skirt.

As she bit into the cooked boar, Hikari began thinking that he first adventure was going well. She'd spent a few years as the apprentice of a magician, and had finally struck out on her own after she felt she'd learned everything he could teach her. She was now finally out seeing the world, and putting the magic she'd learned to real use. In this area was rumored to be the lair of a sorcerer called the Lipomancer, a being no one had seen in decades. Hikari figured that the sorcerer was dead (all-powerful sorcerers tended to remind everyone that they were there once in a while), which meant that whatever valuables she could find in the lair were fair game.

Despite the size of the boar, Hikari was able to finish all of the meat, which caused her round belly to bloat out a little bit. Patting it with a sigh of contentment, Hikari cast a quick alarm spell which would (in theory) wake her up should anyone get near. She then lay down to sleep, visions of treasure hordes dancing in her head.

1521.content:
The first thing Hikari did after waking up was check the alarm spell she had cast. It was undisturbed, which was good. Afterwards, it was time for breakfast. Hikari didn't have any of the boar meat that she had eaten last night left, so she had to content herself with some jerky and water. After she was done, Hikari took what possessions she needed and left the rest behind her. She still had some distance to cover, though by the end of the day she would find the entrance to the Lipmancer's lair. At least, if the information that she had found was correct.

Hikari hiked for several hours, enjoying the lush wilderness around her. Many heavier people might have had trouble with long-distance walks, but Hikari had magical symbols tattooed all over her body which greatly increased her physical strength. In theory, she would be able to retain mobility no matter how much weight she gained, though Hikari never really wanted to test those limits. She didn't mind being chubby that much, but she'd rather stay at her current weight than get any heavier.

(Later on in life, Hikari would admit that such thoughts were basically daring the universe to do what it did to her.)

Finally, in the middle of a forest clearing, Hikari found it. A large cave, with several warnings in all kinds of languages warning people not to go inside. A smirk appeared on Hikari's face. She wasn't going to turn back now, after spending several days away from civilization. She incanted a spell that created an invisible shield around her which would hopefully protect her from anything inside that would attempt to harm her. Afterwards, Hikari stepped up to the cave, found some stairs leading down, and descended into the darkness.

After it became too dim to see, Hikari held up one of her hands and cast a spell which caused an orb of light to wink into existence. The orb began orbiting Hikari's head, allowing her to see clearly. At the foot of the stairs, there was a large corridor which extended a long way in front of her. Hikari began moving slowly down the corridor, prepared for anything to happen, when all of a sudden...

15211.content:
The only warning Hikari got was a click a split-second before the ground under her opened up. Her reflexes were very good, however, and she began to chant a spell as soon as she began falling. Just in the nick of time, Hikari reinforced her legs and behind before she crashed into the ground below. It still hurt quite a lot though, and Hikari remained sitting for some time muttering obscenities under her breath. After that was over with, Hikari looked up only to see that the hole she'd fallen through had disappeared. There would be no flying back up to the entrance.

The room she'd landed in was bare, with only one passage leading onward into darkness. Hikari's light spell was still orbiting her head, so she could see well enough as she headed down the passage. It went straight for some time before ending in another room. As she entered the room, a giant sliding door shut behind Hikari, locking her within this room. A moment later, a hole in the ceiling opened up, and out of it dropped...

153.content:
Snow swirled in the constant breeze that swept through the frosted rocks of the Aquiq Mountains. Slowly making her way along a barely visible path through the only pass, Mist held her fur lined cloak ever tighter. A mask was taut across her face and the hood was pulled low over her brow, leaving only the barest twinkle of her eyes visible, though even that was almost entirely hidden in the drifting snow. All around the young woman was silent except for the mournful wailing of the wind passing around the craggy rocks, and the crunching of the snow beneath her boots. Ahead of her, she could just make out the crouching bulk of an old way station nestled between two outcroppings of rock. As she got closer, she could see that the structure hadn’t been well maintained, but that wasn’t surprising considering that most people tended to take the longer but safer journey along the seaside road along the other side of the mountains.

As Mist came close to the door at the front of the building, she saw a brief glimpse of a small fire burning in the central fireplace. Before she could make out anything else inside, there was a shout and a trio of men in mismatched armor with ill maintained weapons dashed out of the doorway. Mist didn’t move, instead she watched as the men fanned out, with one swaggering straight at her, and the other two swinging wide around either side of her.

“Ho traveler!” the one in the center called, likely the leader judging from his marginally better equipment. “Not exactly the best weather to be traveling in. Perhaps you might come indoors…just until the weather breaks?”

“I’m fine right here, actually,” she replied to the swarthy man.

“Yeah, this ain’t a case where you can say no, girlie,” the orc said with a laugh. Mist noted he had a rather eye-catching metal ball in place of one of his hands.

“Be that as it may, I just did,” Mist calmly countered, though she couldn’t resist a slight smirk from crossing her face; fortunately, between the snow and her mask, it went unnoticed by anyone but her.

“Come on, boss, let’s just get it over with, I’m freezing my tail off here!” shouted the third of the group – a stocky wolf with a scar tracing one side of his face over an unseeing eye.

The “boss” huffed – Mist could see the cloud of his breath as he did so – before saying, “Fine, let’s get this over with, and try to save the cape if you can, I like the look of it.”

The two others smiled wide as they closed in on Mist, thinking they must have had an easy target, maybe even frozen in fright or something considering that she didn’t move even as they stalked towards her, brandishing their weapons. Their thoughts were cut short as – quick as lightning – Mist threw one side of her cloak back, before a thunderous bang rippled through the winter air. The wolf fell to the ground, the previously untouched side of his face now mangled even worse than the scared side.

Before either of the other two brigands could realize what happened, Mist turned towards the orc and there was another loud crack. Unfortunately, the orc had lifted the crude replacement for a hand in shock, and the metal happened to deflect the crimson bolt that flew from the pistol still smoking in Mist’s hand. Mist was more than a little upset at not downing her target, which gave the orc a chance to respond. With a throaty roar, he charged at the smaller human. Mist recovered, quickly slipping beneath the ham-fisted swing of the ball that would have crushed her skull. She then easily dodged the swing of the short sword that tried to separate her arm from the rest of her, before driving the barrel of her weapon into the orc’s chest. The blast was muffled somewhat, but still enough to shake some of the nearby hanging snow free. He lurched back, and a second shot knocked him backwards to lie still in the snow.

“Bloody frell!” the human shouted, trying to duck behind one of the large boulders that peaked through the snow. “Miriam, where the fu—“ he started to call out, but didn’t get much further after another bolt flew from Mist; this one taking out his throat.

He staggered several more steps, his sword dropping to the ground and both hands reaching up to prod the still smoking hole that had appeared below his chin. A fleeting look of alarm crossed his face before he pitched forwards into the snow. Mist didn’t relax, between the report from the one trader that had encountered this group survived – though he was half mad from exposure – and what the human was saying, there was supposed to be a fourth around here somewhere. Almost as if on cue, an arrow punched into the ground just next to Mist’s foot. She lunged to the side, darting for one of the boulders herself, as two more arrows plunged into the snow, narrowly missing their mark. Skidding behind the black rock, Mist holstered the pistol, and traded it for the rifle slung across her back. Of dwarven make like the pistol, the rifle was Mist’s preferred means of attack, but the bulkier long barreled weapon wasn’t so handy for being covert or for close–in work, so she had opted to go in with the pistol in hand instead. She was somewhat regretting not being to find a nice quiet spot to take them out from range now, but couldn’t dwell on what was past.

Bracing the rifle against her shoulder, Mist edged the barrel around her cover, keeping her gaze locked down the scope running the length of the barrel. Judging from way the arrows struck, the last target had to be on the bluff around the back of the way station. Scanning along the rocky ridge and ignoring the snow that tried to blind her, she saw a ripple of movement and was about to fire, when a humanoid shape fell to the ground and lay there unmoving. Suppressing a grin, Mist returned the rifle to its place under the back of her cloak, and marched over to the corpse of the fourth bandit.

Looking up at the rock towering over her, she called out, “I was starting to wonder if you were going to show up before everything was over!”

Briefly, a face appeared over the edge of the cliff, before retreating back. Soon after, the face and whole rest of the person hopped over the edge, sliding down the rough rock face to a shambling stop at the bottom. With a grumble only partially muted by the cold-weather gear, the figure stood up, revealing Mist’s partner.

1533.content:
As her companion stood their hood slipped off of their head revealing their dark green skin, small tusks and large underbite completing the expected profile of a healthy orc. The scowl across their face and chattering teeth would go against that however.

“Would’ve been here fast’r if not for this gods forsaken cold.” He spoke. “Why are we out ‘ere again?”

“Because Kurz this group has been taking from poor innocent people for months now, someone had to do something!” Mist said in a tone one would only use to show how deeply they cared about the situation they found themselves in. Kurz chortled and crossed his arms looking down toward his partner clearly not falling for the act.

“And a few rich and guilty people who’s secrets were worth more than any gold a trader forced to walk through these parts would realistically have.” Mist continued in a tone completely betraying her earlier sincerity.

“‘Ight.” He replied. “Now you can continue to remind me of our sworn duty while we’re out of this blasted cold.”

“A touch too cold for the strong and powerful orc?” Mist mocked. Kurz waved her off and stomped off towards the newly vacant cabin. Mist smirked as he walked off.


Kurz was far from a stereotypical orc, potentially the furthest one could be withtout being half human. While most thought of orcs as walking masses of muscle Kurz was rather small compared to most people’s mental images of an orc. While he was seven feet tall with a large jaw and hands and feet bigger than the largest humans his muscles were realatively small. While he was clearly physically fit evidence by his muscular body with cut abs, large arms, rippling back and strong legs he would sooner be described as “skinny” than “muscular” when stood next to a “normal sized” male orc of his age and a head or two shorter.

While most orcs seemed to cave to blood lust and charge screaming into battle without a thought of their chances lugging a massive war axe or hammer with them Kurz preferred to stalk his targets with his trusty bow and throwing knives. He also knew how to throw his voice futhering his ability to sneak up on unsuspecting individuals.
And lastly Kurz was a huge wimp when it came to extreme heat or cold a fact Mist likes to remind him of whenever he complained.

Mist followed Kurz into the humble cabin; the orc was already crouched down by the fire warming his hands and stripped of his hood leaving him in his form fitting leather armor dyed with darks blues, dark browns and blacks to further help him stay in the shadows. Kurz looked over to her as she removed her own outer wear and gave him a nod. He stood up and they searched around the cabin. Their first big find was a plain chest at the foot of one of the two single beds within the cabin. Mist’s attempts to open it were met with resistance from the single lock on it. “Keys probably on one of them.” She said curtly.

“I’ll get it open.” Kurz said placing a hand on the crack between the lid and body of the chest and in a sharp motion yanking the lid completely off of it revealing the rather stuffed chest filled with various seemingly valuable things. Mist scoffed and rolled her eyes.

“Most theives pick the lock.”

“And most women would app’eciate when a man presents he’ with a box of jewels. Don’t hear me complaining.” Kurz said as he started to dig around the chests contents. As he did that Mist started to walk around and take note of the cabin.

It was a single story with two beds draped with furs in the corners opposite of the entrance, the seemingly only way in or out of the place, the fireplace was embedded in the left wall; the stone breaking up the logs making up the rest of the house’s interior. A fire was actively burning in it, a fresh log having just been added by who Mist guessed was Kurz. Near the fire was a pile of furs. “Two beds and a makeshift sleeping area.” Mist announced.

“Permanently ‘ad one on watch then.” Kurz replied not looking out of the chest he currently buried himself in.

The right wall had several cabinets and counters along it. A search proved all of them empty. “No food or water here.” Mist said.

“They either hunt nightly or weren’t planning on staying for much longer, judging by how full this chest is I’d say they were ‘bout ready to leave. As for water they probably just melt snow.” Kurz replied.

The middle of the cabin was dominated by a wooden table a few plates, metal cups and sets of utensils were set up on it.

“Map.” Kurz said. Mist turned around to see the orc bent over looking into the chest with his right arm straight up clutching a rolled piece of paper as he continued to scour the contents with his left hand. Mist walked over to him and took the map and without breaking stride walked over to the table and pushed everything on top of it onto the ground then spread out the map, using two of the cups to keep it from rolling back up.

The map was fairly rudimentary. Chicken scratches made out the location of the nearest town from where they were, about three days out, along with several other towns and cities through the land. Curiously across the sea was a large red X. “So what is it.” Kurz called to her. Mist did a double take as she acknowledge the orc.

Apparently he had found several gaudy rings and a fine robe and was currently wearing them all. The smirk he had let her know this was the reaction he was going for. “Well your highness it seems one party of unfortunate souls had knowledge that cost them their lives. Which means all the profit is ours.”

He gave the map a once over. “Gonna needa ship.”

“Well we can afford passage now.”

“It’s so hot in Gourdun...” The orc whined. Mist looked to confirm the X was in fact on the continent Gourdun. Most known for attracting incredibly strange magical practices, vibrant natural colors to be used in dye, and the fact it was practically a massive desert with temperatures and quantities of sand to match. Mist laughed rolled up the map and shoved it playfully into the orc’s abs. “We’ll go to Eymirn, it’s the closest port city. We’ll stay here for the night then head out.” Mist said. Kurz nodded. “Dibs on the extra furs.” He said gesturing to the bundle on the ground. Before long Mist was asleep as Kurz took the first watch.

1541.content:
Kairi was a young woman of legend. Born to a family of humble librarians, the young Kairi discovered in herself an unquenchable thirst for knowledge. She poured over countless magical tomes, absorbing their wisdom and insight by the dozen each day. By age seven she had already mastered the basics of pyromancy. Not long after her thirteenth birthday, she earned an honorary diploma from the Academy of Elemental Magics, completing her mastery over fire, ice, earth, and air. Alchemy and Restoration came easily to the quick learner, shortly followed by Illusionary magic. Enchantments and Conjuration were little more than child’s play for the up-and-coming seventeen-year-old girl, and at age twenty-three she began creating her own magics by combining the highest artforms of each school.

Yes, at age twenty-five the prodigal sorceress had attained incredible fame and magical power, earning her legendary title: Omnimancer. Indeed, her crowning achievement was the discovery of an ancient spell which could only be cast by one who had mastered all other magics: Eternal Youth. Confident in her abilities, Kairi created the proper magical array and attempted to cast the incantation upon herself, thus assuring a limitless lifetime of seeking knowledge. However, the spell did not cast as she had expected. The young sorceress created the correct runes, spoke the proper incantations, but the spell had no effect. The grand mages of the six schools stood dumbfounded at the failure. In a fit of furious disappointment, they threatened to revoke her title of Omnimancer unless she could perform the ritual. She pleaded and begged, but the magisters abandoned her without another word.

Kairi was not prepared to give up so easily. Although still young, she was determined to reclaim her title through research. Surely there must have been something missing from her practices, perhaps a spell or cantrip slipped past her studying. For weeks she scoured the archives of the six academies to no avail. Kairi returned home in defeat, visiting her parents for the first time in several years. They welcomed her home and consoled their sorrowful but talented daughter. Her father suggested she find something relaxing to read for a change, and she accepted, returning once more to the first library of her studies. It is here that our real story begins…

*****

“Ouch!” For all her cunning, Kairi tended to fit the label of clumsy. She buried her hand into her golden locks, rubbing her head with more than a few curses beneath her breath before bending down to fetch the assaulting book. A soft velvet cover halted her fuming, and the girl examined the strange tome with the keen eye of an appraiser. “Where did you come from?” She had never seen this odd book before, and it bore no writing on its purple, velvet cover. Turning it over, she blew the dust away from its spine, revealing one word carved into the broad spine of the heavy tome.

“Lipomancy? This must be a joke…” The omnimancer sighed and cracked open the book purely out of bland boredom. If this was a ruse, it was an elaborate one. The pages were absolutely filled with diagrams, runes, and magical arrays she had never seen likes of. Unfortunately, none of the writing made sense. The words were all in common tongue, but the syntax was just gibberish. “What madman wrote this nonsense?” Kairi began to shut the book but paused as she remembered all of those ancient tomes written in code. “Could this really be some long-lost form of magic? A seventh school of sorcery?” Still sitting atop a pile of dusty books, the young mage drummed her fingers along the spellbook’s spine, lost in thought. The runes and arrays were useless without the proper incantations, but it was worth some investigation. If by some sort of dumb luck she accidentally discovered the spells missing to cast the Eternal Youth ritual, she could reclaim her title!

“That settles it!" Cracking her knuckles, Kairi opened the creaky, dusty tome once more, landing on a random page near the middle. As it opened, something fell from between the parted pages. It hit the floor with a light clink, drawing the girl’s attention. “What is this?” It appeared to be a solid ring of gold, inlaid with three of the most beautiful garnets she’d ever seen. Even in the dim light of the empty library the ring seemed to shine with a light of its own. “Beautiful…” Captivated by the golden trinket, Kairi unwittingly slipped it over her finger. She quietly gasped when it fit perfectly, almost as if it were crafted just for her! Turning her hand over, she admired the beautiful gold against her fair skin. “It would seem this is my lucky day.” With a contented sigh, the young girl dropped her hand to the book, landing her ring finger directly at the center of an unusual array spanning the whole page. A flash of purple light erupted from the spell tome, swiftly engulfing the girl in its blinding aura.

Whatever spell had activated from her touch left the poor unsuspecting girl unconscious. Before Kairi even awoke, she was no longer in her family’s library. No, the ring and spellbook had actually teleported her away, but where will our heroine’s journey begin?
