15411.content:
Kairi groaned with discomfort as she slowly woke up. She slowly opened her eyes and was surprised to see that she was no longer in her library. She was laying on the floor of what looked like a small bedroom with walls and floors made out of stone. The room was ornately decorated with fur skin rugs and finely woven tapestries on the walls. Only a noble could afford furniture like this, so she must be in a castle.

"What happened?" The mage muttered to herself as she noticed that the book that was still tightly gripped in her hands and the strange ring was still on her finger.

Knowing that it was responsible for this, Kairi dropped the book like it was on fire. She then tried to pull the ring off her finger, but discovered that it could not be removed no matter how hard she pulled!

"Well... the book and the ring are obviously enchanted." The mage remarked. She always found that talking to herself helped to focus her thoughts, "That book got me into this mess, so it's probably the only way to get me out of it."

Moving carefully, Kairi approached the book and slowly opened it, afraid of any other tricks the book could have in it. Thankfully nothing happened. Kairi was surprised to see that some of the pages in the book had changed. Before, she could barely understand must of the words, but now it was like someone had translated some of the pages for her. The first page in particular caught her attention so she began to read it.

...

A Brief History of Lipomancy

Lipomancy is a school of magic centered on various ways to control and manipulate the body weight of any living thing. Lipomancy has been around for thousands of years, but no one remembers the exact origins of this form of magic. There are theories that it was invented by an obese king that was desperate to lose weight so he could get laid. His experiments ended badly when he accidentally made himself so fat that he became immobile. No one knows if that story is true though.

Lipomancy was once an extremely popular form of magic. Lipomancers were often paid a small fortune by overweight nobles that wanted a slim physique, but were too lazy to exercise. However Lipomancy fell out of favor in the year 492 after a Lipomancer went crazy and turned every person in a small city into a fatass and then vanished. Common knowledge of Lipomancy slowly faded after that. Today, most scholars consider Lipomancy to be nothing more than a fairytale.

...

"What a strange form of magic." Kairi remarks as she finishes reading the first page and turns to the second.

...

If you're reading this book, then you must be interested in learning the lost magic of Lipomancy. Learning Lipomancy can grant you great power, but it also comes with great risks. Many novice lipomancers have made themselves permanently obese after accidentally messing up a spell. Some Lipomancer spells cannot be reversed by anyone, even by the caster or another Lipomancer. In such cases, the only way to undo the effects is with diet and exercise.

You should start out with something simple. The most basic Lipomancy spell is known as the Touch Fat spell. It causes the part of the body that the lipomancer touches to gain fat equal to the amount of energy they put into the spell.

...

Kairi reads the instructions for the first spell and then forces herself to stop reading. The book is very interesting, but she should focus on finding a way out of this castle. She picks up the book and opens the door leading out of the room.

On the other side of the door, she comes face to face with a small male goblin! Kairi stares at the small monster in surprise and judging by the look on the creature's face, it is just as surprised to see her! Kairi is so surprised that she reacts instinctively and bonks the goblin on the head with the Lipomancy spell book.

15412.content:
A surge of pain rushed through the young sorceress’ head. However, as Kairi moved to pinch the bridge of her nose, she immediately realized she was lying on her back. The pain dulled beneath the panicked return of her last memories. The purple flash rendered her unconscious, but opening her pained eyes now revealed her surroundings. This was not her library, and somehow she was tucked into… a bed? Not her bed by any means, and Kairi had never seen this room before.

The mage hastily sat up, swinging her feet over the side of the bed. To her relief, whoever tucked her into bed did not take the liberty of changing her clothes. Her hands mindlessly gripped the baggy waistline of her robes before laying their palms atop her slender thighs, lightly gripping the violet fabric. “Wherever could I be?” She frowned and looped a strand of golden hair behind her ear before rising to her feet. The soles of her simple shoes met a wood floor, and peering around the room hinted that she may be at an inn. But her hometown had no inn. “This is absolutely strange…” The young woman glided toward the door, hoping to keep herself hidden for just a bit longer. With an ear to the door, Kairi could hear loud laughter and the hum of a lively tavern. Her room had no window, but she wagered it must be night if the pub had so much business.

“I suppose I should thank my host.” More than a little anxiousness filled the young mage, but she reached for the doorknob before her eyes set on the golden ring. “The book!” Whirling about, Kairi leapt at the bed, frantically rummaging through the bedside drawers, baskets, and she even dove under the bed in search of that wicked tome which spirited her to this strange place. Yet with all her ruckus, she found no sign of the spellbook. The search did yield one result, however, as a knock came to her door. Prone on the floor, Kairi froze. The doorknob creaked, and the mage turned her head with fearful delay. The man who now filled the open doorway quite literally filled the doorway. His frame was almost as broad as it was tall. He wore rough, heavy clothing, but the stained apron tied around his hefty middle identified him as the barkeep.

“Looks like ye be awake, then. How’re ye feelin’, lass?” A thick, northern accent poured from his wide, gapped smile. The warmth of his voice melted the frigid fear in Kairi, and she stumbled to her feet, smoothing out her robes. After clearing her throat, the mage offered a deep curtsy, almost falling over to one side.

“Thank you for allowing me to stay in your fine establishment, sir.” The mage offered a practiced smile, bowing her head some. To her shock, the innkeeper slapped a hand to his belly and burst into deep laughter.

“Sir? Ain’t nobody be callin’ me sir, lass. The name’s Finn. I’m just a simple man who enjoys takin’ care o’ good folk like yerself.” He folded his arms across his wide chest, still beaming. Although still a stranger, something about the man left the young woman feeling more at ease.

“Oh-- I… Yes, how silly of me.” Kairi, bowed her head again before glancing toward the bed. “Thank you again.” A low rumble rose in the pit of her stomach, and she clasped a slim hand over her middle. Redness instantly flushed over the mage’s cheeks, and Finn barked another laugh.

“C’mon, lass. Ye must be starvin’. Let’s get ye somethin’ to eat.” The broad innkeeper bobbed his head, motioning her to follow. Turning about, his footfalls down the stairs sent a slight tremble through the whole floor. Having had no chance to respond, Kairi gnawed at her lip before following after her host. Kairi shut the door behind her and breathed in a familiar scent. The warm, spicy sweetness of cinnamon met her nose and left the mage salivating. Gripping the railing tightly, the poorly balanced mage tread down the stairwell, descending into the soft light of the main tavern. Hunger renewed as the savory scent intensified. To Kairi’s astonishment, the tavern was absolutely packed with patrons, though perhaps the general state of each patron caused this sensation of occupancy. Not one of the people in the pub were anything less than overweight. These folks ate well, and with such a delicious scent in the air it was no wonder why.

“C’mon over, lass. Ye’re just in time fer a fresh batch o’ the wife’s bakin’!” Finn’s voice pierced the buzz of the tavern, and Kairi turned her head toward the bar. Cinnamon rolls. Not just any cinnamon rolls, but the fluffiest, stickiest, most heavenly scented cinnamon rolls that Kairi had ever seen. A small pyramid of the delicacies sat atop a wooden tray, each roll drizzled with a heavy hand of sweet frosting. Kairi all but floated toward the beckoning baked goods. A few of the portly patrons stretched their thick fingers toward the perfectly stacked pyramid, but Finn swatted them away. “Not just yet, lads. Let the lil’ lassie have first pickin’s.” As Kairi approached the high counter, she looked up and was met with a grinning nod from the broad barkeep.

“They smell divine, sir.” She paused, and he raised a brow at her. “Finn.” She smiled and corrected herself before eyeing the pile of pastries. Again the girl gnawed her lip as a low rumble rose in her slim tummy.

“Well go on, lass. No one’s stoppin’ ye.” Somehow his grin widened, but Kairi still felt nothing but warmth from his presence. Each of the cinnamon rolls looked absolutely fantastic, but the mage could only imagine the unhealthiness of such a treat. 154122.content:
Kairi again glanced at the overtly salivating crowd around her, and decided against the baked delight. However, no proper lady wishes to offend her host, and as such the mage offered a polite bow. “I apologize, but sweets often disagree with my stomach. Is there anything else I might be able to eat for supper? Perhaps you have some bread or vegetables?” The innkeepers looked at Kairi as though she had two heads, but quickly sighed and nodded his head.

“Aye, lass. Go on and find yerself a seat. I’ll bring yer meal shortly.” Finn threw the towel onto his shoulder and turned to the kitchen doors.

“Ah! One more thing…” Kairi leaned out across the counter, and the innkeeper paused to glance back. “When you found me unconscious, did you happen to see a book?” The barkeep shrugged and shook his head.

“Book? No, lass I didn’t see a book with ye. Ye were just lyin’ out there in the grass. Lucky I found ye before the snow came in.” Snow. So she must be somewhere in the Northlands. “What sort o’ book was it?”

Kairi paused and made two L’s with her thumbs, creating a square frame in the air. “It was approximately this large, and it was heavy with a purple cover.” Finn still shook his head. “I’m still a little hazy, but I believe the word ‘Lipomancy’ was written on its side.” At that point, the entire bar fell silent. Several utensils hit the tables with soft thuds, and from the kitchen a few mugs could be heard crashing to the floor. Fearful that she had said something forbidden, Kairi scanned the room for any sudden movements. “Did I say something to offend?”

“Our town be lyin’ in the shadow o’ a terrible sorcerer, lass. Calls himself the Lipomancer.” Finn marched back to the counter and snatched her upper arm in his beefy mitt. He squeezed far harder than necessary, and Kairi’s eyes lit up with fear. “What’re ye doin’ pokin’ around in that sort o’ magic?” A vein began popping up along the side of his head. “Ye drop out o’ thin air, ye cannot explain where ye came from, and now ye be askin’ about dark magics. How do we know ye ain’t a spy fer the wicked, crafty ol’ Lipomancer?” His nostrils flared, and Kairi uttered a one-word cantrip, sending a light shock into the man’s hand. He immediately released her, and the young mage fell backwards, hitting the floor rump first with a thump.

“Ow!” She gritted her teeth, but to her surprise, the pain wasn’t coming from her backside, but from her stomach. Suddenly she felt like she hadn’t eaten in days, though the sensation would soon be drowned out by fear.

“Ack! The damn brat zapped me! She’s a witch! I knew it!” Finn barked, clutching his hand in pain. She hadn’t intended to hurt him, but the panic in her chest must have empowered the spell a little. Now all of the overweight bar patrons were circling around the young woman. “Get her!”

Kairi uttered the initiator of a fire spell and stretched out her hand, palming a globe of fire in front of her. “Stay back! Allow me to leave in peace and I shall not harm you!” The superstitious townsfolk begrudgingly obliged, stepping away from Kairi as she took her exit. With a slam she shut the door behind her, immediately gasping at the cold, night air. Her breath clung to the cold breeze before blowing off into the dark, and the abrupt change in temperature broke her concentration on the fire spell.

Summer time in the Northlands did not make much impact on the weather, and Kairi was dressed for her home in the far south. Each gust of bitter wind cut right through her simple robes. If she didn’t want to freeze to death, she’d need to fight off the cold. Weaving her hands, Kairi uttered her invocations and a soft glow encased her frame. A re-purposed fire enchantment would keep her warm, but only for so long. If she wanted to survive out here long enough to get back she’d need to equip herself with proper winter wear. Scanning the dark street, Kairi saw what appeared to be a shop closed for the night. In a dash she scurried to the door and found it locked.

For any non-magic user this would have been problematic, but for the once and future Omnimancer, it was a simple solution. Kairi reached into her reagent pouch and withdrew a simple stick of copper, no longer than her index finger. Quietly she whispered her words of power, and the key seemed to almost melt into the lock. With one final word it re-solidified. A single, simple turn saw the door unlocked, and Kairi took no time to look around before scuttling inside. She shut the door behind her and leaned on it just as she dissipated the fire enchantment. It was still cold in the dark shop, but there was no wind to freeze her bones. From the initial looks of it, the young woman guessed to be some sort of general store. “Perfect. They ought to have at least a coat or something I can--” An audible growl rose from her stomach, and Kairi doubled over in pain. Just as before, the pain came out of nowhere, though this time it was twice as painful. Perhaps she should have eaten that cinnamon roll after all. Stumbling forth, the mage pushed the pain out of her mind, at least for the moment. Several minutes were spent rummaging through the various drawers and containers located about the poorly organized store, but what Kairi found was no coat.

In one drawer, under a pile of scrolls lay a familiar purple tome. “Ah! There you are.” Kairi grasped the book and immediately tucked it beneath one arm. With this she at least had some semblance of hope to return home. However, upon turning about, the young woman found...
