"Wait! No! Stop! Please!" A young catgirl in a dancer's outfit cried out as a shadowy figure flew above her, before dropping down and blocking the only escape from the room.

"Color Spray," The figure muttered, and instantly, the victim was overwhelmed by a vivid assortment of colors, to the point where her mind had to shutdown to block out the painfully bright images. As the feline's body fell, a clawed hand reached out and stood it back upright, before a set of long fangs bit down at the base of the neck, and began draining the dancer of about a quarter of precious bodily fluids. After about a minute of draining the victim, the predator casted the body to the floor, before letting out a loud belch.

"Man, i really need to cut back," The figure said as it lit a candle, revealing that the young dancer was just one of about a half-dozen entertainers who had fallen before the assassin Hemia. She was a dark gray furred vampirebat with black-tipped ears and eyes as red as her favorite drink. She was reknowned throughout the countryside as a deadly hunter who specialized in illusions to distract her targets before she went in for the kill; though honestly, if you were to look at her now, you wouldn't be able to guess that contract killing was her profession of choice. Ever since that man had made her an offer she couldn't refuse, Hemia had been camping out in Greenshire waiting for her targets to pass by in the area. What she hadn't expected to find was that almost all of the inhabitants of the prospering city were overweight and that their blood was filled with enough sugar and fat to keep a bakery running. Consequently, in the month or so she'd been waiting for her targets to arrive, she had put on a good 40 pounds, the majority of it going straight to her belly, causing a sizable muffin top to replace the bat's once rock-hard midsection. At the very least, finding new clothes that fit was never a problem here, as she found out that the dancer outfit her latest meal had been wearing conviently happened to be a perfect fit.

Hemia removed a letter from between her generously sized cleavage and quickly skimmed through it again. The targets were a vixen and wolfess adventuring pair that were traveling in the area. Likely to have some sort of combat skills and be wary of a potential attack. Once apprehended or slain, they were to be taken back immediately to Castle Darkcloud, where the agreed upon price would be paid in full.

"Well, Lucille and Rose, I don't know who you are or what you did, but if he's willing to pay this much for you guys, how can I say no?"

The illusionist assassin let out a chuckle as she dragged all of the unconcious and blood-starved servants under a tarp she had brought along for the occasion, before stepping out and collecting a truely enormous serving dish from the front counter and began lugging the thing up the rather long flight of stairs.

-----------------------------

"So, Rose, what are you gonna do with your share of the reward money?"

"One should not consider the prize before it has been won," the wolfess monk said stoically- before dropping the act and resuming her usual smile. "But I have afeeling that I already know what you'll be buying when this is all over."

"Really now, is my recent...weight...problem all you can talk about?" The vixen let out an exasperated sigh as she collapsed onto her rather large and plush bed.

Rose let out another chuckle as the two picked up the sound of panting coming from behind their door. Followed by a few seconds later by the sound of knocking.

"The help's here!" Lucille said as she lept out of her seating position to her feet in a single movement. "About time too, I haven't had a good bath in over a week!"

The door began to slide open, revealing a chubby female figure clothed in an Arabic style dance garb which managed to both look revealing and conceal her identity at the same time- well, it hid her facial features anyway, the pair of hairless wings sticking out of her back made it glaringly obvious to the adventuring pair that their entertainer for tonight was a bat.

"What?" The vixen said, sounding rather underwhelmed. "We only get one? Gwen seemed to imply that there would be atleast a few of you."

"Oh, I assure you my lady," The bat said in an alluring voice. "I'm all that you'll be requiring tonight."

As the last syllabel exited the dancer's mouth, the lighting in the room seemed to all pinpoint on her; and with a snap of her fingures, a dozen lovely copies of herself materialized in the room.

"And now, my ladies, please enjoy this lovely feast that has been prepared for you."

The bat pulled the top off the platter, revealing an assortment of meat so vast neither woman could truely comprehend it. There were boar ribs, cow flanks, chicken breasts, bear steaks, and veal; it was like a little platter from carnivore heaven.

The meal was placed on top of the table set aside in the back of the room, and the vixen and wolfess began digging into the meal with great vigor; clearly rather pekish after the long trek into town. As the two adventurers ate, wonderous music seemed to fill the room from nowhere as the dozen bat girls began to sensuously dance in key to the ebb and flow of the sounds. After about twenty minutes, the feasting duo managed to lick every single of the many bones now scattered about the place clean.

"Ohhhhhh!" Lucille let out a slight moan as she rubbed her swollen middle. "That...that was good!"

The dozen bat girls all chuckled in unison, before they all took a few steps closer to the now bloated adventurers.

"Now, my ladies. Before either of you ask anything else of me this evening, I ask but one small request from the two of you..."

"Oh, and what would that be?" The vixen turned herself towards the bats with no small ammount of effort.

"Hold still for a moment, would you?"
15533222221121122.title: Spoiling the party...

choices: One big meal, and Hemia snaps like a wicker chair.
Hemia holds out for almost a week.
155332222211211222.content:
"Hold her arms, umph -- I've almost got her tied -- there!"

"One more thing." Lucille socked the hapless bat in the face. "That's for making me fight on a full stomach!"

A groaning, trussed-up Hemia was tossed onto the bed. "I ... I don't understand... how I could lose to these porkers..."

Lucille raised an eyebrow. "Excuse me? Have you looked in a mirror lately?"

"It's this town... this town ... so much food... so easy to catch..." Hemia panted. "Why couldn't you have gotten here three weeks ago, you stinking dawdlers? I had a waist three weeks ago!"

"So that's your game?" Rose growled. "You were planning to feast on a two-course meal of stuffed adventurer? Well, looks like you'll be going hungry tonight."

"For the first time in, uh, probably your whole life," Lucille added.

"No!" Hemia said. "No, I wasn't going to eat you!"

"So you say now."

"It's the truth! I've been guzzling blood all day. I couldn't drink another drop. I swear!"

Rose flipped the frantic bat over and put one hand on her abdomen. "Tight as a drum. She's telling the truth."

"Then why did you attack us?" Lucille snapped. "Did someone send you? Who?"

"Not... telling!" Hemia spat.

Lucille rolled up her sleeves. "I guess I'll just have to knock it out of that fat head of yours."

"Do you worst! I know you goody-goody adventurers types. You'd never be able to bring yourself to kill a helpless prisoner, and I don't care about being smacked around a little. You have to let me go sooner or later, and when you do... I can kiss this stupid sugar heap goodbye!"

"I think you'll talk," Rose said, "if we hold something you value hostage."

"You don't have anything I care about!"

"What about your figure? Or should I say, what's left of it?" Rose grinned. "You see, I know your type... all show and big ego, but no willpower at all. I'm fairly certain your instincts will drive you to gulp blood as fast as we can put it to your lips. If you ever want to assassinate someone by a method other than sitting on them again, you'll tell us what we want to know."

"You -- you're lying! You wouldn't dare!"

"Oh, wouldn't we? Lucille, start rounding up volunteers. This is going to take more blood than the two of us have. A lot more. And I think the people of this town will be very interested in helping once they learn that our exotically dressed friend here has been treating them as her own personal buffet."

"Right," Lucille said grimly. Hemia paled.
155332222211211222.title: Bound Bat

choices: "It was... The Lipomancer!"
"I don't know his name... But he lives at Castle Darkcloud I think!"
1553322222112112221.content:
Lucille flung open the door to their room and rushed through the hallway and down the stairs, ignoring the slight wobble of her taut belly. She didn't want to leave Rose alone for too long with the bat, even if she was tied up and apparently helpless. As she was entering the front room of the inn, she stopped, wondering just who she could get to help them in their noble, though remarkably odd task. While the townsfolk might very well enjoy a bit of payback, would they really be willing to part with even a fraction of blood? Who could she find to help them with such an unorthodox and painful form of interrogation?

The vixen stood there before the front desk with her chin on her paw thoughtfully, starting to think that maybe this wasn't the best of plans...

“Excuse me Miss, do you need help with anything?”

Lucille turned towards the gently inquiring voice and grinned as she saw Gwen still standing behind the check-in counter. The white, tubby dragoness merely stood there, a nave yet curious look on her face: The look that said she’d do anything to make her guests happy.

“Yes! Yes you can!” Lucille said, her grin widening even more.


“I’m sorry, but you want me to do… what?” Gwen said, absentmindedly poking her plump lip with a clawed finger as she frowned.

“This bat tried to kill us, and isn't telling us why, sooooo we figured the best way to get her to talk is to, umm… overfeed her,” Lucille said as she looked over at Rose, now definitely uncertain of their plan.

“Right…” The dragoness responded, placing her hands on her wide hips, “And you want me to just… let it bite me?”

“Errr… yes?” Rose said, scratching behind her neck as she looked away from Gwen, feeling more than a little uncomfortable asking somebody to sacrifice their blood for them, “It seemed like a better idea earlier…”

“Yeah, I was pretty enthusiastic about it until now…” Agreed Lucille.

“I could have told you it was stupid!” Hemia growled, “Jeeze, I always thought canines were dumb as bricks, but you two? Ooooh boy… I’d say you two take the cake, but looks like you already did!” She said, cackling at her own joke.

“Oh shut it!” Lucille said, giving the bloated bat a kick to her blood-filled stomach, not enough to be too painful, but it did make her wince and send her paunch jiggling.

“Why not just take her to the city guard?” Gwen asked.

“If we do that, then we’ll never find out why she was sent to kill us!” Lucille pointed out, “They’ll just lock her away somewhere for the rest of her life in some dank, dark pit.”

Hemia’s face grew pale once more.

Rose looked from Lucille to Gwen, “If she was even sent by anybody at all… She won’t even tell us that much!”

Gwen looked at the murderous bat lying on the bed with her arms tied behind her while the bat herself looked away from them all, a pouting expression on her face. The dragoness seemed to think about it for a minute before finally deciding, “Alright, I’ll do it.”



Not long after she agreed to it, the pudgy dragon girl found herself sitting on the bed next to Hemia, who began to kick and struggle against her bonds as the two adventurers grabbed her and brought her into a sitting position.

“You’re sure you want to do this?” Rose asked Gwen.

The innkeeper nodded without hesitation, “If it could help save you girls’ lives, then of course.”

Rose nodded in gratitude, and then brought Hemia’s head against the dragoness’s shoulder which caused Gwen to wince, fully expecting the painful puncture of the fangs against her softer scales at any moment. At first Hemia only struggled, pushing against Rose’s grip on her head and Lucille’s hold on her pudgy sides, “You let go of me you filthy hogs! I’m not going to eat! I told you I was full!”

“It’s not going to work Rose!” Lucille cried out to her partner.

“Just hold her still!” The wolf barked back.

Hemia’s eyes widened as her large, sensitive ears twitched, picking up the subtle, but distinct sound of Gwen’s blood pulsing through her veins. Her mouth hung open as she stared at the dragoness’s neck, the bat, despite being stuffed full, drooling ever so slightly. Gwen looked about nervously for a moment, having second thoughts,
“This isn’t going to hurt much… is i-EEP!”

She was interrupted by Hemia’s piercing bite, the bat ravenously lapping at the blood that leaked from the dragoness’ neck. Gwen whimpered, but held still, closing her eyes and trying to think of other things than the blood being drained from her. Meanwhile Hemia seemed to be enjoying herself, even as her stomach stretched wider and wider, trying to accommodate the influx of blood. The bat continued for a long while, even as she grew painfully full, now looking as if she were in a stupor as she leaned fang-first against the dragoness, her eyelids drooped while she indulged herself fully in her literal bloodlust. She did not stop until Rose and Lucille forced her to, pulling her roughly away from her meal and tossing the bat back onto the bed.

Gwen swooned woozily, Lucille catching the dragoness before she hit the floor, “Are you okay? I think we might have gone a little overboard…” The fox said, wincing a little.

“I’m… I’m fine…” The dragon girl groaned softly, looking a bit weary, but not in any danger, “Just need to rest a bit…”

Lucille nodded and helped the hefty innkeeper to her feet, guiding her over to a nearby chair while Rose strutted along the bed to look their would-be assassin over. Hemia laid on her back, sinking into the plush bed quite a bit as she groaned and whined in pain. Her belly was now grotesquely bloated, not so much sticking out of her dancer’s outfit as exploding forth from it, wobbling with each breath she took.

“Aww, looks like somebody’s had too much to drink!” She teased, grinning as she looked down at the helpless vampire bat, “What did she call us earlier babe?”

Lucille looked over at her partner as she helped settle the woozy dragoness into her chair, the seat creaking audibly, “Uhhh… Porkers?”

“Nah, we addressed that one… The one she just called us…” The wolf said, chuckling as she looked back at the groaning bat who squirmed and whined in pain.

“Oh!” Lucille gasped as her ears shot up and she turned around to look at them, “Filthy hogs!”

Rose snickered as she placed her paw on the bat’s distended, blood-packed gut as pushed down firmly, “Ah yes, that’s right, filthy…!” She pushed down harder, making the bat girl gasp in discomfort, “Hogs!”

“Please…!” She squealed, moaning as she lolled her head about and panted feverishly, “Stop this you sick freaks! This is awful! Too much damn blood…”

“Oh I will hun… As soon as you tell us why you were trying to murder us!” She sneered down at Hemia as she pressed her paw more firmly into the bat’s stomach, laughing in surprised glee as she forced a loud, wet belch from the assassin, “Heh, and she called us filthy Lucille!”

“She would know it seems…” The vixen smiled as she walked over to the other side of the bed, poking and prodding at the bat’s exposed, bulging belly, making her whine and wobble, “Maybe we could feed her some of our blood too Rose, doubt she could take a drop more…”

“Naaaahh…” Rose looked up at her partner, grinning eagerly, a wicked gleam in her eyes, “I bet she could take a whole cup at least, maybe a gallon of blood!”

Hemia let out a strained wheezing gasp of utter terror, her lip quivering as she squeezed her eyes shut, “You barbarians! You merciless bitches! FINE DAMMIT! I’ll tell you who hired me!” She groaned suddenly, her belly sloshing painfully, “Just leave me and my fucking tummy alone!”

The two partners looked at each other and grinned. "Fair enough! So then, who was it?" Rose asked.
Hemia pouted before reluctantly telling the duo the truth... Or was it?
1553322222112112221.title: Treating Hemia to a Drink

choices: "Let us gather some supplies first, it may be quite the journey."
"We may need another ally for our new quest. Perhaps a Paladin or a Cleric?"
15533222221121122212.content:
"I don't know his name, but he lives at Castle Darkcloud I think!"

Luicille glared at the bat. "You think?"

"Yes, I think!" Hemia spat back, before wincing in pain. "Look, I never actually met the guy, I just recieved the request in the usual manner and it said to drop you two off there when I was done with you."

"What was the name the request was put under?" Lucille continued.

"I-I don't know! The name at the bottom was too illegible to read."

"Uh huh," Lucille began pulling her sleeve up to expose the veins in her arms. "Okay, this is crap. I hope you don't mind some more stretch marks."

"Wait," Rose said, placing a hand in front of her companion as she began to think back to the start of their adventure. "Lucille, do you remember how we got in contact with our current employer?"

"Uh..." Lucille tried to think back that far, she normally left the more boring parts of their job to Rose. "We got a letter, right?"

"That is correct. We got a letter with no return address signed off at the bottom in a language I wasn't familiar with." Rose reached into a small bag in a pile with the rest of their adventuring gear, pulled out the letter in question, and began to read it out loud. "'When the targets have been aprehended, deliver them to the castle up high on the Gray Cliffs.'"

"What?!" Hemia blurted out, before the pain from her midsection reminded her that she didn't have the luxary of yelling. "That's where Castle Darkcloud is!"

"T-that has to be a coincidence." Lucille said. Wishing she could sound more certain.

"It isn't! Castle Darkcloud is the only place around on the Gray Cliffs. Everyone else ran away apparently because it was 'haunted'..Oh, this is some conspiracy bullshit, isn't it?!" Hemia winced again in pain as she let out another beltch, her body doing it's best to digest the massive amount of blood before her lack of an indoor voice proved to be the death of her.

"If what you said is true," Lucille responded, still not keen on accepting the posibillity that this whole figure destroying trip was a setup. "Do you have anything to prove to us that your story checks out?"

"Duh, I have the letter stored in my boobs, if you'd just-"

"No need," Rose said as she reached down into the bat's cleavage and swiped the paper.

"Hey!" Hemia shouted, unable to come up with a good insult at this point, she settled on mumbling something under her breath. "pervert..."

Ignoring her, Rose unfolded the letter and read through it. Sure enough, it was scribbled by the same hand that had writen the request that they had recieved a month ago; down to the alien signature at the bottom. Rose passed the two letters off to Lucille, who saw the weird signature as proof enough that the assassin wasn't lying.

"Holy shit! We've been had!"

"So it seems," Rose said in agreement, before smiling. "Well, it appears as though our employer very much wanted us to meet you, Miss Bat."

"Rose, how can you be joking at a time like this?" Lucille said indignantly. "Whoever this Darkcloud guy is tried to have us assassinated."

"Yes, but why? We're hardly what one might call big time adventurers, and we've done nothing to offend Lord or Lady Darkcloud. There has to be another reason behind this."

"Well, we aren't going to find out just hanging around here! C'mon, let's pay the Gray Cliffs a visit." Lucille said as she began repacking the things she had taken out mere hours ago.

"Wait! What about me?" Hemia complained.

"What about you? You're probably going to hang." Lucille said dismissively.

Hemia began to panic. "B-but you'll never be able to get there without me! There's this stupid mist all around the place, I've been in the area before, and the only reason I know up from down there is because I can fly."

"Oh? Well I'm afraid you won't be doing that much anytime soon." Rose teased as she pressed down on the bat's exposed middle again.

"Stop that! and I can too still fly! And I can do illusions, and judging by our fight earlier, neither of you have ever even cast Ghost Sound!"

"True, but if we were to let you go, what's to stop you from attacking us again?"

Hemia sighed, knowing that this was her chance to avoid being sent to prison and possibly executed, did her best to sound reasonable. "Look, I've been through this conspiracy thing before. I was never meant to kill you two and I sure as shit wasn't going to be paid if I did. I want to find the asshole who set this up and make him pay for ruining my figure!"

Rose chuckled, before turning to Lucille. "Well, she seems trustworthy enough to me, what do you think?"

Lucille frowned. She wasn't comfortable having a bloodsucker as a party member, and she really wasn't looking forward to having to deal with Hemia yelling all the time.

"...Alright, fine." Lucille agreed, if only because having a guide meant they'd get there quicker. "But if I think that for any reason that you're going to betray us, I will rip off your wings and make you drink them dry."

"Yes, fine, whatever! Now for the love of gods untie me!"

"Done," Rose undid the knot in almost an instant, and the vampire bat spread her limbs and wings across the incredibly soft bed as quickly as she could.

"Aaaahhh... much better." Hemia moaned.

Lucille looked up from her packing work. "Okay, Rose. So what's the plan now?"
15533222221121122212.title: The Story unfolds.

choices: Fiffnick goes to meet  Rose, Lucille and Hemia.
Suddenly, she notices a special condition on the request.
155332222211211222122.content:
"Having a little healing on hand would be a good idea," Lucille agreed. "You've been here for a while, chubs. What are the dominant faiths around here?"

"Don't call me chubs," Hemia said wearily.

"Whatever you say, tubs--and I'm waiting for an answer."

"Well..." Hemia began. She paused to burp. "There are the Maloricans, my personal favorites. They conduct blood sacrifices..."

Her face turned green. "N-never mind."

"No evil cults," Rose said. "Who else?"

"The Valos, bunch of hard-asses, hate magic--no good if you want me along, and the Romarians, who don't have much in the way of powers or patron gods at all, and then there are the Sisters of the Wheel."

"What are they like?"

Hemia sneered. "They're mice."

"They're nice?"

"That, too."

-----

"Thank you so much, priestess!" the young mouse woman sobbed happily, clutching her little pink bundle of joy to her chest. Several dozen more precious little treasures were clustered around her ankles, tugging on her skirt, punching each other, wailing, and picking their noses. "If it wasn't for the Sisters caring for him, little Squirmathy might not have made it!"

"We did no more than do our duty in the name of cheeses," High Priestess Sniffletwip said solemnly, making the Sign of the Hole-y Wheel on her chest as she invoked the holiest of foodstuffs.

"Well, I-I know it's not much, but I baked you a little something," the beaming mother said, removing a package from the folds of her robes. "They're cheddar crumpets!"

The Priestess' heart sank--not that it could go very far before encountering her stomach. A stomach which had already been treated today to brie and crackers for giving the morning blessings, and bread slathered in mozzarella courtesy of a lonely old woman, and gorgonzola biscuits, and camembert cookies, and six slices of good old fashioned cheesecake...

"Oh, no, I couldn't possibly," she said feebly, even as the woman pushed the bundle into her hands. With such generous parishoners, the priestess reflected, it's lucky we don't regard gluttony as a sin...

But there was such a thing as far too much of a good thing, and the Sisters of the Wheel hadn't been immune to the recent...thickening around the town. In fact, most of them had grown nearly round as balls of late under the constant avalanche of baked goods.

Sighing, Sniffletwip took an enormous bite and favored the young woman with a grateful smile. As soon as she and her brood were out of sight, the priestess groaned and dropped the half-eaten biscuit back in the package.

"Finish these, would you?" she said to a pudgy young acolyte. The girl squeaked in dismay. "B-but I just got back from the orphanage bake sale!"

The high priestess shot her a look and the acolyte gulped. "Right away, High Priestess. D-down the hatch!"

With that bit of business polished off, Sniffletwip turned to the next matter on her plate (she really needed some new metaphors...): the Sisters had received an inquiry into the possibility of hiring an adventure-worthy companion. The cause--preserving life--was just, and the fee for such an endeavor could be put to good use helping the needy. The only problem, Sniffletwip had to admit, was that quite frankly, hardly any of the Sisters were in any shape for adventuring.

With one exception.

Sniffletwip found her in the courtyard, a whirl of silver mail and platinum-blonde hair, her great ears shiny with sweat as she danced around the practice dummies.

"Fiffnick?" she asked.

The buff young acolyte spun and bowed without missing a step or losing her balance. "Yes, High Priestess?"

"I have a special mission for you," Sniffletwip said solemnly. "Thanks to your, er--"

She glanced at numerous perforated, ventilated, and generally decapitated training dummies.

"--exuberant lifestyle, you're the only member of the Swiss Guard who's kept herself fit enough to adventure."

"Adventure?" Fiffnick said, frowning. "That is hardly a holy pastime."

"Perhaps not, my child, but it can be a noble one." Sniffletwip smiled sadly. "Besides, it may be a good idea for you to leave for a while, before whatever immunity you carry to this recent, er... largening...fails you."

"It's nothing more than exercise, discipline and a healthy diet," Fiffnick protested, but she examined the job description she'd been handed.

"Hmm. Very well, then. Tell these unscrupulous-looking ladies they'll have their paladin."
155332222211211222122.title: Mus Muscular!

The party gets sidetracked.
1553322222112112221221.content:
Fiffnick strode off the training field and made her way towards the monastery foyer where her employers would be waiting. Sliding her longsword into it's sheeth as she walked, the paladin couldn't help but to think about the... peculiar condition that had befallen her home. While she knew better than to expect everyone to have the strength of will and divine discipline that she possessed, the speed at which the town had... grown, to put it nicely, had to be unnatural. At first her mind had immediately jumped to suspecting the Maloricans and the other heretical cults that the town had foolishly allowed to set root. However even after numerous raids into the holes they whispered dark words in, she was unable to find any evidence that the cults had any link to the town's current dilemma. The source, she mused, must lie elsewhere in the surrounding countryside.

But that would have to wait. For now she had to see to her duties as a Paladin of the Sisters of the Wheel. The Foyer was only a short walk away from the field, and by the time she had finished her thoughts on the matter at hand she was already opening the door to a very... unorthodox scene. There were three women waiting for her. A slightly plump Vixen with a bow watching with frustration as a still foot wolfess danced around with glee as a gray bat tried in vain to land a hit on her with her claws.

"Gah! Goddammit hold still!"

"Oh? Is this too much for you? Perhaps I should close my eyes and stuff my ears as well? I think you may stand a chance of striking me yet."

"Excuse me." The mouse barked, causing the quarrel to stop, but not before the wolf jabbed the bat in the side, causing her exposed midriff to jiggle.

"I'm assuming that you three are the ones who requested my assistance?"

"Why yes," Rose said, with more than a hint of smugness leftover from tormenting the bloodsucker. "My name is Rose, and this is my companion Lucille." Rose made a quick gesture to the Vixen behind her. "And this is-"

"A vampire bat," Fiffnick said with disdain as the mouse got a better look at Hemia's fangs. "You keep strange company, miss Rose."

"Yeah well, she's not our friend or anything." Lucille spoke up. "We just need her to show us where Castle Darkcloud is so we can kick whoever's living there in the ass."

"...Kick them in the ass?" The Paladin's mood lowered. "So you hired my services to get revenge on a noble?"

"To be fair, said noble tried to have us killed." Rose added, lifting the mouse's hopes slightly. "And we're not even sure that the person is a noble. The land around the castle has been abandoned for some time."

"I see,"Fiffnick nodded, before turning to face Hemia. "I'm warning you, bat. If I catch you trying to feast on anyone, I will cut you down."

"If I catch you feasting on anyone!" Hemia spat in a poor imitation of the mouse.

"Enough. You're on thin ice as it is, do not make things worse for yourself." Rose glared at Hemia.

"Fine, whatever. I'll just starve to death. Stupid racist paladins. Always jumping to conclusions and thinking they know best."

With that Hemia stormed out of the monastery, unfurled her wings, and took off. "This way, assholes!"

Lucille bit her lip and put her hand on her bow. "Can I please just shoot her?"

"No, we may need her help yet. Now come, she's moving quite fast for one her size."

Fiffnick watched as the two canines took off after the bat. It took quite a bit of effort to not sigh in frustration at the whole spectacle.

"This, is going to be a long journey."
1553322222112112221221.title: A full party/ The adventure continues.

155332222211212.content:
"It is your mind that ails you. Please, tell me what troubles your thoughts." The wolfess looked to Lucille with a soft smile, in that all-understanding way the monk had about her. Rose had known the vixen all her life, though there was the obvious divide between where they learned their techniques, and how they viewed their health. The ranger took a deep breath and sighed, nodding to the lupine.

"Alright. You have to promise me you're not going to give me any weird looks or anything, cause... I've been having these weird dreams lately. Recurring nightmares, I guess you could say. Can I sit down?" The vixen asked, with Rose immediately releasing her friend's wrists before backing away. Sweeping her cloak off the ground, Lucille came to sit upon a tree trunk that had been felled, but not collected. The wolfess calmly sat next to her troubled comrade and placed a hand on her shoulder, leaning in with a soft smile.

"You can tell me anything, Lucille. I believe it's in your best interest to get this load off your chest. You'll feel better, trust me." Those last two words were wasted. There was no one Lucille trusted more than Rose, though the vixen was still nervous about telling her exactly what was on her mind. The fox hunched forward, clasping her slender paws in one another, before she finally spoke up.

"There's always some sort of variation, but... I'll tell you about the one I had last night."

"Last night? Forgive me for saying, but I could um..." The wolfess grinned a little, "I could smell that you were quite pleased with whatever dream you had." Lucille's cheeks flushed pink, and she shook her head.

"That's the scary part, Rose. I'm terrified of what happens, but I always get..." She squeezed her thighs tight, obviously ashamed. "I'm sorry, but here goes nothing..."
*****
The vixen seemed to wake in the world of her own dream, gasping and looking about to find that she was in a cell. Cool stone walls surrounded her, with heavy iron bars to her frontside. Distant groans came down the torchlit hall, the voices mostly female ones, muffled in one way or another. Accompanying those ominous tones was the sound of belching, which served to revolt the vixen a bit as she attempted to move forward, but was stopped by the iron shackles around her wrists, effectively keeping her against the wall with her hands above her head. As if being in bondage wasn't demeaning enough, she soon discovered she was stark naked, her ample breasts freely wobbling as she struggled, and her fuzzy crotch wide open to any of her captors. At the very least, her ankles weren't spread with bars, though she was getting a bit uncomfortable with the hard, moist stone against her pert rump. A soft chuckle came down the hall, a male voice unlike any she'd heard before ringing in her ears before a hooded and cloaked figure appeared, lifting a key to the iron door and unlocking it, throwing it open. She couldn't be able to make out what he looked like under the hood, but she did see a pair of gnarled hands raising up, making an arcane gesture that seemed to start something rolling down the hall, squealing the whole way.

"Ah, Lucille. I do so love a new arrival who hasn't fallen to many of my traps. I daresay I may enjoy treating you to my hospitality better than the others." He chuckled again, approaching the nude vixen as she snarled and tugged on her binds, the squealing getting louder as a metal cart approached the door and slipped inside the cell, right next to the cloaked man.

"Let me out of this stuff and I'll kill you quickly." The vixen balled her fists, the futility of her resistance bringing forth a full-on laugh from the mass of dark robes before her. He seemed to be shaking his head as he turned his attention to the cart, lifting a silver lid from a tray, revealing a large stack of warm cinnamon rolls, drenched in icing. Reaching inward, he grabbed one of the large treats and raised it to Lucille's maw, waving it in front of her face teasingly as his spare hand settled on her hip, working inward towards the white fur on her trim tummy, pressing inward.

"You're not going anywhere. Your new job is to sit back, relax, and get hungry." Those bony fingertips pressed firmly inward at the vixen's stomach, causing her to wince and open her mouth just slightly enough for the hooded man to stuff that sweet roll into her mouth. Lucille's cheeks bulged with the stuff, her tongue taking in the taste of that fresh dough, the spice of cinnamon and sugar mingling with the rich creamy frosting. Though she was rather indignant with a bit of the icing dripping from her lips, she began to chew and start swallowing the delicious pastry, narrowing her eyes at the seeming void in the hood. "Not so bad, is it? Have another." Quickly grabbing for another roll, the man in the hood saw that Lucille was going to be difficult, swallowing the first treat and turning her face sharply away, cheeks flushed with embarrassment. "What's the matter, my dear? Don't you want more?"

"I'm not hungry, you bastard." The vixen tried focusing on a brick in the wall, preparing for the bony fingers to press into her white stomach again. But instead of pressure, the vixen nearly doubled over, an immense hunger pang hitting her as her knees buckled slightly, groaning loudly. She suddenly felt like she hadn't eaten for days, and at the risk of looking stupid, she lunged for the roll in the man's hand, snatching it up greedily, her cheeks bulging once more as icing dripped down her lips, the treat disappearing with a big gulp, sending that fattening food right down into her belly as it gurgled and growled for more. "Gimme another!"

"That's what I like to hear." The hooded man lifted his palms, the remainder of the pastries rising into the air before the vixen's maw, jamming themselves inside while Lucille held her mouth open, salivating as she messily started to bite through each and every one. Every mouthful became a lump in her throat, traveling downward to settle in that tummy that was proving to be not so very thin anymore. Whatever magics the man had worked on the ranger, whatever potions brewed into those gooey treats, she was starting to fill out instantly while she ate. A deep belch made her belly jiggle, the stomach having curved outward into a doughy dome of flesh, with pudge all over making her breasts fuller and heavy, not to mention making her thighs and butt nice and soft to the touch. That touch was first experienced by that hooded man, leaning in close to the vixen as she gorged, taking big handfuls of an ever-expanding ass as Lucille's belly wobbled more and more, brushing into the man's robes as two hefty rolls of fox gut began to form, dimpling in along the line of the fox's navel. "Such a good girl. You show much promise, my dear." Another teasing chuckle came from that hood as Lucille snarfed down the last of the pastries, panting after swallowing it down. The poor girl had to be at least three hundred pounds, sporting chubby cheeks and a double chin smattered with warm icing, and a bloated body with breasts approaching the size of her head. Those gnarled hands trailed upward along the vixen's form, taking a squeeze of her love handles, jiggling her tummy, and taking a few firm gropes of sensitive breastflesh.

"A-aah... stop... please..." The vixen pleaded, her hunger having subsided, replaced by the shame of being reduced to such gluttony, not to mention being aroused by the freak in the robes handling her tits. It was simply pointless, fighting that urge when her body was so warm, soft, laden with fat and skin stretched to being sensitive about just any touch. Her nethers became moist as the gnarled hands tweaked her pink nipples slightly, a moan escaping her messy maw as she looked into the hood, finding a long tongue snaking towards her lips from the void, licking at the icing upon her lips, the hooded figure obviously taking pleasure in feeling the vixen's shaky, warm breath upon his tongue.

"I shall stop if you can honestly tell me you want me to." When the figure's reply was only a blushing, chubby vixen looking bashfully back at him, that long tongue surged forward along with the rest of him, tightly pinning the flabby foxy against the wall. That slimy muscle wrapped around Lucille's tongue, filling her maw and snaking down her throat, her eyes half-lidding at the overwhelming lust radiating from the man, the darkness of his hood taking over her vision before she eventually woke.
*****
As the vulpine finished recounting her tale, she rubbed at her arm underneath her cloak, while her friend the wolfess sat with wide eyes, still digesting that tale of rapid digestion.

"Well, I am not sure of this dream's meaning, but... perhaps it is best you come to terms with the fact that you enjoyed it." Rose said, sliding closer to the ranger and putting a comforting hand upon her thigh. "Perhaps you need a holiday. Time to clear your head and perhaps indulge a little."

"Well, that's very kind, but you know we can't afford any lost time. I'd rather find this book and make a clean profit, not have some creepy old man stuff my face." Lucille smirked, and Rose laughed softly, rising to her feet and helping the vixen to hers. They began walking to their next destination, an old stone fortress in the distance, worn with time and apparently abandoned. Along the way, Lucille couldn't help but dwell on her dream. She couldn't seem to decide if she liked it or not. Being so fat and helpless... she didn't even know if the feeling of gaining that much weight would be as good in the dream as reality. Then again, the pleasure -was- convincing. She eventually decided that...

155332222212.content:
INTRODUCTION:

CHARACTERS:

Veradelia: A dark-skinned human female sorceress from the desert, Veradelia specializes in reagent magic, and can cast a variety of magics. She is sultry, sarcastic and can easily become bored by down time. Sleep is her favorite pastime. Some describe her as carefree. Veradelia has a natural pear-shaped body toned with no visible fat. Most of the time her dark, thick hair hangs at a medium length just above her shoulders. Veradelia stands at a modest height of five feet even.

Laeryn: Laeryn is an elven female ranger, and specializes in survival tactics. Her weapon of choice is her longbow, which she wields with deadly accuracy. She is reserved and almost always serious. Her comrades see her as a stick in the mud, but they know she is the most logical and will usually follow her advice. This elf has a naturally slender hourglass body with slight bust and hips. She keeps her blonde hair tied up in a high ponytail, and she has pale skin. Laeryn stands at an average height of five and a half feet.

Gwendi: Gwendi is a halfling rogue who specializes in pickpocketing, lockpicking, and general sneakiness. Most of the time she is skittish and shy, but has a certain curiosity toward most things around her. One might confuse her stature and size with innocence, but as a thief she is hardly so. This little halfling has tanned, freckled skin and she likes to keep her scarlet hair in two short, low pigtails. Although quite thin, Gwendi has somewhat of an apple-shaped body, with no obvious disparity between her waistline and hips. She is obviously the shortest member of the party standing at barely above three feet. Speaking of feet, hers are NOT hairy.

Thrakka: The team's orcish barbarian lass lives to fight and never backs down. Hotheaded, the others often have to ease her down during arguments. Drinking is her favorite pastime after fighting. Grakka is heavily muscled, looking much like a statuesque amazonian woman. Her skin is dark green, and her head is shaved. She stands at six and a half feet, making her the tallest member of the party.

SETTING:

The first scene begins with the quartet of adventuring ladies all meeting up in a tavern, the most original of fantasy beginnings. Each has heard bits and pieces regarding a valuable treasure trove within the craggy canyons to the east, and each has their own reason for pursuing the treasure. However, their interest has not gone unnoticed. The Lipomancer has sent his own forces against these women to prevent them from stealing his treasure and perhaps capturing them as the newest members of his collection...
155332222212.title: The Doomed Heroines

choices: Our heroes arrive at the first of the Scars to find an old fortress.
Our heroes arrive at the first of the Scars, but are stopped by a witch.
1553322222121.content:
The sun rose over a small tavern at the edge of civilization. Wit's End, a tavern whose name could only chosen by a man who laughed at his own jokes, was the last place a would be adventurer could get a warm meal and a warm bed for the evening before they entered into the uncharted territory of the Eastern Scars, a series of bleak canyons that seemed to go on endlessly. You might think such a barren land would be as uninviting as it was hostile; but you'd be completely wrong, for the Eastern Scars were shrouded in so much myth and lore that any adventurer worth their salt would have to go there before they died. Rumors of lost civilizations, caves of diamond and sapphire, and the gold of a thousand kings, all were rumored to be waiting for the first person to find them; so long as they were willing to explore farther into the scars than any man or woman before. It was for these rumors and more that Wit's End had recently become the main base of operations for adventurers from all across the land. During a busy day, parties a dozen strong would be formed of absolute strangers and they'd be marching on the Scars by nightfall. Today, however, only four people of interest sat at the meeting table, and it is with these four heroines that our story begins.

The meticulous elf Laeryn studied the adventuring contract she had drawn up, reading off the terms of agreement that the four of them had just negotiated for.

"...On today, the 13th day of the summer season, the following stipulations have been agreed upon by the present company: 1. Treasure, in the form of gold, silver, and copper coins, precious and semi-precious stones, and other treasures valuable but otherwise mundane, shall be split by the present company evenly. 2. Artifacts of the arcane that are non-Eleven in nature shall be awarded to the present sorceress. 3. Artifacts that are discovered to be of Eleven craft, particularly those of the long deceased native elf Kingdom that once was based in the Scars, shall be awarded to I, the original writer of this contract. All small-sized weapons, equipment, and other tools, as well as any item that is decided on as being a "Collector's" item that is non-Eleven in nature shall be awarded to the present rogue. Lastly, any weapons of considerable strength and other battle gear fit for one who might be considered "The strongest in the lands", shall be awarded to the present barbarian. Are there any objections to the agreed upon terms?"

The elf looked up from the long scroll to see that the rest of the company had long since found other things to pass their time. Veradelia the sorceress had fallen asleep where she sat, head resting on top of an open tome of considerable size, Gwendi the rogue had busied herself inspecting her "lucky" dice to ensure that they matched the exact weight and shape of the tavern's set, and Thrakka the barbarian was currently ordering yet another tankard of the strongest ale the tavern had to offer.

"And make it a big one this time! Or I think I might just help myself to the tap!"

"y-yes your hugeness... (Don't squish me!) "The serving imp stuttered before hurriedly flying off on its red bat wings. Laeryn glared at the imp. It was odd enough to see one working in a respectable establishment; but what was even more peculiar was that the little winged creature was so tubby that she was astonished it could still fly. Clad in strips of cloth that were barely enough to cover its naughty bits, the imp's stomach was so swollen with fat that it jiggled with every push of its wings. Coupled with its considerable cleavage, Laeryn wondered if the infernal creature was even aware it had feet.

Turning her attention back to the matter at hand, the ranger calmly banged her glass against the table.

The halfling tensed up momentarily at the sudden sound before placing her dice back in her equipment bag and snapped to attention, while the sorceress merely turned her head slightly so that one of her eyes could lazily look at the elf through several strands of her dark hair.

"So are we ready to go yet?"

"Nearly, I was just reading off the terms of our agreement again and was asking if there were any objections before we began?"

"Nah." Veradelia muttered as she forced herself back into a seating position, an imprint of the page's incantations dug slightly into her cheek.

"Nope! Sounds good!" Gwendi nodded in excitement.

"Aye, the three of you look like your up to the challenge!" Thrakka said with a wide toothy grin, downing her latest drink in mere moments.

"Very well then, it seems as though we are in agreement. I look forward to our time working together."

With that Laeryn rolled up the parchment she had drawn the contract out on and slid it into a special pocket in her adventuring pack that she had selected to hold such important documents.

"Right then, lets go crack some heads!" The orc roared and sprinted out of the tavern, taking the imp waitress by surprise and causing her to drop a serving platter filled with drinks all over the tavern floor.

"Uh! Er, sorry!" The halfling quickly apologized to the imp and followed the orc out.

"...She's going to be a handful, isn't she?" The lone human of the group muttered to the elf as she closed her spell book.

"...It's too early to judge people on such matters." The Laeryn responded.

"Whatever. So long as she directs that energy at the monsters and not at me."

And so our heroines were united and their adventure began. With the sun at high noon and spirits high, it seemed as though these four might just have what it takes to conquer the challenges of the Scars.

... Unfortunately someone else had plans for them.

The imp watched as the last of the four adventurers left the inn, a wide, scheming grin growing on her face.

"Hehehehehehe! I think those four might just be what the boss is lookin' for."

With a quickness quite odd for her mass, the imp quickly placed a "closed, fuck off ya poor sods!" sign in the window, locked the front door, and extinguished all of the lights, before flying over to a secret hatch in the back of the kitchen and throwing it open, before flying down the stairs to a secret basement containing a dark altar. The imp then took out a paintbrush and drew a seven pointed star on her stomach will all of the lines running through her navel, and then squeezed her fat stomach so that the symbol protruded further forward.

Instantly, a brazier on the alter became lit, and a low and commanding voice flowed into the room.

"Ah, Hectica. I trust you have great news for me?" While powerful, the voice was also rather seductive in nature, and the imp couldn't help but turn a brighter shade of red.

"You betcha! Four wannabe heroes comin' your way. There's a human, an elf, a halfling, and an orc! All thin as a bone- well, the orc's big, but its the wrong kind of big, ya know?"

There was a momentary pause."Quite the selection to choose from... you've done well in bringing these four to my attention."

"Aw shucks..." Hectica looked at the ground and ran a finger through her black-as-soot hair.

"You shall be rewarded in the usual manner, for now stand by and await further instructions."

"Yes ma'am!" The imp saluted as the brazier went dark.
1553322222121.title: The Adventure begins...

choices: They stop so Veradelia can eat, Manfred's magic makes her gain a little weight!
They continue onward and discover the next Scar: a labyrinth!
15533222221212.content:
After what felt too brief to be even an hour, the adventurers arrived at the first of the crags. Laeryn paused at the top of a cliff, raising one hand to veil her eyes from the afternoon sun. Below lay a scar etched into the side of the land by time and weathering, and though the drop was steep, it was not impassable. "This looks like as good a place as any. We shall begin our descent--"

"To victory!" Without warning, the orc barbarian leapt over the ledge and skidded down the steep surface like a skiing master. At the bottom of the slope she pounded her chest and beamed a fanged smile up to her companions. Laeryn could not help but palm her face.

"Someone's eager." Veradelia leaned lazily on her staff, one hand cupping a soft yawn. "Any other ideas, elf?" She gazed at Laeryn through half-closed eyes. Clearly, staying awake was its own struggle for the human woman.

"Yes. We shall climb." Delaying no further, Laeryn dropped to a knee and reached into her highly organized traveling pack to procure a length of rope. She unwound the thick climbing equipment and fastened it to a nearby tree.

"Ooh, nifty!" Gwendi unbuckled her small belt, but her pants remained in place. She looped it over the rope and held fast as she zipped down after Thrakka, landing gracefully at the bottom.

With only the elf and the human remaining, they gave each other a slight shrug, and Laeyrn mimicked the rogue's hasty entrance. However, she underestimated her own weight and acceleration and landed at the bottom in a heap, much to the enjoyment of her comrades. Veradelia blinked listlessly at the humiliated elf, and shook her head lightly. "I don't think so..." Scarcely lifting her arm, she tapped the tip of her staff to the cliff, surging forth a small burst of magic. In a succession of loud thuds, the cliff face shot out in blocks, forming a crude, but navigable staircase.

"Wowzers!" Gwendi commended her sorceress friend with a round of applause, but Thrakka and Laeryn simply scoffed at the woman's idle abuse of her magic.

"Let us continue." The elf had finished dusting herself off and once again slung her pack over her shoulder, marching into the shadow of the craggy Scar. The others followed suit, and since they were entering unknown territory, none dared speak up. Once inside, they each drew their appropriate weapons: Laeryn nocked an arrow into her longbow, Gwendi drew her miniscule daggers, and Thrakka unslung her club.

Time slipped by without count in the dim light of the Scar, but before long they could see torchlight ahead. Laeryn nodded to the rogue, and Gwendi scouted ahead. She reached a small hut and peeped in through the window. "What the..." Blinking hard, she even rubbed her eyes before scampering back to the party. "It's a house! And someone's home!"

"Perhaps he can provide us with directions." Laeryn muttered and tapped a slender finger to her chin. Nodding her approval of her own plan, she shot a glance back to the others. "Be wary, they may not be trustworthy to live out in such secret." Thrakka snorted and strode past the elf, bumping shoulders with her.

"Don't wet your loincloth, elfy. Let me handle this." Before the others could stop her, the orc had already pounded on the ramshackle wooden door. Again, Laeryn facepalmed, but took this opportunity to duck behind a nearby stalagmite. Gwendi mimicked the action, but found a nice, small rock to peek around while Veradelia sighed and sauntered up beside the barbarian.

"Hello? Who is it?" A man's muffled voice came through the door, though it was awfully high-pitched. Thrakka pounded another fist against the wooden barrier and snarled.

"Open up! We have questions for you!" Her nostrils flared wildly and the veins in her neck were beginning to pulse.

"Oh! Yes, at once!" With a click the lock came undone and the door swung wide into the slightly less dim hut. "Good day, strangers. How can I help such lovely young women?" He was most certainly a man, but he was dressed in the most stereotypical witch's garb imaginable. A big, black pointed hat sat atop his head, and he wore a long, flowing black robe that showed off the top of his chest.

"Ew..." Veradelia rolled her eyes and strode into the hut past the homeowner, taking in the sights. At the far end of the hut sat a cauldron and the tables were each lined with beakers and jars full of eyeballs and toads and bat wings, everything you would imagine in a witch's home. Seeing their friends unharmed, Laeryn and Gwendi both followed, and were greeted by the manwitch. They sheathed their weapons and looked about the house with curiosity and caution.

"My name is Manfred. Welcome to my humble abode!" Before his welcome was even finished, the four women had already begun snooping about, picking up jars and sniffing beakers. Laeryn placed jar of spiders back onto the shelf before looking to the manwitch.

"Salutations, Manfred. We come in search of treasure. Know you of any such troves within this Scar?" Her arms folded across her chest, and she gazed into the man's dull, tired eyes. He wasn't old, per say, but he must have been at least middle-aged. Manfred stroked his beard before offering a single nod.

"Ah! You must be looking for the Golden Hoard! It is said to be a mountain of wealth and cultural artifacts numbered beyond imagining." His wide smile was equally eerie and calming.

"Snap! That sounds great!" Gwendi was hopping up and down with excitement, and Veradelia simply rested a hand on her head to steady the little rogue. Thrakka had found a coat rack and was now taking practice swings as if it were a battleaxe. Even Laeryn's eyes lit up at the description, and she nodded eagerly.

"Tell us, do you know where we can find this Golden Hoard? Rather, can you point us in the direction to begin?" The elf closed the distance between herself and the manwitch, and Manfred nodded, though his face shrank into a small frown.

"Yes, though there are many monsters and evil creatures who guard the treasure. It is their duty to protect it from outsiders." Laeryn took a step back, concern furrowing her brow. Gwendi hid behind the sorceress and her knees shook. Thrakka grinned with ferocity and tossed the coat rack over her shoulder. "Yes, they are most terrifying horrors who serve an even more terrifying master!" Manfred nodded fervently.

"You sure know a lot about these beasties for some old coot living in a shack." Thrakka frowned and her nostrils flared again, sniffing the air like a hound. It was then that the expression on Manfred's face shifted from concern to madness.

"But of course! I am Manfred the Manwitch, servant of the master!" With that, he shot forth his arm, launching a bolt of purple energy toward Thrakka. The orc barbarian had anticipated treachery, and easily dove out of the way. Lazy Veradelia, however, was not prepared and took the blast in a direct hit. She fell back, tripping over Gwendi.

Laeryn, who no longer had her bow at the ready, rushed forward and slugged the manwitch with a right hook, knocking him back into his workbench. Gwendi rushed to Veradelia's side and shook the sorceress from her unconsciousness. "Hey! You okay?!" The sorceress pushed her aside and rubbed her head.

"Yeah, just a little dizzy." Meanwhile, Thrakka let out a bellowing roar as she once more hefted up the coat rack to assail the manwitch. Laeryn widened the gap and unslung her bow, nocking an arrow in an instant. She took aim and pulled back the string.

"Hahahahaha! You're doomed! You're all doomed!" The manwitch seized a nearby jar filled with yellow liquid and crashed it to his feet. As soon as it touched air, the liquid ignited, setting Manfred and half of the house ablaze. Thrakka threw Gwendi and Veradelia over her shoulders and barreled out the door. Laeryn watched in horror as the man collapsed into a burning heap, still cackling.

"ELF!" Thrakka's shout shook Laeryn from her horror, and the ranger fled the hut just as the roof caved in. The roaring flames illuminated deeper into the Scar, revealing a small altar some distance away. With everyone back on their feet, Laeryn cautiously approached the ritualistic platform.

"Veradelia, what do you make of this?" The sorceress sluggishly sauntered up beside the elf and peered over the altar. She knelt over it, examining the wooden bowls of food and one filled with paint and a paintbrush.

"Looks like a ritual, but I don't know this magic." The sorceress rose to her feet and offered a slight shrug. This was immediately followed up by a long growl from her stomach. Her eyes widened beyond half-closed, and she rubbed a hand over her flat tummy. "Huh, guess I'm hungry."

"I had thought you ate something when we set out on our quest." Laeryn raised a curious brow, but was only met with a nod and another shrug from the sorceress. As the human waltzed by, Laeryn could have sworn the sorceress' backside looked a little rounder than usual. Perhaps it was just a trick of the firelight. She turned back to the party and nodded once. "We know our prize. Let us set out on this grand quest for the Golden Hoard." Gwendi and Thrakka cheered at this, and Veradelia simply rolled her eyes.

Once more our heroines set forth toward the canyon to pursue the next chapter in their adventure!
15533222221212.title: Manwitch

choices: The party finds a dungeon filled with traps and bloated baddies!
The party camps for the night. The goblin injects someone with a wicked serum!
155332222212121.content:
No sooner than the quartet had ventured back into the daylight, Veradelia's stomach resounded its hunger once again. Thrakka halted her marching and turned to the trailing sorceress, offering the human a chuckle. "Your stomach has a better battle roar than most orc warriors!" She snorted heartily and continued onward. Laeryn just shook her head and followed, but Gwendi tugged on the sorceress' robe.

"You okay, Veevee?" Gwendi furrowed her little brows and folded her arms across her chest. Veradelia sighed and shook her head.

"I'm real hungry." Her gaze lifted and settled on the two backs to her. "Can we stop?"

"Stop? We just got started!" Thrakka growled. Laeryn raised a hand and approached the sorceress with a nod. "I didn't even get to kill anything yet!" The orc grumbled but complied, joining the others to set up a temporary rest station.

"Yes, but if we are not at full strength then we cannot defeat the monsters of which Manfred spoke." Laeryn turned to Veradelia and gestured for her and Gwendi to sit. Thrakka only gnashed her teeth again, planting her strong hands on her chiseled hips.

"I am always at full strength!"

"Yet our party is not. We must be cautious in the Scars to come." Laeryn opened her pack and procured a loaf of elven spice bread and an apple. She offered both to the sorceress, and Veradelia took them with a nod.

"Thanks. Besides, it's lunch time." Indeed, the sun hung high at noon, and the entire group agreed this would be the best time for all of them to eat. Veradelia ate the bread and apple, Laeryn gnawed on a carrot, Gwendi ate a handful of berries which was more than enough to fill her small stomach, and Thrakka chewed on a large hunk of dried meat. After all had been finished, they began to pack their belongings, but something odd happened. "Ouch..."

"What is it?" Gwendi tilted her head and approached the human woman, and Veradelia clamped both hands to her hips.

"It feels like my robe shrunk. Might be the heat." However, her eyes went wide when her hands met her flanks. There was certainly a bit of padding there that she did not recognize. In fact, as her fingers coursed around the curve of her already generous hips, the usual toned muscle seemed to be masked by a thin layer of softness. It was subtle, but the human woman could definitely feel some flab that hadn't been there before. It felt like she must have put on only a few pounds, but when? How?

"Shrunk? I doubt it. This is what happens when you're so lazy, witch! You get fat!" Thrakka cackled and slapped a hand to her wall of abs. Laeryn shot the orc a scowl and inched closer to the sorceress, still sitting on her knees.

"No way! I'm lazy, but I don't eat that much! I take care of myself!" Veradelia pouted, pinching at her somewhat-less-toned rump. Laeryn eyed the woman up and down and stroked her chin in thought.

"Perhaps this is the work of the manwitch. Were you not struck with some manner of spell during our conflict?" The elf continued her pondering posture.

"Yeah. You don't think..." Veradelia gulped and gnawed at her lip.

"We cannot say just yet, but we must be wary. If you are in fact cursed, we may encounter a cure during our journeys." Laeryn offered the sorceress a reassuring smile, but deep down she really didn't want to turn back. If one mere human had to gain a little weight in order for Laeryn to reclaim her family's treasure, it was worth it.

"Can we get moving now? My swinging arm is getting flabby." Thrakka glanced at Veradelia, but the sorceress replied with a dagger stare. "Erm... sorry." The orc chuckled quietly and rose to her feet. She was followed by Gwendi and Laeryn. The elf nodded and looked east.

"Yeah, I'm ready!" Gwendi threw some air jabs, hopping from one foot to the other in a boxing stance. Veradelia sighed and pushed herself to her feet with a tiny bit more effort than she would
* * * * *


And so the noble quest continued until the party arrived at another crag, but this Scar was not deep. The only thing in this pocket of a crag was an old stone ring etched with runes. The four adventurers approached cautiously, and Veradelia sauntered to the front. "These runes are the same as the altar." She lazily brushed a strand of hair from her face and stared blankly at the stone sculpture, eyeing the moss and lichen growing along its edges. "Looks pretty old to me."

"Thanks, eagle eyes." Thrakka cleared her throat and spit on the ground. "Looks like a door." She wrinkled her nose with a sniff. "A magic door." Veradelia smirked at this and ran her fingers along the runes before looking back to the orc.

"You're a clever one." However, her sarcasm was lost on the orc as Thrakka only puffed up her chest with pride at this subversive insult. The sorceress frowned as she continued to trace her lithe fingers within the runes, but there was no effect nor any sign of latent magic. "I don't think we'll get anything out of this." She dropped her hand and turned to the group. They all shrugged to one another and continued along the winding cliffside path.

Though the investigation of the circle was fruitless, the runes did in fact begin to glow after they had marched out of sight. A pale purple light coalesced at the ring's center, and soon the portal shimmered brilliantly. In a flash the light faded as quickly as it came, but at the center of the tall ring hunched a female goblin. Much like Hectica, this short creature sported a bloated belly and heaving bust balanced out by her thick thighs and shelf of an ass. The light dwindled, and she accepted the torch. Their faces shone orange in the torchlight, and each looked in an opposite direction: Laeryn east, Thrakka west, Gwendi north, and Veradelia south. "Our torches should last us several hours time. We should meet back here before they run out."

"And how are we supposed to tell time underground?" Thrakka snorted and lowered her torch, staring at the elf. However, it was the human woman who then rummaged through her own pouch.

"I think I can help with that. Hold out your torches." Each woman held their torches together like the three musketeers, and Veradelia sprinkled powder over each. "We must press onward, we will meet up deeper in the tunnels." Laeryn gripped the strap of her backpack tightly and chewed her lip. Yet almost the opposite was the case, as the skies always seemed to be overcast, if not outright pouring rain, and crime, poverty and filth were daily realities. Even the occasional attack from undead bands originating in the neighboring wilds wasn't unheard of in this dismal town.

In a town like this, there is nothing extraordinary about a row of thin, dilapidated houses, crammed side to side and looming over a narrow, grimy cobblestone street. Even less surprising are signs of recent use of one of these homes, as even in their current, almost uninhabited states, the poor still live here, clinging to the pathetic shelters that they claim ownership over.

No, the fact that somebody was using this home was hardly surprising. What was, however, was the grotesque stench wafting up from its cellar. If one were to follow this odorous trail down the stone steps, one would soon find its astonishing source: A spectacularly obese German Shepherd.

The canine was massively fat, now wider than he was tall and completely and utterly immobilized by his own tremendous girth. He had greatly outgrown any clothes he had been wearing before this incident, the relatively clean looking garments lying about him on the floor as a testament to how recent and abnormally fast his weight gain had been. The blubbery dog was so big, his flabby body spread across so much of the floor, he nearly took up all space in the room, a room that seemed to have been a dining hall before even the table and remaining floor had been crushed under his ocean of fat.

The mutt simply sat there on his wide, lard-filled ass, it was really all he could do besides groan, pant, sweat, and digest at this point. Even wagging his tail wasn't an available option for him anymore, like the rest of his body the base of his tail was surrounded by his own blubber.

She cackled. "Well, it's settled, then! It's time to go to market, Piggy!" she said in a sing-song voice. "... But, tomorrow. I'll need a cart, and the cover of night; I should have those tomorrow..."

The bat wandered over to a cupboard behind the dog's colossal ass, nearly tripping on a large white vase she kept beside it. She clutched its little wooden handles and opened it, revealing a few shelves covered in various objects and tools. On the top shelf were a few oily, blood-stained knives and cleavers of varying sharpness and length, which she'd used to "dispose" of some of her past projects.

The next shelf down held a few empty jars, and a few containing various colored liquids, some of which Voxiche herself couldn't identify; they'd been here long before she'd decided to take residence. She could identify one to be a Potion of Featherweight, which would greatly lessen the effect of gravity on the person who drank it. "It's a good thing I've got this," Voxiche mused, "Otherwise, I'd have a lot more trouble lugging this fat-ass up the stairs." She'd only wished she'd had a potion like this for all of the other projects she'd had to haul away; being a sorceress with a levitation spell made it somewhat easier than it should have been to move such heavy things, but it was still cumbersome to keep her concentration throughout the ordeal... Especially with less-than-willing subjects.

The third shelf held a number of actual tools, each of varying usefulness: A tape-measure, a rusty hammer, a bent handsaw, a little pile of assorted nails and bolts, and a hand-drill. "Ah, yes, the tape-measure; just what I was looking for..." Voxiche took out the tape-measure and set it on a table by the cupboard. She wasn't done looking through the cupboard, however.

She came down to the last shelf, which was covered in a number of odds-and-ends, knick-knacks and doodads, many of which were "trophies" she'd kept from previous projects... Like the necklace she'd taken from the mouse-girl, or the bushy orange tail she'd cut off of the fox, or a little jingle-bell she'd taken from a bracelet that a rabbit-girl wore. She wasn't really a sentimental creature, but thought it would be interesting to "collect" such things. Among these, though, were a few marginally valuable or useful objects. Namely, a red coin-pouch. "Ah, there you are..." She reached in and pulled it from its resting spot next to a necklace that Voxiche had made out of a wolfess' teeth. "Now, let's see how mu-"

She was interrupted, mid-sentence, by a rather explosive bout of gas erupting from Leonard's ass... Which she'd had the misfortune to be standing only two feet from. She was covered in flying droplets of sweat propelled by the dog's fart, which angered her greatly. "You fat sack of-!... Let's see you try to do that with a vase up your ass!" True to her word, the bat picked up the large white vase right beside her and proceeded to ram it between the dog's ass-cheeks... Forcefully. Even in his unconsciousness, Leonard managed to let out a short yelp of pain, which made Voxiche giggle. "There!" she said, watching the dog continue to pass gas, only now blocked by a vase. The force wasn't negated, though, but was merely redirected into the dog's blubbery body, which now jiggled immensely with each trumpet.

Voxiche smirked, and after changing out of her sweat-soaked black dress into a fur coat she'd made from the same wolfess she'd made the necklace from, and returned to the coin-pouch. "Now... Let's see how much I have." She pulled the drawstring and dumped the pouch's contents out over the table, next to the tape measure; the pile created was disappointingly small, but hopefully would be enough to purchase a cart of adequate size for the mountain of dog-blubber she'd be hauling out of town. She counted them. "394 gold pieces... Hmmmph. Barely enough for a cart... And doesn't leave me much left." She sighed. "Oh, well." It wasn't that hard for her to come by money, usually... But it still didn't set right with her to let any of it go if it wasn't for something she really wanted. She didn't want a cart, but definitely needed one, what with her lack of teleport spells. "Yes, enough for a cart, but... Is it enough for a big enough cart?" This is what the tape-measure was for, to determine Leonard's "dimensions."

Darting about the dog, she expanded the tape-measure along various stretches of the dog's fatted form, and after much checking and re-checking, determined that he was 10 feet deep from the furthest of his belly-flab to the base of his tail, and 6 feet wide from hip to hip. She also found that he was about 5 feet tall, but that wasn't very important. She would have tried to get his exact weight, but didn't have the tools available to her at that moment to determine such a thing; she'd have to go with her estimate of 11,000 pounds... Which was just a thousand pounds shy of the heaviest furry she'd ever "owned," an enormous purple skunk-girl, who she sold to a village of dragonoids.

"Such a shame, mutt... You could've beat her record." She shrugged. "... Oh, well! This just means you aren't too huge for a cart."

The dog would be a bit large for the cart he'd have to ride in, 8 feet by 4 feet, but she figured she could squish his fat into a more manageable space... Or at least be able to "muffin" it over the sides of the cart without too much trouble.

"Well, my gassy little Piggy... We'll be taking a little trip tomorrow... But tonight, we rest." She yawned. Instead of adjourning to her sleeping quarters upstairs, though, she pulled a large spread of soft skunk-skin (a different skunk, of course) and threw it over the dog's belly. "Good night..." she said, as she jumped onto the fur she'd laid out, and drifted off to sleep.

The next day, she set off for the town's marketplace...
