15533222222211.content:
Kana ran out of rooftops just at the edge of the grounds of a large mansion within the city. A wide street separated the nearest buildings from the wrought iron fence surrounding the manicured lawn, but this posed little problem as the dragoness performed another running jump with a boost of her wings to drop silently to the grass. A quick dash across the rolling hills brought her to the topiary nearer the building, near enough to be able to plan a path between the few guards patrolling the paths in the gardens on this side of the manor. Darting through the shadows, Kana was soon right below a darkened window barely cracked open. Taking advantage of the situation, she eased the window open, careful in case of a noisy hinge. Fortunately, the window opened with barely a noise, and she slipped in, pulling the pane nearly shut behind her again.

She found herself in a sitting room generously furnished with many expensive looking decorations. While Kana did help herself to a few choice pieces from around the room, she was after a specific target, so she quickly continued on her way. A peek through the keyhole showed no sign of life in the hallway outside nearby, so she quietly slipped out, letting the door click shut. Moving swiftly through the hallways, she had to sometimes duck into alcoves or down detours to avoid a passing guard or servant. Strangely, the dragoness noted that the eyes of everyone she saw seemed to be slightly glazed over, and their motions were a bit stiff. It almost looked like all of the people in the mansion were under some sort of spell or enchantment. Shrugging it off, she continued on her way, knowing approximately where she was going.

She suddenly found herself in trouble when she ended up boxed in with people coming from both directions. The only choice she had to hide was a door next to her, with no time to check it out she was forced to dart through it just before the people were able to see her in the shadows. As she leaned against the door, she could hear the footsteps pass by right outside. Letting out a sigh of relief, she then froze when she heard a voice behind her.

“Come now my dear, you can surely do better than this,” the haughty voice said.

Whipping around, Kana was again relieved to see that the speaker wasn’t taking to her and hadn’t even noticed her at all. The vixen in question seemed to be speaking to a rather unfortunate raccoon fem, tatters of a maid outfit was trapped around the raccoon’s body. The clothing looks like it might have fit better if the girl wasn’t fattened and stuffed to such a ridiculous degree, her whole body reduced to a jiggling wobbling mass that oozed over the edges of the bed, while her carriage sized gut looked like it might be rock hard to the touch despite the fat covering.

“Of course, ma’am, I…urp,” the raccoon managed to gasp out with the rest of whatever she was going to say cut off as the vixen shoved a massive pastry into the young woman’s mouth.

The vixen riding atop the bloated stomach wasn’t what Kana would consider skinny either, but she was quite a bit lighter than the young woman below her. It took Kana several minutes to recognize her as Lady Mantrillian, the owner of the mansion as well as the current owner of her target. From all reports, the Lady was rail thin and quite the strait-laced prude, nothing like the fattened woman stuffing the poor woman beneath her and obviously enjoying the action quite a bit. As Kana watched, the Lady pulled another huge pastry out of thin air before quickly shoving it into the maid’s mouth to chase its brother. There had also been no mention of Lady Mantrillian having any sort of magical talent either.

Kana brought herself up short suddenly, realizing that she had been slowly walking forward towards the spectacle. A quiet whispering scratched at the back of her mind, but not loud enough for her to understand the words. Shaking her head, she found that she had again walked closer to the bed, being drawn towards the two women by some unseen force, though neither had noticed her yet, too engrossed with what they were doing. It occurred to Kana that Lady Mantrillian had likely put some sort of spell over the rest of her staff, explaining the stiff motion and glazed eyes. The thought that perhaps the recent item that the Lady had acquired, and that was Kana’s target, was the reason for the sudden change of personality and her new magical abilities was pushed out of her mind as the whispering grew stronger for a moment.

Shaking her head more vigorously, Kana forced herself away from the bed, though her mind and body seemed to protest with each step that she took. The feeling grew weaker when she returned back to the door, but didn’t pass away completely. Cracking the door open, she peeked out and saw no sign of anyone outside, and was about to head out and find the vault she was looking for when she gave another look over her shoulder. She saw that Lady Mantrillian was now roughly groping the younger woman’s breasts, both of them letting out little erotic moans. A thought for Kana to stay here floated through her mind, and if she hadn’t been so foggy headed, she might have realized that the thought wasn’t her own.

155332222222111.content:
A burst of willpower forced Kana to turn away from the scene before her, and she swooped through the door and shut it behind her before she could look back again. Shaking her head helped dispel some of the fog gripping her mind and somewhat quieted the whispers plaguing her thoughts. A quick glance around let her remember her position compared to her target, and she set off before another person came by to see her standing there. Reaching the lower levels of the mansion, she found that no lights were to be seen, leaving it all pitch black. Reaching a hand out, she performed a quick series of hand motions, tapping into the tiny trickle of magic she possessed. As she finished, she blinked a couple times before the spell took effect, allowing her to see in the dark without any outward sign of light. Able to see again, Kana set off into the shadows.

As she continued on her way, her thoughts drifted to the one who taught her that simple spell: Talia, a snake mage in one of the local guild halls. Kana and Talia had met rather unexpectedly when the dragoness was trying to escape from a rather persistent group after an accidently botched job. Kana had managed to gain a slight lead and saw an open window that she could reach. Quickly leaping through the window had deposited her on a bed…as well as the unfortunate occupant of the bed: Talia. Realizing what she had done, Kana had quickly silenced the serpent – who didn’t seem to be putting up much of a fight anyways – as she made sure that the mob hadn’t seen her hasty hiding spot. Once the gang had passed, Kana released the serpent who promptly responded with a bolt of energy that threw the dragoness across the room. A quick explanation with some lies mixed with enough truth was all that saved Kana from a repeat blast. After the unpleasantness, the two actually started a conversation that turned into a casual relationship over the following months.

Kana had to admit that Talia was attractive in a bookish way, with a slender frame with some womanly curves and bright shiny scales, though the standard mage robe that she wore hid most of this. During the course of their relationship, Talia had recognized Kana’s minor magical talent and had helped her nurture it in a few directions like her dark sight, having been told about Kana’s late night activities by the dragoness. It had all come to an end rather suddenly when Talia was transferred away from the capital to another city far away. Kana had thought of maybe tracking Talia down, but another job always came up and she shoved off the idea for another time.

As Kana continued to stalk through the dark halls within the bowels of the mansion the whispering continued to scratch at the back of her mind, though she was starting to get used to the constant low noise. It subtlety nudged her mind to keep thinking back to Talia and their dalliance. She swiftly stepped through the darkness while her mind’s eye watched the memories of Talia cascading through her thoughts. She never realized how the memories were being twisted and changed as she thought back to them. It started with their first meeting, where the formerly slim serpent was a bit pudgier. Over the course of their sexual escapades, the new memories showed Talia growing steadily fatter and fatter, mostly due to how Kana would bring her food each time and feed the snake more and more. As the changes continued through the memories, Kana would push Talia to eat a bit more each time, savoring the pained groans that the serpent would give as her stomach stretched further and further. After a number of times of this, Talia started to beg Kana to feed her further, pushing well beyond her limits and speeding her gaining. Talia continued to balloon to new weights till eventually she couldn’t even support her weight on her fattened tail. When the changes to her memories finished, Kana thought that the end of their relationship came when Talia was taken away mysteriously in the middle of the night without her seeing a thing.

Kana stumbled a bit, bracing herself against the wall. Shaking her head, she wondered why she was thinking of Talia so much. She hadn’t thought of the swollen serpent as much recently, and now she was going over much of their time together. Shaking her head again more vigorously, she forced herself onwards. After a few minutes, she had finally reached her destination: the vault of Lady Mantrillian, its large metal door having beaten plenty of would-be thieves over the years, though none of them had been up to Kana’s skill. With a wide grin under her mask, she first checked for any traps or alarms before moving to the vault door and setting to work. Despite her considerable skill, defeating its complex locking systems still took Kana time, too much time as she became more and more concerned about being discovered before finishing.

1553322222221111.content:
With one last muted click, the vault door eased open, and Kana again gave a wide grin beneath her mask. The door was well maintained and expertly balanced – made by dwarven master smiths from the looks of it, making it exceedingly costly – so the slightest touch was enough to open it just wide enough that Kana could slip inside, while leaving little sign that it had been opened. Massive elaborate paintings; golden utensils that would never be used; ornate jewelry boxes filled with rings, necklaces, bangles and more, all made from the finest metals and studded with precious gems; there was so much in this vault alone that Kana could have brought a team of a dozen thieves and never made off with everything. She secreted a few smaller items into the pockets of her armor, but kept moving, looking for that one specific item. Towards the back of the room, she found it: sitting on a plinth all by itself was a fabulous gold necklace, with a massive ruby as the center of the amulet. The edge of the amulet was inscribed with arcane symbols, nothing that the dragoness had a hope of understanding with her meager knowledge of arcane lore. All she knew was that her client was paying an enormous amount for this particular item.

Picking the necklace up, she examined slowly, admiring the size and weight of the valuable. As she looked, a glow rippled across the surface of the ruby, she thought it a bit odd, but shook her head and put the amulet in another of her pockets. She was unable to see that her eyes glowed the same way briefly as she secreted the piece away. Satisfied that the easy part was done, she now had to make her way back out with her prize. The vault door shut just as soundlessly as it had opened, and she quickly relocked it to help hide her activities. As she continued to avoid the guard patrols, she found that she was ending up back outside the bedroom she had hidden in just a short time ago. For some reason, she found herself pressing her ear up against the door, listening to what was happening inside.

She could make out lady Mantrillian cooing, “Ooh, excellent job, pet.” A muffled grunt could be heard, then she snapped out, “You two, get over here, she’ll be having you two next.”

Two hushed voices then responded simultaneously, “Yes, ma’am.”

Kana then heard loud gulping and slurping noises mixed with pained moans and groans. The thief didn’t want to know what was happening in there, though a portion of her mind seemed to be resisting her, making her legs harder to move. She shook her head vigorously and gritted her teeth, forcing herself to move on. The room she had come in was blocked now though, so she had to change the plan a bit. She managed to find a clear staircase up to the second floor, which led her to another weak spot in the defenses. From there, it was a simple task to fly partway across the grounds, dodging the patrols, and then get up and over the wall. She had little trouble avoiding the rest of the district guards, flipping up and over the dividing wall, and return to the slums. The entire time though, that whispering was at the back of her mind, almost completely unnoticed by the dragoness. Just a short time before dawn, she slipped through the window above a shop near the port, and landed softly in her small bedroom. Her eyelids were drooping as she put her loot in a secret compartment within the floor, and stripped off her armor and hid that away within the wall, before slipping under the threadbare covers and drifting off to sleep, completely unaware that she had gotten tangled up with an incredibly powerful force.

With a loud yawn, Kana sat up in her bed, listening to the noise of the bustling city going about its day outside her window. The dragoness shook her head and rubbed her temple: the oddest dreams had filled her mind as she slept. With the morning’s light, she found that she couldn’t recall anything specific, but the feelings of revulsion and disgust still lingered in her thoughts. Suppressing a shudder, Kana leapt from her bed and got ready for the day. Several minutes later, she bounded down the steps, the smell of breakfast mingling with the much more acrid scent of a river redweed cigarette.

“Ah, just what I wanted to smell while eating breakfast, you burning that noxious herb,” Kana called out.

“Don’t like it, you can go get your own breakfast,” came the gruff reply.

Kana smiled slightly as she followed the smells back from hence they came, finding Etem already hard at work on one of his clocks. She always thought scared wolf looked a bit ridiculous with those spectacles with all of those lenses and everything perched on his nose.

He grumbled out “Heard you get in early this morning, figured you would be in bed longer” without looking up from his work.

“Oh, you know me, things to do, places to go, and people to meet,” she replied cheerily.

The wolf huffed slightly as it performed some intricate task in the body of the clock, most of the parts seemed to be still scattered across his work table. The dragoness patted the older man on the shoulder, wrinkling her nose as the pungent green smoke drifted off of the smoldering cigarette at his elbow. She had no idea how anyone could stand being around one of those things, let along sucking on one. Breakfast was simple yet filling, cooled slightly by how long it had been sitting around, but still more than good enough to eat. As she ate, Kana gave a report about how the job had done, though when she came to the bit about the radically altered lady of the manor, something made her skip over that portion.

At the end, she tore up the remaining fried bread and tossed it between her teeth before asking, “So how long do I have to hold onto the product?”

He took off his glasses and set them aside as he looked up at her. “Now that you have it Daring, you can take it to the customer tonight. I’ll send a message that you’re bringing it.”

Hearing him use the nickname he gave to her when they met years ago always bought a smile to Kana’s face. When he caught her pickpocketing him, she thought for sure that she was going to lose a hand or worse. But instead, the wolf took pity on the scrawny street rat and took her in, saying that she had a lot of potential, but would need to work hard to let her talent blossom. She couldn’t have known that the brusque black wolf who worked as a clockmaker was also a highly experienced lockpicker and thief. He wasn’t very famous, but as he taught her the best thieves aren’t supposed to be famous. That was plenty of practice and many jobs ago. His fur had gone more to salt and pepper now, but he still had plenty to teach his protégé and she was eager to learn.

“Good, where am I going?”

155332222222111111.content:
Kana spent the remainder of the day helping out around Etem’s shop, easily slipping into her role as the wolf’s assistant. Despite the filling breakfast, the dragoness found herself snacking throughout the day, as well as eating a big lunch on top of everything else. The few times he looked up from his work, Etem furrowed his brows slightly but didn’t say anything about her new eating habits. No matter what she was doing though, Kana’s mind often drifted back to her memories of Talia and their time together.

She felt a blush creeping up her neck and into her cheeks as she remembered one night when she slipped into the snake’s room earlier than usual. The dragoness had brought plenty of food, quite a bit more than usual, and proceeded to tie her lover down and stuff her with every bit. Not even halfway through, the mage was moaning and half-heartedly begging for Kana to stop. The thief wouldn’t hear of it, there was still plenty of food all for her bloated scaly lover. More and more of the food vanished down Talia’s gullet till the scales on her belly were stretching apart. Only after the last little bit was forced down the snake’s throat did Kana finally untie Talia, though the snake was so savagely stuffed that all she could do was lie there moaning and cradling what appeared to a vastly overdue pregnant belly. Kana left a trail of kisses across that stomach – each bringing another moan to Talia’s lips – before she slipped beneath the swell to lap at her dripping slit.

The vividness of the memory crashed over Kana; she could smell the remnants of the feast mingling with the heady aroma of their combined arousal, she could feel the heat radiating off of the mage’s belly and womanhood, and she could hear the panting and moaning that Talia made as Kana gave her such a tongue lashing. It was almost like she was experiencing all again, so much so that she had to dart off, breathlessly saying that she would be taking a break. Etem’s usual stony silence was all the response Kana received, but she was past caring if she was needed for the time being.

Later on, Kana rinsed her face off, especially her lip where she bit herself to keep from crying out. She briefly though about how odd that had been, she had never had a memory hit her quite so hard like that before. She shrugged it aside, just like she had when she lost track of that odd whispering that had been going on in the back of her mind. She instead turned her attention to getting more appropriately attired for her short jaunt to the Gold District. It was one of the richest portions of the city, and her usual simpler attire would stand out there, adventurers usually weren’t even let in. The servants from that area wore comparatively expensive attire, but they were relatively easier to attain, so that is what she went with: a higher quality dress that was cut to be a bit revealing yet tasteful at the same time, as if she was maybe one of the pleasure servants for the noble houses. The dress was also made specially so that she had most of her range of motion and could hide a dagger without anyone noticing it, just in case she got in a bit of trouble.

Adding a vibrant cloak and an appropriately haughty expression, she headed out. Before she left, her mentor let her know that her contact would be wearing a rose and ebony broach on their right shoulder. Kana bid Etem good-bye and made for the Gold District. Getting past the guards took a bit of time, but was easily achieved. Soon enough, the dragoness was standing looking up at the sign for The Shattered Mountain tavern, complete with a simple design showing a mountain cracked apart. Stepping inside the door, Kana slipped through the milling crowd up to the bar and ordered a drink. Turning around, she noted a few people looking her over, but none wearing the broach. As usual, the Mountain was packed this time of night, full of off duty guards and other servants that works for the nobles, there were even more than a few pleasure servants, so Kana didn’t stick out too much.

Some concern that this was all a set-up started to wash over the dragoness after nearly half an hour of time spent in the tavern without spotting her contact. She almost made it to the door when a glimmer out of the corner of her eye caught her attention: it was the broach.

155332222222221.content:
Silgad stood at the ridge, looking over towards the village below; her latest target.
The female hyena was planning in her mind how she would lead attack, she knew their wouldn't be much resistant, given the population. The village was full of pigs, or so she was told by her sources, but she had not seen a single inhabitant in the last two days, and her men were getting restless.

¨Silgad, lets just storm the village while noone is here, take what we can, and burn it down!¨

The hyena turned to face the hulking polar bear behind her,revealing a scar on her brown nose, her black hair flowing down to her lower back.

¨Omar, for the last time, I am in charge, not YOU! If it weren't for me, you would still be in a cell.Now shut up, and keep an eye on the camp, sharpin your axe if you want, just stay away from me, and let me focus!¨

The bear backed down, he had once been in a brief relationship with her (If you could call it that) and knew when to leave her alone.
Silgad turned around, eyes back to the village. Omar observed her figure, she wore light iron armour, with blue leather trimming at the sides. Her ¨Assets¨ were slightly big for her body type, but that just
¨Added to the charm¨ in her opinion. Her thick black tail started to wag
She could see the pigs waldeling into the village square, by the gods, her sources were right, they were huge!Their huge bellies sagged to the ground, the sweat as they struggled to move, but they seemed content. Their were no children in the group of twenty or so swine, which seemed strange, but Silgad didn't seem to care. ‘Easy prey’
She licked her lips, ohh, what a meal this would be
¨Omar, gather the men, we need to discuss our options!¨
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
¨Alright boys, I know that it's been awhile since we had a good meal, but hell, let that fuel your rage, and lets take this village in the name of their Black-Tails!¨
The men cheered, and drew their weapons.

¨So boys, what do you think, do we slaughter the pigs and have a feast of bacon tonight, or do we take our time with them?¨
155332222222221.title: Alright, the hyena bandit it is!

choices: Later, the fires are built up, bodies gathered, and the feast begins!
Something else entirely different.
1553322222222211.content:
Almost immediately after asking her gang what they wanted to do, everyone said yes to pillaging the village right away. Silgad grinned wickedly, happy to see that her cohorts were so eager to kill. Swishing her tail around, Silgad turned to gaze at the peaceful village, chuckling to herself.

"These swine won't know what hit them..." Silgad pulled out her duel short-swords that she got from some merchant caravan, and yelled at the top of her lungs. Her band of cutthroats responded with enthusiasm, the crescendo of voices becoming almost deafening. By now the pigs in the village were looking in the groups direction, confused as to what was making such noise.

With one last yell, Silgad pointed one of her swords forward and began the charge. The pigs were still staring blankly at the bandits, until one mildly intelligent pig woman finally realized what was happening. Screams of terror resounded in the village, pig men and women shuffling as fast as they could to their huts, hoping in vain that the wooden shelters would shield them from the marauders.

Silgad and her bandits had reached the edge of the village now, weapons drawn and teeth bared. Several of the bandits split off from Silgad's main force, spreading death into other areas of the village. Soon, squeals could be heard from all sides, and the cackles of the bloodthirsty bandits were just as loud. Silgad, Omar, and two dog men were heading for the center building, which they guessed was the 'Town Hall' of sorts. The wooden door of the building gave very little resistance when put up against Omar's massive stone mace. Two fat pigs were knocked to the back wall, as they had futilely tried to hold the door closed, and were quickly pounced on by the two dog men, their squeals silenced in seconds.

Silgad and Omar split up, Omar heading towards the back rooms and Silgad heading for the main room. "Most of the pigs will most likely be cowering inside," thought Silgad. "Oh, what a meal this will be!" Silgad broke out into evil laughter, and cut down a helpless pig woman who had been locked out of the main room. Silgad was salivating madly now, the smell of blood and meat making her pant heavily.

"I need to finish this quickly, else I go mad with hunger." With that thought, the bandit leader rammed into the large wood door of the atrium with the force of a boulder. About twenty pigs had holed up inside here, each one squealing madly with fear. Silgad full out sprinted to the nearest one and cleaved its head in two, gaining momentum as she jumped over the body and slit the throats of two other robed pig men. In a dazzling display of bloody acrobatics, Silgad flew around the room like a barbarian ballerina, striking down pig after pig with no remorse. All had been cut down.

All but one.

This lone pig, quite possible the largest, was kneeling down at an altar at the front of the room, speaking in rapid tones of a language she couldn't understand. Not wanting to waste anymore time, Silgad walked up behind the robed pig, and stuck both her swords into its back. With it's last breath, the pig muttered a last unnerving sentence.

"Our...god...will make you....pay" The pig then lurched forward, blood dripping from its open mouth. Silgad just stood there, basking in the glory of her final kill. She arched her back and let loose a victory yell. She could tell from the guffaws and yells from the outside that her band of outlaws had taken the village, and slain its denizens. She sensed someone and turned, only to see Omar covered in blood with a twisted grin on his face.

"We should do this again, Silgad." said Omar with a light chuckle. Silgad merely humphed at the polar bear, crossing her arms over her chest. "First, you and some others have to gather up all these swine and start building a fire. We're not done yet, Omar."

The polar bear let out a heavy sigh. "As you wish, my lady..." muttered Omar sarcastically. Silgad watched him go, then looked over her handiwork.

"So much meat! My men and I will be feasting for weeks. Not that that's a bad thing..." Silgad grinned, and brought her gaze to the front of the atrium. What she saw nearly made her jump back in shock. Shrouded in shadow was a foreboding statue of a hooded figure. Long tentacles were coming out from the opening in its hood and were wrapped around a figure clutched in its hands. It appeared to be a rather fat woman.

"Wow. These pigs sure were fucked up..." Silgad took one last glance at the statue, and turned to leave the atrium, not wanting to be in the same room with the freaky thing.
1553322222222211.title: Pillage and Plunder

choices: "We've got riders coming towards us! All wearing black robes, it looks like!"
"There's some clouds gathering up ahead, looks like a bad storm is coming."
15533222222222111.content:
The bright fire light shined in Silgad's eyes. Row upon row of roasting pigs upon bonfires went through the courtyard of the once bustling village, once full of happy and worry-less pigs.

Now there was but the scent of roasting flesh, the panting of bandits, and groaning of empty bellies. Silgad sniffed the air, the tantalizing scent of the succulent swine making her body quiver. What was she waiting for? What was the whole crew waiting for? Silgad was perplexed as to why there was not a tasty haunch of pig leg in her mouth right now...

“Raaahhhhhh!!!!” yelled Silgad as she launched herself to the first pig in her sight, first bite of many to make its mark. The others all followed in a mad rush of hunger, different groups contending for bigger and fatter pigs to gorge themselves on. There was no order, no control. Everyone just let themselves go, mentally and physically. If anyone was truly foolish enough to try and get a line set up in some orderly fashion, they were going to surely starve tonight.

Several pigs were stripped to bone in a matter of minutes, with bandits moving on to other pigs. Everyone steered clear of Silgad, though. The fatty pig she had taken was hers, and hers alone. Most likely the largest pig of them all, Silgad didn't realize how difficult a challenge this would be. Sure, she was hungry as hell, but that pig was really, really big.

During the gorge-fest, someone broke out a couple of barrels of mead, rolling them out among the drink-craving bandits. One got to Silgad (not by accident), and she quickly quenched her mighty thirst, getting her fill of the drink. She wiped her mouth with her greasy arm, and got back to stuffing herself with her mighty feast. She had gotten a good sized hole in the side of the roasted porker, and began ripping out fat, meat, guts, whatever she could get her claws on, really. She was beginning to feel some pressure in her stomach, rounded out with deliciousness.

The hyena bandit unclasped her trousers and tossed them aside, sighing pleasantly as her gut gained more room. Energized by a second wind, Silgad dove right back in to the portly pig, eating, eating, and...eating some more.

A good number of bandits had gotten their fill of meat, and broken off to collapse into food comas on the ground. But, the massive polar bear marauder, Omar, was still going at it. He had a whole pig to himself, and was making short work of it. He had even guzzled down two barrels of mead all on his own, making the bear teeter back and forth in a drunken stupor. He held a hand on his bloated gut, and let out a thunderous belch.

This garnered the attention of a severely gorged Silgad, who pulled her body out of her pig to find out whatever made that noise. She tried to stand, nearly losing her balance in the process, but managed to do it. She clutched her round, gurgling belly, hefting it in her hands, and letting it drop down. It didn't move much, being packed with all manner of pig innards, and just stuck out in front of her. She placed a hand on her mouth and stifled an up-coming burp, gaze finding itself back on her half-eaten meal.

She had eaten most of the left side, yet the right side was still ripe for the taking. Surprisingly, Silgad heard a grumble from her belly. “....Hungry still?” thought Silgad, her mind and body slowly shifting to sleep mode. She shuffled lethargically over to the other side of the pig, her eyes glazed over with weariness. Her tongue was half hanging out of her mouth as she lightly rubbed her already over-stuffed stomach.

Slowly but surely, Silgad got to the other side of the pig. But, rather than start “pigging” out again, she sorta collapsed against the thick side of the swine.

“Ugghhhhh, my stomach is.....Urrrppppppp!!!” Silgad hunched forward to let the gassy belch escaped unperturbed, leaning back almost instantly at the end of the burp. She massaged her globular stomach, the minor discomfort causing her to grimace.

It seemed that sleep was imminent, as the hyena's eyes were flickering heavily with exhaustion. With one last stretch, and a tiny straggler burp, Silgad relaxed and sped off to dreamland.



***


Silgad found herself laying down on a stone pillar, alone amongst a sea of blackness. She flipped her head back and forth, very confused and slightly afraid.

“Where the fuck am I?” she softly spoke. The empty quiet of this place was unsettling, so much so that she had broke out into a sweat.

Silgad's heart rate had picked up, and her eyes were twitching about so much she was starting to become dizzy.

“Welcome.” Silgad jumped nearly three feet in the air, letting loose a shriek so loud she herself didn't even know she could muster a sound so loud.

“Wha-what the fuck! Who-whos there?” Had her bandit cohorts seen her in this state, they surely would have mocked her relentlessly.

The unknown voice chuckled deeply, a resonating sound that surrounded Silgad.

“Who I am...does not matter. Yet.” That last word made Silgad's stomach sink. “Just know this, Silgad, leader of the Black Tail bandits. I know who you are, where you are, and what you have done.”

Silgad's eyes widened with extreme fear. “What I have done...” she repeated to herself. She hung her head down, tears beginning to pour from her closed eyes.

The sound of her sobbing was drowned out, though, as a deep, rumbling groan was sounding throughout the chasm. She looked up, surprised to see a thin white crack against the back-drop of darkness. The crack was spreading, pieces falling down around Silgad, as a sort of opening began to form. A blinding stream of light shot through, forcing her to cover her red, puffy eyes......


***


“.....Silgad!......SILGAD!!!” Silgad opened her eyes, taking in the sight of Omar unched over her with his hands on her shoulders. “Finally! I've been trying to wake you for five minutes! Listen, we've got to get moving.”

Silgad sat up slowly, back sticking against the meaty hide of the pig she had passed out on. “Ughhh....not-not so loud, Omar! Whats so important that you had to wake me up so damn early?!”
15533222222222111.title: Good Food and a Bad Dream

choices: The statue slides back, revealing a hidden trapdoor...
It emits a cursed shriek, causing any remaining pig corpses to become zombies!
155332222222221112.content:
The polar bear's words held truth. As Silgad looked to the horizon, there were indeed dark clouds gathering. The distant rumbles of thunder could already be heard, much to the dismay of Silgad.

“Shit! That's no-...wait.” Silgad stopped and looked around, snorting at her own idiocy. “Why worry? We have this empty village to take refuge in! It's not like those porkers will be needing the huts anymore, right?” Silgad arched a brow and looked back up at Omar, who was scratching his stomach.

“Yeah, 'spose you're right...” The polar bear yawned, a low, drawn out sound coming from his mouth.

Silgad stood herself up, dusting off her legs and backside. Did her ass feel a bit...jigglier? Silgad began inspecting more thoroughly, patting her cheeks and rubbing her hands up and down her hips.

“Well, I guess that's what I get for stuffing myself on pig fat...” Silgad sighed and bent over to pick up her discarded trousers and pull them over her legs, the act a bit more difficult than before.

With that minor task complete, Silgad got to strolling amongst the groups of snoozing bandits, most of them either still bloated from the feast of last night, or getting up themselves to stretch out their bodies.

“Alright, get your lazy asses up! A storm is comin', and unless you wanna get soaked like a back-alley whore, you'll wake up and move your food n' shit into a hut right now! This little village is gonna be our hang-out for tonight, or maybe even two more nights, depending on how long the damned storm lasts!”

Silgad kicked at the side of a husky who happened to be napping in the way of her march, smirking cruelly as the cohort yelped. “Out of my fuckin' way! Didn't you hear me, you slimy scoundrel? Wake the fuck up!”

The husky whimpered lightly, crawling away as Silgad growled at the poor sod. The bandit leader relished these moments, making sure her merry band of assholes knew that she was the boss. She watched with amusement as even more bandits scampered away suddenly, dragging their pig remains and supply sacks into randomly picked huts. She yawned, itching at her belly button. Her stomach even felt less toned! Where there was once a flat, well-sculpted board of muscle, there now was a slight pooch of pudge. Silgad pressed more into it, studying the foreign feeling.

“Damnit, that little feast of mine ruined my stomach!” Silgad groaned in disappointment as she let her hand drop to her side, other hand resting on her hip.

Speaking of feasts, Silgad turned to look back at her own unfinished pig, one side completely stripped, while the other still had plenty of meat and fat on it. She found herself licking her lips as she stared at the roasted corpse, the smell of the juicy fats and succulent meats entering her nostrils once again...

“Gahh, snap out of it, Silgad! You're not even fucking hungry...” The bandit leader shook her head, trying to get the thought of the pig out of her mind. “Gotta find something else to do...”

And so, Silgad did, in berating a crag-bear marauder who was with the group. She didn't think to remove her iron armor before digging into and stripping clean several pigs (three and a half, to be exact), so now her burgeoning gut had grown too large for her armor! Her pudgy body was squeezed out of the gaps in her armor, causing a very comical look for the other bandits to get a kick out of.

“Ohh shit, Terga, you're like dough squeezing out of it's package! Look at you! Bwahaha!” Silgad roared with laughter as the marauder tried in vain to pull off her ill-fitting iron armor, the futile effort only managing to tire Terga out. She sighed in frustration, giving up on the task and laying down on her back, her grey furred belly pushing the tight iron plate out in all directions.

Silgad simply gasped and wheezed from laughter, wiping a tear away from her eye.

“That's some funny shit right there, heh...”


* * * * *

The rain was pouring now, a relentless fall of silver streaks mingled with bright flashes of lighting. Silgad, Omar, and a few trusted others had chose to hold up within the town hall. Seeing as it was the largest building in the village, it seemed natural for Silgad, the leader, to immediately claim it. She only let Omar join her due to their history together, and the fact that he hauled the leftovers of her unfinished pig into the building without being told to. The twin dog bandits were in there as well, accepted due to their damn good killing work in the first moments of the attack on the village.

Even Terga, the she-bear with the armor problem, was admitted inside only due to Omar's apparent feelings for her, and because Silgad felt just a tiny bit sorry for her due to no other huts being large enough or having any room left in them.

Silgad couldn't help but grin as she watched Omar try and help Terga get her armor off. They had made progress, but a couple last straps were being stubborn, so now Omar was carefully slicing them with a knife.

“Th-Thank you, Omar...” Terga blushed as Omar softly nuzzled the top of her head.

“Say no more, my mountain flower. It's the least I could do.” The last couple strips had been cut, and the front plate of Terga's armor popped off straight away. She breathed a deep sigh of relief, hands rubbing her red-marked belly. Silgad snorted at the sight, glancing down at her own slight paunch.

“Gross....hrrmm.” She leaned her head back, eyes searching about the quiet hall for something interesting. Her gaze found itself back on that dark statue at the back of the hall, near the wooden podium. The hooded figure still gave her the same feeling as the first time she saw it, that cold, slithery feeling...

Then, it did something.
155332222222221112.title: The Gathering Storm

choices: "Prepare yourselves. We are going down there!"
"Rest up for the night, we head down in the morning!"
1553322222222211121.content:
Silgad swore that she saw two red flashes where the eye sockets would have been on the statue, but an instant later, they were gone, and the statue started to move back, stone scraping on stone.

"What the fuck is going on?" She snarled as she drew her twin blades. Omar drew his war axe, and threw himself in front of the exposed Terga, acting as a hulking guard for her. Terga hid behind him still, having left her weapon somewhere when they had tried to remove her armor.

Stupid bitch! Silgad cursed to herself. Why the fuck would she not keep her weapon by her side at all times? She wondered how she had even survived this long in this bandit clan.

Other bandits in the room drew their weapons as well, preparing for an ambush. A male tiger nocked an arrow and pointed it toward the statue, and held it, ready to release. However, nothing happened. They waited, but nothing happened.

Silgad nodded towards Omar, and the two traveled towards the statue, weapons bared and ready to strike. Terga followed behind Omar.

Hell-fire, she's like a goddamn puppy dog when she's with Omar. She had to admit, she had no idea what he saw in Terga, she was a bear, like Omar, but she was not becoming at all, in her opinion. She was fairly big boned to begin with, but with the added weight, she looked even bigger. She had absolutely no bust size at all, and in general, was a coward.

When they got closer to the statue, they noticed a dark hole where the statue had once been, with a ladder leading down into the blackness.

"Omar, light a torch will you?" Silgad 'asked' the polar bear. He was hesitant, looking at Terga and back at the wall where the a torch burned already.

"Oh god, get the fucking torch Omar, Terga will still be standing there, like a fucking idiot when you get back." She snapped at him. Omar sighed and went to the wall, removed the torch from the wall scone, and walked toward the black pit. he held the torch down towards the pit, and Silgad looked down. She could see that the ladder lead to a dark underground chamber.

"Looks like it could go right under the entire village boss, it could be a tomb."

"Or a treasure trove, you never know with these pigs, greedy slobs " Silgad added.

"You want to head down there then?" Omar asked her, he didn't turn towards her, but she could see the feint outline of a smile on his face.

Of course she wanted to! Who the fuck wouldn't want to uncover a damn treasure trove She wanted to exclaim out loud, but something unnerved her about that statue. She remembered her dream from earlier. She remembered what the voice had said
“ I know who you are, where you are, and what you have done.”
It was just her mind playing tricks on her, she knew that, but still, thinking about it sent a shiver down her spine…

Maybe it was not such a good idea to head down there, at least, not right now anyway, the group could always take a rest and go down later. Then again, Silgad could not shake off the thought of a massive amount of treasure being hidden down in the chamber below.

“ All right boys, listen up…”
1553322222222211121.title: The statue slides back, revealing a hidden trap...

choices: --it's time to clear up this matter of the road.
--it's time to investigate this mysterious dungeon.
15533222222222111212.content:
"But it's already open," Omar said blandly. "We're not going to go down?"

"It'll be there tomorrow!" Silgad snapped. "We'll set a guard tonight. Anyone who goes down there alone will answer to me, if you're not eaten alive by grues or cave spiders before then!"

She pieced one warrior after another with her eyes, daring them to object. None did. She felt a sense of satisfaction. She was tough. Dominant. It was almost enough to allow her to forget that somewhere deep inside of her, a part of her was quaking like jelly at the thought of descending into that dark abyss.

"Terga. You take first watch," she said, grinning cruelly. A night alone by the hole ought to toughen up the overfed she-bear. And just to make sure nobody interfered with the toughening...

"Omar, take two men out to the road tonight. Don't want anyone else stumbling on our little squat, do we?"

--

Some hours later, Silgad lay in the pig chief's bed, drowsing and digesting her dinner. She stretched. The bed was so large that even when she extended both arms as far as they could go, she couldn't get her fingers over both edges at once, and the mattress was firm and pliable. It was truly a bed built for a pig. Even the stolen silk nightgown she was currently luxiariating in, swimming in the vast sea of fabric like a toddler in her mother's dress, had been originally tailored with a pig in mind.

The food, she reflected, had been fit for a pig too--in all the best ways. As one might have expected, every pantry in town had been bursting with delectables, and she'd scraped together a dinner of preserves, sweetmeats, and cured beef topped with another juicy haunch of pork. If it hadn't been for the pinch of her belt (already a hole looser than it ought to have been) offering a painful admonishment not to go back for fifths, she'd probably still be stuffing her face.

Really gonna have to watch it in this place, she thought, idly scratching her distended belly. I'll be fatter'n Terga if I'm not careful.

She yawned. The candles were burning low, and she'd almost drifted off to sleep when there was a thumb on the door and Omar strode in, looking concerned. Rainwater poured in rivulets down his armor, and his boots were caked with thick, black mud.

"I told you to guard the road!" Silgad said.

"Yeah, bad news," he said simply. "The road's gone."

"What do you mean, 'gone'? You couldn't find it?"

"Oh, we found where it should have been, but it wasn't there," he responded. "No road. None of those farmhouses we passed on the way here. I even followed our own tracks back--they just peter out in the forest."

"Idiot," Silgad snarled. Omar said nothing, but she thought she saw reproach in his eyes. "Get out!" the hyena finally shouted at him. He turned and left, leaving the bandit leader alone with her pounding heart, her churning belly, and her fears.

The next morning--
15533222222222111212.title: A Rainy Night of Doubts and Dinners

choices: Continue.
155332222222221112122.content:
Silgad woke with a start, head twitching up as she heard a rumble coming from above. She blinks several times, one hand going up to rub her eyes, the other scratching her furred stomach.

“Ughh, great. It's still fucking storming out...” growled Silgad.

She tossed the heavy covers of the bed away from her form, turning her body around and setting her feet down on the floor as she inched to the edge of the bed. Arching her back, she stretches her arms up above her and yawns, the flowing nightgown still wrapped around her.

Silgad stood herself up, glancing at the floor where her discarded armor lay, her pants and boots not far from it. Might as well gear up, seeing as I won't get anymore peaceful sleep, thought Silgad, frowning.

And she did just that, removing the billowing nightgown, and quickly replacing it with her aforementioned tunic, pants and boots. The iron breastplate was a smidge tighter than before, though Silgad hardly noticed. She just pulled the leather straps tight around her torso, not aware of how much it actually revealed her pudgy stomach to the world. A sliver of brown fur could be seen, a small part of her belly button also peeking out from the plate.

The leather pants also proved a challenge, for they were tight on Silgad even before coming to the village. She really had that much junk in the trunk, so to speak.

“Fucking armor....huff!...fucking pigs....oof!.....fucking...food....” Silgad grunted as she barely managed to pull the pants up and over her chubby ass, the material stretched taut. She had no difficulty with the boots, at least. That's good, right?

She walked slowly to the bedroom door, one brow raised slightly. “I don't hear anybody...hmm.” She quietly grabbed her pair of short-swords, pulling the door open and poking her head out, looking around.

Omar, Terga and the others were all still asleep, to the annoyance of Silgad. Her mouth twitched slightly as she saw the remains of some sort of feast around the two bears, Terga nuzzled up against Omar's gut, who was snoring loudly.

Silgad grinned evily, striding over to the snoozing bears, her hands cupped over her mouth. She bent down, getting right by Terga's head. The hyena took in a deep breath, leaning in even closer.

“.....WAAAAKE UP, FAT ASSSSS!!!!!!”, roared Silgad with villainous glee.

Terga's eyes shot wide open, her arms flailing around wildly, accidentally hitting Omar's face. The polar bear was by now also looking around wildly, growling lowly as he spotted Silgad guffawing in front of him.

“Ohhh hell, Omar! You should've seen your fuckin' face! And Terga, too! Haaaa! I'm surprised she could move that fa-...” Silgad's mocking was cut short as Omar stood over her.

“What....the fuck.....is your PROBLEM?!?!” yelled Omar, bending down to get right in the bandit leader's scarred face. The polar bear stared long and hard at Silgad as she blinked in surprise.

“Hey, now....it was just a fuckin' joke! Alright?” stammered Silgad, for once the one being on the receiving end of a scolding.

Omar snorted, raising his body back up slowly. “A joke, huh? Well, I didn't find it funny...maybe I need a new sense of humor...” The bear glowered at Silgad, turning away from her to go and comfort the slightly whimpering Terga.

Silgad just stared, shaking her head as he walked away. The fuck has gotten into him?! That's the first time Omar's talked back to me...
155332222222221112122.title: Hijinks and High Tempers

choices: Let's investigate this damn hole already!
No, wait. Everyone needs a snack before heading down.
1553322222222211121221.content:
The next couple of hours were spent gathering up supplies, weapons, rations, etc. for the journey down the hidden passageway, a journey that Silgad was less than happy about. She obviously didn't let any of her cohorts know this, though, being the stubborn and headstrong leader that she was. She still had a reputation to maintain, ya know.

“Alright, listen up, I'll take one more of you sorry sods down with us all, just cause I like having my back covered.” There was a resounding silence among the crowd of bandits, a token tumbleweed making its way across the dry ground behind them. Silgad squinted at them all.

“I see...hmph. Makin' me do the hard work myself, eh? Bastards...” she looked out over the small group, sighing loudly.

“...You! Tiger guy! With the bow! Yeah, you! You're a good shot, so you're comin' with. Yes, you fucking are, now get up here!!!”

The tiger bowman made his way up to the steps with a sullen expression, already praying to his gods that they have mercy on his soul.

“Good tiger...now fall in behind me.” Silgad canted her head to her right, where Omar already stood. The polar bear listened, tall and silent, peering over the ruined village as Silgad told the other bandits to guard it, and that if any of them abandoned the gang, she would hunt them down and personally tear out their entrails to wrap around their traitorous necks. Omar couldn't help but smirk. Even though Silgad was a heartless bitch, she knew how to make him smile.

He eventually caught the eye of Terga, the mountain sow he had taken a liking to. She almost looked sad, sad to see Omar go...and maybe never return. The polar bear cleared his throat, looking longingly back at Terga.

“...Omar.....Omar!! Get the wax outta your ears, I'm talking to you!” Silgad shoved his side, Omar blinking in surprise.

“Hmm, what? Sorry, I was...enjoying the view...” Omar grinned, looking back to Terga.

Silgad arched a brow, her gaze going to where Omar's rested.

Ah, for fucks sake..., glowered Silgad, wiping her hand over her face. “OK! Terga's coming with, damnit! She needs to get toughened up!” Omar turned slowly to the bandit leader, eyes squinted. After a short stare-down between him and Silgad, he growled, beckoning Terga with his large paw as he headed for the town hall. Silgad grinned as Terga caught up to the white bear, panting lightly.

“What. A. Fat ass.” Terga chuckled lightly, ignoring the jiggle around her middle and rear-end as she followed the pair.

The tiger archer slowly brought up the rear, staring at all three of his partners. Is everyone in this clan getting fat?!, he pondered, as he watched Silgad's round ass sway ahead of him. The still slim bowman sighed in frustration, shutting the town hall's gate.

15533222222222111212211.content:
Silgad dropped a torch into the darkness, the red-orange flame fluttering as it plummeted past the ladder and clattered to the stone floor. Satisfied that nothing was waiting below to sink its teeth into her juicy rear end, she climbed down the rickety steps and picked up the burning wood.

"This isn't just a tomb," she said thoughtfully, sniffing the air. "It's big. I can feel it." She took a step in the direction that felt the most open.

"We're coming," Omar said. The ladder creaked ominously under his weight. "Wait for us. It might not be safe."

"Anywhere's safer than standin' right under the two of you on that rickety ladder," Silgad laughed. "That's just asking to be crushed. C'mon, get down here before it falls to pieces."

The ladder held, surprisingly -- or not so surprisingly, when you considered the people it had been built for. As soon as the group was assembled, Silgad led the way forward into the gloom.

It took them several minutes to work their way across the room as Silgad scrutinized every paving stone for tripwires or pressure plates. When they finally reached the other side, they discovered the far wall wasn't a wall at all, but a mountain of crates and boxes piled nearly to the ceiling.

"There must be thousands of them," Terga breathed. Silgad felt her mouth begin to water. Gold! Gems! Valuable ancient pig portraits! The size of the treasure grew in her mind as she jimmied a crate loose from the pile, forming into a towering peak of gleaming metal and collapsing in an avalanche of wealth as she worked the lid loose. The inside was filled with what looked like golden bars. She picked one up--

And stopped short. Pure gold was soft all right. But not that soft.

"This isn't gold!" she snarled, bringing her torch closer. She took a nibble to confirm her suspicions. "This is cheese!"

"There's wine over here," the tiger reported. Omar thumped something in the darkness. "I think there's hams or roasts or something here, hanging from the ceiling."

"More food!" Silgad moaned. "Well, that's just great! As if we didn't have enough already!" She took a large bite of of the bar. "As if we wanted their stupid cheese! As if --*mmph*--as if it was worth it to come down here--*mmp*--juff to stuff ourf faffes..."

"I think this one is cheese, too," Terga said, nibbling. Silgad snatched the bar away from here.

"Lemme. Gotta be sure." She chomped down on the second bar. "Yeff. 'at's cheese all riffe."

"Maybe this is just a pantry," Omar suggested.

"There's more here--*glmmp*-- than than," Silgad said. "Has to be, with a setup like this. Who would set up that whole glowing-eyed statue thing just for the sake of food?"

"Pigs?"

Silgad frowned. "No. There's more down here than a few moldy old curds." Moldy old delicious curds, she had to admit to herself. Despite a heavy breakfast, she was practically inhaling the stuff.

"Those porkers were hiding something down here. We just have to find it."

155332222222221112122112.content:
"Alright Black-Tails!" Silgad blurted out, before biting off another chunk of the block of cheese she had snatched from Terga. Fuck, this cheese is divine... she thought to herself as she swallowed it down. Just as quickly as it traveled down her gullet, her mouth moved back towards the cheese once more. Silgad stopped herself from taking another bite however; why was she so ravenous lately? The pigs must have laced their foods with something, in order to let them consume much more than one could generally eat.

"Check the crates; there has to be something in them; I don't care if you have to take everything out of them and stuff it in your faces." she ordered, giving a stern look towards Terga's frame. She'd probably enjoy that, now wouldn't she? she joked to herself, considering Olmar's behavior towards her lately.
Silgad's own words struck her odd as well; while she had meant to order them to smash everything and throw it all on the ground, those weren't the words that left her mouth at all. Eat. Why eat? They had had enough at this point, hadn't they?

Subconsciously as she thought about this, she nibbled on another piece of cheese. Before long, that entire block was gone, and her hand was now free. Good shit.

"Hey Tiger guy!" She shouted out; she still couldn't think of his name, but that didn't matter; he was quite the looker...

"Get back up there and get more men down here; we've got a lot of crates to go through." She ordered. If the men weren't awake at this point...

"If they're still lazy shits, tell them they can gorge themselves when they get down here!" She added, before turning back to the crate of cheese before her. She'd look in there; might as well, who was going to stop her from doing so?

Her search began with another block of cheese being lifted from the stack...

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

The lower pantry had become much louder than it had before, with plenty of folk now searching for lost treasure. Someone had found a small bag of coins, which Silgad confiscated. She was the boss after all, lot went to her first before the others.

Two hours after the search had begun, and no one had found a damn thing other than that. Maybe the lack of productivity could be answered by the fact that most people were, as Silgad had ordered, eating the contents of the crates. The Hyena included of course, still munching on that gods-forsaken cheese. A light burp escaped her lips, though at this point, it was not an uncommon sound to hear from the others. Silgad snuck a glance at Terga and Omar; she was shyly sneaking a cookie from one of the crates.

Silgad scoffed at the sight, as if she needed to hide her gluttonous manners, the irony of Silgad's judgment of Trega completely lost on the bandit leader. While Terga was still much larger than her, the cheese had slowly begun to do a number on her own body as well; her stomach was much more bloated than it had previously been, and her buttocks shook much more as her body swayed. She had noticed, but her mind didn't have the time to be self conscious about it, pushing it aside as she shoved another block of cheese into her muzzle. Would she react to it later? Of course she would, just not at the moment.

Without looking into the crate, Silgad reached within it, her hands stumbling around for another block of delicious cheese.

Her hand did not feel anything soft however, just cold iron... Wait a moment.

Jolted out of her trance, Silgad shifted her body to look within the crate. Lo and behold , she had found something.
Hidden within the cheese was a sphere-shaped knob, slightly tilted towards her. She ripped off the sides of the crate in a frenzy, catching the eyes of everyone present. She then proceeded to sift through the stacked block of cheese, sending them tumbling to the ground. For a moment, she felt disappointed that so much of the fine stuff was going to waste, but shrugged it off, until she could plainly see what those delicious curds had safeguarded for what could have been years.

A metal lever stood idle, tilted to the side. Her mind rushed with excitement! When she pulled that lever, what would happen? What would be revealed to them all? Treasure...or more food perhaps? She'd be Ok with that if it so happened.

"Well well well folks, looks like we're on the right track!" She called out. She heard murmurs throughout the room, some of excitement, some of wonder, and some of...annoyance? For the first time in a long while however, Silgad shout out against those voices, and instead, took the lever in her hands.

"Finally time to get our loot ladies and gents!" She shouted, as she pulled it towards her.

The sounds of metallic screeching and gears was fully audible, as the mechanism the lever was controlled by served its function.

"Dammit!" cursed a voice as hands rifled through stacks of papers, his movements frantic and erratic like those of a man scrambling for escape, "What do you mean by "Our options are limited"? How did we run out so easily?"

Another voice grumbled forth from the darkness that obscured much of the room, the sound of solid, pacing footfalls coming from the same spot, "It seems simple, but when you're limited to two choices each... sometimes mistakes are made."

The hands gathered a specific stack and flipped through them. There were stories here, some written and some waiting for ink to meek parchment, both rich in potential. The pensive digits gripping the papers paused for a minute before neatly arranging the papers evenly into a pile.

"I understand, but there's a simple way to fix this one." He murmured, "We need to stay organized. Every account we find must be sorted and understood. Legends from truths... if they're to form a whole, then maybe we can piece together what happened..."

The other voice chuckled as his pacing stopped, "As well as what might lie ahead."

"Yes... maybe..." The first voice said, grabbing for a nearby bottle of spirits. The man didn't need to uncork it as he poured himself a small glass of absinthe, "But first, choices..."

15533222222222221.content:
A gentle breeze rustled the green leaves of the trees. Sweet birdsong lilted from branches all around the grove. Squirrels nattered to each other, and scolded the predators that had chased them high into their havens. Not far away, a sheep bleated.

Yet it was none of these things the armour-clad tiger in the middle of the clearing had his ear cocked to listen to. With his sword drawn, tip piercing the soft, fertile soil, and his large, strong hands folded on the pommel, he looked like a statue, albeit a sleeping one. His eyes were closed, and his chest hardly moved. His nostrils flared slightly, the scent of mutton still in its wool coat wafting by unheeded.

"Yes, Shining Master," he murmured, lips barely moving.

A squirrel ceased its chattering, looked towards the prone figure, and scurried further up its tree. A breeze sighed around the clearing, and then all was still.

Still, the tiger heard, loud and clear. "Thy will be done, Brightest One."

Opening his eyes, he flicked them around the glade. Buttery yellow sunlight slanted through the leaves on the trees. Motes of pollen danced in Nature's own spotlights. Animals sunned themselves, soaking up all the heat they could bear. Big trees and small shoots alike photosynthesized the solar rays into natural sugar, reaching ever higher towards the sky.

To others, this was merely a peaceful scene worthy of a portrait. But the tiger-! He knew better! He saw more! "He is enlightened! He is... Sir Jules DeNoon! Champion of the Light! Paladin of Sol-Ra the Illuminated! May he shine forever in the darkness." He punctuated this last, quietly-spoken phrase by tracing the symbol of the radiating sun upon his cuirass.

The handsome and fit tiger (dashing, too, if he did say so himself - and he often did) could read the sun's rays like a scroll crafted by the most reclusive of monks. This sight beyond sight had been granted him for his pure and unwavering devotion to Sol-Ra the Illuminated, God of Light. There was not a message from his god in every ray of light, but today, in this green glade, he had been sent a small novella.

But this was no love story he had seen - unless one counted the love of the man for torture and death. No, this was a laundry list of sins, mortal and venial, against gods, devils, monsters, mer, and men alike. He had stolen, swindled, lied, and cheated. Murder, after long periods of torture, were to him as thoughtless as dessert after a meal. He encouraged and fostered slothfulness, greed, pride, and gluttony in all his "subjects" - some, in his thrall; others, eking out a meager existence in his perverted "kingdom" before death; more, trapped and twisted in his labyrinths while trying to vanquish the vile villain for good.

Jules lifted his lip in a snarl. The Lipomancer! To call him a devil wouldst gave the devils a bad name!

When the tiger closed his eyes, he saw red, with the sunlight shining through his eyelids. And on the back of his eyelids, he saw printed the names of The Lipomancer's mortal associates, loaded Lords and Ladies, already of dubious moral standing, who offered the dark sorcerer monetary and fleshly support in his ventures of death and conquest, both of land, and the spirits of the races of mer and men.

"Sir Jules DeNoon will cast Sol-Ra's divine light upon thee, wrongdoers, and by it, your dire truths will be revealed!" The tiger boldly pledged, sunlight flashing along the length of his sword as he pointed it in the direction of nearby Wellingham. "You will divulge the location of this Lipomancer unto us, and our final campaign against the foul creature will begin!"

155332222222222211.content:
Sheathing his sword, after brushing the dirt and grass from its tip, Jules strode confidently (the only way he ever walked) off in the direction of Wellingham. The Lady Chattow would hardly be able to deny an audience with an illustrious crusader of moral righteousness such as himself, lest her reputation be further tarnished. As he saw it, she was already teetering on the edge of damnation; his actions alone could save her soul.

The green cape fastened by golden cords to his shining steel cuirass stirred in the slight breeze that cooled him, its gold trim catching the sunlight. His armour was well-oiled, and moved smoothly with him, producing only the expected clanking. The care with which he maintained his blessed suit of armour was second only to his own self-upkeep. Carrying around an extra fifty pounds of armour daily demanded strength, and strength stemmed from sacrifice.

As he would readily share with anyone he thought deserved to hear it, he had been making the necessary sacrifices for ten years. His body was a temple in the heyday of its worship. Chiseled jaw, six-pack abs, muscled arms, firm thighs, and buns of steel, all accentuated by his immaculately-groomed fur, the contrast between his orange base and black stripes as crisp as noontime shadows. Creamy, whitish fur framed his lower jaw, and flowed from there down to his toes, covering his neck, chest, stomach, and inner thighs. Powerful canine teeth, an inch long each, gleamed in his beguiling grin, and his golden eyes shone like the emblem on his cuirass, a radiating sun.

Boasting extensive training and experience in combat, his platemail was as little bother to him as a ranger's leather, or a mage's robe. One could reasonably expect him to fair bake without cover of shade at noonday, but his god, and Nature, the closest companions, ensured not so much as a bead of sweat glistened upon his brow. It was a small blessing he was ever grateful for, mindful that otherwise, he'd have a lot more grooming to do.

Wellingham was just over a mile away from the glade he'd paused in, and so the trek took little time. The village was fair-to-middling-sized, a safe enough rest spot for travelers and carriages alike. It was home to two taverns, one at either point of ingress, and a single, large inn, smack in the middle. A blacksmith offered his or her services, there was a tailor ready to outfit those with the coin to pay, a bakery wafted delightful aromas into the air, and the presence of a cobbler spoke to a heavy human populace. On the opposite side of the street from the inn, and situated on a rise that gave it a view of the village, there sat a sprawling manor, apparently intended to intimidate by its presence alone, never mind its Gothic architecture.

Without needing to be told, the tiger turned in its direction. He would find his target there.

The road leading to the mansion, wide enough for two carriages to pass comfortably, was of better quality than the broad dirt path bisecting the village, paved smoothly with bricks. It left little doubt as to whom the person at the other end of it valued most. The sun-baked bricks were also less comfortable than the hard-packed dirt, even through his custom steel boots. If no one had warned the Lady of their discomfort, it was because she had not wanted to hear them.

After a walk at least eight times shorter, yet eight times more irritating, than the one that had brought him to Wellingham, Jules raised a mailed fist, and knocked on the double doors of Chattow Mansion. After a quick glance at his reflection on the back of his hand to ascertain his social acceptability, he straightened his back, puffed out his chest, and turned on his charm.

The door swung open smoothly, and a perky vixen began to greet him with a smile. "Good afternoon, sir, what can I- I-" she trailed off, dazed or intimidated by him.

Jules was used to this, however, and answered gently, but firmly, "Sir Jules DeNoon seeks an audience with the lady of the house."

"Pl-please, sir, come in," the vixen scuttled out of the way, opening the door wide. "I will pass this onto Lady Chattow myself!"

"Thank you, fair woman," Jules smiled down at her, stepping into the lavish foyer. Thick rug cushioned his feet, and the sunlight streaming through the windows high on either side of him lit even the deepest recesses of the ceiling far overhead. A gas-lamp chandelier, all sparkling crystal and gleaming gold, hung from a rafter above. Some twenty feet away, two grand staircases curled back on themselves as they connected the first and second floors. The third floor, situated overhead, seemed to have but one staircase leading to it, from what he could tell.

His inspection was cut short when a thud and a small shriek reached his ears. His hand instinctually strayed to the hilt of his sword, his eyes swept the immediate area, and his nostrils flared open for the stench of evil.

However, it was only a mouse maid who had dropped a laundry basket as she'd entered the room from his right. She repeatedly squeaked something like "Sorry, sir, so sorry!", face flushed red, as she gathered the fine clothes, and hurried form the room.

Jules allowed himself to relax inasmuch as reassuming a casual stance. He could hear distant giggles, and the faintest traces of whispers, which he was also accustomed to. Turning towards the source of these, three more maids (also noticeably furry) peeking around the corner of the hallway past the stairs to his left, he winked, and grinned.

The faces of the two topmost maids disappeared as the giggles grew louder, but the third maid swooned, and slumped to the floor. She was barely visible for a second before the other two carted her off, out of sight, and hopefully out of trouble.

Jules, blushing a little himself, tried to go back to looking noble and businesslike. He wasn't here to cause trouble, but he was prepared for it.
155332222222222211.title: Lady Chattow's Gentleman Caller

1553322222222222111.content:
Meanwhile, on the third floor landing, Doris (Lady Chattow's vixen maid) composed herself, and knocked upon the door to her mistress' private quarters, preparing for a tongue-lashing even before she could state her business.

"Now what is it you featherbrained imbeciles want?!" the Lady herself demanded from within. "If I have to repeat myself one more time today, it's coming out of someone's hide! Enter!"

Doris let herself in silently, averting her eyes to the floor. "You have a- a gentleman caller, Mistress Chattow. He seems to be a knight."

She considered this coolly, looking out at the village below from he large, round window, which from outside resembled a leering, Cyclopean eye. Then all at once, she turned on the vixen, satisfied to find her gaze on the floor, where it should be. "Tell me, Doris... Is he handsome?"

In the moment it took the maid to work up the wherewithal to answer, the mansion's mistress read it in her red and trembling countenance. "I see. Very well. Send him up."

"To your- private quarters, mistress?" Doris hesitated.

"Did I not make myself clear, fleabrain?" Lady Chattow snipped, glaring daggers into the fur between the vixen's ears. "Or do you not think you cleaned it well enough to be seen by someone you deem more important than me?"

"I- I'll send him up straightaway, mistress," Doris gulped, backing out of the room.

Once relatively safe, with a thick oak door between the Lady Chattow and herself, the maid dabbed her forehead with a cleaning rag. It was stressful, being the mistress' personal handmaiden, but still better than being the low woman on the totem pole! Lifting her skirt slightly, she scurried down the stairs.

Jules had been studying the sunbeams for any further information relayed to him, but Sol-Ra (the Illuminated; may he shine forever in the darkness) seemed to think he had adequately prepared him already. The tiger offered his god a quick prayer of gratitude, and turned to face the maid who now approached him in a hurry.

"Lady Chattow will see you in her private quarters on the third floor, Sir," Doris told him, trying to discretely catch her breath. She was supposed to be rearing children at this time in her life, not running up and down flights of stairs! "If you'll follow me, I'll take you to her."

"Thank you, fair maiden, but you deserve rest," Jules smiled easily, taking her unresisting hand in his own. Bending down, he planted a small kiss upon the back of it, and then released. "Sir Jules DeNoon will guide himself to the Lady Chattow. Her private quarters are above us?" He pointed up towards the ceiling.

Doris nodded, temporarily dumbstruck, then managed a breathy "Y-yes, Sir."

Jules nodded firmly, and set off, leaving the girls with a final, dazzling smile.

Doris' knees failed her then and there, and if Mimi had not been behind her with the laundry basket, her landing would have been considerably more jarring.

The tiger ascended the stairs easily, taking them two at a time, and paused outside the Lady's door to make sure his headfur was smoothed down, and his armour sat just right. Then, he knocked, mindful not to leave impressions in the wood.

"Come in!" lilted a falsely-cheerful voice.

Jules entered the room, the large window catching his eye before the figure just six feet in front of him did. He closed the door behind him. Bowing at the waist, as was respectful when introducing oneself to those of a higher station in life than one's own, he said "Sir Jules DeNoon, Paladin of Sol-Ra the Illuminated."

Lady Chattow lifted her lip in distaste. Paladins were not 'gentlemen callers'; they were arrogant, meddling goody two-shoes, to be shown the door as soon as they'd come in. Fleabags like this were not to get that far in the first place. She would have to have a stern talk with her staff later. "Lady Viola Chattow. You may rise."

Jules straightened up, quickly taking in the composition of the personage before him. Her prosperity showed on every inch of her, whether in the rings and bracelets bedecking her hands and wrists, the necklaces of gold and silver ringing her neck, the fine fabrics of the dark purple dress she was swaddled in, or the extra two-hundred pounds, or so, she carried on her stout frame. Yet she managed to have an unpleasantly sharp face, which Jules felt calling "ratty" would insult the species, bipedal and feral. Her dark hair was pulled back into an intricate and tight jeweled headdress. That she was sizing him up with obvious disgust dispelled any qualms he had about what he had come to do.

"Lady Chattow, Sir DeNoon is here not on Temple business, but on a quest given to him by Sol-Ra Himself. We wish for your assistance in but a small manner."

"And what might that be?" Lady Chattow asked, turning her back on him, and slowly sauntering towards the writing desk situated near the large window.

Jules took a few steps towards her, to ensure only she would hear him. "The Lipomancer."

Lady Chattow stiffened for a second, then slowly turned back towards him, two spots of color riding high in her cheeks. "What an ugly name. I am afraid, though, I have no idea to whom you refer."

"Lady Chattow, wherever there is light, Sol-Ra is there. He sees all, and he knows all," the tiger said sternly, stepping towards her twice more. "Sir DeNoon would not be here at his behest if you could not tell him what he needs to know."

As nonchalantly as possible, Lady Chattow positioned herself up against her desk. "Many slanderous lies are written about me, by light of day and candle. I am afraid you are misguided."

Jules reached for his sword, resting his hand on the hilt. "Sir DeNoon warns you, Lady Chattow, you do not want to touch that bell."

The big window seemed to flash in his vision, just for a moment, and he drew his sword anyway. Approaching his less-than-gracious hostess with the point held towards her heart, he commanded "Lady Chattow, truth is to Sol-Ra the Illuminated as a candle in the darkness. Your disingenuous lies serve only to further jeopardize your soul. Before this gets ugly, tell Sir DeNoon the truth."

Gulping, and beginning to sweat unpleasantly, Lady Chattow backed away from the tiger's sword, around the writing desk, and towards the light falling through the Cyclopean window. "Doris said that you were handsome, but I see now she should have meant as a rug! If you do not leave this instant, I will scream, and my guards will tear you limb from limb!"

Jules took three more steps forward, and she three more steps back. Now, she was fully illuminated in the shaft of yellow sunlight streaming through the window.

"The truth always comes to light, Viola Chattow!" he declared.
