15533222222222221111.content:
The three-hundred-some pound woman opened her mouth, perhaps to scream, but all she emitted was a sickening sort of glorping sound, like a ladle being dropped into a pot of oatmeal.

Jules backed away, shifting his grip on his drawn sword, and holding it at the ready. The Lady Chattow looked like she was going to vomit, but what, he didn't know.

The dark-haired woman's adipose-laden torso began to rhythmically distend, here and there, and it was a grotesque sight to behold. In her dark purple dress, it came to look like a pot of ink bubbling. Quite literally, she seemed to be coming to a boil in her own skin. Domes of flesh swelled outwards, then disappeared with audible, gut-wrenching pop!s.

Not limited to her stomach, the effect soon spread to her heavy arms, thick thighs, and fat-swaddled neck. She seemed to be trying to scream, but she could only hiss like a teakettle over the fire.

Out of respect for the nice person she may once have been, the tiger paladin averted his eyes from what happened next.

With a sound like a gravy-filled water balloon bursting, if it were three feet in diameter, Viola Chattow exploded in a red shower of blood, guts and gore. Her dress floated down in tatters like confetti, and her shoes were propelled to opposite sides of the room. Rings, bracelets, and necklaces flew off in all directions, like the world's most expensive fragmentary grenade. A truly hellish smell filled the air. It was over.

Jules stumbled blindly forward into the embrace of the sunbeams shining unfettered through the large, round window, in places splattered with gore. His gorge was rising like a rocket, demanding he reintroduce his lunch to the world; breakfast would tag along, too. But he clamped down on it, telling himself he did not want to make a bigger mess for the maids.

However, Sol-Ra must have seen his distress, for momentarily, the dappling sunlight soothed his stomach, and calmed his heart. On the backs of his eyelids, he saw spelled "writing desk".

Rising, the tiger kept his head bowed as he first uttered a prayer of thanks and praise to Sol-Ra the Illuminated ("may you shine forever in the darkness") before turning around, away from the gruesome sight to his left.

The late Lady Chattow's writing desk sat just five feet from the window, and by luck, or divine intervention, it was as clean as Doris (or whomever the maid was who had tidied the room earlier) had left it. Sheathing his sword, Jules spun the top sheet of parchment around so he could read it.

15th - "Ample Ampitheatre" performances, Lipomancer's  Castle Lair.
Two days by carriage IF travel twelve hours/day.
Room and board w/ other nobles at "Golden Chalice Inn". Ask "Newberg" (owner) for "Lip Service".
Take Doris (old vixen) to serve; Mimi "to serve".


Attached to this were finely-detailed maps. One showed exactly how to get to Little Silverhorne, host to the Lipomancer's Lair, from Wellingham, and the other laid out the town at the base of the castle, down to the residences.

"Sol-Ra, you are as generous as you are wise, and from the bottom of his heart, Shining One, Sir Jules DeNoon thanks you," the tiger said humbly, taking a knee while facing the window.

He took this opportunity to consider his choices. Today was the tenth. Armed with this new knowledge, he could continue his crusade against the Lipomancer this very day. A carriage would not be hard to find, especially for coin. He could even arrive in time to perhaps spare the poor souls destined for doom in this "Ample Amphitheater".

Or, he could wait a few days here in Wellingham, and then follow the late Lady's itinerary. Posing as one noble among many, perhaps he could get close enough to the Lipomancer to end him before he quite knew he was being struck down. He would have a few days to prepare himself, and to help clean up the messes he had created for the maids.

Wincing, he opened his eyes; there remained the mess that once had been a woman. The maids were now unemployed - and he wasn't happy to have to break that news to them - but would they still want to clean it up? Or would they only wish to turn their backs on a house full of bad memories, and never look back?

Jules rose, and took a deep breath, the horrific smell filling his lungs unnoticed. He would pass along the news to the maids, and see how it went from there. Before leaving, he tucked the notes and maps into his coin pouch, and pushed the window open; the glass swung out from its diameter, like a coin flipping through the air.

He considered leaving the door open, but then relented; the window would air out the room plenty. Maybe not enough, but it was better than the stench pervading the rest of the house. He plodded down the stairs to the second floor, green cape as still and solemn as his countenance. He saw the vixen maid waiting for him as he descended the stairs to the ground floor.

"Doris, is it? Please, if you can, gather the others in the employ of Lady Chattow here. Sir DeNoon has to say something you must all hear."

Catching his grim demeanor, the vixen nodded, and hurried into another room. As Jules repositioned himself, he thought he saw chairs. A dining room, then? A sound that may have been the faintest of tinkles emerged from it, followed swiftly by Doris again.

As modestly-dressed servants began trickling into the grand foyer from every direction, she explained to the tiger "All the maids have a spell laid on them so they hear the silver bells, wherever they ring, and wherever we are. They'll all come here."

Gently squeezing the vixen's hand in his own, much-larger and steel-mailed one, Jules offered a sympathetic "Thank you."

Once all the maids stood before him in the foyer (all furry, he noted, as if the Lady Chattow had thought humans above positions of subservience), he cleared his throat, and began. "Fair maidens, Sir Jules DeNoon must apologize for this. His questioning of the Lady Chattow took an unexpected turn for the worse, and she- she has passed away. It was not Sir Jules' intention to create the mess that has left you unemployed, or the one in the bedchambers."

He had not known quite how they were going to react, but "with cheers" would have been a thought too silly to consider. Yet the women were laughing, cheering, hugging one another, and jumping up and down.

Wringing his hands, Jules turned to a broadly-beaming Doris in worry. "Sir Jules does not quite understand. He hopes you might enlighten him?"

"Vile Viola was a mean and hateful bitch," the vixen stated bluntly, overflowing with relief. "No one liked working for her, but we did what we had to so we could survive."

"Yes, but now Sir Jules has eliminated your source of income," the tiger said sadly, ears lowered. "That is why he was not eager to tell you."

"There's always a demand for our skills out there," Doris assured him. "And whoever buys this place - and someone will, because it's a nice place, despite the last owner - may well choose to keep us on as their staff, because we know it so well. There is little to worry about, Sir DeNoon. You should just be happy you have freed us."

Smiling hesitantly, he nodded. "Sir Jules will try."

Loosening the leather straps on either side of his cuirass that held it tight, he hefted the heavy armour up over his head, leaving his top half in just the soft leather tunic he wore to prevent chafing. Not a few breathy gasps were heard from the crowd. "But before Sir Jules does anything, he has left a bloody physical mess in the Lady's bedroom he intends to help clean up."

Doris glanced out at the assembled maids, most of whom were transfixed on the hunky tiger. They certainly weren't going to argue. "Yes Sir! If you insist!" she smiled happily.

Every individual maid would later swear that he had looked right at them when he flashed a grin that made faces flush, and knees go weak, and said "Then let us get to it, ladies!"
15533222222222221111.title: Lady Chattow, Illuminated.

choices: Another Paladin - but of Nocturpus.
A hairy barbarian.
155332222222222211111.content:
Despite insistent pleas and reasoning from all the maids at the late Lady Chattow's mansion to get him to stay, Jules departed that evening. He had every intention of ridding the land of the blight that was the Lipomancer as soon as he could, even if it meant departing that very night.

Having waved a last farewell to the maids, he now clanked back down the brick-paved path to the rest of the village. The setting sun had been visible through the big third-story window in the house, situated on a rise above the rest of Wellingham, but as the path dipped, the glowing orb fell behind first the inn, then the village's wall, and out of sight, though it still offered some illumination. Night was fast approaching, and the land was entering the domain of Nocturpus, She of the Inky Tentacles and Moonlight Eye. Some said she and Sol-Ra were forever chasing one another across the sky, and the explanations for this ran the gamut from forbidden love to eternal hatred.

Personally, Jules had never heard anything from the god Himself to confirm or correct this.

Wellingham's inn, according to the sign, bore the moniker of "Le Chateau du Jour", leading him to think the founder had been from Luxumentum, or had been pretending to be. The symbol on the sign was of a bowl, presumably of stew or soup, with a spoon protruding from it, contents steaming. This had the desired effect of leading him to realize it WAS suppertime, and a hot meal before he hit the road would be most welcome.

Stepping inside, Jules saw nigh two dozen other patrons, not a few seated at the bar, and more around the tables. With an eclectic mix of cloaked figures, armored patrolmen, small families, single men and women, and even a few elves, clustered together for comfort, if not protection, he attracted next to no attention. Strolling up to the bar, he pulled out a stool, and set himself on it. The last time he'd dropped onto one while fully-armored, he'd snapped its legs in twain. That had been embarrassing...

"What can I do for ye, Noble Sir?" A human barmaid in attention-grabbing dress asked him.

It did not cross the tiger's mind to lower his eyes from her own as he told her "Sir DeNoon will have your beef stew, if you have such a thing available."

"We can do that," the barmaid confirmed with a polite smile. "Bowl, or pot?"

"Excuse?" He blinked, nonplussed by this turn of phrase.

"Would you like a bowl of the beef stew, or a pot of it?" the blonde barmaid repeated patiently.

"Oh. Just a bowl, please," Jules said, adding, almost as an afterthought, "and a flagon of milk, if you would."

"I'll have that out to you in two shakes, Sir," she assured him with a pretty smile of her own, flitting away.

What need would Jules have for a whole pot of beef stew? he wondered, picturing such a dish being set in front of him. Does she think he would feed his family? Perhaps the less-fortunate? He is not sure if it is rude to ask...

No more than a minute later, a good-sized bowl and a tall flagon were set in front of him. He pushed the proper coinage across the counter with a "thank you", and delicately closed his mailed fist around the handle of the provided spoon. Happily enough, it, too, seemed slightly oversized, perhaps just for people such as himself.

As if the aromas alone didn't get the message across, one bite of the stew relayed to his taste buds just how scrumptious the stew was. The meat chunks were sizable and tender, the vegetables moist, the gravy full-flavored and thick, and the potatoes baked just right. The milk was creamy and cool, speaking to either magic, or expensive refrigeration techniques. In the tiger's estimation, it was a meal worth twice what he'd paid for it, and a lovely way to start off his journey.

He was about halfway through the bowl when a heavy hand clapped him heartily on the back making the ring of steel resonate in the air. "I'm surprised you don't have a bowl for your milk, too, kitty-cat!"

Looking towards the source of this verbal tweak of the ear, Jules saw it had come from...
155332222222222211111.title: Le Chateau du Jour

choices: Take it outside!
"Discuss" it in the tavern!
1553322222222222111111.content:
Jules, taking his supper at Wellingham's inn, "Le Chateau Du Jour", was about halfway through his bowl of beef stew when a heavy hand clapped him on the back, making steel ring. "I'm surprised you don't have a bowl for your milk, too, kitty-cat!"

Looking towards the source of this verbal tweak of the ear, Jules saw a black wolf, armored not unlike himself, sliding onto the stool next to him at the bar. The most notable difference was that over his steel cuirass, the jerkin he wore was a deep, inky purple-black, and bore an insignia of a full, silver moon. This, and his late rise from bed, marked him as a Paladin of Nocturpus. Not his opposite number, exactly, but his mirror-match.

"Sir DeNoon will find you some roadkill to gnaw on for breakfast, if that is what you're after," the tiger needled right back.

"Ha ha! Thanks, but I'll stick to the ribs they got here," the wolf laughed, clapping him on the shoulder in a friendly manner. "Hey, you Daydreamers are alright; I don't care what nobody says. What brings you Wellingham way? Patrol?"

Jules waited for the wolf to place his order, then told him "Nay. Sir DeNoon is in pursuit of The Lipomancer."

The black wolf winced visibly (and perhaps exaggeratedly), hissing through his teeth. "Ooh. REAL nasty piece of work, that one. Was he supposed to have been in this area?" He fetched glances around the inn at this.

Before the tiger could answer, the wolf stuck out his hand towards him. "Oh. Sir Sidney Coltrane, at your service. 'Sid', to my brothers-in-arms."

The tiger set his spoon down, and grabbed the proffered hand. "Sir Jules DeNoon. He is often called 'Jules' by his fellows when in their company, and he has no objection to this. Well met, Sir Sid."

"Well met, Sir Jules," the wolf agreed with a grin.

"To answer your question-" Jules began.

Before he could get any farther, however, the barmaid set a bucket and a pitcher in front of the wolf, who thanked her heartily. Seeing his companion's strange look, he shrugged, and said "What? I'm going to take some with me!"

"Sir Jules had been wondering why such a thing was on the menu..." the tiger admitted, seeing the mystery was solved.

"You clearly haven't been in town for very long if you think that's why, though it is nice," Sid shook his head, pausing to chew and swallow a piece of his breakfast. "If you'd seen some of the regular clientele, you wouldn't be so surprised."

"It's a bit early, but they'll be along before too much longer," he added, swigging some ruby red liquid directly from the pitcher.

Though curious as to just what he meant by this, Jules tried to get back on topic. "Well, anyhow, no, the Lipomancer has not been in this area recently. Sir Jules was here to question one of his associates. She was recalcitrant, and Sol-Ra saw to it she came to judgment for her life of poor choices and lies."

"He did, huh?" Sid raised an eyebrow. "How'd he go about that?"

"She backed away from Sir Jules as he approached - he'd had to draw his sword when she threatened to call her guards for a fight - and she stepped into the sunlight falling through her large window. She soon began to... bubble, like a cauldron, and then she exploded! Sir Jules was not harmed, but he was surprised."

"Was she, uh, a little on the heavy side?" Sid questioned thoughtfully.

"More than a little," Jules confirmed. "Over twice what an average woman of her stature should weigh."

Sid nodded, as if this explained everything. "Thought so. Hate to burst your bubble, but I don't think that was your god, powerful and mighty as I'm sure he is, what done that."

"No?" The tiger questioned stiffly, raising his eyebrow. "Sir Jules is not prepared to listen to heresy about Sol-Ra without a vigorous verbal debate. He advises you to speak carefully."

"Hey, I could go on all night about Nocturpus, but hear me out, Sir Jules," the wolf waved him down. "I've heard about this before. 'Acquaintances' and 'allies' and 'accomplices' of the Big L who, when captured, cornered, or sometimes even only questioned... Well, whether they like it or not, some sort of defense is triggered. Their bodies - well, more accurately, their adipose - starts attacking them, or starts sloughing off, or, like you saw, they just burst."

Sid leaned in, lowering his voice. "He doesn't like people like us, people with the power to act against him, getting in his business. I don't think he's powerful enough to act against us directly, but he can put obstacles in our way. Now that you know where to find him... Pal, you're a big, fat TARGET."

This might have made a lesser (or more intelligent) man quiver, but Jules only sniffed. "Let him try to stop me. I have the blessings of Sol-Ra the Illuminated upon me. Creatures of the dark cannot bear the light."

Smiling at this bit of pompousness, Sid declared "And sometimes, you gotta fight fire with fire, which is why I'm coming with you!"

Jules scoffed into his flagon. "Says who?"

"Says Nocturpus! She of the Inky Tentacles and Moonlight Eye. You might have heard of her?" Sid nudged.

"There is still light in the sky. Sir Jules does not believe you," Jules maintained stubbornly. "Sir Jules has heard plenty about Nocturpus. He has heard of her ties to the Duplicitwins, for example. Shadows and 'secrets' go so well hand-in-hand."

"There is nothing evil about my goddess! Inherently, or otherwise!" Sid snorted, jabbing him in the chest. "You want to take this outside? It just so happens to be twilight! Your deity and mine share the sky! They'll clear this up."
1553322222222222111111.title: Wolfing Down Dinner

choices: They are able to hire a carriage and leave right away.
No carriages until morning - but Sid has a room!
15533222222222221111111.content:
Jules set his spoon down in his now-empty bowl, drained his flagon of milk, and stood up. "Sir DeNoon would so happen to like to take this outside!"

Grumbling, Sid stood, remembered to leave money on the counter for his meal, and followed the tiger out the door - but not before stripping the meat from the last few ribs.

Together, they marched out past the village walls, stopping at a point where they had an unobstructed view of the sunset. Jules cleared his throat, and took a deep breath. Sid swallowed, and washed his breakfast down with a draught from the pitcher he'd carried out with him. They started to speak, individual invocations entangling in the air.

"Sol-Ra the Illuminated, who will shine forever in the darkness..."

"...Nocturpus, She of the Inky Tentacles and Moonlight Eye, bringer of the blissful nights, your humble champion begs..."

"...your light of truth upon the situation. Illume the path..."

"...reflect the truth. Bounce your moonbeams through a hall of mirrors, and construct a..."

"...verity. Sol-Ra, Reality Star-"

"-Nocturpus, Tallier of Tenebrous Tenets-"

"-I/Jules DeNoon call/s upon you to lift the fog from my/his eyes!" they finished together, in something like harmony, focusing their gazes on the streak of sky between the sinking sun and falling night. Their chests heaved, and nostrils flared, for they had become a bit boisterous in their contentions.

There, in that band of twilight, the heavens seemed to shift. Sunlight and starlight refracted in odd ways. Like a laser light show worlds and centuries away from the time and place for such a thing, words were there writ for the two of them to read.

Jules began. "Caped Crusaders of the Clock: mirror-matched ye may be..."

"...but radiate, each of ye, the rays of justice, strong and true..." Sid continued, with a sort of wonder.

"...from hearts of steel, and spirits, too. On this day-"

"-over this night, share this common cause to fight. The Lipomancer! Evil through-"

"-no match, still, for justice you-"

"-bring, for the crown and the ring-!"

"When thy swords' thirst for his blood is slaked, two Legends that day we'll see awaked!" They bellowed this final line together with gauntlets raised into the air.

The perfect balance shifted, the words faded, and all was "normal" in this part of the world again.

"Hah!" Sid released an excited sound somewhere between a gasp and grunt, then turned to look at Jules, grinning ear-to-ear. "Does that answer all your questions, smarty-stripes?"

"All, save one," the tiger conceded.

"Sheesh. What else could you want to know?" Sid laughed a little, oddly impressed by his dedication to a stoic demeanor.

"Why are you holding Sir Jules' hand?" He demanded, raising his left hand, clamped in the wolf's right, up between their faces. Quite as a side note, he now noticed their height difference: at six-foot-four, he was two inches taller than the wolf.

"I just thought we were having a special moment, here, you and I..." Sid said softly, looking at him with doe eyes, "...and you're ever such a handsome tiger..."

Jules couldn't quite tell from his tone just how much he was joking, and tried on a few different, confused facial expressions before finding one that would do the trick: righteous indignation. "Sir Jules would thank you to let go of him now."

Sid did, unable to stop a smile growing on his face. "Hoo, boy, this is going to be one fun quest!"

Jules only began marching back to town, muttering "Sir Jules suspects you are going to be unbearable."

"No, no, not at all!" the black wolf scoffed, bending down to grab his borrowed pitcher, then rushing to catch up with him.

"Well," he considered, falling in step beside the tiger, "maybe a little."

The tiger heaved an exaggerated sigh. "C'est la monde."

"I don't understand what you just said, but it was beaucoup cute," Sid teased. "Is that a twist of Luxese I hear in your voice?"

Jules touched his jaw self- and subconsciously, as if evidence of this might lie in its shape. "Sir Jules originally... hails from a region of Luxumentum, yes."

Sid's tail swept the air behind him frenetically, and he was never more glad for his dark fur. "I thought so. It makes everything you say- That is, it gives you quite the silver tongue. Er, I reckon."

Before they reentered the inn, the wolf asked "Hey, uh, when it's just the two of us- I mean, it seems a little silly for us to call each 'Sir' when we both know... Um, that is, are on a first-name basis, in private?"

Jules considered this, then smiled a little, and nodded. "That is acceptable to Jules." He stepped into La Chateau Du Jour.

Sid remained behind a moment, to let out a quiet "Yesss!", then followed.
15533222222222221111111.title: Twilight Princes

choices: Continue...
155332222222222211111111.content:
Sir Sidney Coltrane (Sid to his brothers-in-arms) found his new tiger companion back at the bar, wasting no time in attempting to drum them up a ride. Leaning over an empty stool, he gave back the pitcher he'd borrowed, and then hurried towards the stairs. He only had a few things in the room he'd rented, but he didn't want to leave them behind.

Jules turned briefly to watch the black wolf mount the stairs with admirable speed, for all the armour he was wearing, then focused his attention back on the matter at hand. The barkeep was due to report back on the availability of carriages at any moment. The sooner they set off for the Lipomancer's Lair in Little Silverhorne, the better. He tried not to think about how many lives might hang in the balance even at his very moment.

"You're in luck, Sir," the blonde woman smiled as she returned, polishing yet another beer mug, seemingly without even looking. "There's a freshly-rested team out there right now prepared to take you just about wherever you need to go. He won't move until you give the say-so."

"You have the gratitude of Sir Jules DeNoon, fair maiden," the tiger smiled, relieved. "Sol-Ra's smile will warm you and yours."

"It's my pleasure, Sir DeNoon," she assured him.

"Could you tell Sir DeNoon which room Sir Coltrane rented?" the tiger paladin asked hopefully. "He must tell him of this arrangement."

"No need, Sir DeNoon. He's- I've gathered my things," Sid said from behind him. "We'll only need food."

Jules, turning to the wolf, frowned slightly. "But you just ate alongside Sir DeNoon not fifteen minutes ago."

"Food for the journey, Sir DeNoon," Sid reminded him patiently, stifling a grin. "Even if you can survive on air and sunshine, I like, and need, ribs. Or, you know- meat."

"Oh. Fair point," the tiger nodded. He turned back to the bar.

Sid decided to trust his judgment, as they seemed to have similar dietary requirements, and turned away to look over the inn's other patrons. A number of them were the "regular clientele" he had earlier mentioned to Jules, and made a note to point them out to the tiger before they left. The three elves were still clustered in one corner, but they weren't his concern tonight. Nor were the cloaked figures sticking to the shadows - as long as they didn't do anything evil in front of him, he had no reason to act.

There, though - the courier! There was usually one hanging about the inn, gathering money and messages throughout the night, and making regular runs about town. His message was a little more long-distance than that, but the courier could get it out for him on the morrow. He carefully made his way to where the man was sitting.

Pushing a folded piece of parchment and the fee across the table to him, Sid said "For delivery to the Nocturpus Temple in Tranquility, as soon as possible."

The courier secured everything in the bag by his side, and nodded. "With the first run of the day, sir."

"Thank you," Sid inclined his head. "May your night journeys always be moonlit."

He made for the door, thinking he would perhaps check out their carriage, but paused, thought, and decided to wait for Jules, instead. Yet no more had he turned around than a sack was thrust at him, giving him cause to jump back, and reach for his sword.

It was only the tiger, however, smiling a little. "Apologies. Sir Jules had secured the provisions, and he is ready to depart when you are."

"I'm ready, as well," the black wolf said, relaxing. "Was just about to inspect our ride, when I thought- Er, let's go."

"You do not have to muzzle yourself around Sir Jules, Sir Sidney," he assured him as he followed him from the inn. "He understands your urge to babble like a buffoon is only due to his incredible good looks."

This was a little too nail-on-head for the wolf, until he realized that the other paladin had been joking. "O-oh, yes, that's clearly it. Wow, looks, and brains bigger than a walnut! You're the whole, hunky package, Sir Jules!"

Carefully, considering his hand was currently gauntlet-clad, Jules ruffled Sid's headfur playfully. "Yea and verily."

Sid voiced the customary grumbles while brushing his fur straight, including something about that "great, stripy lummox", but secretly was rather pleased. Yes, he thought he was going to enjoy this quest very much...
155332222222222211111111.title: Farewell, Wellingham

choices: They make it to Half Measure Hamlet undisturbed.
Trouble strikes in the middle of the night!
1553322222222222111111111.content:
Their awaiting carriage was a fine-looking example of Bitemarsh craftsmanship, big enough to comfortably seat four, and assembled from some exemplary red wood. The two painted horses who'd be drawing it looked healthy and strong, as tall at the shoulder as he was overall. They snorted, and shook their manes, ready to hit the trail. Their driver was a stocky human, probably in his middle ages, in an... unusual suit. He greeted them with a showman's smile.

"Good evening, Sirs. Fine gentlemen like you, paragons of purity, the gods' own forces for good, you deserve only the best transportation, and in this town, or any other, that is us. You've chosen well, and we thank you for it. Arthur Linkin, with my fast and faithful steeds Axle and Rod, at your service."

"Sir Jules DeNoon," the tiger introduced himself.

Following his lead, the wolf spoke next. "Sir Sidney Coltrane."

Hands were shaken, and Arthur opened the carriage door for them, gesturing towards the interior. "Plush and comfy interior. Viewing windows on either side, with curtains to keep wandering eyes out. Benches long and wide enough for both of you to have a lie-down, enough leg room to swing a cat around your toe, and secure storage compartments overhead for your carry-ons."

At Jules' behest, Sid climbed in first, and then he followed, lowering himself onto the seat catty-corner from the wolf. It was so well-cushioned beneath his bum, he couldn't feel the wood of the bench at all. He had to admit he was duly impressed, but Sid said it for both of them.

"Gods be praised, this is amazing! If I had my way, I'd never use a different carriage!" he grinned happily, unable to resist bouncing in his seat a little. "Most impressive!"

Arthur laughed, pleased. "Well, thank ye kindly, Sir. Me work is me love, and I've given her only the best. Speaking of, her suspension is a revolutionary new build out of the mountains. Promises a ride as smooth as silk. Is there anything I can get you before we get underway?"

Jules and Sid exchanged a considering glance, then looked back at the driver, and shook their heads. "We're all set," the black wolf said.

"Then off to Little Silverhorne we go!" Arthur proclaimed happily, shutting the door.

The paladins listened as he climbed onto his own seat, settled in, and urged the horses into action. With a slight jerk (to be expected), they were underway. Now, they needed only to wait.

"If you want to take off your armour, and lie down for the night, I'll keep the vigil," Sid offered. "I mean, despite what I said earlier, I think we'll be safe, until we get there. And we'll both need our rest."

Jules mulled this over, but it didn't take long. "Fair enough. Jules shall return the courtesy in the morning."

"We'll be halfway there by then," Sid reminded him. "Probably resting up the horses at some wide spot in the road. They'll probably have an inn; lucky us. You get to hang about in the tavern, and I get a bed."

He leaned over to help the tiger out of his cuirass as he said "Lucky you, Jules thinks you mean. Mayhaps if he were one for drunken debauchery..."

Sid looked and gestured toward the window, to spare himself the embarrassment of Jules' reaction to his reaction to the tiger's current state of dress. "Are you kidding? You're not the one who gets to watch the landscape fly by until morning. You'll have something to see. So I do mean 'lucky you'."

"Now Jules sees what you mean," the tiger said, with a note of apology, as he placed his gauntlets, boots and leggings in the compartments overhead. "You can put his cuirass and helmet on the floor."

"Huh? Oh, yeah," Sid nodded after a moment, caught up in examining the emblem of the radiating sun on the big, reflective piece of armour. He lowered both gingerly to the floor.

The tiger kicked up his feet, and laid down on the cushioned bench, folding his hands on his chest. His soft leather tunic and pants were far more comfortable sleepwear than his protective panoply. He had been planning to nod off sitting up, but Sid could watch his back. He was beginning to enjoy having the wolf along. "Good night, Sid."

"Sweet dreams, Jules," Sid smiled. He liked the way that sounded...

The tiger was out in no time, recharging from his long day of walks in the woods, questioning gone wrong, and god-conferencing. Naturally, or as a result of conditioning, he remained quite still, and breathed quietly, chest rising and falling steadily.

And what a chest it was! Sid took quick notice. Clearly muscled, each pectoral was defined, looking like you could bounce copper coins off of it! What a shame, then, that his abs were yet covered. The wolf was sure they were just as shapely and fit as the tiger's chest and arms (and surely his thighs and rear).

He had never quite achieved such a level of in-shape himself, owing to his inclination for infrequent indulgence, and inability to truly dedicate himself to something requiring that much hard work. Fighting evil was his great passion - never let anyone doubt that - but unlike many paladins, even of his order, he had... other interests he wanted to pursue.

Smiling wistfully, Sid turned his gaze out the window, onto the passing, moonlit landscape.
1553322222222222111111111.title: Farewell, Wellingham (Cont.)

choices: Continue...
15533222222222221111111111.content:
As promised, the carriage ride was, at least that night, "as smooth as silk". Jules slept for a solid eight hours on the cushioned bench, more comfortable than his typically-spartan living arrangements at the Temples. He awoke all at once, but laid still to determine the source of the murmuring noises. He had to strain his ears to catch them, and even then, could make only so much sense of them.

"...bedchamber activities... domain. Still, what... down? I... broken heart, and... over it? ...wait, or... ready? ...Sigh..."

Jules gave up trying to make sense of what (he thought?) he was hearing, and sat up, yawning and stretching. There was more room to do so than he expected, but not quite as much as would have been ideal.

Thump! "Drat!"

The tiger looked sharply to his left, but it was only Sid, rubbing the back of head tenderly. "Ow- Er, good morning, Jules. Sort of."

The black wolf pushed aside the curtain over the window in the carriage's door, revealing, through the open window, the horizon; it was still the colour of the wolf paladin's jerkin, and yet dotted with stars. "By my estimation, it's about two hours before dawn."

"Good morning, Sid," the tiger said, so as not to be rude. "Did you also hear something just a minute ago? It sounded like someone talking..."

Sid gulped, and shook his head rapidly. "Huh? No, nono. Didn't hear a thing. May have been Arthur, talking to his horses." He winced as pain blossomed anew on the back of his head.

"What happened to you?" Jules asked, concerned. He scooted over towards the wolf, and leaned forward. "Let Jules see."

"It's nothing, really," Sid protested, bowing his head anyway. "Just a bump."

"So it is." The injury was no more than a minor wheal that didn't even protrude from his fur. It would be sensitive for a short time, but no real threat to his performance. "Still, Jules can prepare a small poultice..."

"That's quite alright, but I appreciate the offer," Sid smiled sheepishly. "I'll just be more careful in the future."

"Good boy," the tiger teased, petting the wolf roughly, but playfully, between the ears.

Sid laughed, and pulled away, face red beneath his fur. "Yeah, yeah, har-har. You want some breakfast?"

Before Jules could respond there came two brief knocks on the roof. "Heads up, Sirs!" Arthur's muffled voice called.

Sid stuck his head out the window to answer, and it came to Jules how he'd incurred his bump on the head in the first place. "Yes, Arthur? Trouble?"

Arthur turned slightly to look down at him, but spoke loudly enough for them both to hear. "No, Sirs! We're nearly to Half Measure Hamlet! We'll rest there!"

"Thank you!" Sid called back before pulling his head inside. "Well, how about that. Early, even."

"Jules sees that Arthur was right to say his horses were fast," the tiger nodded, impressed. "He was not expecting to arrive until well after first light."

"Same here. Guess we got lucky..."

Sid seemed almost... disappointed, the tiger saw with a small frown. "Worried your bed in town will not be as comfortable as your seat here?"

"Hm? No, that's pretty much a given, I know," Sid chuckled. "Why do you ask? Do I look too comfortable, or something?"

"No; you look disappointed," Jules stated. "Jules reminds you that, barring unfortunate circumstances, you will get another ride in this carriage."

"I'm not! I'm not worried, or sad, or anything like that!" Sid protested. "Now, just- Come on. You want my help suiting up?"

Watching the hunky tiger encase himself in steel, instead of only soft leather, was going to be disappointing, too. Whether more or less than losing three hours' worth of chances to sneak glances at him, he wasn't sure. Maybe it was an extension of the same disappointment.

"Jules will gratefully accept your help," the tiger acquiesced, after a moment of thought. In a confined space, it would be easiest.

First, he fetched his boots and leggings from the overhead storage compartments. These, even under these conditions, he could get on by himself. Sid salvaged some happiness watching the tiger wriggle around as he clamped on and tightened the bottom half of his armour.

Next was his cuirass, itself as heavy the rest of the set combined. Sid stood behind the tiger, and helped him fit his cuirass one right, and strap it up tight, sighing quietly. Such broad shoulders he had, and what a fine tail...!

Jules put on his sword belt, with pouches for money, papers, simple field medicine supplies, and a dagger, as well as a place to tie his helmet on with a simple knot, ready to grab and wear at the first sign of battle. Sid noted it was an arrangement mirroring his own.

Finally, he pulled on his gauntlets, flexing and clenching before securing them to make sure they'd properly function. They were heavy, but he'd always liked the way they felt on his hands, and while wrapped around the hilt of his sword.

The carriage jerked at just the wrong (or right) moment, making the off-balance tiger teeter backwards. Fortunately, Sid was right there to steady him, wrapping his arms around his chest and waist, and easing him back onto his feet. "Whoa, easy there, big cat. Don't want to find out if you'd fall through the floor."

He held him a moment longer than was quite necessary, and Jules noticed. "Jules thanks you, but you can let go of him now, Sid."

"Er, heheh, sorry," the wolf recoiled, looking down sheepishly. "Just, you know, making sure you're safe."

The tiger gave him a strange look as he sat back down, but said nothing more of it. "Have you communicated with Nocturpus since we left?"

Sid sat down a little harder than he'd meant to, and bounced. "Er, uh, no; not a word. Why?"

A vague memory of some recent dream stirred sluggishly in Jules' head, but slipped away before he could grab it. "Jules was only wondering if there had been developments to keep us abreast of, but now, he would guess not."

"Oh, nope, nothing like that," Sid shook his head, relieved. "Everything is just peachy."

There was a slight sway as the carriage decelerated, and then stopped. They heard Arthur clamber down from his seat, and then knock at the door. "We've arrived, Sirs!"

Jules leaned over, and opened the door. Arthur stepped aside, and held it open for the paladins as they stepped out. "The hamlet of, well, Half Measure Hamlet. Room and board, a tavern, a blacksmith, and a stable. And a jail; mostly for highwaymen caught closer to here than Little Silverhorne or Wellingham."

"Thank you, Arthur," Sid said warmly, and Jules echoed the sentiment. "When would be a good time to set out?"

"Just after lunch, I think," the man said. "That'll give us all a good chance to rest up, freshen up, and feed up."

"We'll see you then," Jules agreed with a nod.

Half Measure Hamlet's inn went by "Halfway Hostel"; if it was supposed to be a play on words, Sid wasn't entirely sure he liked it. Jules marched in without pause, though, so he had to follow.

At this hour, all was deathly still and quiet. On their left was a row of three rooms; all the doors were shut. To their right, a candle was gradually melting into a puddle on the counter; no one stood behind it. Straight ahead, the drinking and dining area sat empty, a single lit candle on the only table fully in view. There wasn't enough room to swing a sword where they stood; Sid readied himself to grab his dagger.

Jules stepped up to the counter, and peered over. The proprietor was asleep on a bedroll, drooling slightly on her pillow. This, and the steady rise and fall of her chest, indicated she was alive. The paladin made it a point to gesture to her for Sid's benefit.

Easing up a little, Sid moved to the counter, himself, and tapped on it with one steel-plated finger. Hopefully, the sound wouldn't wake any other residents of the inn.

The woman, slight, dark-haired, and human, rose with enviable alacrity, taking in the two of them, and asking "Welcome to Halfway Hostel. One bed, or two?"

Jules smiled gently, and replied "One, please."

"And I don't suppose it's too early for a spot of breakfast?" Sid asked hopefully, while she was dazed by the tiger's teeth.

"Of course, Sirs," the woman nodded, more awake now. "You can have the first room, and I'll get you menus right away."

She pushed the big iron key across the counter to Jules, then strode swiftly towards the dining area, perhaps to locate and awaken the cook.
15533222222222221111111111.title: Halfway Hostel

choices: "So close to Little Silverhorne, they HAVE to be!"
"It's to show our appreciation for you paladins!"
155332222222222211111111111.content:
Jules, meanwhile, used the key on the lock on the room door nearest the door to the greater outside world. It clunked and clattered, but released, and the door creaked inwards. Sid waited while he stepped inside, and used the provided flint and steel to light the candle in the sconce on the wall. In the small space, it provided all the light necessary. Jules backed out to let Sid in.

Sid thanked him, and entered his room for the night. A simple armoire stood along the wall to his left, the bed with a straw mattress was pushed against the furthest and right-hand walls, and in the corner on his right squatted a wooden chair. A trunk at the foot of the bed sat ready to accept anything child-sized or smaller he might want to place inside it. There was, at least, enough room to turn around when standing between the furnishings.

"Reminds me of the sleeping quarters at the Temple," he muttered to Jules, watching him get accommodated (or perhaps that he did not fall through the floor). "Want to help me out of this cuirass?"

Jules squeezed through the doorway, and undid one half of the wolf's bindings, while he took care of the others. Largely, the insignia or jerkins they wore were the only markers to differentiate them on sight.

"Thank you," Sid said gratefully, hanging the armour on the pegs inside the armoire. "I wasn't about to try sitting on the chairs here in full regalia."

Jules cast a glance at the chair in the corner, then admitted "Probably a good idea."

"I kind of want to take my leggings off, too," Sid said lowly, removing his gauntlets as spoke, "but I don't want to be too far from my blades. Something about this place... I don't know..."

"Jules does not feel completely at ease, himself, which is why he plans to patrol after he has eaten," the tiger shared. "He wonders if it is not knowledge of our quest instilling in us this sense of foreboding."

Sid worked his boots off, one at a time, and wriggled his toes in relief. "Hmm. Could be. Either way, I'm glad it's not just me."

He stood up, tested his weight, and then stretched his arms over his head, yawning. His soft leather tunic pulled up over his stomach an inch or two as he did. This naturally caught Jules' eye, and he was perversely pleased to see the wolf wasn't quite as defined as himself. His arms left no question as to his strength, though.

Sid followed the tiger into the inn's dining area, where a table had been cleaned and set with menus for them, as well as another candle lit. Jules took the stronger-looking of the two chairs, and both held under their weights.

"Eggs, eh? I am impressed," Sid muttered while scanning the breakfast menu, not entirely kidding.

Also on offer were such things as ham steaks, bread and toast, oatmeal, fruit tarts, and flapjacks. To drink, there was milk, water, ale, and fruit juices.

"Although, I suppose they get a lot of traders through here," the wolf realized. "Flapjacks sound good to me. What tickles your fancy, Sir DeNoon?"

"The fruit pastries do, Sir Coltrane," the other paladin responded in kind, aware others may well be listening.

"Splendid," Sid commented mildly, seeing he was understood.

As if to prove their point, their hostess emerged from a swinging door in the rear of the area, and came up to their table. "Do you know what you'd like to order, Sirs?"

"Sir DeNoon will have the fruit pastry plate, and a glass of milk, please, fair maiden," the tiger began, placing a hand on his chest to clarify whom he spoke of.

"Small plate, or large plate?" She asked politely.

"Small plate, please," Jules finished, offering his menu.

The woman took it, then turned to Sid. "And for you, Sir?"

"I'll try your flapjacks, please," he replied. "Large plate. And a tall glass of fruit juice to drink."

"What kind of fruit juice, Sir?" their hostess asked.

"Surprise me," Sid smiled a little, chuckling. He held his menu out to her, too.

"We'll have those out to you as soon as they're ready, Sirs," she assured them, taking the wolf's menu. "Thank you for your patronage."

"Thank you for being so accommodating at this hour, fair maiden," Jules returned with a smile.

"It's our pleasures, Sirs," the woman assured them, before heading back to the kitchen.

"How come you never smile at me like that?" Sid pretended to pout, though he had felt a sting of jealousy.

Jules looked at him now, but in confusion. "You mean, like this?" he asked, and then beamed his most charming smile.

Dazzled, Sid could feel himself blushing crimson to the tips of his ears, and it was all he could do to nod.

Jules stopped (a shame; yet a relief), and frowned thoughtfully. "Sir DeNoon had not thought about this before... He guesses it was because he did not feel the need to be charming to you. But Jules will make an effort to do so, realizing you are in it with him, too."

Sid tried very hard not to squeal with delight, and managed to squeak out "Fair enough."

The tiger seemed to be sizing him up, but on the verge of saying something, he stopped, looking away with a small smile hovering about his lips.

Sid's heart jumped, but he tried not to show how nervous this made him; how it sent his mind racing. What did it mean? What had he done? What hadn't he done? How was he supposed to react? To what purpose was the tiger doing this to him? Was he going to be able to stop his guts spilling out through his mouth? He clamped his muzzle shut with his hands, and stared resolutely at the table.

Jules had before encountered a very few cases of what he'd been told was his "animal magnetism" affecting other males, but only in passing. It was funny to see such a case up close, and further amusing to have an extended opportunity to observe just how the wolf might react.

Starting with teasing him about what he might or might not be thinking. And if he hadn't had his boots on, he might've "accidentally" nudged his feet under the table, just to watch him squirm. As it was, though, he was only likely to injure him more. He rested his chin in his hand, and stared at the black wolf as if he were the most fascinating thing he had seen in quite some time.

Sid couldn't help but shift his gaze upwards, of course, but when he found Jules gazing at him like a schoolboy, he averted it to the table again, cheeks reddening. Maybe he had been a little hasty in wishing for him to loosen up around him? Although, he is just trying to have fun with me, in his own way, and now I'm the one who's being uptight. If I relax... It can only lead to good things, right?

Releasing the hold he had on his muzzle, he met Jules' gaze, and though he felt heat flood his face anew, he opened his mouth to say something. He wasn't sure what; only that it would be clever.

He didn't quite get the chance, though, for their hostess chose that moment to bear down on them with breakfast. Well, Jules' breakfast, at least. She set the plate and his glass in front of him, announced "We'll have those flapjacks out for you in a moment, Sir", and just as quickly returned to the kitchen.

Eyeing the plate, Sid whistled lowly. "Alright. Now I'm impressed."

"And more apprehensive..." Jules muttered.

The so-called "small" plate had a dozen thick, oozing strudels arranged on it, each stuffed with fruit, and as big as the tiger's palm. This was an absurd amount of food for a single person, never mind if they were six-foot-four, and active-duty paladins wearing fifty pounds of steel plate armour all day. There was plenty to drink, though, for the cup looked like it held enough milk to fill a mixing bowl.

"Jules cannot hope to eat all these in one sitting," he said, surprised. "Four would make him nauseous. And you ordered a large plate!"

Sid's ears and tail drooped. "Oh dear. I did, didn't I?"

Ominously enough, the door seemed to bang open with the sound of thunder. Sid saw the tiger's eyes widen as he beheld whatever was approaching, but didn't dare turn to see for himself. Frozen in place, he offered a quick, silent prayer and apology for every stupid thing he'd done, including this one, to Nocturpus.

The plate - no, the platter - their hostess set in front of him was loaded with a half-dozen stacks of a half-dozen flapjacks, each the size of a dinner plate, each stack topped off by a mound of whipped cream. To help ease all this down his throat, pitchers of maple syrup stood ready. If he got thirsty, there were three pitchers of fruit juices to wash it all down; enough to overflow a milk bucket.

I'm going to be here until lunch! he silently despaired.

"Excuse, fair maiden," Jules interjected as politely as he could. "Sir DeNoon is curious as to how you, ah, decided on your serving sizes."

After taking a moment to decode this into Common, the woman said...

1553322222222222111111111111.content:
Waiting for their breakfast at Half Measure Hamlet's inn, "Halfway Hostel", Jules' and Sid's fears that something was off were realized when a "small" fruit pastry plate contained no less than a dozen huge strudels! Now, faced with the wolf's impossible flapjack feast, they ask their all-too-obliging hostess "What's going on?"

"Why, Sirs," the dark-haired human woman began, "so close to Little Silverhorne, they have to be! I'm sorry! I thought you knew."

Jules and Sid exchanged an uneasy glance, but this didn't stop the black wolf from beginning to nibble at his one of his flapjacks.

"Why is that, innkeeper? Do you know?" Jules pressed.

"I haven't been to the city, myself," she replied, looking vaguely ill-at-ease. "We're just close enough to be bound by its laws. I-if you don't like that, I can get you something else..."

"I like it..." Sid murmured defensively, chewing on a piece of flapjack.

"No no, this will do fine; thank you," Jules assuaged her.

"If there's anything more I can do, Sirs, just call," the woman bowed slightly, then headed back towards the kitchen.

Once she was gone, Jules stood up from the table, and said quietly "Sir DeNoon will be looking into something outside. Do not worry if he does not return right away."

Sid nodded (his mouth, at the moment, full), acknowledging this.

The tiger controlled his footfalls, and stepped out as quietly as possible.

With no one around he might have to make conversation with, Sid let loose on the flapjacks, pulling a stack towards him, and drowning it in syrup. They were indubitably delicious, each one moist, flavorful, chewy, without being mushy, and otherwise perfectly cooked. There were still far too many on his platter, but he thought he was going to put quite a dent in them.

Since Jules was outside, the wolf snagged a strudel from his plate, and bit deep into it. The warm fruit filling gushed out, galvanizing his taste buds with yet more delicious flavors. The crust was flaky and soft, yet not so much that it fell apart, complementing the rich flavor of apple, in this particular pastry. The tiger didn't know what he was missing!

The black wolf downed a dinner plate-sized flapjack soaked in syrup, then pulled close a jug of his fruit juice to wet his whistle. As no smaller cups were provided, he guessed it was alright to drink from the jug, and did so, taking a long draught. The liquid was crisp and cool (which surprised him, although he didn't know why, everything else considered), cutting through the sticky flapjacks with the spirited taste of... strawberry - and raspberry.

"By the Crescent, this is great!" Sid sighed happily, between mouthfuls. "I wonder if the food in the city is even this great?"

He grinned, and tucked back in, while meanwhile, outside...

"Thank you, Arthur," Jules said again, "and sorry to have roused you."

"Don't worry about it, Sir," the cabman said dismissively. "I hadn't even laid down yet. Just making a visual inspection."

"Regardless, it was kind of you to answer," the tiger said. "Sir DeNoon will stay out of your way, now. Goodnight."

"Goodnight, Sir," Arthur nodded, closing the carriage door.

Jules switched their sack of provisions to his left hand, keeping his sword arm free. He had felt a gut need to get out of the inn, and was already regretting not dragging Sir Coltrane out with him.

But the wolf, too, was a holy warrior, he reminded himself, and would be just fine on his own, for this short time.

Feeling restless, the tiger paladin decided to begin his patrol early. They were in the countryside, some twelve hours away from major cities, and the night was quiet; he'd be able to hear trouble coming. Still, crime was not known to sleep; nor most gods. He borrowed a torch from outside the blacksmith's forge, lit it from one mounted outside the village's gates, and set off on the path to Little Silverhorne.

If trouble was coming, he thought, it would come from that direction. But where there was light, there was might - the might of Sol-Ra the Illuminated!

***

Sid made a valiant effort, complete with a second wind, but in the end, the flapjack feast had proved too much for him to handle.

Not bad, though... he thought with a smile, surveying the extent of his destruction. Fully three of the six stacks of flapjacks had been decimated, nothing more than sticky plates with a few crumbs left behind. One jug of fruit juice was drained of its last drop, and a second was lacking a quarter of its fluids. The only syrup remaining in one pitcher was stuck on its sides, too inert to follow gravity's pull. And there were only nine fruit tarts remaining of the dozen that had originally festooned the tiger's plate. Not bad at all.

Sid grunted as he heaved himself up, belly so full, it was swollen, rounding out an inch in front of him like a curious distortion in the fabric of the night sky. It felt very good, though, warm and pleasantly sensitive to the touch. It poked out against his soft leather tunic, and just about over his steel leggings.

Ooh... It's definitely time for bed...

15533222222222221111111111111.content:
His hostess came out of the kitchen just then, murmuring a surprised "Oh!" at seeing the wolf up on his feet, and asking "Is there anything else I can get you, Sir? Are you done?"

The black wolf considered this for a moment, then turned to her with a grin. "Right now, I've got to be, but can I take this to my room, so I can finish it at lunch?"

"Of course, Sir!" The dark-haired human woman beamed, nodding. "I trust you found it enjoyable, then, Sir?"

"Best flapjacks I've ever had in my entire life," Sid swore, hand on his heart. "And you can trust me on that; I'm a paladin."

"Thank you, Sir! I'm very pleased to hear it, and I know the chef will be, too!" The woman said happily, cheeks blushing red. "Enjoy your sleep, Sir, and if there's anything we can get you..."

Sid traded the dirty plates for Jules' barely-touched plate of fruit pastries, nodding "I won't hesitate to ask. Yes. Thank you."

Wondering what kind of behemoth strength the woman was hiding, if she'd carried the tray when it was twice as heavy, he lumbered into the room the paladins had rented, now the furthest one away, and on the right. If the door to the outside world happened to slam open when he was sidling through the one to his room, then there would be a mess... but it stayed shut.

Sid set the tray down on the table, which creaked worryingly, and then turned it so that he wouldn't bump it off, brushing by. Next, he closed and locked the door, remembering Jules had the key to let himself in. He unfastened his sword belt - which afforded him some relief - and leaned the weapon up against the wall, next to his bed. At long last, he removed his steel plate leggings, sighing again at the release of pressure on his abdomen this allowed him.

Enough, he thought, to fit in a last fruit tart before turning in. He blew out the candle in the sconce on the wall as he leaned in to take one, then straightened back up. Naturally, being a Paladin of Nocturpus, his vision in the dark was as clear as day. He lay down carefully in the bed, relishing the gooey, warm fruit flavors exploding in his mouth.

Ooh, but his bloated belly felt so good...! If only his tiger were there to rub it.

MY tiger? Now there's a thought... Sid smiled, closing his eyes. MY tiger. My hunky, brave, silver-tongued, dreamy tiger...

The thought, and his smile, followed him down into sleep...

155332222222222211111111111111.content:
With the noontime sun overhead, Jules made his triumphant return to Half Measure Hamlet. Triumphant, at least, in that Truth and Light and Justice had come through, and on his patrol of the roads west of the small village, he'd detected no criminals to keep at bay. A day without crime was always a day of triumph!

Reentering the Halfway Hostel was eerily like stepping in for the first time had been, though with better lighting. It was silent, and there was no one in sight - except when one stepped up to the counter, he saw, and looked over. There was the owner again, sleeping on her bedroll. He decided to try and not disturb her, and turned to wake Sid up.

Fitting the big iron key into the door's lock, he turned, and with a few clunks, the door swung slightly open. Jules pushed his way through, and closed it behind him.

Sid was sprawled inelegantly across his bed, mouth agape, tongue lolling. One leg lay straight, and the other bent at the knee. His one arm thrown was above his head, and the other rested on the upper part of his abdomen, unknowingly pulling his shirt up some. A broad swatch of his black, furry (firm, cut) stomach (belly) was exposed, and though it was inarguably silly, Jules caught himself thinking of the rumors that said if one rubbed a canine's stomach just right, his legs would kick by themselves.

Such a thing was certainly very silly... Yet he felt an odd yearning to try it out. He was worried about the wolf's reaction; but then, he was a bit of a silly sort, himself. He would more than likely appreciate the joke. Jules removed his gauntlets.

Sidling into the space between the bed and armoire, he crouched down carefully, steel buns impacting the wooden cabinet behind him. He held his hands over Sid's stomach, looking for a good place to start, flexed his fingers, and then began. He picked a spot, and ran his big, cupped hand up and down the black wolf's body.

"Aroo?" Sid made an inquisitive sort of noise deep in his throat, and sighed, stretching out. His subconscious mind had registered a feeling, and it was good.

Jules smiled, and tried up near his ribs, wondering if it would only tickle him.

Sid (or his body, anyway) bent one leg, knee sticking up in the air...

Jules shifted his area of effect just slightly...

Success! Sid's right leg bent itself into the air, and began to kick quickly and rhythmically, as if he were stomping spiders, or pedaling some machine. At the same time, he let out a low, quiet sort of howl, smiling dopily. His dreams were getting better by the second!

Jules tried not to laugh (out loud) at the sight, grinning wide enough for it to hurt, merely memorizing the location of this mythical "spot" (just in case). Still curious, he used his other hand to rub a different spot, to see if this would affect the wolf any.

There is no earthly way of knowing how the future might have been different if that second spot he'd chosen was not a broad stroke of the middle of Sid's belly...

As it happened, Sid reacted to this almost instantaneously, with deep, pleasured moans, an arching back, and a whispered litany of "Oh yes, oh yes, oh yes, oh yesss, oh- Oh, Jules...!"

Jules did laugh, now, delighted, and said "Yes, Jules! You can be very silly, Sid, but this is why Jules likes you." He stopped rubbing him.

Sid came around momentarily, blinking, sitting up, and then uttering a short scream as he realized Jules was right there, apparently watching him. "Agh! Jules!" he snatched at bedclothes that weren't there, trying to cover himself up before he caught on that he was dressed.

The tiger flashed him a happy smile, and asked "Have good dreams, Jules hopes, Sid?"

The wolf blushed crimson beneath his dark fur, but decided it was safe to nod, if he didn't have to elaborate.

"It is lunchtime," Jules clarified for him as he stood up, "though Jules sees you've got something there, already. Was it that good, Sid?"

Sid's hand unconsciously strayed to his (again flat) stomach as he nodded. "You have no idea."

"Well then, do you want your second breakfast in bed?" Jules teased, "Or shall we take it out there?"

Despite what the thought of the tiger offering him breakfast in bed was threatening to do to him, Sid grinned, and agreed. "Yeah, alright. I will take it in here."

Shaking his head, not unamused, Jules said "Then decide how you want to sit, and I'll bring the platter to you."

He propped himself up against the headboard, legs extended straight out in front of him. "Just put it on my lap."

Jules obliged, lowering the loaded platter carefully onto his thighs. "Are those Jules' fruit strudels he spies?"

"Uh, heh, I was just holding onto them for you," Sid said sheepishly. He picked up the plate, and offered it up to him. "Uh, here you go! Lunch!"

"Jules was teasing you; he already ate," the tiger smiled. "You may have the rest of them, too."

"Thanks, but I doubt I'll be able to finish them all," Sid frowned slightly. "I'd feel worse if I didn't try, though." With that said, he dug in, starting with the flapjacks.

Jules didn't trust the chair in the corner to hold his weight, fully-armoured or not, so he sat down between the bed and armoire again, parallel to Sid. "You are quite determined; this is good. We will need strength of spirit to succeed in our quest."

The wolf decided not to mention how sorely tempted he was to call the whole thing off, and run away with the tiger; find someplace they'd never heard of the Lipomancer, and live together in peace. Problem with that was he didn't think the tiger - or their respective gods - would go for it. He tried not too sigh too loudly.

"You look bored," he commented of the tiger. "Why don't you pass the time with a story? I get the feeling you like to talk about yourself."

Jules shot him a glare that bounced right off his thick skull and wide grin. "Fine. Jules will tell you of the origins of an illustrious paladin."

"And here, I thought it was going to be non-fiction," Sid ribbed.

"You shush," Jules scolded mildly. "Now, his story begins at the beginning..."

"There's a novel idea."

"Shush!"

1553322222222222111111111111111.content:
Jules cleared his throat, and began his tale. "Once, on the Luxumentum Riviera, there lived a healthy and happy family of... leopards."

"Were they orange? With stripes? And actually tigers?" Sid interrupted, grinning ingratiatingly.

Shaking a finger under the black wolf's nose, Jules warned him "Jules is going to make you wear your breakfast!"

Sid only stuffed another bite of syrup-soaked flapjack into his maw, and chewed quietly.

Glaring steadily at the wolf, Jules resumed his story. "Ahem. This family of leopards were not the most prosperous, but they were good people, and lived a comfortable life. There was a mother leopard, a father leopard, and one each leopard son and daughter."

He paused, silently daring the wolf to say something.

Though Sid was bursting to, he behaved himself, fearing the tiger might follow through with his threat.

Satisfied, Jules relaxed, and continued. "Though the children differed in age by a gap of seven years, the older girl loved and cared for her brother as if he were her twin. From the day he was born, she doted on him; tickling his toes, spoon-feeding him meals, playing with him, and tucking him in at night with stories. He was like a child of her own. It would not be inaccurate to say he loved her more than his mother.

One day, at fourteen years of age, the girl announced her intention to become a cleric. This was certainly unexpected. She had never before expressed a strong devotion to any particular god, and she had seemed to be a natural fit for the role of mother. Nevertheless, her family loved her, and they were proud of her decision. They gave her what money they could spare, and saw her off to follow her dream. On the day she left, her brother swore he, too, would dedicate his life to being a holy warrior.

Though she was gone, her family received a letter from her every week. In them, she told them she was doing well, having fun, learning much, and making lots of new friends. She was happy with her decision, she said, though curiously, never what decision this exactly had been. And she always said to tell her brother she loved him. The boy treasured these letters always, keeping them in a special box beneath his bed.

For a year, these letters were their only connection with their daughter. Spring turned to summer, summer to fall, autumn to winter, and then spring came again. The leopard boy missed his sister terribly, but knew she would want him to grow up big and strong. He ate his vegetables, roughhoused with the other village boys, lifted heavy rocks, fished in the river for dinner, and greeted the rising sun every day with a wooden sword and shield he swung at imaginary shadow-foes. His parents saw in him a bright future.

Then, one Spring day, they received their shortest letter yet; just two words: 'Coming home!'. Of course, they were overjoyed at the prospect of seeing how worldly and womanly their daughter had become in her absence. Her mother gathered all the necessary things to bake her a cake when she returned. Her father bought his buddies a round of drinks at the tavern, and they toasted her triumphant return. The boy promised his own friends that his sister was coming to kick their butts with her 'awesome cleric powers', so they had better just watch themselves.

It was just a week before she arrived, in the dead of night. She tied her black horse - her very own! - outside their home, and knocked. When her father came to the door, the candle in his hand did nothing to cut the shadows in this mysterious stranger's hooded cloak. But when a pair of st- spotted hands pushed the hood back, a familiar face was seen - his beloved daughter! His loud, joyful greeting and laughter woke the other members of the house, who came rushing out to see the situation, the boy armed with his little wooden sword and shield. But they laughed, too, when they saw her, and there was much hugging all around.

The boy of course proclaimed how much he had missed his beloved sister, and how he was going to grow up to be just like her. She smiled, and laughed, and said she had missed him, too. And she had missed his birthday - but she still had a present for him. He was, of course, excited to see it; surely, it was some mysterious and foreign object that would make him the envy of all the other village boys. But she poked his nose, as she had always done, and told him he would have to wait; she had something to discuss with their parents.

The three of them - the mother, the father, and the daughter - went, laughing and smiling, into the leopard parents' room. This was the last memory the boy would have of his parents...

Knowing nothing of this now, the boy warmed himself in the light of the stove. His mother had lit it in preparation for a cake she would never get a chance to bake. He never got too close, knowing well how fire could burn. It was perhaps ten minutes before he heard a door open, and then the padding of paws that he had come to know as his sister's. He turned to greet her with a great, big smile, and that, perhaps, saved his life that day.

The leopard woman, for that she had become after leaving home, had her hands outstretched towards him, and her hood back up. The light from the stove behind the boy dispelled the shadows on her face, and he saw, just for an instant that his sister's eyes were colored red - not a feature he remembered, and he had seen her face every day for seven years. Perhaps she sensed this, though, for she stepped back from the light, and the boy came to dismiss it as a trick of the fire.

Opening her arms wider, she beckoned him towards her for a hug, and once he was in her arms, she told him 'Your birthday present is that you get to visit the city with me! Won't that be exciting?'

His eyes widened, and he gasped. Leaving the village? Traveling across the countryside? Going on an adventure his friends would only be able to envy? He was sold in a heartbeat! 'But what,' he asked, 'of Mother and Father?' Had they objections to this plan?

'Don't worry about Mother and Father,' his sister told him. 'They are not going to disagree one bit.' She held up his bag, packed full of his clothes. They would leave right now, she said, and be to the city in a week. 'Say goodbye,' she said, 'to Mother and Father. They are dead tired right now, but Sister will hug you enough for both of them.'

'Goodbye!' the boy yelled, all too trusting. 'Goodbye, Mother and Father!' And, of course, that he loved them; he would bring them back big-city presents. And he followed his sister outside, to her horse. This would be the last he saw of his house.

His sister helped him onto the horse, then sat behind him on the saddle. She spurred the dark steed on, and they raced out of town. The night swallowed them up.

15533222222222221111111111111111.content:
It is not easy, riding such a distance, but the boy, although raw and untrained in the art of horsemanship, and unfamiliar with sleeping anywhere but a bed, enjoyed it all immensely. It was all an adventure, see. With his beloved sister, no less. The greatest time of his young life yet. He would never forget it. Not even the village they had rode so quickly through, all he could remember was its scent - death, decay, unlife.

It appeared and grew on the horizon, one sunny day, but they stopped just short of the city at sundown, and made camp. The boy was disappointed, of course, but his sister assured him they would go in the very next morning. He should try to get some rest, she said, because it was going to be a big day for him. He didn't think he could sleep a wink, but after supper, he was out like a light.

As promised, the next morning, mounted on their horse, they trotted through the big gates, and Sister announced 'Welcome to Vermeil L'on!' The city was, and still is, enormous; there were many shops and services up and down the street. Temples and taverns dotted the city. A huge castle towered over it all, keeping watch. And people! People everywhere! More people than the boy had ever seen in his life! Furries in shapes he had never imagined! And humans, living alongside them! He was smiling fit to burst.

Leaving their horse at a stable, they walked around the city on foot, taking in the sights and sounds and smell of it all. And the tastes! It seemed they were eating all day, always stopping at this restaurant, or that stand, to sample something new and exotic. It was all very good, and it was a wonder to the boy how people created it all. He would never forget anything about this day, either. Including what happened that night.

After supper, with the gates closing on the sunset, they retrieved their horse, and Sister led them all deep into the city. 'Now you will get to see,' she promised, 'the secret temple where your sister lives.' They left the horse in a nearby stable, home to other black horses, and entered a big, old house.

Inside, they went not up, but down, into the basement; through a tunnel, and to a red door. The leopard sister knocked, spoke some cryptic phrase, and it opened. Ignoring the smell, of blood and decay, the boy followed her through.

The sanctuary was far bigger than the house above, four stone pillars hung with red tapestries supporting the main room, double wooden doors to either side, a corridor straight ahead that turned sharply away, and more red rugs underfoot. Torches on the walls and pillars kept it well-lit, though it was slightly damp and cool.

He could stay in her bedchamber, for now, his sister told him, leading him off to the right, while she talked to her Master. And she would have a ceremony that night, she explained, so if he fell asleep without her, he shouldn't worry.

The double doors opened onto a short corridor that quickly turned to the right, and then opened on the left into a bigger room. The right half of this room was semicircular, with beds arranged in just such a pattern along the wall; wooden chests squatted at their feet. The left half of the room was square, with wine racks and dining tables, chairs arranged around them. The rugs, more wall hangings, and even the beddings were red.

The leopard boy's big sister escorted him right to her personal bed, sat him down on it, and said the last things he'd ever hear her say. 'You can sit or lay down right here. I'll be back, but don't leave this room. And remember: Sister loves you.' Then she kissed him on the forehead, and she was gone.

Filled with food, and fresh memories of fun and excitement, the boy dozed off into a peaceful slumber.

So it seemed like hardly any time at all before he heard a distant door crash open, and the steely thunder of armored men stomping around. When he began to hear yells and screams, he rushed down the short hall, and nearly into the double door. Thinking better of it, he settled for peering through a crack in the wood.

From what he could see, the double doors across from him had been torn off their hinges, and there was a scuffle inside. Light glinted off of steel swords as they cut through the air. Cloaked figures, unarmed, raised their hands, in defense or pleas, against the marauding men, but were swiftly cut down. More than one bellow of 'For Medremelth!' could be overheard. Cries of frustration and hatred rent the air.

Then, hardly a minute after it had begun, it was over. The armored men clanked back into the sanctuary's 'hub', and stopped. Someone - mayhaps their leader - suggested 'We had best check the bedchambers; though I don't feel anything coming from that direction, Medremelth wanted a clean sweep.'

At this, the boy scrambled away, as fast as he could. Gods only knew what they would do to him if they caught him! Desperate, he spotted a chest that wasn't latched shut, and dove inside. It was tight, but empty; apparently because it wouldn't close, leaving only a sliver of light streaming in.

He hardly dared breathe as the sound of steel-booted footsteps pervaded the room. For what seemed like an eternity, he crouched, prone and motionless, in that box. Terrified. Wanting to scream; to jump up, run; to burst into confused tears; to kill; to die.

But, finally, a voice called 'All clear!', and the armored men, whomever they were, left the room. In a kind of terrified stupor, the little ti- the leopard boy, so young, passed out.

For how long, he did not know, but when he came to, all was silent; deathly so. The boy climbed out of the chest, joints aching from being curled up so long. But he hardly noticed; he ran, out of the bedchambers, through the common area, and past the shattered wooden doors. The sight that awaited him was horrific.

Blood. Everywhere, there was blood. The floor. The walls. The room's pillars. A book, a blood-soaked book, lay nearby. But this wasn't what made him scream.

Numbly, he picked up a severed arm, still wrapped in a dark robe sleeve. Pale, hairy, scarred - it had belonged to a human man. He set it down, and moved forward.

There were bodies, and parts of them, scattered all around. Hacked-off hands, far-flung fingers, lopped-off legs. Hooded heads. Still, he did not cry out.

The boy stumbled forward until he found what - whom - he was looking for. His sister. His beloved older sister. Her mouth was frozen in a rictus of pain. All the light was gone from her glassy eyes - mysteriously red. Her fingers were curled up, as if frozen partway through making a fist. Her tail was limp and lifeless. She was in one piece, he saw. She had received a sword through her heart.

Now he screamed. He screamed, cried, threw out all the curse words he knew, and asked the world at large 'Why?'. He screamed until his throat was raw and swollen, then squeaked terribly, sobbing, tears wetting his shirt, and his sister's robe. He sat with her a long time, petting her head, over and again.
