155332222222222211111111111111111.content:
It was some time before sense returned. Knowing he would have to bear this terrible news home to his parents, the boy stood up, laid his sister down gently, and kissed her goodbye. And he swore to her, on whoever had done this, he would one day take revenge. It was a brash promise; the kind young men are given to make. The gods to later come would not hold it against him.

As he returned to the bedchamber for his bag of clothes, though, he began to think. What was it the men had said? 'For Medremelth'? He had heard that name before... The God of Medicine! The God of Health! But- That made these men- 'Paladins!'

As you can imagine, he was crushed. Why had holy warriors - paragons of peace, and justice, and good - done something so- so evil? Why had they wiped out these clerics, other men and women of the cloth? Why had their god told them to do it?

The leopard boy felt he could no longer join their ranks in good faith. Yet, he couldn't just be evil, either. So he had no hopes; no dreams. He would grow up to be a farmer, or a blacksmith, or a cooper; live a quiet life, grow old, and die. This was depressing.

He changed his clothes, wet and stained with blood, and took his bag with him into the city above. Dawn was just breaking; he could tell. What should have been inspiring was only saddening. This was the first day of his life without his sister.

The horses were all gone, he noted. Even if he could have mounted one, he had no idea how to control it, or how to get home. He would have to rely on the kindness of strangers. If he had stopped to think, he might have been scared. But he only wanted to get home.

Completely lost, a stranger in a strange city, he walked to the east, towards the rising sun. The first friendly-looking face he saw, he decided, he would ask for help. You see, everyone in the village he had come from was willing to help one another; they had to be. He assumed, besides those Paladins of Medremelth, it was the same here.

He did not catch sight of anyone until he found his way back to the merchant's district, where he'd received his first impression of the city. There, people were setting up stalls, opening shops, doing breakfast shopping, and stumbling home after long nights in the taverns. Except for the drunks, they looked friendly enough to the boy.

He first approached a comfortably-familiar target; that is, a furry. The fox ran a fruit stand, and at this time, he was examining his stock for anything he couldn't sell. The boy had a polite, but heart-wrenching speech planned. 'Please help!' he'd say, to catch their attention. Then he'd go on about how his sister had brought him to the city for a vacation, and met a terrible fate. Could he help him find a way home?

But, alas, all the boy could muster was a pained squeak. His throat had not recovered from its earlier exertions. Try as he might, he could not properly talk. It should go without saying that this discovery did not fill him with hope.

Still, the fox heard him, or perhaps sensed him. Turning, his polite smile fell away at the sight of the dirty little child. Selecting a few rejected fruits, he tossed them to the leopard boy, saying "Aw, geez. Here you go, kid. Now beat it; you'll frighten off the customers."

Surprised, dejected, yet grateful, the boy took his prizes off to a quiet space behind a nearby building, and sat down to eat and think. The fruit wasn't rotten; just not 'pretty' enough to sell. He would... come to relate, over the years.

Ahem, anyhow, he thought about what he would do now. Until his voice recovered, he couldn't ask for help. So young, and with no money, he could not buy parchment to write on, ink and quill to write with, or get his message out. He could try to find a place where they would take him in, no questions asked. Normally, this would have been one of the Temples; but he'd seen he couldn't trust them.

He racked his little brain, and with his blessedly ignorant, black-and-white view of the world, he came to a solution: he would go to the castle. Everyone knew the king was a 'good guy'; he would help him out. And he would surely bring his sister's killers to justice, too. This was the last time he would get his hopes up, nearly ever.

Locating the castle was hardly difficult. The widest road led straight to its gates, and the stone structure was an intimidating presence, looking over everyone's shoulders. It reminded the population to behave themselves - or be very wary when they weren't. Countless carts were on their way there, so the boy naturally assumed getting in wouldn't be a problem.

He got through the outer gates without trouble. Urgent as his mission was, he took the time to goggle at the splendor of the castle up so close. Old, grey stone, fresh green ivy climbing its walls, old and new wooden fortifications and stairs, and the beautiful garden. This area was open to the public; at least, before sundown.

The boy followed a path, bordered by flowers, deeper in towards the castle. The pair of great wooden doors, reinforced with steel bands, rivets, and who-knew-what spells, beckoned from across the drawbridge. He thought to march right in. Bold fool he was. But, you already know that.

The soldiers stationed on the inland side of the moat stopped him. 'What business have you,' they asked, 'in the castle?'

Of course, he could not tell them. He gestured to his throat, then shook his head, trying to convey that he had no voice.

The soldiers understood at least that much. They did not, however, particularly care. 'The King has no use for mute, dirty urchins,' one man sneered. 'Get out of here, before you're thrown in the moat!'

The boy would not understand the meaning of that word, 'urchin', for some time yet, but he understood the tone well enough. He was again unwanted. He was frustrated, more than anything, this time, though, because he knew the King would help him, if only he could get in to see him. The leopard boy decided to wait in the castle garden, and hope an opportunity would present itself.

To be brief, none did, though he waited all morning. Near lunchtime, remembering how the fruit vendor had treated him, the boy returned to where the food stalls were set up. He found that, even without saying anything, many of the merchants were kind enough, or eager enough to get rid of him, that they had a little to spare him, and he made a decent, hodgepodge meal of samples and rejects. This was a trick he would not soon forget.

After eating, he went back to wait in the castle gardens again. He was there until sundown, when he was hustled out, no closer to his goal. If the King would not see him, even after he had waited all day near the castle, then he never would, the boy felt. And now, he had nowhere to sleep.

Maybe you can imagine how he felt. Alone, unwanted, miles from home, in a strange city, one beloved sister short, and with night falling. Maybe not.

The boy tried to make his way back to the house he had left that morning. He could avoid the massacre easily enough, and use the beds there. He remembered enough to find the area where the fruit vendor had been set up, and then walk towards the setting sun from there. By fate or providence, he made it.

But the house itself had been boarded up, solid planks of new wood nailed across the doors and window, barring entry. He walked all around it, but there was no way for anyone, even his size, to sneak in. The paladins had covered their tracks. Profoundly saddened, he curled up behind the house, out of view.

Sleep did not come easy, but it eventually took him. Transported him, for a brief time, away from the nightmare he was living.
155332222222222211111111111111111.title: A Tiger by the Tale (Cont.)

1553322222222222111111111111111111.content:
Ah... The next six years of his life were... the toughest he ever experienced, even considering what was to later come. Tough, emotionally and physically. Even more than his childhood up to that point, it shaped him into the man he would become. We'll not go into great detail...

The boy lived alone on the streets of Vermeil L'on, an unkempt, unwanted, unloved orphan. He eventually stopped wondering why his parents hadn't come for him. He stopped thinking anyone was going to help him. He stopped thinking of that distant village as 'home'; his home was the streets of Vermeil L'on. He forgot the very name he had been given at birth; no one ever used it. He never forgot, though, his sense of right and wrong.

This would put him at odds with the city's other 'street urchins' and dwellers. By and large, they were a swindling, thieving, cutthroat bunch. They did whatever they thought they had to do to get by, including stealing from houses, shops, and food stands, extorting more upstanding citizens than themselves, breaking into empty houses, eliminating their competition, and so on.

These people did not like that the tiger- leopard, excuse - would not join them in their illicit activities; even foil them. They did not like that he seemed to think himself above them, hardly speaking to them, even when they challenged him to his face. They really did not like that he could beat down many of them in a fair fight. He was an outcast among outcasts.

The leopard learned quickly the value of fitness and self-defense, living on the streets. When unwanted, one too often had to make a quick getaway, be it from angry citizens, shopkeepers, or soldiers. In this way, too, he came to know the streets in a way only those who become a part of them can. He resumed rising at dawn, and his training, as the sun rose, discovering, before too long, where the soldiers daily drilled. He watched religiously, studying all their moves and mannerisms. He had left his wooden sword and shield at home, but a discarded metal scrap proved just as good, for his needs.

Between waking and sleeping, he usually sat in the alleys around the market area. Sympathetic strangers sometimes offered a few coins, scraps of food, small charms from their temples, or rarely full meals. The leopard always thanked them politely, with his earnest smile. More often than not, this made them offer a little more, which always vexed him. After all, he was not, exactly, the tapestry-boy for charm. But he never turned them down.

Always, always, when living on the streets, he avoided paladins like a plague, regardless of their affiliation. They were easy enough to hear coming, clanking like kitchens in their weighty armour. He knew they offered alms and food for the poor, but he didn't trust them a bit. It would be too easy for them to curse or drug him at these meals, or kill him in his sleep, and rid the city of him, once and for all.

Living on the streets made the leopard agile, crafty, and cunning. Maturity made him tall, strong, and good-looking - it is said. He shot up in height rapidly his twelfth year, nearly two feet. And his growth topped out the next year, making him, it is said, nigh six and one-half feet tall. For a young man of thirteen summers, this was unusual, indeed, but an indicator of great heritage, and great destiny. Or, so he would be told.

His height made it harder, if not impossible, to hide some places, but opened paths to many more. And he enjoyed seeing the world from such a vantage. He felt, as he had so long ago, powerful. The others of the street would come to leave him alone, for his victories seemed assured now, more than ever.

On the day he believed to be his fourteenth birthday, the same age his sister had been when she'd left home to pursue her dreams, the leopard was approached by a most unusual man with a most unusual offer.

The man was dressed in a dark cloak with the hood up, even on such a warm day, and no part of him was exposed to the light. He seemed to glide along the ground, rather than step, and his movements were furtive. His face was hidden in shadow, and the leopard had a brief, distant memory of his sister looking the very same way when she had returned- and then it was gone.

The man explained that he had a prime job opportunity, just for him. He was an artist, and the leopard would be the subject of his next painting. All he had to do was come to some sittings, and he would be fed, clothed, and paid handsomely. Just for sitting still!

Now, this was tempting, but the leopard wanted to get a few things straight. Did the man work for a temple? No, he said, and laughed. Did he work for the castle? No, he said. Not them, either. He painted what he liked, and sold them to whomever paid the most. One final question: would they have to leave the city? Again, the answer was no.

Once, the leopard had wanted to see the world. Now, he had seen quite enough of it. He knew the city of Vermeil L'on like the back of his hand, and he never wanted to feel lost again.

So the leopard agreed; it really was too good of an offer to pass up. He'd soon find out why...

With these promises made, the man led him deeper into the city, to the west. The leopard kept an eye on his mental map, and it became increasingly clear where he was being led. He was not surprised at all to find himself once again at the house that stood over the secret sanctuary where his sister had been slaughtered six years ago. Did the man know what lay in the basement, he wondered, or had it been sealed away, too?

The house itself had been nicely restored, and instead of down, they went up, into the attic. It had perfect light, and space, and essence, the man said. The leopard didn't disagree with him, or think much of this. Artists were known to be strange types.

He was, though, slightly uneasy about where he would sit. There was some large, odd circle carved into the floor around and beneath the chair, made of some mysterious, icky lines and letters. Candles dotted the edges of the circle periodically - but they were black. The man would only say, though, that it was all decoration; a part of the painting. So the leopard sat.

Preparing to begin, easel and canvas already set up, the man pushed back his hood, and this is the only thing the leopard saw: his red eyes. So much like his sister's...

He said as much, and the man smiled. 'Well. Isn't that just a funny coincidence. Who is your sister?'

And the leopard told him 'She was killed. By paladins.'

The man seemed shaken, but said only 'Apologies for your loss. Let us begin.'

He... the leopard... would not later remember much of what happened between that, and the next thing, and so not much is known of the details of what the 'artist' did in the attic that afternoon. But they are details best left that way: unknown. What matters is what happened next.
1553322222222222111111111111111111.title: A Tiger by the Tale (Cont.)

Sid hugs him tight, ignoring his Armor Rating.
15533222222222221111111111111111111.content:
There was a crash! from downstairs; a sound the leopard had heard before. He started to quaver inside.

Then, the thunder of steel-booted feet. The leopard's insides turned to jelly, and the man started to work faster. Now, the leopard could hear him chanting.

Stomp stomp STOMP!, up the stairs came the feet. The leopard wanted to move, but he couldn't; he was frozen in place. He shut his eyes against what was to come.

STOMP! STOMP! STOMP! The boots, the armored men, were coming closer, crashing and clanking up the second flight of stairs. Any second, the door would burst open. The man was practically screaming, now, rushing to finish his odd incantation.

A bright, senseless, clutter of noise... And then

BOOM! The door was knocked off its hinges!

'SOL-RAAAAA!' A hoarse battlecry scraped the air!

'EeeeeEEEEEE-' a girlish shriek was cut short!

Thump.

Then, silence.

An exhalation. The clatter of steel.

'Boy! Say there, boy!' The leopard winced at this voice, refusing to open his eyes, praying with all his might they would just go away.

'Boy, are you alright?'

He opened his mouth. His head swam. The world spun.

He passed out.

When he awoke, he was on a cot. A stone wall loomed on his right. His throat felt raw and swollen, and for a second, he feverishly wondered if the last six years hadn't been some sort of horrific demon-dream.

But no, when he swung his legs out, they met the floor. His clothing was current, if dirty. He was long and lanky, head full of streets.

To his left, a small cart waited. On it was a fresh change of clothes - they were yellow, not a colour he particularly cared for, considering his fur - a bowl of water, presumably for washing his hands and face in, a towel, and a glass and pitcher of water for drinking. Despite the danger, he grabbed at these eagerly; his throat was on fire.

After slaking his thirst, throat throbbing, he considered the clothes. If they fit, he should hardly pass them up. He unfolded them, held them up, and found that they did. It was unsettling, to be sure, but you know that old saying about beggars...

Once changed, he left his old clothes on the bed, and started to look for an escape. Wherever he was, he didn't want to be there. He wanted to be out on the streets he knew best, putting this whole terrible incident behind him. He wanted to be away from the paladins who had finally caught him.

He looked around, and saw he was in a room lined with other cots, though none of them were occupied. It seemed to be a soldiers' dormitory. There was a wooden door in the wall in the middle of the room, between the two sets of rows of bunks. He opened it up, and peeked out.

He was at the end of a hallway, with another wooden door across from him, and a possible escape route to his right. Assuming the other door led to more beds, he crept down the hallway.

At the next junction, he took a left, away from the lights of what seemed to be a dining hall in the distance. This part of the temple, if he had to guess, was darker; he was less likely to be spotted.

The hall let out onto a training area. There were wooden dummies, slices from bales of hay painted with colorful rings, heavy bags hanging like men at the gallows... And best of all, racks of weapons! Though he couldn't picture killing anyone, he knew he could use one to threaten anyone who got in his way. He took an iron sword, grinning just a little.

On the far side of the room were stone stairs that led to an upper level, which seemed to ring the training area. He took a torch from the wall as he continued down the hallway up here, for it was dark. The corridor jigged right, and ended in a door.

This time, when he pushed through, he found himself in a courtyard. And below, down a set of stone steps, lay the city! Once he got to those streets, he could flee from this place, and they'd never find him again! That it was nighttime made no difference to him.

He was just about to run for it when slow, dry claps began to ring out around the courtyard. From out behind a pillar stepped a smirking paladin, looking right up at him. He was unarmored, but a fine steel sword hung by his side.

'Jolly good show, boy; jolly good,' the man said. 'You are a wily one. And quiet, too. No one else thought you would leave. But with the way you were screaming- Well, someone had to know better. And that someone is Sir Yancy D'white!'

The leopard said nothing, of course; only calculated his chances of outrunning, and then losing the man. They looked pretty good - he was a burly warrior, not a fleet rogue - or cleric...

D'white must've known the leopard better than that, for he drew his sword. 'Sorry, boy. Can't let you leave; we'd never find you again! If you'd get back inside-'

But the leopard brandished his own sword, mostly as a warning. He would hurt him if he had to.

At this, D'white laughed. 'Well then! If you can best me in a duel, you can go free. We fight to first blood. Agreed?'

The leopard nodded, and moved down the steps towards the man. They met in the middle of the open courtyard, staring one another down. They raised their blades, tapped them together, and sprung back. The duel was begun.

The ti- leopard had seen duels before, in the square, and had been in not a few, himself. Those were street fights, though, where dirty pool was expected as a matter of course. The leopard, honorable though he considered himself, was not entirely above this, when it came to survival.

So it should come as no surprise to hear that after some sword clashing, with parrying, thrusts, circling, jumps back and forth, and feints, he batted aside the man's arm, and with his left hand, punched him in the nose. D'white fell down, from the force or surprise, and clapped a hand to it - sure enough, it was bleeding.

He just laughed. 'So, the kitty has claws,' he said. 'Go, then; you've won your freedom. But know what you'll be passing up if you do. A better life. A chance to help people. Heh; three hots, and a cot. A reason to get up in the mornings, and live...'

A few sparse rays of light broke the horizon behind him, and the leopard turned, realizing it was dawn. As a new day began, so could he begin anew. He really didn't have a reason to live; he'd only been living not to die.

But these men were paladins... Could he trust them? Could he forgive them? By the time he figured it out, would it be too late to run away?

But why run away? At this point, the futility of life staring him in the face, he was ready to die.

The leopard turned back to the man, and crouched down. He set his borrowed sword on the ground, and then extended a hand to help the man up.

D'white broke into a sunny smile, and stood up with him. 'Welcome, brother,' he said, 'to the Temple of Sol-Ra.'

The tiger - all he could do was smile back."

Jules finished his epic tale, and took a draught from the pitcher of juice he'd snagged from Sid, clearing his throat. "Ahem. Excuse."

He set the juice aside just in time for Sid to drop down onto his lap, throwing his arms around his neck, and moaning "Ohh, Jules! Wh- That's- I- What a story...!"

There were tears in his eyes, and tracks on his face, as he shook his head. "That was beautiful, and touching, and-! And I'm so sorry!"

Blushing with modesty, Jules started to say "The story is not really-"

But he quite suddenly stopped, when
15533222222222221111111111111111111.title: A Tiger by the Tale (Cont.)

choices: As they get underway, Sid speaks up.
The carriage continues towards Little Silverhorne...
155332222222222211111111111111111111.content:
Sitting on Jules' lap, the black wolf had the tiger pinned, sitting between the bed and armoire, with his back against the wall, as he was. As the tiger had just finished telling his harrowing backstory - thinly veiled as being about some unnamed leopard paladin - Sid had teared up, overcome with emotion. And before the tiger could get more than a few words out...

The black wolf pressed his lips right onto the tiger's own, releasing the confusion, excitement, and lust that had been building up since he'd met him. It was, he knew, so very wrong. But in this moment, ooh, it felt so right!

Jules felt confused for a very short fraction of a second; then, he was feeling something else entirely. Pleasure. Pleasure, and warmth, flooding his body, from his lips to his ear tips, and down to his toes. Carefully, delicately, he squeezed Sid to him with his steel-plated arms, against his battle-ready chest, and kissed back. If he'd had to think, he wouldn't have known what to do. But this felt perfect, and natural; think, he did not.

Jules began to involuntarily purr with pleasure, and Sid's tail wagged faster than ever before behind him; if there had been a candle still lit, it would have been blown out.

The wolf moaned again, this time happily, and stroked what little of the tiger's fur he could feel: his head. Over and again, he worked his fingers through the thick fur on the back of Jules' head, loving how smooth, but wiry it felt, and how warm. He could only imagine what stroking his arms, or back, or even chest would feel like, and what pleasure it would bring.

Jules instinctually worked his hands up under Sid's shirt, rhythmically rubbing his ribs, up and down, fur working against him, and then flowing with him. He could feel his heart racing in his chest, and each breath he took. He thrummed beneath his hands, like a raw current. It was somehow exciting; he enjoyed it very much.

When, finally, regrettably, they pulled apart to breathe, faces still mere centimeters from one another, Jules had the sense to say "We shouldn't be doing this..."

"I was always a lousy Paladin," Sid panted, petting the fur between the tiger's ears. "You're perfect; the gods will forgive you."

It was irresistible; they went back for seconds.

***

*Pant, pant, pant...*

*Wheeze... Wheeze...*

It was official: they were too winded to continue.

Sid sat on Jules' lap, reclining against him like an odd steel chair. His tongue hung out of his mouth, and he panted rapidly, as if experiencing a heat wave. The room was getting warm, really.

Jules leaned up against the wall, hands on the wolf's waist, beneath his soft leather shirt. He was glad he had taken his gauntlets off before starting his story; funnily enough, to rub the wolf's stomach, though not quite as he was doing now. His chest heaved steadily, seeking fresh air; he was really quite hot, in nearly full armour. The room seemed stifling.

"Well... I think I can finish that breakfast, now," Sid said, breaking he relative silence.

"Do hurry," Jules encouraged. "We need to be going."

Suppressing a string of curses, Sid nodded, and rose. "Yeah. Only got one stack of flapjacks, and those fruit strudels."

"Jules is surprised you didn't finish already," the tiger commented, rising rustily, himself.

"I kind of got caught up in your story," Sid said apologetically. "Uh- Were the red-eyed guys who I think they were?"

Jules nodded grimly, attempting to stretch, in the small space. "Sanguimancers. Hemocytes. Blood Mages. Whatever you want to call them. The leopard dedicated himself to fighting evil after learning this, and learning his sister had been tricked and seduced by these scum."

Sid winced sympathetically. "Yeah. I mean, it's not an inherently evil art, but what most everyone seems to end up using it for..."

"Indeed," Jules sighed heavily.

"I really am sorry," Sid said, and resumed eating.

"Thank you, Sid," Jules said, his only implicit acknowledgement that his story had not really been about a leopard, at all.

Sid did finish pretty quickly, downing the last six, dinner plate-sized flapjacks, soaked in syrup, the eight remaining fruit strudels, each the size of the tiger's palm, and the last jug and a half of fruit juice. This, of course, was on top of the twelve other giant flapjacks he'd eaten before cutting himself off a slice of a certain tiger.

He was stuffed, and quite happily, at that, black belly bloated out at least an inch over his soft leather trousers. He was looking forward to having a lie-down in the carriage, and hopefully having the tiger give him a nice little belly rub...

"Great; you're done," Jules clapped, eyeing him happily. "Jules will take your dishes out there and pay the tab while you grab your stuff, and then we can go."

"I might need some help with that," the wolf said sheepishly. "It's just, er, difficult to carry it all when you're not wearing it, you know."

"Fair enough," Jules nodded, pulling his gauntlets back on before grabbing the tray. "Jules will be right back, then."

He stepped out, while Sid rose. Groaning lightly, the black wolf slung his sword belt over his shoulder, and opened the armoire to get at his armour. The cuirass was the heaviest single piece, so he took this, and started towards the door.

Jules was off to his left, but he opened the door on his right, and walked out into the fresh air. He would miss Half Measure Hamlet a little, he decided - or at least, the food at Halfway Hostel. Seeing Arthur was sitting atop his carriage, he waved as he made his way over, and opened up the door.

Climbing in, Sid stowed his cuirass and sword in the overhead compartment, then backed out. He didn't want to bend over, if he could help it, so hopefully he could just grab his boots and gauntlets from the armoire, and Jules could get his platelegs. He hurried, as best as he could, back towards the inn.

Jules was still discussing something with the innkeeper, a dark-haired human woman who had been uncomfortable with their line of questioning regarding her serving sizes. The wolf reentered the room he'd rented, took his gauntlets and steel boots from the armoire, and headed back out again. He took his time storing them in the carriage, hoping Jules would come out with his leggings quick.

Happily enough, he did, waving to Arthur, as well. Sid made room for him to enter the carriage, scooting to the far end. "Everything square?"

"Everything's paid for, if that is what you mean," Jules said, climbing in. "You Marshins have strange expressions."

"Do not!" Sid stuck his tongue out at him. "You Luxumites are the weird ones. All fancy, and eating snails, and frog legs. And always drinking wine, instead of beer."

"The empty and petty criticisms of the ignorant Marshin drudges," Jules needled right back. "You are jealous of our excellent, high-class food and fine drinks."

"More like we're tired of your snobbery," the wolf retorted, lying down so his head was across from where the tiger sat. "You've got your noses up in the air so you can't smell the tripe you spew."

"Only around Marshins, because you all smell like manure, from rolling around with the farm animals," Jules sniffed.

"That's the smell of victory, you cheese-eating surrender-monkeys," Sid harrumphed. "Fighting all your battles for you."

"You beer-swilling cornpones are just bloodthirsty savages," Jules poked him in the chest. "Why not let the lesser 'men' take the front lines? Fewer of them to stink up the place afterwards."

"This must be the legendary 'Luxumite charm' I've heard so much about," Sid sneered. "It should have stayed in Luxumentum."

"This Luxumite is about to throw down the gauntlet on your thick skull, boy," Jules warned, literally removing his gauntlets.

Sid rolled away from him, scoffing. "Pfft. Empty words from an empty head."

Jules seized him, and rolled him back over. With one hand on his chest, he pinned him down, and with the other, began to softly rub his swollen stomach. Smiling, he bent down to stare the wolf in the eyes. "Jules dares you now to say one more disparaging thing about him."

This was not entirely unlike a dream come true for Sid; he was having trouble thinking, much less saying anything, with the powerful waves of warmth and pleasure coursing through him, weakening his defenses. But he managed a smirk, and a quiet "I hear... Luxumites didn't really invent the 'Luxese Kiss'... I hear they're terrible at it..."

"Jules has obviously never done this before; he's honestly pretty lost," the tiger admitted quietly. "He does not know how to deal with these new feelings. He thought had had found meaning in life again when Sol-Ra found him. Now, he wonders why he feels the same way again."

Before Sid could really take this in, he was being kissed again; he did not, could not, resist. With the added pleasure of the belly rub, it was, in a word, bliss.

1553322222222222111111111111111111111.content:
After Jules pulled away, with the carriage resuming its journey towards Little Silverhorne, the black wolf sat up, facing the tiger, and took his hands in his own. "Wait. Let's talk about this. What is it you're feeling?"

Jules blushed, looking away. "When Sol-Ra arranged for Jules to see the light, as it were, he realized that he had been, up to that point, living just because it was expected. He lived, because nothing had stopped him. But when he joined the Temple of Sol-Ra, he felt purpose in learning to vanquish evil, in avenging... the innocent, and protecting them. He is happy to serve the greater good, and die doing so."

He sighed, thinking. "Now, Jules thinks he has had a moment like that again. Where the light washes over him, and everything seems so clear... This was when you- you kissed him. It was like the sun breaking the horizon, and this new path was revealed."

Sid squeezed the tiger's hands, heart thumping in his chest. "Yeah? Is it- are you on the path? Is there a fork in the road?"

Jules squeezed back gratefully. "Oui, it is a fork. Jules thinks, on one side, there looms in the distance this... Lipomancer's Lair. Light falls sparsely on this path; Sol-Ra is saying his help and influence here is... limited. That this will largely be a path Jules would walk... he does not want to say alone, but..."

"I understand," Sid assured him. "Without that comforting hand on your shoulder."

"Yes, like that," Jules nodded, and began to blush. "And the other path... Jules sees himself, and you, hand-in-hand. And it is clear, and it is brightly lit. This says to him that Sol-Ra would be... would still give him his blessing, if- if he chose this. That means a lot to him."

He sniffled, and freed a hand to wipe at his eyes, alarming the wolf. "Jules! Are you okay?"

"This is just a difficult decision; Jules is sorry," he apologized. "Jules thinks this first path could join up with the second, at some point past all this Lipomancer business... Jules does not want to abandon the life Sol-Ra has gifted him with! He is very torn up about this; very conflicted on these feelings..."

"Well, it's- You don't have to stop being a paladin entirely!" Sid said, feeling his urgency. "Wherever we go - if we did go - maybe Luxumentum, if you wanted. Anyway, you wouldn't have to stop fighting for good there. Or even being a paladin! You could just work on a smaller scale, like you've been doing, right? Isn't that what Sol-Ra could have been saying, too?"

The tiger thought on it, and nodded slowly. "Yes... Jules could see that. But, if he is working the day, and you are working the night, when do we have time to see one another?"

Sid laughed a little, bowing his head. "Well, I- Like I said, Jules, I make a lousy paladin. I don't have your dedication, or qualms. I haven't really been touched by Nocturpus' inky tentacles like you have by Sol-Ra's... shining rays, or whatever. I mean, we have spoken, but I'm sure everyone in my order can say that. I joined because it seemed like a good career choice, really. I'm not cut out for much else."

Swallowing hard, and blushing, himself, he reached out, and placed his hand lightly on Jules' cheek. "You talk like us being together forever is a given... You have no idea how that makes me feel, Stripy Snout."

Jules chuckled, and raised an eyebrow. "Stripy Snout?"

"Well, I thought I should come up with a pet name for you," Sid teased. "You like that one? No? Maybe I'll keep working on it. Heh. So anyway, I can give it up. Be a- heh. Be a housewife."

"Would you be happy with that, though?" Jules asked, concerned. "Would that be a life you wanted?"

Sid closed his eyes to picture it. An image of himself, pink bow tied around his forehead, as if keeping the hair he didn't have out of his eyes. A pink, frilly apron tied around his waist - and just his undergarments beneath. Cooking for himself, and Jules. Tidying up their nice little house. Snoring the morning away, after snuggling his tiger all night.

Grinning, he nodded. "Very happy, mon tournesol."

Jules nodded, satisfied by this answer, but still deep in thought.

"You'll want time to think about this, of course," Sid acknowledged, leaning back in his seat. "I'll probably just doze off, and-"

"No." Jules sat up straight, and looked him in the eyes. "Jules is ready to make a decision right now."

Taking the black wolf's face in his hands, he said:
1553322222222222111111111111111111111.title: The Quest for Peace

15533222222222221111111111111111111112.content:
For Jules, the choice he should make, the path he should set himself on, was as clear as day. Holding the black wolf's hands, looking into his inky purple eyes, he said "Let us begin our new life right away!"

Sid uttered a happy sort of squeal, and threw himself at the tiger, hugging him as tightly as he could through his plate armour. "Oh, Jules! You're the best! What direction are we heading? And where's Luxumentum from here?"

"Little Silverhorne lays south of Wellingham," Jules answered automatically, "but Luxumentum is west of here."

Releasing him, Sid threw open the window in the carriage door, and stuck his head out. "Arthur! Scrub the mission! I will pay you whatever it takes to get us to Luxumentum! Go west, young man!"

Arthur looked down at him, surprised. "You- you're quite serious, Sir Coltrane? You want me to take you to Luxumentum?"

"That's right! And I'll pay handsomely!" Sid said happily.

"Then I'll make the next turn west, Sir!" Arthur agreed, deciding not to ask why. "Hope you're prepared for a long journey."

"Thank you, Arthur!" Sid said, and assured him "We'll have no cause to regret it."

He pulled his head back into the carriage, grinning at Jules. "Think Luxumentum is far enough away from this Lipomancer business? Warmer than the Northern Territories, for sure."

Jules smiled back, but it looked tight and worried. "Yes, and Luxumentum has many beautiful areas. It will be good to see her again."

"Don't worry, Tiger Lily; they'll send someone else to clean up this Lipomancer deal," Sid comforted him, squeezing his hands. "Fate will, probably. It'll find some great hero whose destiny it is to stop him, and he or she will get the glory and fame, but me and you? We'll have each other. And no one else can say that."

Jules nodded, and exhaled, relaxing. "Jules is sure you are correct. Meanwhile, he will continue to serve Sol-Ra in a smaller, but no less important, capacity. And adore and dote on his Nightingale."

"Nightingale? Please, I'm more like a nighthawk," Sid sniffed.

"Whatever you say, Sidney..." Jules shrugged, smirking.

"Oh, don't you even go there, Julie," Sid challenged right back, though he was smiling. "You know, if you take off your armour, the ride could be a lot more enjoyable..."

Jules caught on, and though he was worried about the possibility of the carriage being accosted by highwaymen, he had trust in his god. "Alright. This once, Jules will. But he is going to be ready if something happens later..."

Sid reached over to expedite his removal of his armour, reassuring him "Tournesol, we are going to be just fine..."

15533222222222222.content:
Saori is a dark mage from one of the many dark guilds in this country, and is notorious for being a very diabolical criminal. She’s mastered a very dangerous art of Dark Puppetry, which as the name suggests, allows the caster to control others as if they were mindless puppets. The ability itself is rather powerful, but doesn’t usually last long since the user’s mana gets depleted at a fast rate. However, Saori has found a way to get past that little handicap – Submission Collars, which hold the same effect as the puppetry magic she has, but filter in Mana from the one who wears it and from the mana from other living creatures (however, making these Submission Collars is quite costly and the materials are very rare, so she only has three to her name, two of which are currently in use).

Saori is a young woman standing around five foot four with long silver hair that is pulled to the sides of her head into a pair of pigtails held with a pair of blue ribbons (giving her a bunny like appearance) to keep out of her cute, yet cold looking face. She has pale skin, but she’s dressed in form fitting black armor that’s covered with runes and a blue chest-plate, a long flowing black skirt that reached the top of her knees (which also has armor on it), and a blue cloak that usually covers her armor. Underneath her armor Saori’s figure is rather average, a modest chest and a curve for her behind and hips, but nothing dynamic (she’s more comfortable in her armor, and is really self-conscious about it since there are a number of scars on her skin).

As mentioned before, Saori has a few Submission Collars in use, this is because she uses them on two of her fellow teammates. A few years back, Saori was a white mage, but because she was treated so poorly by her teammates she studied the dark arts and sought revenge against the two teammates that got on her nerves when she was a nerdy white mage. When she perfected the Submission Collars, the two were made into her mindless servants who now serve as her personal body guards and, should the need arise, her personal toys.

One of the two was a warrior wolfess – Diana – Who stands about seven feet tall and physically built to match her height. She has a dark fur coat save for a tuft of white hair just at her collar (dipping into her impressive cleavage) and usually dressed in a leather bikini with light silver armor on her shoulders, waist, and limbs. She also known to wield a powerful lance and was well-known throughout the warrior guilds. Before she was tricked to wear the Submission Collar, Diana was quite cocky and often berated Saori for studying the mystic arts instead of training her body.

The other unfortunate soul who had a Submission Collar placed around her neck was the Elven Archer of the group – Rose (or that was the name that she gave). Like a number of her kind, Rose is a girl of natural beauty, silky blonde hair, smooth blonde skin, and a figure that would steal the gazes of everyone she passed. Considering the fact that she also wore a leaf green tunic with silver leggings and leather gloves/boots, her figure was only enhanced. Unlike Diana, Rose was actually really nice to Saori, but really cared for Diana as well and Saori knew that if Rose was left uncheck, then her submission collar would be removed from Diana and Saori would be punished by the hot-headed wolfess. So she had no choice but to put Rose under the control of one of the three Submission Collars.

Now, the reason why Saori is seeking out the Lipomancer is to find a way to improve her own magical abilities and make it so that she doesn’t need the Submission Collars to control people for long-term times. It also wouldn’t hurt to learn some more dark arts to add to her spell book.

So, do you wanna take this storyline so you can get three victims for the price of one? Or do you wanna have more?

1553322222222222212.content:
Saori sat up in bed, wiping the sweat from her brow and rubbing the sleep from her eyes. Whatever Little Silverhorne was, she needed to find out more. Hoping out of bed, the silk pajama'd Puppetmaster stretched her back and arms, already planning where she'd look for information on the village. Walking down the hallway towards her personal library, Saori lit torches against the cold walls, opening the heavy oaken door with her magic. Inside, she casually strode through a half dozen bookshelves, sliding out a book as she passed, bending over to stack a large tome over that, levitating another thin one from a shelf over...

With a loud thud, all of Saori's selected texts and tracks of parchment piled up on her desk. Rolling her neck, The Puppetmaster sighed, "So much for a full night's rest..." Swinging open the first tome marked the beginning of her lengthy cramming session, one that wouldn't keep the night young...

Morning slowly peeked it's head, the sun's soft glow beam in through a grand window over Saori's desk... Where her head lay sleeping in an open book. Her eyes creaked open, a hand propping up her groggy body up. "Ughhh..." She groaned, doing her best to remember what information she learned in the wee hours of the night. Looking down at her lazily scrawled notes, the village didn't appear to be far. It seemed fairly average until she read a few manuscripts written by some of the townsfolk. Nearly each account across the years had a tidbit about adventures being called in via some sort of dream, or so the questing folk told them, and were in search of the fabled lipomancer. Every 5 years it seems, a swell of people visit the village and go off into the forest. Adding to the suspicion, nearly no one came back; when some did, they hardly looked the same.

There was certainly enough suspension surrounding the village, enough to warrant Saori's investigation.

15533222222222222121.content:
The Puppetmaster stewed over the idea of leaving her home in search of a man (or woman, for that matter) that might not even exist. However, if the scrolls and history texts suggested, there was irrefutable evidence that something strange and powerful is dwelling in that forest. After all, you don't get dozens of adventurer types hearing the same whispers in their heads and never returning unless it's something good. "The raw power I could take," Saori mused to herself, "The piles of loot!" Her voice filled with energy, a smile appearing on her giddy face; it was settled.

"Diana, Rose!" Saori shouted in their room's direction, "Wake up and gather up traveling supplies, we're going on a bit of a road trip!" She clapped her hands together, sending a small stream of magic for their collars to receive as a bit of an incentive for the two to get the job done quickly. The silver haired girl walked to the kitchen, whipping up a little traveler's breakfast. Her culinary skills still served their purpose from her days as a white priest...

Saori finished her hardy breakfast, putting away the dishes for her puppets to clean later. Turning round the corner as she exits, the two 'subjects' were waiting with bags packed and ready, dressed, and at attention. "Jeez, can't a girl get some space? What's the rush about, you're only making me feel late!" Saori nudged Rose's chin, "Come on, I'm not even dressed yet." She scoffs, going back to her room and away from the stone faced Puppets.

Quickly rounding up her scattered bits of onyx black armor, Saori mumbled on about the incompetent help, "Maybe I should just use that third one already, get someone who can do things without making me feel like I need to rush..." She begun the process of strapping, belting, and zipping up her armored garb, loosening and tightening to ensure a comfortable journey. Once all was said and done, Saori ribboned up her signature silver hair, giving her reflection in the vanity a smile, "Alrighty!" She turned to the door and pulled up her hood, clasping the front to conceal her clothes.

Passing the Puppets, The Puppetmaster wordlessly commanded them both to follow her to the stables and grab their horses for the road ahead. Walking through the front door, she waited till her servant were through and locked it behind them with her key. Channeling dark magic she warded the entrance for good measure. Turning around, her servants were trotting upon their horses with Saori's in tow, "Let's get this show on the road!" Mounting on her steed, Saori set off down the path, the sound of two horses following her...

15533222222222222212112.content:
Travis has heard of this place; it is the home of the Lipomancer. He heard that the Lipomancer can cater to his, desires, by providing them to him. He wasn't there to gain weight, he was there for the girls who gained weight. The place was easy to find; it stood out like that castle from An Unexpected Jouney(Yes, that is a reference, and I will continue to make more along the way). After he climbed up the mountain, though most would have taken the stairs, Travis was exhausted. He reached into his bag and grabbed some bread and water. But it wasn't the fat, beautiful girls; he heard that there was a gladiator style game for fighting for the amusement of the Lipomancer. The front doors to the castle were huge, but he had no trouble opening them so he could enter. When he closed the doors, he shouted, "Lipomancer, Where are you? I wish to speak to you personally.". No reply. "Lipomancer, Where are you?". Still no relpy. "LIPOMANCER? LIPO..."

"WHAT FOOLISH ADVENTURER DARES TO INTRUDE INTO MY CASTLE?" the Lipomancer screamed. "WHAT BE YOUR BUSINESS HERE, FOOLISH ONE?"

"Yeeeaaahh, I'm here because of what you do." Travis replyed.

"Ah yes, and you wish to learn the Dark Art of Lipomancy?" Asked the Lipomancer.

"Nah, I'm more of a lover and a Fighter, not much need of magic." answered Travis.

"THEN WHAT ARE YOU HERE FOR, IF NOT FOR MAGIC? THEN, IF YOU ARE NOT HERE FOR MAGIC, YOU WILL LEAVE, OR YOU WILL MEET THE FATE MANY BEFORE YOU..."

"Where do I check in? Where to I sign-up to fight?" Travis interrupted.

"What?" The Lipomancer asked.

"You know, where can i get my own room? Where to I enter to fight against opponents?" Travis said.

"FOOL, THIS IS NOT SOME SORT OF HOTEL WHERE YOU CAN..."

"Will you pay in money?" the Lipomancer's roommate, who was an average man of size wearing armor and a helmet covering his head down to his mouth, asked.

"Yeah, I guess." answered Travis.

"2nd floor, 3 doors down, on the left side of the hall." the roommate said as he laughed at money falling into his hands.

"Is there a place where I can go head-to-head against opponents?" asked Travis.

"Sign-ups are on the desk over there." the roommate answered as he continue to laugh as he piles the money into a chest.

"Thanks." Travis said as he climbed the stairs.

The Lipomancer sighed as the talked to himself, "To do list: 1. Kick out roommate, 2. Relocate Castle".

155332222222222222121122.content:
CLINK! CLANK! CLASH!

The dragonkin gladiator whipped her head around, the nearby sounds of battle calling her as the flower called the bee.

SHINK! She drew her sword, "Barb", and rushed headlong towards the source of the sounds.

Crashing through bushes, she screamed "Hi-YAAAAH!" and charged forward sword ready to-!

"Pfft!" "Haw haw! What is THAT?!"

The fighters, a brown-haired human male and a blonde elf male, had lowered their swords to stare incredulously at her. The elf bowed his head, hiding his face behind his curtain of hair, blood dripping from the gash on his forehead to the ground, trying to maintain the veneer of elegance his people had cultivated over centuries. The barbarian, in his fur armor, had not bothered, going so far as to lean on his broadsword for support, chest shaking with mirth.

"Raise your swords! Let's go! I'll take both of you!" the dragonkin, Margret by name, snorted, bringing her own to bear.

"Look at it! Pink! It's so cute!" the barbarian guffawed. "Is it real? Haw haw!"

The elf straightened up, trying to look serious, but unable to keep a smile from tugging at the corners of his lips. "Go home, child, and sheathe your toy sword. You might trip, and put your eye out."

Margret snorted again, brandishing her sword at the both of them in turn. "I am not a child, and I am not a toy! I demand honor!"

The barbarian, smirking with amusement, drove his broadsword point-first into the ground, and raised his fists in a loose ready stance before him. "C'mon, then. To first blood." He wiped the blood from his chest and face to put them on an even keel.

Wasting no time, Margret charged forward, ready to strike, amethyst-purple eyes narrowed in fierce concentration. She was swift! She was deadly! She was a peerless gladiator, the likes of which-!

CLONK SCREECH!

With effortless ease, the barbarian backhanded the sword out of her hand, disarming her, and placed his other hand against her forehead, stopping her in her tracks.

Margret swung her fists and talons at him, running ever forward, trying to break free from his humiliating grasp. Her blows fell well short; at just four and a half feet, he had a good two feet on her. Even the horns cresting her head seemed to present no threat to him; they bent like quills beneath his hand.

Suddenly, she found herself being picked up - first by her head, with the carelessness a child handles a doll, but then the barbarian's hands were wrapping around her narrow waist, and holding her above his head, as if he were a father making his little girl "fly".

"Lookit 'er little wings," he commented to the elf, indicating the membranous appendages jutting out of her shoulderblades. "Now that's attention to detail."

"She does seem like some wizard's magical little toy brought to "life", does she not?" the elf agreed. "Oh, look, I think she's trying to set your helm aflame!"

Indeed, Margret was inhaling and puffing, cheeks rounding out, going quite red in the face. She was trying with all her might to summon a gout of flame to incinerate his face, but all that was coming out was a mildly-uncomfortable hot breeze, ruffling the fur crest on the helm.

"What do you think? Should we keep her? A little mascot?" the barbarian grinned. Bringing Margret down to face-level, he offered "We'll pay you in sweets. How does that sound?"

"Put me down, you dung-farmer! You brute! You smelly grunt! I'll tear out your throat!" the diminutive dragonkin swore, gnashing her sharp little teeth.

The barbarian began looking around and, spotting a lake far below where the mountain path dropped off steeply at the sides, began to turn towards it, rearing his arm back. "Five gold if I make it."

"Give me ten if she does fly," the elf agreed, watching with interest.

"Ha! Deal!" the barbarian leaned back, and threw the pink dragonkin as hard as he could, far and away.

They watched the pink dot grow distance, the elf's sharp eyes more easily able to pick out the moment she splashed down in the middle of the lake. "Well, I wouldn't call that flying. Five gold it is."

The barbarian found the sword, examined it, and carelessly chucked it after her. "What were we fighting about, anyway?"

"Our last bet, you dung-farmer," the elf reminded him, smirking just a little. They set off up the path together. "Thusly, I'll be keeping that gold, thank you."

"Yeah, yeah.. How was I s'posed to know bears have that weak spot...?" the barbarian grumbled, sheathing his sword.

1553322222222222221211222.content:
GASP WHEEZE

"Ack-hack-pth!" Margret hauled her battered body further into the tall reeds, belly scraping along the dirt, sky-blue scales there turning brown as they were caked with mud. She had landed back-first on the surface of the lake, breaking it with an incredible SMACK! that must have resonated for a mile around. As such, her back currently felt like it was on fire; there couldn't be an inch she wouldn't soon have a bruise.

Vomiting weakly, she dragged herself away from the bilious puddle, lying face-down in the rough crabgrass. Humiliating. That whole performance, just humiliating. Why hadn't she just snuck up? Waited for one to kill the other, then stab him in the back?

Rogues are cowards, dishonorable, shameful cowards, that's why... she reminded herself. Not a scrap of honesty or honor in any of them. I'm better than that. I'm a gladiator!

A gladiator, sure. But what was a gladiator without an arena? An audience? Fame? She was a nobody, a wannabe, a dreamer. All the heart, all the spunk, and none of the luck. She just needed one little break, one chance to show what she could do.

And a new sword... Shit. She sighed into the dirt. She'd trudge back up the mountain, see if it was still there. Maybe that would be her lucky break for the year.

Face-first on the ground, she felt the footsteps instead of hearing them, light footfalls coming nearer. She looked up, squinting against the sun, and croaked "Help... Please...?"

A dark brown cat in black leather armor approached her warily, seeming surprised she was still alive. he said nothing, only drew cautiously close, came to her side-

-and snagged the coin purse from her belt, making it jangle in his paw before he stole off, leaving her alone again.

"Poooooooop..." the pink dragonkin groaned into the dirt. Filthy, stinking rogues.

The sun began to set shortly after, and it was full dark and growing cool before Margret found the strength to sit up. As expected, her back was a tapestry of fire and pain, muscles pulled tight, bones aching. Her wings flopped uselessly; she couldn't feel the muscles that controlled them.

Standing took it out of her; she was gasping and wheezing as she claimed her feet. Still, she persevered, bringing every last scrap of moxie to bear as she trundled along the side of the lake. Off in the distance, on the other side, she could see the dark opening of a cave. She would take shelter for the night, and strike out in the morning.

Her own leather armor weighed her down as she dragged her scaly butt around the lake, the moon high and bright before she reached the opening of the cave, collapsing in the cool, dark interior.

Gods preserve me... she prayed, and closed her eyes.

155332222222222222121122222.content:
The pink dragonkin opened her eyes slowly, muddled memories of yesterday running through her mind - or maybe half-forgotten dreams. Flying? Swimming? A castle, shrouded in darkness, standing out as a black spot against the face of the full moon...? Where was she...?

Soft candlelight; silken sheets; a fluffy pillow; a plush bed. When was she...? These were the accoutrements of home... Where once she had called home... How long had she been asleep? How much had she dreamed?

Sitting up, she winced, as if expecting pain... but none came. Reaching around to rub her back, confused thoughts floating back to her, she felt mud caked there, but no soreness. Hadn't she... been in a fight? Reaching to her belt, she found her purse was still gone. She had been robbed...

Pushing away the depressing memories as they sharpened and became crystal-clear, margret swung her legs out over the side of the bed (they dangled over the floor; they always did), and took stock of her new surroundings.

She was in a... quite nicely-furnished room, actually. A wardrobe next to the nightstand next to the bed, a bookshelf opposite her, a wooden door to her right, a table for one pushed into the corner of the wall she was facing. Craning her neck, she saw a full-length mirror behind her, where the wardrobe stood on the other side of the bed, a chest next to it, a wash basin along the wall behind her, a rack made for weapons next to it, and an armoire.

Where she was, she couldn't begin to guess. Rubbing her face in her hands, she murmured "I need a good scrub before anything. I'm filthy."

The air tingled, and-

SPLOOSH The wash basin behind her was suddenly filled with water. The tendrils of steam rising from it spoke to its apparent warmth.

"Wh-what the heck? What is this place...?" Margret gasped, wide-eyed.

Soundlessly, yet somehow drawing her attention right to it, a rolled-up scroll appeared upon the table.

Rising to her feet, approaching warily, the dragonkin reached out a hand, and took it. The parchment was very real. She unrolled it, and it said:

Welcome, weary warrior, to the Wishing House! This magical place is a temporary respite from the cruel world outside; a safe haven into which the Gods see fit to invite the ailing, such as yourself, to stay a while, and get back on their feet. Some small services will be available to you if you only ask, such as a warm bath, a hot meal, and even some basic equipment to protect you from the barbs of the cruel world to which you must return. Sorry, but unlimited wealth and power are off the table! Please, take your time, mend your spiritual and physical wounds, and avail yourself of our comforts. When you are ready to proudly face the mortal world again, simply open the door, and walk out. You will find very little time has passed outside, and that you exit into a safe position. Even if you don't believe in us, we believe in you!

"Wow..." Margret breathed, more deeply touched than she could say. What a stroke of luck, indeed! The Divines had blessed her this day! She could get her sword back, get her money back, and get ready to fight again! She was feeling better already!

Stripping down out of her worn leather armor, she hopped into the wash basin, finding it just the perfect temperature - naturally. With the provided cloth, she scrubbed her scales clean of mud and grime, bringing them back to their natural luster. Sky-blue scales embraced her lower jaw, flowed down the front of her neck, over her flat chest (being non-mammalian, her species had no use for milk-producing glands), and between her legs to the underside of her tail, nearly to the tip. The rest of her scales were the pink not of healthy roses, but of some artificial dye; a garish color. It had been said (to her face, nonetheless) that the only threat she posed upon sight was to fashion. Several small, white horns crowned her head, angled backwards, though they were more like porcupine quills in shape and number.

The water never seemed to get dirty nor cold, no matter how much mud she scrubbed off of her, and the cloth remained pristine, too. A slight fragrance rose on the steam. It was the most relaxing bath she'd ever had.

Initially reaching for her outfit when she stepped out, dried off in a fluffy towel, Margret instead hesitated, and spoke carefully aloud "I wish I had some new leather armor."

The air tingled as if a storm was coming, and her attention was drawn to the armoire next to her.

Striding over, and throwing it open, she found awaiting her a brand-new set of brown leather armor, in her size, freshly oiled and looking ready for battle. She couldn't help but smile, pleased.

"I guess new clothes to wear under that won't hurt..." the dragonkin tried.

And just a moment later, she knew she'd find what she needed in the wardrobe beside the bed.

Hurrying over, Margret dressed herself, then armored up, finding the clothes comfortable and attractive, and the armor tough, but easy to move in. Already, she felt like a brand-new woman!

"If it's possible, Gods," she said after she had finished looking in the mirror, clasping her hands in prayer, "I would like my sword back; my Barb. Please and thank you."

She squeezed her eyes shut, hoping...

...and vorp! There was suddenly a familiar weight on her hip. Her grin widened as she saw Barb was back, scabbard and all. Whipping it out, she gave it a few experimental swings, then sheathed it again, satisfied.

Not feeling it right to linger too long in this house of wonder, Margret moved for the door.

"Thank you, Gods..." Yet, she paused with her hand upon the knob, her thoughts growing muddled again with a dozen unspoken desires. The one that fell from her lips, though, was "...I just wish I was bigger..."

Opening the door, she stepped out with her eyes closed, fighting back the tears - of joy, of gratitude, of wonder, of pain - and swung it shut behind her with a click.

When she opened her eyes, Margret immediately looked around, startled. Grey stone walls, a torch above an archway, a wrought-iron portcullis before her...

She was not at all where she'd thought she'd be. This looked like... a dungeon. Where was she?

The portcullis opened, drawing up into the stonework above with a shriek, opening the way before her. Stepping forward, now her ears caught the distant sounds of... a crowd? Chanting and cheering? Applause? what was going on?

Margret walked forward, drawn on, through a smooth, stone tunnel, then into an area that curved around to her left and right, more iron portcullises separating her from the center. From the arena!

She was on the outskirts of an arena, beneath the seats above, lying in wait! Through the portcullis before her, she could see an anthropomorphic lion warrior and a fiery elf girl duking it out, blades clashing, before a table laid with a grand feast. Gladiatorial combat! Where was this magical place?

A hand fell on her shoulder, and a voice said from behind her "Welcome to the Ample Amphitheatre, meat..."

1553322222222222221212.content:
(Author's Note: When I created the chapter introducing Anna, Lilly, Margaret and Travis, I had intended for them to travel together, but that's not possible anymore, so I'll have to deal with separating them at the start. Also, in case there's any confusion about Margaret's "Gladiator" class, I mainly based it off of the Gladiator class from the Dragon Quest series, specifically Dragon Quest IX, so look that up if you want the full details. So, without further ado, let's get this show on the road.)

         Anna, Lilly, Margaret and Travis split into groups of two to try and find the mysterious "Lipomancer," whatever that was. Its lair was easy to find; it was a giant castle perched atop a tall, wide plateau. Getting inside, however, was another matter; the cliffs were too steep to climb, and the only way in was through a cave at the base.

         Once they entered the cave, they noticed something that struck them as rather odd: the walls appeared to have been carved by hand rather than any natural phenomenon, and it was fairly well-lit to boot. Our heroes believed it was the work of the Lipomancer, but before they could ponder that, they came across a fork in the tunnel and decided to split up. Anna and Lilly took the left tunnel, while Margaret and Travis took the right tunnel.

         "This is a very strange place," Travis said. "It feels like there could be traps or monsters waiting for us." Margaret rolled her eyes. "Calm down, Travis; as long as we stay on our guard, we'll be fine." "I'm not scared," Travis interjected, "I'm just saying that we don't know anything about this Lipomancer. For starters, we don't if it's a guy, a girl, or if it's even a person at all; it could be a monster for all we know. Second, we don't know what it can do. I mean, given the name, I guess its powers have something to do with BMI, but, until we see what it's capable of, we won't know for sure."

         Margaret sighed. "Those are some good points, but just remember everything we've taught you about combat and you'll be fine. You were a pacifist when we all met, and now, not only are you a capable fighter, but you also get really sadistic in battle, so I know we've trained you well. Quit being so paranoid."

         Travis took a deep breath and calmed himself down. "Ok. I'm calmer now, I'd feel a lot LESS paranoid if you'd just use a shield." Margaret turned and looked at him. "How many times to I need to remind you; Gladiators don't use shields because they're for cowards who don't trust their armor." Travis replied, "I know that, but between you wearing light armor and not carrying a shield, I worry about you. I get that heavy armor is kinda redundant for reptiles when you guys have tough scales, but still."

         Margaret stopped walking, which prompted Travis to stop. "Then why did you decide to come with me this time? You and Anna are the only two members of our team with healing spells, so I know why you never go with her whenever we split up like this." "Yes," Travis said, "because if me and Anna are together, you and Lilly are left without any healers, and you'll eventually run out potions." Margaret nodded. "Yeah, so if you're so concerned about my choice in armor, why didn't you just go with Lilly like you normally do? I'd say it's because you want to have sex with me, but as you're currently demonstrating," she gestures to his shield and heavy armor, "you don't have any balls!"

         Travis indignantly retorted, "Oh I have balls. I have two of them, and they're the only two I'll ever have, so I ain't too keen on losing them. Mammals don't have internal testicles like reptiles do, so we need to protect them, and I do that by wearing heavy armor and carrying a shield. And, to answer your question, I felt like mixing it up a bit."

         Margaret sighed and said, "Well, quit complaining about my armor and get a move on." Travis nodded and they started walking again. "Speaking of your armor," Travis started, "it really accentuates your curves." Margaret blushed (at least as much a cold-blooded creature like a dragoness could) and said, "Thanks, that's part of why I wear it." "Although," Travis continued, "it also accentuates your slender arms, which reminds of something I've been meaning to ask; how are you able to use that giant axe so easily? I mean, the blades are as big as you are tall and the handle's as tall as you are," he then gave Margaret's upper arm a light squeeze, "and with these slender arms of yours, it's a wonder you're able to even lift it, let alone use it in battle efficiently."

         "That's a secret," Margaret giggles. "Besides, Anna uses a giant hammer, and I've never seen you question how she's able to use IT efficiently, with one hand, no less." "Her hammer's half the size of your axe, and her arms aren't as slender as yours," Travis replied.

Before they could discuss this any further...

15533222222222222221.content:
Breeze went about her home, dusting away cobwebs as she hummed to herself cheerfully. It was her annual day of spring cleaning; a day she always pursued with a very chipper attitude.

As she dusted off a small pile of dust off of the top of a bookshelf, she wiped a bead of sweat from her brow and scanned her eyes across the room, reveling in how clean and new everything looked.

"*Sigh*...another day of spring cleaning, come and conquered!" She said with a hint of pride. "Now all I have to do is check inventory."

She bustled about her kitchen, checking to see if any products had been depleted recently. Thankfully, there were only three items that were in need of replacement.

"Oranges...soap...and Redweed!" She narrated as she wrote them down on a small parchment.

She then trudged up the steps, exiting through a door to the left that led to the balcony. Rather than go to the nearby shop first, she decided to get the more challenging Redweed first, which could be found in the woods at the foot of the eastern mountains. Thankfully, she knew of a small clearing in the woods where Redweed was quite common.

With a crack of her knuckles, she stretched her arms to their greatest length, letting all of her large feathers show. She crouched down, then shot herself in the air, flapping her wings to remain airborne. After a few desperate flaps, she'd managed to maneuver herself horizontal.

The wind increased in her face as she flew onward. There weren't many others outside as she flew off, as the overcast sky seemed to foresee some incoming rain. The plain she lived in receded from the horizon as she neared the stripe of trees ahead.

She circled above the forest a few minutes as she tried to zone out the clearing.

"Hmm...It's got to be somewhere...but where?"

BLAM!!!

An ear-shattering blast of thunder roared above, causing her to let out a shocked yelp and frantically try to re-achieve equilibrium.

Once her flight was reestablished, she looked to the sky with unease.

"Better get home soon...There's no telling wha..."

Her voice trailed off as she looked ahead at the tree she was barreling towards.

SLAM!

The now dazed hawk began to plummet towards the ground. As she blinked her eyes to sight, she saw a strange body of green substance below. She stretched her wings out, trying to ease her descent as she continued to fall...
15533222222222222221.title: Into the woods.

155332222222222222211.content:
Despite her efforts to slow her fall, she hit the body of liquid with speed. Her sight was temporarily lost as she gasped for air, forcing some of the ooze into her mouth. She cringed as she swallowed the viscous fluid.

Her eyes burned as she opened them, letting her see the translucent green she was immersed in. She swam upwards towards the light, and let out a loud gasp when her head broke the surface. She hoisted herself back onto the ground, laying on her ground and panting.

After a few minutes, she finally sat upward and looked to the green slime nearby. She stood up and walked towards it to get a better look.

The substance left her baffled. She'd been in these woods before, but she'd never come across anything like this! To top it all off, it was traveling in a stream that journeyed somewhere deeper into the forest. What part of the forest could it have been coming from?

She reached a hand out and touched the surface, claiming a small bit of the fluid on the tip of a feather. She brought it up to her beak and got a small whiff of the substance, which smelled rather sweet. The sweetness of the smell brought her back to when she swallowed a mouthful while underwater. Despite the shock and urgency of the landing, she could recall a vaguely sweet taste to the amount she had consumed.

That memory of its taste, for whatever reason, seemed to fascinate her. She brough the sample she retrieved up to her beak, just touching it with her toungue.

Her eyes widened in amazement. It tasted amazing! She scooted closer to the slime in order to observe it with a more generous handful.

She looked with interest at the handful of the stuff she held. Despite the chilled moistness of it, it seemed to emanate some sort of comforting, almost warm sensation in her hands.

...did she dare?

1553322222222222222111.content:
"...Meh, why not?"

Breeze brought the liquid to her mouth, drinking it slowly. With a larger quantity consumed, the delicious taste was overwhelming. She immediately reached for a larger handful, happily downing it as she had the last.

Several handfuls had gone before she resorted to bending down near the stream to get to the slime faster. She continued to shovel out large amounts of the slime and devour it with glee, oblivious to the world around her...

...and what a world it was. Her stomach naturally began to bulge out further and further in an attempt to contain her spontaneous gluttony. However, there was no pain...the slime seemed to alter her stomach in a way that would allow her to stuff herself with no hesitation.

As she ate more and more, Breeze became more detached from the environment, her mind gradually becoming more and more focused on eating the river. It went on for several minutes, culminating to the point where she was pretty much eating unconsciously.

But then the slime's second effect took place. It digested immediately within her stomach, it's unfathomable calorie content piling onto her body. Slowly, but noticeably, Breeze began to broaden. Thankfully, her clothes (which were soaked from the landing) stretched with her body as she fattened up.

Still it went on, with Breeze devouring the river's stream like a pig eating slop and inflating like a blimp. Her stomach grew larger and larger, starting to claim a lot of the area beneath her, her breasts starting to inch closer and closer towards her chin.

But then her body started to stretch in height, as well...Her arms, legs, and shoulders lengthened along with her gain as if trying to match her expansion. Higher she inched...

higher...

higher...

higher...

until finally she began to tilt towards the river, her rounded body rolling downwards. She hesitated (albeit slightly) as she felt herself in motion, but it was too late, as she rolled into the stream.

She was surprised to find herself underwater, but was happy to realize she could eat as much as she desired. So she gulped as much as possible, forcing as much of it into her expanding belly as possible...




Some time later...





"ugh..."

Sick.

That's how she felt, sick.

Her stomach. Oh, man, her stomach. She felt that she's explode if she ate another bite, her stomach was so tight. A massive headache stabbed at her brain, rendering it hard to see anything or remember the past few whatevers. She could feel her body trapped beneath some sort of soft, unfathomably heavy mass up to her cheeks. As her vision cleeared, she could make out a blurry, light-tan mass that apparently pinned her to the ground. It pressed against her chin, blocking part of her sight.

"Ugh...my head..." She moved her arms to massage her temples, but she grew surprised when the mass binding her seemed to shift as well. When she looked to her arms, she'd noticed that the mass had swallowed them, her dainty hands peeking out...

...only they weren't some random constriction. Her eyes widened in shock when she recognized her feathers on their surface.

As she noticed the feathers on the now familiar-colored prison atop her, reality struck her, prompting her to scream in horror.

"WHAT HAPPENED TO ME?" The mass atop her was her stomach; she was pinned under her own weight. She desperately tried to roll over and orient herself upright, which was thankfully easy despite her massive size.

After about ten minutes of struggling to become upright, she finally managed to roll over in a way that she could get back onto her legs. Now able to stand at full height, she gaped in pure horror at herself.

The once petite hawk now stood at over ten feet tall, near double her height. Any semblance of a once slim, lean bird was now hopelessly lost in the monstrosity she had become. Her globular, tight belly stuck out over eight feet from her back, her gigantic breasts resting atop. Her legs had fattened to over four feet in width at their widest point, her ass nine feet wide and sticking out three feet from behind when standing. Each of her arms had fattened to over golf-bag widths at the biceps, the shirt she was wearing stretched to almost a latex-like surface.

Breeze could only stand there, whimpering and mumbling in shock as she took in how big she now was. Her sight of anything directly in front of or beneath her was obstructed by her enormous breasts, also preventing her from getting her hands to meet. As she turned to look at her own butt, she was met with yet another surprising sight.

The stream she stood in was coming from a nearby passageway in the mountain.

"But... how could I have floated upstream?...and how could I have traveled into such a shallow part of the river?"

She began to think about the situation more and more, pondering every possible solon to her dilemma. As she did, she started to feel relief.

"This...This is a dream." She chuckled. "Yeah, a dream! All I have to do is close my eyes, and it'll all be over."

She proceeded to clench her eyes shut, envisioning herself in bed about to wake up. She opened them again, only to be met with the same landscape.

Suddenly, her stomach let out a monstrous rumble as the remainder of the slime within her was digested. The surprised Hawk began to grow again, giving herself almost a few inches in height. The fat she accumulated forced her belly out further by a foot, her breasts growing so they'd obscure her view slightly more. As her arms, legs, and ass grew wider and softer, her clothes met their peak elasticity and started to enter tearing territory.

Aghast that her nightmare was a reality, her shock worsened when the grumbling persisted. Despite her gargantuan size, she was painfully hungry.

Trying to clutch her stomach, she glanced fearfully at the environment around her.

"This is not good..."

He even managed to learn the featherweight spell, a spell from one of the Lipomancer's spell books when he saw one of his apprentices. After defeating the apprentice he tried to learn whatever spells he could but the featherweight spell was the only page out of the whole spell book to be in good condition with the rest being splattered in blood or faded.
