1553322222222222222222222122321.content:
Working at a pleasure-house was a little uncomfortable if you were a sorceress, a creature of magic that was meant to be enchanting some objects, or places curses on some unlucky victim, or brewing up some nasty concoction. But when it came to my master, a wizard, another being of magic that was far more superior than I, I had to do his dirty work, or else he'll inflate my already plus-sized body until it popped like a balloon!

So, here I was, naked, avoiding cold puddles of water as I stepped into the small room. The excessive amount of steam made it hard to see only a few feet in front of you, and the air was so thick that I could not help but cough a little, waving my hand in front of my face. With the humid and hot conditions, sweat began to break out all over my body, droplets running of my ample rump and breasts.

"The more flustered I look, the better," I thought to myself.

A private session was rather costly, which meant that whoever I'm going to serve was wealthy, which also meant that I had the right target. With his back leaning against the wall, his arms spread-out over the railings, half-sitting and half-laying down, the hot water reaching up to his hairy chest, Lord Fernando Alberto Augusta, or simply Lord Augusta, was grinning at me like a schoolboy.

Being one of the most powerful men in the city, a shady political figure, it was hard to believe that this bald-headed person was ones a ex-soldier, a commander that boldly defended his lands from invaders. But the years in office had pampered him until he grew soft, but the evidence of muscle still lingered on him: his arms were rather thick, suggesting that there was more than fat underneath, his torso still toned, his belly a round sphere, a little bit larger than a beach ball, sticking above the water like a little island, his navel like a small crater on the landscape.

"Care to join me?" he said.

His accent, the way he rolled his "r", gave away his nationality. He didn't come from here but from lands far from this, where it was hot and dry, where people are ridiculously hot food and held strange celebrations on the end of each month.

"If there's room," I said, fusing with my long, red hair, flashing one of my pretty smiles to give him the idea that I was eager.

Goosebumps sprouted across my flesh when I slipped my feet into the water, and I slowly began to swing my wide hips. His grin grew wider as I kneeled before him, my busts pressing against his muscular chest, my hands resting on his shoulders.

"You know," Lord Augusta began, cupping my round chin, "when I asked them to bring my a large women, I was half-expecting them to bring me something half-descent, like a women only leaning towards the chubby side, but you-" he gave one of my moons a squeeze "-take the cake. Perhaps I should pay this pleasure-house the tip I promised them."

I leaned over and gave his prominent noise a kiss. "Thank you, my lord," I said, giving his shoulders a squeeze myself.

Although I hate to admit it, but his words genuinely flattered me. It wasn't everyday that a fat women like me was complimented on her figure. Most men were after those skinny ladies, and shunned the heftier ones. And still they complained about a difficult childbirth? With thin hips like those it was bound to cause complications. I almost felt ashamed of what I had to do to him.

With one hand cradling my soft cheek and the other running through my hair, Lord Augusta said: "Why don't we get busy, then?"

He pulled my head into a long, passionate kiss, his tongue working its way into my mouth, his meaty hands groping every inch of my flesh. Now was the time to work my magic. While he was kissing me, my hands left his shoulders and moved down his back, squeezing at his love handles.

I felt the warm, fuzzy of magic beginning to spread to it, and my hands began to glow a eerie blue, like that of the full moon on a foggy night. His skin was most likely soaking it up like some sort of sponge, the blue light visible on the surface of his skin before disappearing all together. I broke the kiss, due to the lack of air, and climbed, with some effort (I'm a big lady, after all), back on my feet again.

Lord Augusta looked at me strangely, and asked, though a little out of breath: "Hey, why...did you...stop?"

I didn't want to answer; there was no need for it. I saw he attempted to rise for whatever reason, but the spell, like to chains keeping him pinned to the wall, prevented him from doing so. Before he could begin to wonder what was going on, lord Augusta's gut, with audible rumbles, surged forward...

The gusty night wind blew litter and howled around the corners of the streets of the Lawless District. It was unusually quiet this time of night. Usually it would still be alive with activity: whores would be standing idly on every corner, waiting to sell their bodies for coin, men would come stumbling out of taverns, spewing alcohol, or they would be standing around bonfires, talking, laughing, and gambling.

I had no doubt that this was the work of my master, placing a spell on the small area that caused people to abandon their late activities and go to bed early. Though I could defend myself effortlessly (I'm a sturdy women and a sorceress, after all), I knew that he cared little for my safety, that he only wanted no one to see me performing this task for him.

People could grow suspicious when they saw a well-fed women, who looked like much like a noble, wearing a red satin dress (my sorceress' robe), which I filled out quite nicely, prancing around the poorest area in the city. Someone could get the idea to report this to the city's guard for a reward, and confrontation is the last thing my master needs.

But, just in case, I kept a lookout for any strangers following me. When I was sure that there was none, I suddenly took a sharp turn into a dark alleyway. I continued to walk down the narrow pathway, looking left and right, up and down, searching for any sign of my master, but I found none. This was odd. He said that it was here that he would meet me. Perhaps I took a wrong turn.

But when I turned around and attempted to waddle out of the alleyway, a voice spoke, startling me. "Well, good evening, Kelly," it said.

Whirling around, I saw a figure emerge from the gloom, stepping into the moonlight. Dressed in a long black cloak, his hood pulled up, his sleeves tucked into each other, it was impossible to tell who it was. But it was his voice that told me that it was my master.

Quickly composing myself, and remembering my position, I bowed as low as my potbelly allowed me to go, saying: "Good evening, master."

"Did you bring what I requested for?" he asked.

I straitened myself. "Yes, I did, master."

I reached between my ample breasts, a place I always liked to keep small, valuable things, and pulled out the blue crystal, which glowed a faint blue in the darkness. I did some modifications on it, and now it had a golden chain fastened to it, making it possible to wear around your neck. He stretched out a bony hand, holding it open, and I plopped the crystal into it.

He held it close to his face, holding it by the chain, studying the crystal. "Well done," he praised, "I had a feeling that you would have failed me. I guess that I underestimated you."

While he said this, he threw back his hood. For a brief moment a saw red hair, but it disappeared when he placed the golden chain around his neck. Before my eyes his figure began to fill out, his girth filling his clothing. He also seemed to lose an inch in height.

He turned around, but it wasn't my master anymore but lord Augusta.

"Surprise," he said.

He looked every inch like him, even having the accent. And no, I was not surprised. To morph yourself into someone else was a rather simple spell, but it demanded essence, like that that was sealed inside the crystal.

I studied him for a few moments with mild-interest. "So, do you think it would fool the council of the city?" I asked.

"Positive," he said, making a show of pushing his large gut as far as possible, giving it a rub and a pat. "The council, or their wizards protecting them, will never know it is me. I'll soon bring this city to its knees!"

I waited a few moments until his fit of evil laughter was over before I asked gingerly: "So, am I free to leave your services now, master?"

He regarded me for a moment. "No," he said, shaking his bald head, "My master plan isn't finished yet, and you could still be of some use. But, to make you feel better, I'll give you this."

He dug somewhere in his cloak, producing a brown bag, the sound of coins jingling within.

"For your hard work," he continued, "I'll give you a bone."

He threw the bag towards me. It would have fallen at my feet, spewing out the coins if I hadn't caught it with my magic, levitating it to me. I opened it a peered inside. Gold coins.

"Now, ho home," he said with a flick of his beefy hand, "You need to save your strength for the next task I have for you."

I knew better than to protest, to except his reward, so I said with a bow: "Thank you, master."

"Don't mention it," he said, disappearing into the darkness.

I turned around and left the alleyway.

Even now she could feel the adrenaline rushing through her veins, aching her knees as she crouched. The thrum of her heart was deafening, but Rozenna knew this was her only chance. With a forward tumbling roll out from behind the pile of crates, the thieving young lass clung to the backside of the empty stall. High noon was the busiest time in the Bazaar District, and she knew the guards were maintaining extra vigilance thanks to the numerous thieves recently arrested for attempted larceny. “Honestly, how hard is it to lift a damned coinpurse?” Rozenna sighed; she had a reputation for always making her mark, and she was not about to break that reputation now just because some thieves were too foolish to keep from getting caught.

Rozenna eyed the adjacent alley and, upon seeing no other living souls in sight, set to picking the lock on the display case. The young woman gnawed on the corner of her lip as the lockpick eased in between the tumblers, sliding silently into the unexpectedly complex lock. “What’s so special about a damned scroll?” the thief muttered to herself. Rozenna jostled the lock one last time before it finally unlatched with a quiet click. “Eureka! Mama’s gonna eat well tonight!” she hissed with glee. Rozenna smirked to herself and reached into the case. Her fingers trailed across several necklaces and bracelets, but she ignored them and continued her search. Another part of her reputation was that she never stole anything besides her objective. Well, nothing that would be missed anyway. With absolute dexterity, she wiggled one ring around her pinky just as her hand grasped the scroll’s casing. “Jackpot.”

“Hey!” Rozenna retracted her hand with the scroll in tow and whirled about just in time to see a large man in a silk tunic. Rozenna was no novice, she always made sure to scope out several escape routes in case of any surprises. Dropping down into another corridor, the young thief slunk along the wall before diving into her home turf, the Lawless District. “That was easier than I expected, considering the reward.” Another means of maintaining secrecy was to always work through connections. Meeting a client in person was a sure way to get your face drawn up on a wanted poster. Thankfully, Mikael was the perfect broker; he never took more than his fair share of the cut, and he never disclosed the identities of his contacts.

Keeping a brisk pace, Rozenna had already arrived at her destination: The Sticky Fingers Saloon. Although the beer was nothing to write home about, the beds were comfortable, and it was a great place to meet in private. That, and they made the best spicy chicken crispers in the city. Where might they get chicken in such an impoverished area? Stolen from the supplies of the aristocracy in the upper level. Regardless, Rozenna’s nose was met with the savory spiced air of the saloon, and it immediately set her mouth to watering. She found her meal for the evening. With a tug, Rozenna lowered her hood and mask as the light of the tavern spilled over her through the windows. The thief stood before the swinging doors to the saloon and pushed them apart as she strode in. No one even noticed her enter, and the low banter continued uninterrupted. She didn’t exactly need to make a scene at the moment.

“Over here, kid,” Mikael called out; he was one of the shrewdest men she had ever met. At a glance he looked like little more than your average thug, but his brains were to be feared more than his brawn. Sure, he could probably beat most men in an arm-wrestling match, but the weight of his coinpurse was much more significant. Mikael was the sort of man who kept his true fiscal worth a secret to everyone. Well, everyone except Rozenna. After all, it was she who ensured his investment was not lost that one time several years ago. During her little escapade at Mikael’s behest, she discovered he was actually worth more than some of the nobility of the upper district. She never understood what kept him down in the Lawless District, but considering his wealth and power, it was probably best not to ask. After weaving between bar patrons, Rozenna finally reached Mikael’s reserved table in the corner of the room. As she pulled out her chair, she shook the loose braid of hair free from the hood flattened to her back.

“Mik, it’s always a pleasure,” Rozenna began with a bow of her head. Removing her cloak, she hung it on the back of her chair. The thief could feel the old broker’s eyes tasting her slight curved body. Rozenna had always been on the thin side, but she kept herself physically fit for the agile demands of her trade. Nonetheless, her tight-fitting leather suit did little to leave her body to anyone’s imagination. She had the common decency to keep herself covered, but the clothing still clung to every supple curve.

“Roz, love, the pleasure’s always mine,” he flashed a yellow grin and gestured for the young woman to take a seat. Rozenna obliged, gracefully folding one leg over the other. She leaned back in the chair, and glanced up as a bar wench sauntered by. Without words, she held up one finger, and the loosely-dressed woman nodded with a smile too heavily adorned in make-up. “And I believe you owe me somethin’, kid,” Mikael grumbled his words, but there was no hostility in them. The pair had been working together long enough to know that trust was not a concern. “What is this thing, Mik?” Rozenna now raised her own brow in curiosity, but Mikael darted his eyes around the tavern. She had never seen him so anxious before.

Hand it over, and the money’s yours,” the broker bobbed his head as he explained his terms, but the faintest bead of sweat coursed its way down his face. He was right about the confidentiality, but Mikael was never nervous about anything. Rozenna played along and rolled the scroll across the table. Better to leave it alone than get mixed up in something unpleasant. The gaudy bar wench returned and laid the platter of spicy chicken crispers in front of Rozenna. The thief flipped her a polished coin and sent the wench on her way. As Mikael reached into his deep pockets, the thief removed her leather gloves and began to chow down on the spicy chicken fingers. Each one seared her lips and tongue, but the wench returned with a tall beer just in time. Rozenna huffed and puffed and flipped the wench another coin while simultaneously guzzling the frothy beer. As expected, it was nothing remarkable, but it eased the spicy heat of the meal. Rozenna, now fanning herself with one hand, peered up at her stocky broker.

“Are you planning on paying me, Mik?” she pried between sips of beer. He was now inspecting the stolen property with great scrutiny but finally nodded and tossed her a bag of coins. The greedy little thief chirped with glee and snatched up the purse. Being the expert she was, she gave it a light toss and scowled. “Hey! This is only half of what we agreed on! Are you trying to cheat me, Mik?” Rozenna growled fiercely, though deep down she knew she could never intimidate the man. However, Mikael did seem to react to the threats and hushed her by holding up his hands in defense.

“Listen, kid, I wasn’t completely honest with you before,” he began. Rozenna only deepened her scowl, now leaning over her crispers with a look of pure rage. “This is actually a two-part job, and stealin’ the scroll was the easy part,” Mikael swallowed hard, glancing about the room with even more anxiety than before. Rozenna stood from her seat and shoved a crisper into her mouth while grabbing her cloak. “Wait, wait, wait! The client is willing to give you ten times the agreed upon reward if you finish the job!” Rozenna spit out the crisper, and it deftly landed back on the plate.

“How much?!” She gawked, immediately plopping down into her seat again. “What do I have to do? Just name it!” Rozenna now bobbed her head like a doll, eager to reap in the reward. That much money could even raise her out of the slums, make a proper lady of herself. She eagerly gnawed on another chicken wing, huffing with each bite.

“I ain’t gonna lie, it’s gonna be rough. I can only tell you the mission if you accept if first,” the broker warned, and Rozenna balked, leaning back in her seat. She didn’t exactly like the sound of signing up without knowing the terms first. “So you in or out?”
15533222222222222222222222.title: A Roze By Any Other Name

choices: Rozenna is ambushed by bandits! They seem to have weighty plans for her!
Rozenna continues down the road and arrives at the stream uninterrupted.
155332222222222222222222221.content:
Rozenna meandered through the bustling afternoon streets of the Lawless District. A heavy scowl hung on her face, and it wasn’t about the imminent inclement weather. Storm clouds were already roiling over head, and the swollen gray sky looked fit to burst into a downpour at any moment. Her cowl was pulled up and her cloak wrapped tightly about her shoulders. “That no-good, sneaky, double-crossing…” Rozenna’s conversation with Mikael had not ended as well as she expected. Then again, the promised fortune should have made her realize the possible risk. Ten times the original offer, but she had to agree before hearing the rest of the mission.

He said it would be easy, but with so little experience outside of the city limits, Rozenna was more than a little concerned with the adventure that would precede her payment. She had always played it smart, played it safe, never biting off more than she could chew. Unfortunately, the prize was too big this time, too shiny. Rozenna now had to march out into the damned forest and find a filthy, dark cave. Inside this cave would be a narrow, dirty tunnel. At the end of the tunnel would be an unnecessary castle filled with all sorts of unusual treasures. Mikael had gone out of his way to explain that this castle belonged to the client and nothing was to be disturbed. Nothing except for the oddly named book: “Expanding Horizons.” Hell, with the amount of money she was going to get paid for a simple snatch-and-grab like this, she’d be willing to dance naked in the Saloon for a week straight!

“Going somewhere, miss?” a gruff voice called out, and upon looking up, Rozenna stood face-to-face with a city guard. Well, not exactly face-to-face. Coming from a long line of short people, Rozenna was at least a head shorter than the man. He shifted his weight, folding his arms across his breastplate. Numerous armor creaks rang out with every movement he made. The thief’s eyes peered around the guard, and she realized she was already in the Gates District.

“Oh! I, um, was going out for a stroll. You know, catch some fresh air,” she feigned a girlish giggle and batted her lashes at the guard to no avail. His brow wrinkled, and a stern grimace overcame his mustachioed upper lip.

“That so? Just goin’ for a walk, then? Outside the city limits? Got any particular business in the forest?” The armored chap leaned forward, narrowing his eyes and casting a scrutinous gaze over Rozenna.

“Yes, sir. I’m a trader, and I must return to my home town,” Rozenna shifted her performance from doting damsel to innocent young entrepreneur. She rested her hands on her modest hips and nodded abruptly.

“I don’t see no wagon with you. What sort of trader doesn’t even have a horse?” he wrinkled his nose as if catching wind of her fishy claims. Rozenna had to think quickly, and promptly removed the scroll from her satchel.

“I’m a courier! I trade messages from one person to another. Yep, that’s what I do,” she replied with a wide, forced grin. The guard raised one bushy brow but promptly shook his head while rolling his eyes. Without another word he gestured toward the tall city gates. Rozenna bowed her head in appreciation and breathed a small sigh of relief before tensing up in front of a second guard. This one, however, said nothing at all as he unlocked the person-sized door crafted into the side of the gates. If she did have a horse, they would have needed to open the whole gates, and Rozenna was fairly certain they would have been more annoyed than they already were.

A cool, spring breeze swept over Rozenna, bathing her with the scent of trees and grass. She deeply inhaled the aroma and exhaled it slowly. Shafts of sunlight peeked between the gray streaks above. “At least it looks like I’ll have sunshine during my travels,” the thief beamed and tapped the toe of her boot into the dirt path that stretched out before her. Rozenna snapped her fingers and retrieved the crude map from her pouch. Although it was only a quick sketch, Mikael was kind enough to sell it to her for only one little gold coin. “Greedy bastard,” she hissed beneath her breath just thinking about it.

The map showed, in hardly any detail whatsoever, that she needed to continue down the road for about a mile. After that she would have to venture into the forest and follow a stream. At least there were some landmarks. Rozenna had little-to-no experience in navigating the wilderness. Give her a crammed city street any day. Following her instructions, Rozenna marched down the dirt path, humming a light tune to herself.
155332222222222222222222221.title: Fetch Quest

choices: Roz decides to pilfer some pork and must deal with the consequences.
Roz decides to let sleeping trolls lie and continues on her quest.
1553322222222222222222222212.content:
Noon crept overhead, but Rozenna had located the particular stream with no trouble. The Summer heat caused her tight, leather armor to cling to every curve, sweat beading along her browline. Mikael hadn’t given her a deadline, so no one would complain if she took a little time to cool off. Ever vigilant, Roz scanned the treeline and continued along the murmuring stream until the road was well out of sight. She leaned her pack against the base of a tree. Scooping up a small stone, she tossed it into the crystalline stream, watching it sink to the bed. It certainly wasn’t running fast enough to carry her downstream, but it looked deep enough for a quick bath.

One final scan of her surroundings led Roz to strip down to her birthday suit. Her slender fingers scratched at her scalp, fluffing out her hair as her toes met the brisk, blue waters. She shivered slightly; a light breeze encircled her at that exact moment, layering her fair skin with a swarm of goosebumps. “Meep!” She squeaked, her foot catching an unexpectedly slick rock. She wavered once before toppling into the stream with a loud splash. It may not have been her preferred method of easing into the cold water, but it was certainly effective.

“Shit! Cold-cold-cold-cold!” Roz shrieked, flailing out of the stream like an octopus on a stove. She scrambled across the riverbank before stopping to breathe at her belongings. “Worst idea ever…” She certainly didn’t feel sweaty any more. With a towel covering her naughty bits, Roz wrung out her hair, a dour expression stuck to her face. Now she remembered why she hated the forest; there was not one enchanted thing about it. Between the freezing water and the incessant bugs, this was certainly nothing like the story books.

After a brief rest to dry off, Rozenna continued onward through the forest, following the the river upstream to its source. The daylight still beat down, but with the extra shade of the deep woods, it was far more bearable. Twigs crunched underfoot, birds chirped overhead, and the petite thief whistled to herself. There really wasn’t much else to do, but as a rogue, Roz learned early on how to keep herself entertained. The life of a pickpocket didn’t make for friendships. Really, the only people she spent time with were her marks, strangers in the tavern, and Mikael. Thankfully, she enjoyed being alone. It gave her time to think.

Deep thoughts make for speedy travels, and before long, Rozenna found herself at a clearing in the woods. Halting, the young thief listened intently to her surroundings. Not only did she hear no voices, but there were no birds calling, nor any crickets chirping. It was absolutely silent. Gripping the strap of her pack a little tighter, she slunk along the outskirts of the clearing to get a better view. It appeared to be some sort of crude campsite. There didn’t seem to be anyone home. Smoke gently billowed from the central campfire, carrying the scent of spiced meat. Though she had already eaten, there was something tantalizing about the smell. Low grumbling broke the silence, and Rozenna glanced around for some wild beast before recognizing the sound of her own stomach. She blushed, even though she was alone, and reluctantly scampered into the camp. Not eager to attract any attention, the thief stayed low and ducked behind a broad tent. It looked big enough to fit a small family.

Rounding the corner, Rozenna blanched. If only it did house a family… instead of the massive sleeping troll. Three other tents of equal size encircled the cooking spit. Oh, and what a meal it held; perhaps the largest boar Roz had ever seen! Poaching in the nobility’s woods was forbidden, but the thief doubted anyone was willing to tell that to a quartet of enormous trolls. Still though, she was amazed that they had the mental capacity to conjure up such a culinary feat. Glancing back at the dreaming behemoth, she eyed its sizeable gut. Second thought, not that surprising. Creeping closer to the center of the camp, Roz licked her lips, ogling the enticing pig. Larceny may have been her lifelong career, but even she had doubts about the sanity of stealing from trolls. Surely they wouldn’t miss a few slices...
1553322222222222222222222212.title: Skinny Dipping

choices: Roz is captured by bandits during her nap. (Girl can't catch a break!)
Roz sleeps peacefully, but awakens a few pounds heavier. (10 lb.)
15533222222222222222222222121.content:
It just looked so tasty. Succumbing to her escalating hunger, Rozenna drops her pack to the ground and unsheathes her dagger. She prodded the boar’s flank and found it soft and yielding. The thief brought the blade beneath her nose, sniffing it once before licking the blade. By all the fires of hell, this was perhaps the tastiest pork she had ever had the good graces of savoring, and she hadn’t even taken a bite yet! An unquenchable hunger glazed over her eyes, and the diminutive damsel plunged her blade into the flank of the roasting boar, carving out a large hunk of flesh. Shoveling the morsel into her mouth, she chewed it enthusiastically, moaning beneath her breath even as the juices dribbled down her chin.

“Ohmygods…” she shuddered with delight before slicing off another chunk of pork. Inhaling the fragrance, Roz chomped into the delicacy, tearing off a mouthful. Meat was hard to come by in the city, and her only regular intake of protein came from the tavern’s spicy chicken crispers. The quality of this roasted pig was beyond comparison. “Mmm, compliments to the chef…” she moaned again, licking her fingers clean.

“Fanks, lil’ lass,” bellowed a deep, growly voice from behind. Roz froze. Whirling about, she eyeballed the towering figure of the tent troll. His beefy arms were crossed, resting atop the bulge of his gut. He looked even taller standing. Rozenna laughed awkwardly before diving for her dagger. However, the troll moved faster than she expected, wrapping its thick hand around her entire arm before it could reach the puny weapon. “Not so fast now. Didn’ anyone ever tell you it’s not nice to be stealin’ fings?”

“Wot’s da ruckus out here, Blag?” a second troll mumbled, stumbling out of his tent while rubbing his eyes. He pressed a finger to the side of his nose before ejecting a snot rocket to the dirt.

“Seems we got ourselves a sneak-fief, Mag,” Blag snarled and grasped his second hand around Rozenna’s legs. He brought her up to his bulbous nose and inhaled deeply, sending a repulsed shudder down her spine. Things were looking worse than grim.

“Oi hate tieves!” Mag scratched his hanging belly and hobbled toward the campfire. “Wot she be stealin’? She take any of our shoinies?” Both trolls stared down at her.

“Don’t fink so. But I can smell some more on her,” Blag turned her upside down and gently shook until her coinpurse plopped out onto the ground. Great, now they were taking her money.

“Noice!” Mag eyed her over and licked his lips. “She smells roight tasty, she does.”

“That’s th’pig, you git,” Blag raised her higher, leveling his dim eyes with her shimmering, terrified pair. “Look here, she were tryin’ t’steal our meat!” Blag growled, glancing between the carved boar and the girl. “Hang on… she might be worf eatin’...”

“Moight be worth eatin’, yeah!” Mag licked his chops as he echoed his comrade. “Want me ta bash her loights out?” The troll cracked his knuckles, eyeing up the small damsel in distress. Roz went wide-eyed, flailing and screaming.

“I got me a better idea,” Blag chuckled and brought her face mere inches from his own. “Ever ‘eard of a turducken, Mag?” His breath reeked something fierce, though even Roz perked a brow. What in the hell was a turducken?

“A wot? Turd sammich? Sounds tasty, Blag!” the dimwitted second troll wrung his hands and bobbed his head. Blag lowered the girl and ran a palm down his face.

“A turducken, you git. It’s when you put a chicken inside’f a duck, inside’f a turkey. Then you cook up th’whole fing,” Blag clarified. Admittedly, it sounded delicious, albeit rather decadent.

The clearly more intelligent of the two trolls plucked up the cooking spit with his free hand and held it alongside the upside down thief. Glancing between the pig and the troll, Rozenna finally solved the puzzle. They weren’t just going to eat her, they were going to stuff her first! Mag took a moment longer, but squealed with glee, hopping up and down. He bobbed his head in wordless agreement, and Blag grinned.

“Hope you’re hungry, sneak-fief. I’m gonna stuff you like a prized pig… wif this here pig,” the trolls attempts at cleverness fell short, but it was by no means an empty threat. Resting the boar on its place over the campfire, the pair of trolls immediately lashed rope around the girl’s wrists and ankles, effectively hogtying her.

Tossing her onto a nearby sack of flour, lest they bruise their savory meal, Blag and Mag seized the huge boar along with a carving knife and crude, wooden plate. Rozenna was in an absolute panic. These monsters were going to eat her! No amount of gold was worth this. Mikael told her the castle would be empty, and she knew how to handle the occasional trap. Trolls were a different story. Her helpless shrieking was cut short as Blag pushed the first hunk of pork between her lips. With a smelly troll hand clasped tight over her mouth, she had the options of chew or choke. The thief silently cursed Mikael before swallowing.

In between mouthfuls, Roz had scarcely enough time to breathe, let alone speak, until finally the more moronic of the pair stopped the feeding. “Hey Blag, Oi were thinkin’. Wouldn’t da lassie taste better if’n we basted her with some of our beer?” Mag beamed a dopey smile at his own brilliant idea.

“Not a bad idea, Mag. I fink she looks a lil’ firsty anyways, heh heh,” Blag lowered the next fistful of pork, allowing Roz a moment of rest. Labored breaths came hastily, for her stomach now squeezed against her tight, leather armor. Why did this have to happen to her of all people? She never hurt anyone. Well… she never hurt anyone other than financially. Mag hefted a troll-sized bottle of ale in one hand, though it looked equal to at least two liters of frothy beer. Roz wriggled in her bindings, dreading the extra volume that would fill her already stuffed gut.

“Please… I’m so full already,” she whined, still trying her damndest to get loose from her bindings. Blag and Mag just cackled and popped the bottle’s cork. They pressed it to her lips, but when she refused to open, one of them pinched her nose. Blag kindly let her take a deep breath before shoving the bottle opening past her lips. Roz never imagined how frothy troll beer could be, but this stuff had more suds than a noblewoman’s bubblebath. As the liquid surged into her stomach, she would close her throat just long enough to breathe before the unrelenting tide of alcohol continued its descent. She now looked at least three months pregnant. Each gulp expanded her middle a little more, until finally Blag bashed Mag over the back of the head.

“You git, don’t waste it all on th’lass. I’m gonna want somefin’ to wash me meal down later,” The second troll groaned and pulled the bottleneck out of her mouth. Rozenna was experiencing the definition of a stupor. Not only was the beer more frothy than what she expected, but it also had at least double the alcohol content. Where there were two trolls, now stood four, and she rolled onto her side. The thief groaned and felt the contents of her distended stomach slosh with every breath.

“She’s lookin’ roight stuffed, ain’t she, Blag?” Mag chuckled and pressed a meaty finger into the poor girl’s gut, forcing a deafening belch to blast from her lips. Both trolls visibly gawked at the number of decibels before turning to one another. “Toime to put her on the spit!”

“What? You fink we’re roastin’ her? No way, you git. We’re gonna sear this one to a nice crisp!” Blag licked his chops and stretched out his hands toward Roz before Mag slapped them away.

“We’re skewerin’ th’lil’ piggy! Oi’m not keen on searin’ her loike a tuna,” Mag growled, stamping his feet. Blag didn’t say a word, but grumbled unintelligibly before slapping his dim friend upside the head. The two trolls roared and their fists flew; both brutes toppled into one of the adjacent tents.

This was her chance, and even in her booze and food-induced coma, Roz managed to finally untie her bindings. One hand scooped up her backpack, and the other clutched her belly before she finally trudged back into the woods. Each step uncomfortably sloshed the contents of her stomach, sending the boar and beer bouncing as she fled the campsite. Custom leather armor did not help ease her running, and after she was out of sight, Roz collapsed in a heap, breathing heavily. She just needed a long, long nap...
15533222222222222222222222121.title: Porking Out

choices: He continures to pursue his target
He drinks with the Scotsmen

155332222222222222222222222.content:
The streets and alleyways of the Lawless District are illuminated by the moonlight and the city's lanterns. A man walks through the streets, unknowingly being followed from the rooftops. The pursuer follows the man who turns a corner and into a lit doorway with a ruined wooden door. The man on streets opens the door and enters. The pursuer jumps from the rooftops and lands, his tail swinging from the impact. He enters the doorway to a tavern where his target sits on the opposite side of the room near the corner of it where a group of the same people sit, pirates. His target is a pirate, more importantly, a pirate captain. he sits at a table where the pursuer takes his hood down and sits at the bar. He casually sits so he doesn't bring attention from his target he was sent to assassinate. He looks over the small piece of paper he received from his contract who meet him in The Representative District. He reads it over and smiles when he gets to the reward at 4,600 gold and remembers the bounty on the captain's head at 45,000 gold. He was looking at a large reward which would set him for life. He puts the paper away as the captain stares in his direction with the look like he thinks he's shooting daggers out from his eyes. He tells a tavern maid something, maybe ordering rum since it is a pirate-y drink.

Suddenly, the door bursts open as men with war paint on their faces, braids in their hair, and wielding claymores bigger than doors. They were loud as their bagpipes and as big as their claymores. They spoke in this accent that sounded much like their personalities. They take the bar sets making the hooded pursuer feel like he was in a ham sandwich and he was the lettuce. "Aye, bartender," One of them says in his accent, "We need a bit o' tha good stuff, so giv' us all tha mead yae got!"

The bar tender gets out the tankards as he pour the mead into them. Then one of the guys to the hooded pursuer's left asks him, "Aye boyo, what's yae business doing here at tha bar? The milk shop be up tha street."

"Sorry, but I'm here doing my business." he replies.

"OOOOOHH, so yae think youre important? Too good for us common criminals? I see how yae be." the guy tells him. "Well this sword be more for decoration, I've actually killed many in the field of battle. What weapon be your usage? Your breath yae skinny, small boned, scaled, wingless dragonkin?"

"Well for a man being more experienced in the field of fighting, allow me to introduce myself," Standing up to bow "Kloppi, Criminal for Hire. I am experienced in stealth and cunning to make my pay."

"Aaahh, so yae think your skills are better than mine. Hey lads," he call out to the others. "Let us introduce ourselves to this lad here. We like to call ourselves the Scotsmen; we come from our home in the highlands and live for the trill of bloody battle."

"I don't wish to join your group," Kloppi says, "I'm more of a freelancer, I can work for you for pay but being a member of your group is something I wouldn't be inclined to."

"Well we wern't askin' for yae to join, yae would have to fill a certain profile: One, being from the highlands; two, being human; and Three, being a man. Yae don't strike off as being a man since your not human, and I doubt your from tha highlands."

"Well I may not be from your highlands, but a am male." Kloppi says without showing anger since he isn't angry. He is a Dragon without wings. His scales colored a darkish blue with 5 fingers on each of his hands, and 4 toes on his feet with an extection from his heel.

"Just because your male don't make yae much of a man. It takes certain qualities to be a man."

"Well, I will love to prove you wrong," Kloppi starts as he sees his target is getting ready to leave. He turns to the Scotsman shoving a tankard full of mead towards him.

"Well prove it." the Scotsman says.

1553322222222222222222222222.content:
Kloppi grabs the tankard and chugs it down, watching as his prize leaves through the door. "Oh well," he thinks, "I'll run into him again later." He finished the tankard as the Scotsmen cheer and laugh at his success. "Give me another." He demands as another tankard full of mead is handed to him. He chugs it down, demanding another as he starts to feel drunk. He grabs two tankards as he chugs them down, feeling a bit more drunk. He tells the bar tender to get a whole mead barrel as he slams the empty tankards down on the countertop. The bartender comes back carrying a full mead barrel. He sets the mead barrel down where Kloppi asks one of the Scotsmen to lift it for him. One of them obliges and lifts it so that Kloppi uncorks it. Then, Kloppi puts his dragonic muzzle to where the hole for the liquid pours from. With his mouth in place, he tilts the barrel and starts drinking. As he continues to drink, Kloopi can feel his armor getting tighter as his belly distends. He loosens his armor and clothes so that he can let his stomach have room to grow. A few minutes in, Kloppi's stomach made him look like to be pregnant and was really drunk. As Kloppi finishes the mead barrel, he is so drunk he blacks out.


A few hours later, Kloppi wakes up in the city's sewer system without his armor, clothes, and weapons. He noticed that his stomach has gone down, but was still bloated. He looked around and found a few hobos were minding their own business and cooking beans over a can with fire in it. One bearded hobo with a funny hat passed Kloppi who was lying on the stones that plastered the walls and floor of the sewers. "Excuse me," Kloppi said to the hobo trying to get his attention, "How did I get here?"

"Your in the sewers boy." The hobo told him smiling with a grin of half his teeth missing.

"I know I'm in the sewers. But how did I get here?" Kloppi asked again.

"You entered." The hobo replied hoping it was a useful answer.

Kloppi got up and quickly his head started to hurt. "Damn hangovers." He tells himself. "Where's the exit?" He asks.

"Always questions you have. Why not ask the Hobo King." The hobo tells him.

"Ok, where's the Hobo King?" Kloppi asks.

The hobo removes his hat and puts on an even sillier hat. "Hobo King speaking." The hobo claims. Kloppi looking more annoyed having met a person turns to walk away. "And I see that you've been branded as well." The hobo tells Kloppi.

"Branded?" Kloppi says as he turns to see that his upper buttocks has a branding mark on his left side. His face goes from confused look to a more oh-no look. "I can't be branded," he thinks to himself. "I'm a freelancer. I can't be owned by anyone." He further examines the mark and realizes it the one used on members of Mel-Felax's. Mel-Felax is the most noctorious crime lord in the Lawless District. Kloppi has two choices he has to make: One, stay in the city, kill his target, find the Scotsmen, and try to find out what happened in the last hours, all while trying to avoid Mel-Felax's men; or two, leave the city.

Kloopi wasn't going out without clothes and armor, so he looked around and found a large, ripped tarp. He grabbed the tarp and threw it over himself like a cloak. He left enough of it to make a hood. He looks around and figures he's in the Lawless District's border near the Quarter's District. He knows he has to make it through the Quarter's District and two more districts before he even gets into the Gates District. So Kloppi starts through the Quarter's District.

A shiny beam shines into Kloopi's eyes as he sees a gauntlet the size of one's arms, made of steel and coated it a silver paint, with some gems on it. Kloopi comes up with a plan to steal it and possibly sell it for money.

He sits dow besides the booth with his tarp-cloak concealing him from public eyes. When the time was right, he peered from his hood to see the vendor turn his attention to another costomer, not looking at the gauntlet. That's then Kloopi snatched it from under his hood and hid it in his cloak. After a while, he got up and left the Bazaar District. He is now in the Guild District.

"One more district." he said to himself.

Adventurers are always so lithe or strong, we'll need to fix that....

Yet adventurers in fantasy stories aren't interested in much other than saving the world, rescuing loved ones, or finding vast treasures. But what happens to some greedy explorers when they travel into the lair of something incredibly evil, something with magical powers never seen before?

Once they enter the den of the Lipomancer, these adventures will have to overcome huge obstacles, stomach bizarre traps, and make weighty decisions (If you catch my drift). And when they come out of it.... IF they come out of it, one thing is certain: their waistlines will never be the same again...
